title: Was it Sabotage?
text: I know I am pretty dense about some stuff ... but I think I am actually now RETIRED!Yep! Â I have looked all around me, in all the rooms, in the closets, under the furniture and Â through my calendar ... Â and I canâ€™t escape the fact that there are no obligations or commitments hiding anywhere. Â I am completely and totally retired!Imagine that!I suspect this is kind of an odd statement to make considering I havenâ€™t held a paying job since 2007. Â But as we near the end of this month, January 2022, I realize that after 15 years of stepping away from formal paid employment, I am retired. It took years to get here, but here I am!!What happened? Â Why did it take so long and did I sabotage myself?When I left my last employment in 2007 they gave me a â€œretirement party.â€ Â And there was no need to correct that assumption, because that was what I was doing. Â Retiring! Â I was only 59. Â But my underlying reason for stopping work so early was my mom. Â She was living with us and it was very hard for me to hold down a full time job and help her out all the other hours. Â  Turns out my mom became a 24/7 commitment as she was developing dementia. It wasnâ€™t retirement for me. But it wasnâ€™t exactly sabotage, because she needed help and I was able and happy to give it.When she died in December 2014, I thought now I will officially retire. Â My commitment to mom taxed all of me more than anything else in my life. Â I needed a break. Â I just needed to close down her estate - and then I was done, done, done. But did I retire? Nope.With mom gone, it became overwhelmingly apparent that my increasingly visually impaired husband was at serious risk of falling on our stairs - and in a townhouse, there are a lot of stairs. Â So from 2015 to 2016 I began the downsizing, taking on tasks my husband could no longer do because of his vision problems, â€œshoppingâ€ for a new and safer place to live, orchestrating the sale of our townhouse, organizing the move, and purchasing our current condo - not to mention the unpacking and settling in a new place and location. Â  I was 69 at the time of that move, and I used up every last ounce of myself. Â Did I somehow sabotage myself over that year and half? Â I donâ€™t see how. Â Now the person needing help was my husband - we needed to move and I had no choice but to take the lead. Â In August of 2016 we moved into this condo. Â I remember thinking â€œall I need to do is get us unpacked and settled and I will be retired.â€ Â The list of obligations and commitments were at 0! Â One day in January 2017 I was walking my daughterâ€™s dog enjoying the feeling of lightness and I was approached by a resident with a measuring tape. Â He asked me to help him by holding the measuring tape while he took measurements of a community project. Â Ha! Â I was thrilled to help, to make a friend of a neighbor, to become part of a community!! Â Within 15 minutes he invited me to attend an informal meeting of the board happening in a few days. Â He started talking ... you should join the board, youâ€™d be great at it!! Â God knows what he saw in me. Â Was it my sparkling personality, or the way in which I competently held the measuring tape or .... was I just a warm body without 2 heads, and they needed a 5th board member - and there I was!! Â Of course, I didnâ€™t recognize any of that at the time - and I started thinking â€œOh yes, this might be fun.â€ Â (In that moment, the â€œOh yesâ€ moment, Â I began to sabotage my retirement dreams!) Like a magnet I attended that meeting, got involved in community activities - crescendoing in a spell as a board member that ate up hours and hours (... and HOURS) of time every single week. Â And this volunteer job felt very much like work without the benefit of a salary! Â  January 3 of this year, I stepped out of that board position and ... for the first time in forever - I didnâ€™t sabotage myself. Â I keep looking over my shoulder, but there are no other hangers-on to hijack my new status!Â Iâ€™ll admit, it's a little disorienting, but I think I am finally retired. Â But then the thought dawned on me. Â Despite all the past demands on my life, I have been lucky enough to reached this point with good health and independence. Â And now finally, my time belongs to me - to do what I want. Â Some folks never reach this point.While I know life can change in a moment I have taken a precaution to prevent self sabotage Â - there is no room in my life for measuring tapes!! Â I am hoping that will be enough. Â Today I am retired!

title: My Winter Puzzle
text: My current puzzle is a Christmas scene. Â It is called Christmas Cheer by the Vermont Christmas Company. Â I havenâ€™t done enough puzzles to develop a favored company.I didnâ€™t have as much time before Christmas to work on this puzzle as I hoped and here I am after Christmas - actually mid-January - working on a Christmas theme. Â I considered stopping the work and putting it away for next year, but knowing me, I might not want to do this same puzzle again. Â I love having a dedicated space that I donâ€™tneed to change out for other use.Of course, today a snow storm is predicted and this puzzle is full of snow ... so now it is my Winter Puzzle. Â It probably is best I finish it this year and then re-home it. Â I seldom re-read books and creating jigsaw puzzles are the same. I seldom repeat a puzzle. Â I have glued a number of puzzles together that were of interest to my Grand daughter and she has them hanging in her play room.This puzzle is quite large. Â As I typically do, I began with the border pieces. Â Then I usually pick items within the puzzle to put together - items that are easy to find in the mix of puzzle pieces - which in the beginning is a lot to paw through.Â This time I focused on the Christmas trees. Â That was a mistake. Â Finding the pieces was not hard, but getting them put together was harder than I thought. Â I started focusing on the people in the picture. Â That went faster. And then the buildings. Â And with time, some of the Christmas trees began to take shape. Â This last tree is still a struggle.The cost of puzzles climbed during the pandemic, mostly because people were so interested in doing home activities and puzzle companies had trouble keeping up with the demand. Â  In 2020 when I rediscovered the joy of putting puzzles together I went on a binge of puzzle purchases. Â I sort of went puzzle crazy. Â Beyond this puzzle I have 24 puzzles waiting for me to assemble. Â Some were cheap - a few were expensive. Â A few were gifts. Now, that puzzles are widely available again, I realize that I wouldn't spend more than $20 for one. Â The time and enjoyment I get from them is well worth the $20 or less spent. Â But some puzzles go for upwards of $30 or $40 dollars. Â Since I donâ€™t repeat many, that cost would be too pricy for one completion only. Â I am a little loathed to buy puzzles second hand. Â I would hate to find a piece missing. Â But if the picture was compelling enough, I might risk it.I have heard the opinion that doing a jigsaw puzzle is not a productive use of time - especially if it is dismantled after it is completed. Â I guess I can understand that opinion on one level, but I also believe that not all activities need to be productive. Â Relaxation is also an important state for both mind and body. Â The path to relaxation is different for everyone. Â Based on recent events - completing jigsaw puzzles is a pretty popular method of relaxation.Do you do jigsaw puzzles?Â Â Do you have a preferred vendor?Â Â What is the range of cost that you find reasonable?Â Â What is your experience with previously owned puzzles?One last picture - update as of Wednesday night! Â The trees are finally complete (and they werenâ€™t fun to do) as well as much of the bottom. Â Hoping the sky isnâ€™t as hard as it looks. Â ğŸ˜€

title: I forgot ... this is fun!
text: Ever have a hobby that you set aside ... set aside for years ... and then, because you have a slight injury Â and extra time ... you pick it up again on a whim ... and remember just how much FUN it is!! Â Forgotten and challenging fun with a few surprises thrown in.That is me and Legos. Â Yep! Â Legos ... the building blocks of children.Â But hasnâ€™t been for just children for a long time. Â Not by a long shot! Â Not by size, or by complexity or by cost! Â Especially not by cost - because the kits for adults (those over 16) are quite expensive, and only get more expensive when Lego retires certain kits.Â More than 5 years ago I built my first pair of buildings. Â The Pet Store and a Private Townhouse Residence.This was my first build. And I discovered when I was searching for these pictures in my blog historythat I built them in 2015! Â My heavens. Â So it has been more like 7 years. Â Time has passed so fast.And these were my first surprises. Â I was building the basement level of the townhouse and following the directions so very carefully ... I began constructing some of the interior pieces - without knowing what they were. Â Imagine my surprise and amusement when I discovered they were a telephone and a toilet! Â I was building a TOILET!! Â So darn cute.Anyway, now that I have set my knitting needles and crochet hooks aside, I looked for ways to fill that time and not stress out my digits. Â Thankfully, over the years since that first build, I have requested a number of lego kits for gifts. Â I must have 5 or 6 waiting. Â The time to begin building again is PERFECT!The kit I am working on now is The Detective Agency - The Pool Hall - Alâ€™s Barber Shop with another residence squeezed in-between! Â This is the picture off the box.For those who arenâ€™t aware of how the construction is approached, Â I thought I would share some of my methods.All the pieces come in separate bags like pictured above. Â The bags are numbered 1 to 4. Â Each number is the sequence they suggest you make the kit in. I made this shot above bigger so you can get the feel and logic of the sorting. Â First off, all the bags marked with a #1 have already been constructed into the first floor of the Pool Hall.Â Front of the pool hall. Â If you look through the glass doors you canÂ just see a bit of the pool table.Looking down from the top you can see the ceiling fan I built (put a smile on my facewhen I figured that out) and below that is the pool table.Here is a better shot of the pool table before the walls went up.Now I am preparing to do all the bags marked #2. Â Beyond the fact they have gathered all the pieces together that Â I need all for the next section in these #2 bags, I can see no logic to the pieces as they are packaged. Â All 4 bags are a mix of shapes, sizes and colors. Â So I had to come up with my own logic for sorting.I simply sort by color.Legoâ€™s instruction book is also a marvel. Â No words. Â Just each step pictured, starting with the exact pieces you need next. Â You then compare your previous work to the picture in the book and use those pieces you pulled to build your room one baby step at a time.Literally - no words. Really very international. Â Legoscan sell their kits all over the world without worryingabout translations. Â Genius.When this kit is complete it will be placed beside my first one in a plastic demonstration case to keep the dust off. Â I will continue building my little town one set of buildings at a time.One final note. Â I have never ever had a piece missing. Â How they manage to manufacture and package this as they do would be a very interesting documentary to see. Â But in the back of the instruction book is a listing of all the pieces used - with a picture of the piece in the color used and its number. Â It shouldnâ€™t be too hard to get a replacement.

title: Shocking - I am making potholders
text: You know ... I gave up a few things since the beginning of the New Year. Â And when that happened I found time I forgot I had. Â So I looked around and realized - hey - you bought this larger than normal pot holder loom last year, and you bought these expensive all wool pot holder loops to make 3 pot holders. Â So here is the pictorial story of the hand made pot holders, that finally got made and I am so glad.This loom is larger than the standard pot holder loom. Â And I love the size of the pot holders it makes.Here is the first potholder that I made in colors that match my kitchen.Years ago I bought a pot holder loom and wool loops and it made the standard (but small-ish) potholders.Â Here is the new pot holder made on the bigger loom. Â Pretty big difference in size.Another photo shot for size.I show this picture as a lesson! Â When I made the first bigger potholder I was sitting on the beach with my sister and cousin. Â I wove the potholder and figured I could get it off the loom with just my fingers. After all, that is what I did before. Â But on a larger loom, it is way easier to lose control and find a scrambled mess in your hands. Â And it was a total mess and I had to take it all apart and start again. Â Notice the tool they suggested you use to release the pot holder from the loom.Notice the anchoring loops used to keep the pot holder ON THE LOOM Â until you are finished binding off.Notice the written instructions that I finally sat down and read before my second attempt at making a simple pot holder. Â After I got over myself, thinking I didnâ€™t need no stupid instructions, (when in reality I did) ... see the 3 potholders I finally made with the very expensive wool loops I purchased when I purchased the larger loom.I have had the supplies to make these pot holders for more than a year. Â When I finally quit my board position and took a hiatus from knitting and crocheting to let my thumb heal .... I discovered I had time for other fun activities - and these pot holders were great fun.AND just so you know, wool is an ideal fabric for making potholders. Â I have had the smaller wool potholders for years and the heat never makes my hand uncomfortable. Â But a bigger size potholder makes better sense so you donâ€™t accidentally touch any hot surfaces directly.Now that these are done, I am once again letting my wondering eye check out what should be next.

title: Downton Abbey
text: Binge watching long running TV shows or limited streaming series are one of my favorite pastimes in the evening. Â I have watch The West Wing, The Walking Dead, Monk, The Witcher, Queenâ€™s Gambit, Outlander, The Wheel of Time, and Glee, just to name a few. Â And some of them I have seen more than once. Â They are great fun.Â My current binge series is Downton Abbey. Â I saw the first season previously, and maybe parts of the second in the past, but there are a total of 6 seasons and it is highly rated so I started watching it again. Â I really enjoy watching shows that are far far outside the scope of my experience, but interesting to watch and sometimes educational of the times depicted. Â Downton Abbey fits the bill because it has many season and it is far far far outside my life experience, and some people really did live like that in the early part of the 20th century. Â It also gives the flavor of the working man ... how they lived. Â It is a time when things seemed to move slower ... not like today when if you blink - you missed it.But I have developed some observations about this series and I thought Iâ€™d share them here.Oh.My.Dear.God! Â The houses of the aristocracy were enormous ... the extreme. Â Of course they had bunches of servants because how else could you live in that much space! Â But I had a hard time wrapping my head around the amount of space in the structures. And the amount of stuff you owned. Â Just an awesome thought. Â The houses are beautiful!! Â Not cozy, warm or even comfortable, but just museums to a time in history when architecture was â€˜king.â€™ Â But imagine trying to heat those buildings! Â Impossible I would imagine.And they dress for dinner every single night like they are going to a State dinner. EVERY SINGLE NIGHT! Â Their hair is dressed by their attendants every single day. Â EVERY SINGLE DAY! Â I would go mad with that kind of structure and expectation!Lady Mary drove me insane in the first 2 seasons. Â I found myself saying frequently - â€œyou stupid womanâ€. Â Her younger sisters seem to be growing and transitioning into the new world that is heading their way. Â Even her father and mother see the changes that are coming and they are evolving in small ways. Â As the seasons progress, she finally seems to achieve a kind of maturity.The clothes are to die for. Â I totally love the styles, the costumes - just beautiful.The social class structure within the English culture is striking. Â Even within the lower working class - there is a ranking. Â With all that said, I am really enjoying it - more than I thought I would - even the parts that drive me crazy. Â Season 2 includes the end of World War I and the 1918 Flu Pandemic. Â I am pretty sure I didnâ€™t see many of the later seasons so it should be really fun and interesting for the next few weeks.Do you binge watch shows on Netflix or Amazon? Â What are some of your favorite shows? Â I am always looking for a few good title.

title: The Price for Stupidity!
text: New Discovery!!Â Just like Covid 19 - knitting disorders haveÂ â€˜variants!'Â As I was preparing this blog post to be titled Start-itis, one of my blog buddies, Susan, of e-i-e-i-omg!Â did a post on AAOCKD - ACK for short! ğŸ˜ Or for long:Advanced Age Obsessive Compulsive Knitting Disorder(Be sure to follow the link to visit her blog to see what she is up to and how ACK as impacted her.)I looked up Start-itis just to be sure of the definition.Â The Urban Dictionary defines Start-itis as - repeatedly starting new projects while having multiple uncompleted projects. Â ACK is most probably very close â€˜cousinâ€ of Start-itis. I am guessing that what separates the 2 conditions are the words â€œadvanced ageâ€ and â€œknittingâ€ - Â both, by the way, are true for me. Â While Start-itis can afflict anyone, at any age, and any activities, ACK seems exclusively directed at us folks of aÂ â€œcertain age!"In my experience, start-itis is the strong desire to have the completed item - and there are so many many wonderful completed items to be desired in knitting and crochet - that you canâ€™t help but want to start them all.Â I havenâ€™t experienced much start-itis in my knitting life. It always seemed counter productive to have many projects started and then starting another new one - it was like creating multiple distractions to stand in the way of getting any one thing finished. Â And when I discover a long ago abandoned unfinished project, I always felt sad for the yarn and the time lost. Â My interest in the project and even the yarn itself waned and I ripped out the work - and sometimes even discarded the yarn.But since January 1st - a fierce case of start-itis or maybe ACK hasÂ gripped me. Â And it is not project driven - it is yarn driven! Â I have a strong desire to actually cast on many of the beautiful - and expensive - yarns I have accumulated over the years. Â God knows, I donâ€™t need another scarf or shawl or sweater - I canâ€™t wear all that I have now. Â But I want to work with those beautiful yarns and see how they look in a fabric as opposed to sitting idle, wrapped in a ball or skein, for ages and ages.... BUT... and it is a very big BUT ... after having casted on a number of new projects - 4 by my count, right after finishing a very large crochet blanket in record time ... I am now paying the cost for all that stupidity! Â Here is a pictorial view of the problem ...Normal right thumb.Not normal left thumb.The Fix #1TheÂ â€œnot normalâ€ picture was taken after I spent some time stretching that thumb into a straight position this morning - which it couldnâ€™t hold without help from my right hand - but at least was improved from what I saw when I got up!! Yikes. (And yes, I did knit last night for about 4 hours, ...Â BECAUSEÂ I thought the problem was due to crocheting, and I was knitting! Â Apparently I was wrong.) Bummer.When I saw how sad my left thumb was this morning, I went out to Google Doctor to self diagnosis myself (no lectures, please, since IÂ had no intention of going to my doctor now and bringing a â€˜hitchhiker virus' home to cause other problems, thank you Covid 19. ğŸ˜·) Â Turns out my symptoms match exactly Trigger Thumb caused by over use - it even listed crafts as a culprit! Crap! Â The price I pay for stupidity! So Fix #1 is no knitting or crocheting for awhile, the use of a thumb brace, and anti-inflammatories - like Advil! While I was getting Fix #1 implemented my brain was thinking ...Â What will I do with my time!!! Â Well being a hobbyÂ hoarder collector, gratefully I have options.Fix #2 PUZZLESI have about 20 puzzles waiting to be completed. Â Since I anticipate thisÂ knitting and crochet abstinence will be for weeks - maybe a few months -Â I set up a puzzle station on a desk - moving the table top computerthat my husband can no longer use - to the side. Â It is a great set up because Ican work on the puzzle in short bursts - out of the way of my husband.I got this puzzle for Christmas. Â A Girl and Her Dragon.And this one too. Â The Curse of Blackwood Hall.Fix #3 - WEAVINGMy looms have been idle for some time. And I have lost interest in most rigid heddlelooms - in fact I am trying to sell my 24# rigid heddle loom with stand now. But I have 2 smaller rigid heddles, several continuous weave pin looms, and 2 tapestry looms - all of whichI am still interested in using - especially now when knitting andÂ crochet is off the table.Â Right about now I should have a cousin who is probably jumping up and down with joy.She has been trying to get me back to weaving for some time.Fix #4 Â LegosÂ I have about 6 Expert Level Lego buildingsÂ that I have put on the back burner for years. Â Itis hard to explain why that is the case. Â IÂ LOVE building lego structures. Â I startedone of my kits last night and marveled at whyI hadnâ€™t been doing this all along.This set matches another set I have already created.And just this Christmas I got the Lego Tree house!!I canâ€™t wait to start that.Fix # 5 Â Audio BooksAdd to that a rather large library of audio books I need to catch up on while I make an effort to increase my daily step counts.And no pictures for Fix #6, but a to-do list calls to me as well - items that have been bumped and bumped andÂ bumped, again and again, when the sirenâ€™s call of knitting begs me to sit and just knit. Â Stuff like cleaning out the pantry so I donâ€™t buy stuff I already have while discarding stuff I brought with me from the townhouse 5 1/2 years ago (that just may be out of date - ha!, or I wonâ€™t eat because it is just too unhealthy,) and sorting out some more craft items I want to donate so that I can focus on the items I really want to do when my thumb returns to normal. Â And there is always the mundane stuff like the laundry this is waiting for me right now as I finish this post - and if I donâ€™t get to it by the morning, Iâ€™ll be wearing the dirty stuff again. Â Ugh!No - I have plenty to keep me busy. Â But despite all my good intentions and all my appropriate Fixes ... I still feel sad about setting aside all my wonderful yarn.But no matter ... I am left handed and this is my left thumb and ... have you tried to do anything recently without using your thumbs? Â Let me assure you - it is damn hard!! And if I want this left thumb back without pain and with some strength ... I need to let it heal and hope it is not aÂ permanent feature. Â The consequences of my stupidity shouldnâ€™t be a life long sentence. Â *sigh*

title: No, I donâ€™t know â€œwhatâ€™s in it."
text: While I profess to be totally annoyed with all those people who donâ€™t get the Covid Vaccine, I am not prepared to place all the blame on the continued pandemic at their feet. Â Since this is a world event, it is a world problem and requires a world fix.  A world fix is almost impossible achieve.  There are so many in the world who would gladly step up and get the shot if it was available to them.  If you really think on it - we canâ€™t even feed all the people that are on this planet - provide adequate housing, clean water, clean air, education. Â Will we ever get a Covid vaccine in all those arms?  Highly unlikely.  So Covid 19 and its family of off-shoots will be with us forever.  When I hear people saying we need to â€œwhip this virus in 2022, I just want to laugh.Just like the flu, I can choose to lower my chances of getting seriously ill or maybe dying from that little bug, but can we get everyone to take the flu shot?  Nope!  Covid will be the same, I fear.But I came upon this one perspective on Facebook.  It really hit home for me.  I just want to share.I'm fully vaccinated and boostered.Â No, I don't know "what's in it".  Neither this vaccine or the ones I had as a child. Nor do I know what's in the 11 secret herbs and spices at KFC.I also don't know exactly what's in Ibuprofen or Paracetamol-- they just cure my headaches & my pains.Â  I don't know what's in tattoo ink, botox and fillers, or every ingredient in my soap, shampoo or deodorants. I donâ€™t know the long term effect of mobile phone use, or whether or not that restaurant I just ate at REALLY used clean foods and washed their hands.There's a lot of things I don't know.I do know one thing: life is short, very short. I personally still want to do things. I want to travel and hug people without fear, and find a little feeling of life "beforeâ€.Throughout my life I've been vaccinated against many diseases. Measles, mumps, rubella, polio, chickenpox, hepatitis, pneumonia, influenza, rotavirus, tetanus, pertussis. My parents (and I) trusted the science, and never had to suffer through or transmit any of those said diseases.I'm vaccinated. Not to please the government. Not to make other people do it.Â But I don't want to:* die from Covid-19* lie in ICU with a pipe down my throat * not be able to hug my loved ones * have to test routinely* live my life in fearCan't say it any clearer.

title: The With Love, Granny Blanket
text: To circle back around on a project I started on November 13, 2021 - here is the finished With Love, Granny Blanket. Â I finished it on December 25 and I gave it to Esk on December 26.I shortened the border from the original pattern. Â It was supposed to be 8 rows around - resulting in a rather wide but beautiful border. I did only 3 rows. Â There were a few reasons why I stopped early. Â As I was completing the body of this blanket I realized it had considerable weight. Such a wide border would only add to that weight.Â The other reason was that the blanket was already quite large. Â It didnâ€™t need to be bigger. It was intended for a childâ€™s junior bed and it was large enough to accomplish that.When I finished the blanket I discovered that it was not entirely square. Â I was so careful in counting my stitches with every single row. Â I suspect the fact it was crocheted from corner to corner rather than side to side, may have played into this result.I did do a wet block (without pins or wires) - something that acrylic doesnâ€™t usually need, and it did help but did not totally correct the problem.When folding it - it is easy to see that the corners donâ€™t meet. Â But I love this blanket and it is going to a 3 year old - who wonâ€™t even notice such things. Â I totally expect to find it on the floor in her bedroom at some point - so it is intended to be used and enjoyed without limits - so it fills that expectation entirely.I may make this pattern again - or one similar. Â It was fast and satisfying to do. Â But if I do make it again it will be made top to bottom or side to side - but not corner to corner.

title: The Wave of Resignations and One of My Own
text: If you watch or listen to the news you canâ€™t miss the stories about the current trend ... Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â The Great Way of Resignations in 2021.Apparently one of the impacts of this extended pandemic is that people have reassessed their current jobs and have started resigning in rather large numbers. Â When I first heard about this I wondered how true this report was. Â But over time I have read and heard enough about this wave of resignations to determine this is a real thing. Â It is sort of like folks have had enough time on their hands (cooped up in their isolation) to stop, think and exam exactly how they are spending their life hours and decided changes must be made. Â In a few years it will be fascinating to read the sociology study of exactly what happened during this time in the group mentality.Since I am retired I figured it didnâ€™t really impact me. Â After all, I donâ€™t have a paying job. Â No boss to please. Â Even though I thought I understood what was going on, I didnâ€™t fit into that great wave of resignations. Â Apparently I was wrong.Starting in the fall of last year, I was very restless and unhappy. Â I was in a 2nd year of a 3 year commitment as a board member to my Condo Association - and, as Secretary, I had periods where I spent at least 30 hours a week focused on board activities. Â If the position was just setting agendas and taking minutes, it would be ok. Â It was far more, and I was fatigued by what it demanded. And as anyone knows who has held a position on a homeowners board, it is also a thankless position. Â  I was so busy and stressed by this â€˜volunteerâ€™ job, that I found myself feeling a certain level of resentment when my husband (who is blind and really does need help at times) asked for assistance. Â (Red flag, folks) Â I would immediately feel shame at my silent reaction.So on December 3rd I resigned - giving 30 days notice.I immediately felt bad about my resignation because the Treasurer followed me in resigning as well as the Member-at-large board memberl. Â All for similar reasons - the work load was too much and the resident support was too little. Â The Treasurer gave 60 days notice and the Member-at-Large gave 3 months notice so it wasnâ€™t like we all walked out the door together ... but it was still a big impact on a community of 106 owners.Â At the same time, I felt great relief and knew this was the right decision for me. Â It was time for someone else to step up and take a turn. Â I knew I had to put my blinders on and not be influenced by my emotions or the reactions of others. Â I think before the pandemic, I might have held on longer and made myself stick with a commitment I made. Â I would self-talk myself into staying by saying things like - there is always tomorrow for the other things you want to do and you are keeping your older brain active in this position. Â On the other hand some of my friends are showing signs of mental and physical decline due to age. Â And who knows - they might be finding the same in me. Â And news reports are filled with so much suffering and death from a tiny and very adaptive virus I cannot see. Â Many people planned on a tomorrow and there wasnâ€™t one. Â I am 75 in April of 2022. Â Exactly how many of my own â€œtomorrows" should I be devoting to this board position. Â The decision came back pretty quick. Â It was 0!I just couldnâ€™t walk away without giving the next volunteer the tools needed to be successful. Â So I saved my electronic files to a thumb drive and cleaned up my paper files for the hand off. Â  When I stepped into this role, I got one file with about 10 pages from the previous board member. Â Not much to build on. Â But I am done now and I have no regrets.Of course, in anticipation of reclaiming personal time, my nature is to start a to-do list of activities that I have ignored or tabled out of lack of time. Â I am a list maker after all. Â It is, however, my list to do or to ignore. Â I feel so much better having control of my tomorrows ... however many more there are.So ... to all those people out there in that huge wave of resignations ... I get it!Â And this is the first of myÂ â€œdoesnâ€™t matterâ€ items ...dropped from all my tomorrows.

title: Happy 2022 New Year and a loss in December 2021
text: Finally .... I made it to January 1, 2022.Welcome 2022! Â Anyone who has read my blog posts knows that historically I have a difficult relationship with the month of December. Â Sadly, December 2021 was no different. Â There was another probable loss, except not a death this time. Â While not entirely sure, it feels like a long time friendship may have just ended. Â I surely hope I am wrong, but at present, it feels like an end. Â  I blame Covid-19 for this loss because the parting of ways might never have happened without it. Â Family needs, however, are always a higher priority than those of friendships - at least in our family. Â Sorry to be so cryptic, but I just want to say it wasnâ€™t the best of Decembers. Â Not the worst but not uneventful either. Â I wonder how many other relationships have been changed or lost (directly or indirectly) by this stupid virus (a virus that isn't so stupid if it can upset the whole world the way it has.). Â I wish the best for these friends as we go our separate ways in 2022.Enough on that topic!December 2021 is gone. Â January! Â Wonderful January. Â The beginning of a new year, a clean slate, a perfect time to change direction, and the ideal time to narrow focus.I did look back to January 2021 to see if I made any promises or (God forbid) resolutions. Â I had not! I gave up New Year Resolutions a long time ago. Â And I wonâ€™t make any this year either. But 2021, with its continued pandemic, did teach me a few things.If I have learned anything from this year it is to narrow my focus and shed the distractions that just donâ€™t matter. Â And it has been an interesting exercise to determine exactly what my personalÂ â€œdonâ€™t matterâ€ items are.Going forward in January (did I say already that I LOVE January?) I plan to bring my â€œdonâ€™t matterâ€ items to the forefront in a few posts. Sort of like the reverse of a Resolution where you add steps or practices to you life to make things better. Â I like to think getting rid of â€œdonâ€™t matterâ€ items can have the same impact.Welcome 2022!

title: Christmas Images and a Holiday Greeting for you.
text: While the holiday season picks up speed - I thought I would provide proof that I donâ€™t back away from participating. Â I think of it as plowing onward a day at a time in an attempt to sweep away the memories of past Decembers, and make this December fun for those that I love. Â She needs no introduction at this point. Â My little Christmas Angel, Eskarina.My tree as seen from my deck.Looking at a fully decorated and lighted Christmas tree works better for me than any meditation.Â We lost this wonderful dog in 2021 - Milo, my daughterâ€™s French Bull Dog andmy grand dog. Â What a heart ripping experience that was for both of us. Â His passingis still fresh in my mind and brings tears to my eyes even 5 months later. Â It isÂ amazing to me how one little dog can settle so permanently inside your heart - as this dog has.Meathead, my sonâ€™s English Bull Dog - gone many years agobut still much loved.My tree has bows on it instead of tinsel. Â Many years ago we switched toÂ bows - cats eat tinsel, as it turns out. Â You donâ€™t want to know how I found out.It involves rubber gloves.Memories of my mom hang on the tree. Â She made these ornaments.An ornament commemorating Esk's year of birth.Â A Pug in a Santa suit - a nod of remembrance for Grimace,Â my sonâ€™s pug that loved me as no other has done. Â Gone many years butstill fills a large part of my heart.A package ornament that my mother-in-law put on aChristmas gift to me - my first Christmas with her son.Â  Â An ornament I purchased the first Christmas myson spent away from family in the Marines. Â Another hard Christmas.Our tree is full of decorations that hold memories. Â We never went with breakable ornaments. Â There are no glass balls. Â After picking my tree up off the floor one year (our very first cat, Ashes, loved to climb trees), I decided that glass balls were out. Â But I love the look of trees with them. Â Beautiful.Decorations I inherited from my mother-in-law. Â She lovedlighted houses.Two other houses I inherited. Â The Christmas tree was made by my mother.Her initials are on one of the packages below the tree. Â ELM for Elaine Leona Mesavage.Â Miss you bunches, Mom.Â My helper! Â ğŸ˜€Although it is not clear, she is trying to tie her dress to my tree. ğŸ¤£A visit to Santa! Â Socially distanced, of course.And a big improvement over previous years - the first of which shecried and cried. Â The second of which she had a stomach virus andthrew up in the car on her way to visit Santa.Ahh ... the memories.ğŸ˜‚May you all have a joy filled holiday season,Â no matter which holiday you celebrate. Â And may you only have happy memories of past holidaysÂ - or at least -Â memories that donâ€™t weigh you down.Be back in the New Year!!

title: The Quilt and the Blanket
text: I dedicated this past weekend to wrapping Christmas gifts. Â It always takes considerable time. Â Because I am working slower now-a-days - this task which used to fill a full 10 hour day, now fills parts of 3 days. Â I just donâ€™t have the energy or desire to push through and complete the wrapping in one day like I used to. Â But I enjoy the process - and this year, at least, I will get a chance to see my family open these gifts in person. Â Last year Zoom was my only option and it was better than not seeing them at all. Â Man, that was a bummer.One of my gifts for Esk is a matching quilt and sheet set for a junior size bed in the Frozen theme. Â For those who donâ€™t know what Frozen is - it is a Disney cartoon story about two princesses, Anna and Elsa, Â their kingdom and their adventure. Â If you want to know more - ask any kid who crosses your path. Â Any kid and most adults. Â Yes, it is that big!Anyway, before I wrapped the quilt set, I had this notion that I would I open up the quilt and place the blanket and quilt together. Â I did this previously as I picked the colors for the blanket specifically using the Frozen color scheme. Â Now with just over half of the blanket completed this might be the last time I could catch a picture of the 2 items together.Â So I opened completely both window shades in the guest room and turned on all the lights - hoping to improve my success as capturing the colors of the quilt and the crochet blanket correctly.And I think I did it. Â I was a bit concerned that the blanket would swamp the quilt. Glad to find out that it wonâ€™t.And as I snapped a few shots I made another executive decision.I am not going to wait until her February birthday to give her the blanket.Â Â I will give it to her as soon as it is finished. Â They are too cute together.Â Note: Â  If you look at the first picture that showed the quilt and the blanket together - in the lower left hand corner the color of the bedspread can be seen. In every previous picture I took and posted, that bedspread looks a dark beige! Â It is not - it is green! Â It is amazing how much better natural light is in photography.

title: Gaslighting with Pizza Cutters
text: This morning I was busily cleaning up the kitchen, hand washing a few dishes, emptying the dishwasher and drying some items that had collected in my dish drain. Â And then the oddest thing happened.Â I casually looked down at the towel in my hand and the 2 items just dried to determine the drawer they should go in and discovered there were 2 pizza cutters. Â Two. Â I own one. Â Only one. Â I stood there in the middle of my kitchen looking at these 2 pizza cutters. Â While my body was still, my brain was bouncing around in my skull searching in my memory banks trying to explain 2 instead of 1.Nothing. Â I quickly texted my daughter-in-law, sure she was missing a pizza cutter. Â Logic, of course, didnâ€™t enter into this action because even though she was here several times - why would she have carried a pizza cutter into my home. Â No matter. Â I texted. God knows what she was thinking when she read my message. Nope! Â She has her pizza cutter. Nuts!Â I circled back into my brain for another reason. Â No one visited with a pizza cutter ... I donâ€™t think.Â  No one of my social circle carries a pizza cutter in their purse or in their back pocket and besides - would you admit something like that? Â I wonder if pizza cutters are on theÂ â€œno fly listâ€ for airports! Â ğŸ¤£ I am going to bet they have seen everything. Â But visiting my condo with one. Â Not likely.Â Â Â Could the former owner of the condo accidentally left this pizza cutter behind and I am just finding it now - 5 years later? Â Ha! Â Only a desperate brain would accept that as a possibility.It is possible, I suppose, that I misplaced pizza cutter #1 and then went out and boughtÂ pizza cutter #2 and just today #1 pops up ... Â Nope! Â  I have no memory of doingÂ such thing and to consider the possibility that I may have completely blacked out on a trip toÂ the store to buy pizza cutter #2 ... well I am not ready to go with that yet.Is someone gas lighting me?Â I sure hope so! Â Â So I am going with that -Â no matter how paranoid it soundsÂ because all other options have ramifications I am not prepared to accept.Â The opposite problem and I are 'good friends.' Â  Items â€˜hidingâ€™ in plain sight ... Â sometimes on the bridge of my nose, on top of my head or right in my hand or right where they should be and I look right past them. Â Yes, I know that problem well!Â But I donâ€™t have room in my life for another â€œgood friendâ€ unless that good friend is causing extra $100 to show up in my hand that I didnâ€™t know I had. Â But an extra pizza cutter ... !!

title: The Heart Blanket - An Executive Decision
text: This is my last progress picture. Â I had not yet reached the center of the blanket.Clearly I have made progress, reaching the center andÂ now decreasing.But with only 15 days left until Christmas it is very clear that this blanket will not be finished when I thought.Although one side matches the edge of the bed, this side shows aboutÂ 4 inches of space not covered by the blanket. title: The Last Minute Granddaughter Blanket
text: Here is my first update on a blanket I decided to start on November 13 (November of this year - not last year) as a gift for my grand daughter. The first pictures are November pictures.The following pictures are from 2 days ago - early December. Â It is a pattern that has grown on me the longer I work on it. Â The lacy hearts are subtle - not easily seen up close while working on it.Even when I spread out one heart on my lap, like in this blue stripe, I think - I canâ€™t really see the full structure of one lace heart.In almost every close up view of my work - as I crochet - the pattern seems lost.But stretched out like so below, it is easy to see how cute it is. Â And the more I do on this pattern,the more I think about doing a second blanket as some point - maybe one for me.In the picture below the blanket is extended it full length on a queen size bed. Â It will be larger than I thought using the colors I wanted and the size of the stripes. Â The pink stripe is the center of the blanket and at present is about double the width seen in this picture. Pink will be the widest stripe. Â As of today, I am about 3 rows into the decreases - meaning I am working on the second half of this blanket now. Â And with each row the rows get shorter now. Â I am so glad I decided to crochet this blanket instead of knitting it. Â If I was to have any chance of finishing this blanket for Christmas I needed to crochet instead of knit since knitting is so much slower. Â And I have really enjoyed making this blanket - the change of the colors, the completion of each row of hearts, the growth in size - all added to the enjoyment.The real question is will this blanket be done by December 24? Â Unlikely. Â Once the blanket is complete, I still have a border that is about 2-3 inches wide to complete. Â But it should be done by the New Year for sure.

title: Please, make it January.
text: (This is not one of my happy posts. Â You can skip it if you need too. I wonâ€™t mind. Just giving a voice to feelings that I carry with me around this time of year - in hopes that putting fingers to keyboard I can shed some baggage that follows me during December.)In the next few days it will be December 1. Â Again!Â December!Â Â My least favorite month of the year. Â I can already feel the holiday pressure of getting things done crowding me. Â How I wish that was my only problem. The real issue is more complicated. I feel concern creeping up on me that the month passes without any bad stuff like illnesses or worse. I know that sounds a little bit paranoid - but December and I have a history together and it isnâ€™t positive. Â Â How did December get such a bad wrap? Â  Truthfully, I didnâ€™t always hate December and the number of happy December holidays far outweighs the sad ones ... so why canâ€™t I just throw off the bad ones and enjoy the season? Being a generally happy positive person the other 11 months of the year, I gave this question a lot of thought and discovered only one answer for me: the intensity of events and life changing nature of some of my Decembers sit in stark contrast to the â€œlet us all be happyâ€ message of December. Â The first dent in my relationship with December happened in 1970 with the death of my dad right before Christmas. It was a sudden event - a fall down a flight of stairs that was not discovered promptly and after a few days in ICU he died - several days before Christmas. Â His passing was a combination of sorrow and some relief. Â He was an alcoholic and he made family life hard. Â But I loved him in spite of all the pain he caused. Â That Christmas without him was my first experience of sadness while all the world seemed joyful. Â  Even in the funeral home where our family gathered to say goodbye reminders of the season were everywhere ... tastefully done, of course, but there all the same. Â Ironically, like bookends - the death of my mother came just after Christmas in 2014. Â These events were 44 years apart - certainly healing should have happened in that time. Â And it did. Each Christmas after his death I remembered him with forgiveness and love. That yearly remembrance felt like a healthy and realistic admission that sad things can happen at Christmas time, and you can move on and to be grateful for the happy events - recognizing that Christmas happiness is not â€˜promised'. Â But my mom's death was preceded by many hard December experiences - each one more difficult than the last until I couldnâ€™t stand the month at all. Â The first event happened about a year after mom moved in with me in 2007. Â A vicious GI bug spread through our family the day after Thanksgiving. Â It was the worst GI virus I have ever had. Â While normal healthy individuals could survive that, my mom was in her 80s. Â It devastated and hospitalized her - not once but twice in quick succession. Â The second hospitalization landed her in ICU because she was septic. As with all her hospitalizations, I was with her 24/7. Â Rehab followed and I followed her there as well. Â Getting her well consumed me. Â I approached her recovery as a battle to be won. Â I pushed medical staff to get her home before Christmas. Â She rallied quickly. Â When she came home it was December 22 - little to no holiday prep had been done for my own familyâ€™s Christmas. Â Some gifts were purchased but no wrapping, no Christmas tree, and no meal preparation. Â But no matter, my mom was home. Â  The tree got put up on December 23rd, and the gifts that werenâ€™t purchased by then where replaced with checks. I purchased a fully cooked Christmas Day meal from a local grocery store - and we called it good! Â The real celebration was ... Mom was home and doing well. Â I won that battle.I won the battle over several other hospitalizations and rehabilitations over the course of a few years getting her back home, but Â each left her weaker than before. At age 85 a hospitalization and a very long rehab experience ended with her being placed in Assisted Living. Â And, of course, that happened in the month of December. Â The community I picked was top notch, very homey with great staff, and beautifully decorated for the holiday, but I knew mom didnâ€™t want any this. Â She wanted to go home. Â The final determining factor were the 20 steps up from the parking lot to my townhome - steps she could not climb any more. Â I remember riding home that first night she spent in Assisted Living. Â The December lights on houses I passed were twinkling brilliantly, the Christmas music was playing on the radio, and I was in tears the entire way home at this permanent change in all our lives. Â That night I started to intentionally ignore December â€˜cheerâ€™ that tried to invite me at every turn to be happy .The last 3 years of her life she lived away from home - 2 years in Assisted Living and 1 year in Nursing. Â As always, the staff made the holidays as grand as they could. Â But it was hard to ignore that fact that about half the residents were mobile enough to visit a family memberâ€™s home for the holiday. We couldnâ€™t do that for mom. Â I hated those last 3 Christmases more than you could imagine. Â As December approached I felt disappointment and sadness begin to grow in me. Â To compensate I spent as much time as I could during those holidays with her, and extended family came for visits as well. Â We even arranged a separate Holiday family meal with her on site, but the one thing she always wanted was to go home, Â and I couldnâ€™t make that happen. Those 3 Christmases cemented my distaste for December and it was when I learned to yearn for January.Starting in early 2014 at 88 years old she had a number of serious health issues that could not get resolved. Her dementia had pretty much consumed her with only short glimpses of who she had been as my mom. Â In mid-December of that year her chronic problems were growing in intensity. Â Her eating had dropped off and she had no interest in her surroundings. I was losing this final battle and it seemed like nothing could halt her decline. Â When medical staff finally informed me that she was actively failing, I had already known in my heart she could not be pulled back. Â The message - your mother is dying - I got on December 22. Â They estimated she would make it to Christmas but not much past that. Â Needless to say, there was no holiday spirit left to crush in me. Â By this time Christmas Day was just another date on a calendar. Â My only comfort in those last days and hours were that the dementia I fought so hard against, was finally her â€˜friendâ€™ ... shielding her awareness of another passing Christmas away from home. Mom and I lost this last battle together, but at least I was the only one grieving.Â She died on December 28th. Â I was numb driving home that evening. Â I donâ€™t remember the trip at all - but I am sure without a doubt - those Christmas images I learned to ignore - were everywhere.This year will be the 7th year anniversary since her passing. Â Unfortunately traditional Christmas sounds and sights still remind me of our years of struggle. Â  I still yearn for January. Â But now at 74, I accept that this will not change. Â You canâ€™t â€˜un-ring a bell' - the memories cannot be wiped from the mind as if they never happened. Â  I accept them now, however, with more grace. Â A grand daughter has helped me to find some peace in these celebrations, but I still feel it is a lot for those tiny little shoulders to bear, so I donâ€™t rest entirely on her existence as my way out of holiday gloom. Â After 7 years I am better at hiding that sad part of me by putting a smile on my face during December - especially with family. Â But when I am alone with only my thoughts during this month, the memories of holidays mom and I shared appear like a flash flood - sudden and sweeping away everything else. Â Â Please, make it January. Â (Has the sharing of this helped me shed some of my â€˜baggage?â€™ Â Maybe a make-up case worth. Â Has it increased just one personâ€™s understanding that others struggle mightily during the holidays? Â I hope so.)During happier times when she would sit onÂ my front step and just enjoy the feelingof being outside.Mom and I in 2011Taken at the rehab facility she eventually would call â€œhome.â€ Â Mom, my sister and I in 2012Taken 2 months after she moved into Assisted Living.Â Is it January yet?

title: Progress Report: Frozen Colors Afghan
text: I made a bit of progress on the crochet afghan I am stitching for my granddaughter for Christmas, so it seemed like the time for a picture update.Â First picture - taken within about 48 hours of starting on November 13.The pattern is called â€œWith Love, Grannyâ€ Afghan Pattern designed by Crystal White-VanCleemput, of JolieKnotsCrochet. Â The word â€˜Granny' is a reference to the Granny Crochet stitch that makes up the heart patterns in the blanket. Â The â€˜With Love' reference is a nod to all the hearts in the pattern. But I love how when you put all the words together in the title it can be understood as a gift from a loving grandmother - which my afghan actually is.Several days later.I am glad I decided to crochet this instead of knit it. Â There is no knit stitch that covers this much ground this fast based on the speed at which I knit and crochet (which isnâ€™t fast.)I am pretty happy with the faint suggestion of the heart pattern in this design. Â Checking Ravelry, one crocheter called it â€œWatermark.â€ Â And that is exactly the impression the hearts give - like a watermark on paper. You know it is there but it doesnâ€™t demand the viewerâ€™s attention on the simple background of double crochets.A few close ups of the design.Based on how much yarn has been sucked up by this project so far, I had to once again purchase additional skeins of yarn to complete the afghan based on the order I am using them. Â Since it is a corner to corner design, the light blue and white are falling into the part of the pattern that is the widest and based on my planned use of the design - there will be more rows of the colors in the wider center ... and therefore needs more yarn. Â Thankfully I could get extra skeins and colors I needed at Joann Fabricâ€™s shop near me.After the light blue is completed, I have a pink that will fall into the center of the afghan. Â It will have more rows than any previous color. Â Then I will begin to decrease, going back to the light blue, and then the white and then the lavender, etc. etc. etc. Â So based on those plans I think I am about 1/3 of the way through this pattern - only 1/3 because the closer I get to the center the wider the stripes are.And I gave some thought to the border.Â Designerâ€™s picture from the pattern.I donâ€™t care for the open lacy border of this pattern.I donâ€™t care for the border that came with this pattern, and I planned to do something that had a picot edge. Â And then I stumbled upon a border called Whipsiderry Border designed by Dedri from her blog called Â Look At What I Made. Â Although I am always going to be primarily a knitter, Dedri manages to drag me into crochet time and time again with her beautiful designs. Â She does the most stunning crochet, and her website is full of her free designs, beautiful pictures, exceeding detailed written and pictorial instructions and links to her YouTube step-by-step video instructions (a must for me with crochet.) Â The Whipsiderry Border I plan to use.I love the solid look of this crochet border. It is wider than most with a solid foundation of double crochets that match the double crochet background of the hearts afghan I am working on ... and then is topped off with an appealing crochet lace pattern.This border will add considerable extra work to the afghan once I complete the body (ha! Â Just what I need with a tight deadline. Not!) Â Other possible designs would have made for a quicker border, but now my mind is settled on this design so it is what I will use - and if it isnâ€™t quite done for Christmas, I will just give it to her after Christmas.Â (See? Â I can be flexible.)

title: Fall - Falls Down
text: My Gosh! Â I have seen some stunning Fall colors in some of the blogs I follow! title: Playing â€œChickenâ€ With Christmas - Again!
text: About 15 years ago I playedÂ â€˜chicken' with Christmas.Â It wasnâ€™t pretty. Â I vowed to never do it again!How does one play â€˜chickenâ€™ with Christmas? Â Well, for me it involves setting unrealistic deadlines for getting things done before the hard deadline of Christmas Day! Â During my last â€œchickenâ€ event Christmas 15+ years ago, I decided in October to knit 8 projects as gifts. Yes, you read that right. Â October and 8 projects, entirely crazy. Â The projects were smaller but still, 85 days divided by 8 projects equals approximately 10 days per project from start to finish. Â Calculate in time for other activities like eating, sleeping, household tasks, typical Christmas craziness, and a full time job (yes, I was working) and you get way less than 10 days per project.Â The experience was intense (actually ridiculous!) Â So ridiculous, that if I hadnâ€™t had a gallbladder surgery on December 5 of that year (followed by a period of short term disability from my job to heal - 'knitting time' by any other description) Â I would never have reached my goal of eight finished Christmas gifts by December 25th. Â Since I have limitations on just how many bodily organs I can offer up to the knitting gods for a Christmas deadline, I vowed never to knit for Christmas again. Although it looks like I am breaking that vow this year, I am not.Â I am crocheting. Ha! (this little loop hole will probably bite me in my butt at some point.)So, with a flush of enthusiasm, on November 13, ( 42 days prior to the deadline) I started a sizable Christmas project - a kidâ€™s blanket! Â Another blanket! (I should be committed!) Â I have 2 others still 'on the hook' and somehow I talked myself into another one - with a deadline, no less.Â But I have important reasons why I am doing this project Â ...#1 - It is for my granddaughter (No other reasons â€œneed apply,â€ but I will add them anyway.)#2 - It is crochet and it goes faster than knitting many times over. (True)#3 - It is a simple pattern. (Also true)#4 - It is a stash buster project (normally, yes, except for the 8 additional skeins I purchased to use up the 5 others I had - I think that is a gain of 3! ). Math was not a strong subject for me in school.Â The colors are all wrong. Â Left to right: true purple, light purple andÂ lavender. Â Light blue, pink and white come later.A finished project of someone on Ravelry.The pattern is called With Love, Granny Afghan Pattern by Crystal White-VanCleemput of JolieKnots.com. Â It uses the granny stitch to make the hearts. My colors match the colors in Frozen - the Disney cartoon that is so popular with children now. Â It is a corner to corner pattern - so at this point I am increasing and each row takes longer to complete.Even under an Ott light, the colors are off.Iâ€™ll post a few progress pictures between now and December 25th - just to help keep me honest and focused on getting this done. Â Â And just to make things really interesting, I added another Christmas deadline project. Â This puzzle which I am working to complete, glue together and frame. Â This Disney mermaid is called Ariel and Eskarina dressed up as Ariel for Halloween.Â She really loved that long red hair.Must stop now - I have deadlines to meet!!

title: A Sunrise Reserved For One
text: I know that no one â€œownsâ€ the sunrise, but there should be some rules or a reservation system or Â something for viewing.Let me back track.My last morning at the ocean I was the first one up (thank you legs!). Â I walked out to the balcony and looked behind me.Â Â Still dark. Â Roads were quiet! Â No one was about.Â Perfect. Â Looking east I could see the start of a beautiful morning with just me and the ocean and the sun.Â I settled in with my camera phone and my coffeeÂ to enjoy the beauty of natureÂ on this last day of my trip to the ocean.I had just these few last hours of my long weekend away from home. Â I wanted to make the best of them.And from the looks of the horizon I didnâ€™t have long to wait. Â There she was, the sun peeking just above the horizon.And the ocean giving me a gentle wave - to tell me the best was yet to come. Â I was ready!And then I heard it!! Â Â Running feet from behind me. Â  This lady was running down the street with her camera held up high in the air in front of her trying to catch the sunrise. Â Seriously ... running with a camera held in front of her!! Â As she passed me her feet were loudly slapping the pavement and she was totally unaware I was watching her - because her eyes were not focused on her surroundings but focused entirely on her camera!!! Â You can even see the brightness of the sun reflected through her lens. Â AND standing between me and the ocean and the sunrise, no less! This was just like butting in line! Â How rude. It shouldnâ€™t be allowed!!And then I immediately chastised myself for my unkind selfish thoughts. Â Â Â So I re-adjusted my camera so thatit seemed as if I was the only one capturing the moment. Â Just me, the ocean and my camera!Out of nowhere, the woman and her dog casually wandered into my picture frame. Â On â€œlittle cat feetâ€ she was (except she had a dog)! Â Dang!! Â Dang!! Dang!! (Deep breath ... be calm.) Ok, she has a dog. And at least she was quiet - not pounding her feet down the street.Â  Â Be kind. Â Pet people are good people.Just get over yourself, I kept saying.I readjusted my camera again! Â *sigh* And again, just me and the ocean and the sunrise (andÂ these â€œalmost late-to-the-partyâ€ folks.)Â Â Â Just look at that sunrise and the beauty of the colorsÂ reflected on the waters. Like a beautiful painting. Â You have GOT to be kidding me!!Â I looked to my left and I saw MORE PEOPLE!! Â Hey, guys, this has happened every single morning since the beginning of time!!!!!Go home, please.Â Â Back through my lens again - things were not getting better! No beach space without people.CARS!! They were now pulling up in cars! I checked the street behind this guy to see if buses were lining up!!!!!More new folks. And you will notice, now I am taking pictures of THEM and not the sunrise!!!Focus, focus!My last picture, with the sun light pouring down between the cloudsand the ocean taking a bow with the lovely splash of a wave.AND NO PEOPLE.Ok, this is my last picture! The rays of sun, just needed to take this last picture.Â Â I knew it was mean of me not to want to share this beautiful event that happens every single morning since the beginning of recorded time (and before.)Â But, seriously, next time I am going to put up a sign at the end of the entrance to 94th Street -Â stopPrivate Showing!Only One Reservation AcceptedThis sunrise is booked!Try again tomorrow.SignedThe Atlantic Ocean!

title: The Phone Call ...
text: I live by the old adage â€œNo news is good news.â€Â Leaving a handicapped husband behind results in spending as much time preparing him for my absence as I do packing for myself. But I have done these short trips with no problems. Â Except I guess my mind is always â€œon the readyâ€ to respond, to anticipate, to assume the worst while I am gone â€˜cause that is what my mind did on this occasion!Important to the following story is this face. Remember this face!Â My cousin and I were on a short shopping trip to purchase some seafood just outside of town. As we traveled down Ocean Highway, I enjoyed the opportunity to see older housing structures from Ocean Cityâ€™s early years. The original buildings of the 30s, 40s and 50s located near the original point of the town were more â€œold-time beachy,â€ painted in typical light colors, older, only one for two stories high, more weathered from years of use and storms. Â I pondered about the history those old buildings could tell! In my youth during the 60s, Ocean City was just a summer beach town and a destination for students Spring Break adventures and family summer trips. Â Why I remember a time ....And then my cell phone rang dragging me out of my head and into the present!I glanced at the screen and was surprised to see my downstairs neighborâ€™s name. Â In lightening speed the scenery was forgotten and my mind went to all the reasons (bad ones) that she could be calling me while I was out of town! Â Topping the list of reasons was my husband and that something had happened to him. I could feel my heart rate start to climb.Â I answered!She said hi - just like that. â€œHi!â€ ... like there was no emergency, just a friendly neighborly call. Â Confusion peppered my brain. Â I was thinking ... Â Seriously? Â I am out of town, and you are calling to say â€œhi?" Â  It was like she was speaking in Greek and I was listening in Spanish! Â All that in one little word ... â€œhi.â€Â And then she said ... â€œI think I have one of your window screens. Found it on the sidewalk.â€While I did my best to put â€œwindow screenâ€ and â€œhusbandâ€ in the same sentence meaningfully, she went on. â€œYes, I am outside now looking up, and I can see it is missing from your Â window. Â Should I bring it up to you?â€Ahhhh ... ok, window screens ... my heart rate began to slow.Â Â  Â #1 She did not know I was out of town.Â Â  Â #2 She isnâ€™t calling about my husband.Â Â  Â #3 How the heck did my window screen spontaneously fall from my window? Â Although my mouth was still bone dry at this point, my tongue was working again. Â After letting her know I was out of town, she agreed to keep the screen at her condo till I returned. Â I think I managed to end that call without letting on how fracture my brain-tongue connection was.I hung up and immediately called my husband. Â He picked up - sounding like everything was fine too! Â Of course, he had no idea a screen was missing, so he really was fine! Â We spent the next 15 minutes ... him opening and closing windows, and checking for the screens - and once he identified the one that was missing, he shut that window so the bugs wouldnâ€™t come in and Aja wouldnâ€™t fall out!Â And Aja. Â My mind had already jumped to the cause and the culprit!Â The story behind the story!A few months ago,Â I discovered what I thought was a defect in a new window screen. Â The screen company replaced it - because it wasnâ€™t even one year old. Â That screen had a slit near the bottom edge of the frame. Â No biggie. Â It was apparent to me that the slit was a manufacturing defect. Â The screen company honored their guarantee. Â All was good. Â But with this second episode - the â€œscreen-jumpingâ€ episode, Â I began to put 2 and 2 together. Â One damaged screen, one screen leaping off the second floor spontaneously ... and birds ... lots and lots of neighborhood birds, and some who like to play chicken with my cat - birds with an obvious death wish! Â It is cool-ish outside now. Â Our windows are mostly closed. Â Yes, that is a mini-screen in front of the window screen - clamped in placeby the window above.The windows that are open, now have a protective window screen shield. No other window screens have been forced into taking that leap to the ground since the use of these mini-screens. Â So what do you think? Â Not naming any names, of course, and I have witnessed nothing. But the evidence is piling up. Do you think this charming little face - is hiding â€œkiller intentâ€ that no thin screen material will keep her from achieving her goal?Â DEATH TO ALL BIRDS!!Â ğŸ˜Well, she is a cat, after all, and cats are only partly domesticated. Â And she is female which is the â€œbusiness endâ€ of her species and designed for hunting down prey to feed kittens. Â  And finally, she is a hunter as evidenced by her stalking of flying insects who might have accidentally stumbled into HER condo (through an open screen I might add) and sadly became an amusement as well as an appetizer for her. Â Those birds were just too much for her! Â Thank God she didnâ€™t fall from the open window.Now in addition to my own prep for travel and my husbandâ€™s needs, I have added Aja to my travel check list!Â Assess cat related hazards. Â  (check â˜‘ï¸ ) ğŸˆNext up: A Sunrise Reserved for One

title: Part 1: Art Show at the Beach!
text: Over its history Ocean City has matured from a lazy beach focused vacation spot to a year round destination for visitors. The large and hard-to-miss Convention Center always has something scheduled but tucked away in a bayside neighborhood close enough for us to walk to is this Arts Center!  I've passed this building on past previous walks never guessing what wonderful things it contained.  The rest of this post will be told with pictures.In the main hall was this dress made entirely of chain links.Â View from the back.A side view. Â Zipper!A matching hat - as if the weight of the dress alone wasnâ€™t enough.Beautiful stone work on the chest!Beautiful bead work dangling from the hem.Picture proof, the dress can be worn. (haha) if you look carefully you can see my hand and phone taking reflected in the glass. Â Missed that!This was the first and most impressive display of the art for me. Unusual materials, flattering dress design, interesting small details. Â My son, who is into gaming, had made a simple chain link shirt for himself. Â I forwarded THESE pictures to his wife - â€œThis is what he should make for you.â€ Â One final picture of the braided chains that ran down each side. Â I just couldnâ€™t get enough of this dress. Setting aside the fact it was all metal, the design features on the dress are so flattering to the female form.Onward ...A â€œTree Trunkâ€ Coat!Stepping back for the full effect.From the back!Up close picture of the fabric and stitching. Â Looks like print out of a book. Â Kind of an interesting feature since books are made from paper which comes from trees.Proof again that it can be worn. The materials listed Â for this coat were: Â fabric, paper, wood, vinyl.This is truly wearable art. Â Art that is stepping outside the box of traditional definitions of â€œart.â€ Â I loved it!! Beautifully created and stunningly displayed. Â There was no fee to enter this art show but I would have paid to view these beautiful and imaginative garments.Â All the items in the show were priced for sale. Â The metal dress was priced at $5,000. Â The tree trunk coat was priced at $6,000. Â While I am not an art collector - if I had the right setting in my home to displays these items, I would pay the price to own them. Â Next time: Â Part 2 - Everything else in the Art Show

title: The View ... Peace.
text: The ocean is a peaceful place for me. Â It is constant, it has a rhythm, it can be quiet and it can be loud. Â And sometimes it can be fierce! Gratefully I have only seen its fierce face on TV. Â Being this close to the ocean when it is in a bad mood is not an adventure I seek out. Â But on this weekend, the ocean was quiet and mostly at rest.Nothing graces my eye and mind as the ocean, the sand, and the birds Â ... elements in harmony along the continent's edge. Even with eyes closed, the sounds have a slow steady beat punctuated by intermittent bird cries. In the off seasons of fall and winter, the lack of human sound at shore line is like music. Â  Sadly, I get to visit seldom. But thankfully the ocean changes little from visit to visit.The view my first morning from the deck.Â It is all in this picture taken the first morning there. Â All my favorite things. The ocean, small waves, the dune, my coffee, my knitting, and the sunrise with reflection on the water.I am an early riser generally. Â Not by choice, but because my legs get irritable in the morning and I have to move or sometimes just get the heck out of bed! Â So it was that morning. Â And for a change my legs did me a favor. Â Because I was up early before everyone else, I didnâ€™t miss this beautiful sunrise image.At a later time I captured these shots.Unlike my walks at home that usually are done with my husband, I get the greatest pleasure walking alone, especially on the beach. Â I donâ€™t enjoy walking on soft sand, so on my own I am free to stop when I choose, to take pictures of something that catches my eye, to just stand and take in the glory of the ocean or watch the sea birds as they putter around on the sand. Â Lately I have been in some turmoil and it was wonderful to just empty my mind out onto the shore line and let the ocean take it all away for a short time.Â I did cut over to the side walk along Ocean Highway for a bit to get my heart rate up and circulate the blood. Â The view there is not much different than any other city, but it easier to walk when you have a temperamental left knee that doesnâ€™t appreciate uneven surfaces.But the beach walk was just for me, the birds and the ocean.Next up: The Art Center

title: On the Road ...
text: Since my husband can no longer drive, I am the only driver - no matter where we go. Â I donâ€™t mind driving generally, but when someone else is doing the driving, it is a real treat to sit in the passenger seat. Â My sister volunteered to drive so that I could knit on the trip. Â I didnâ€™t knit a stitch. Just ran my mouth the whole way, and it was lovely.Although I have driven to Ocean City many times, I have always taken the most common route - Route 50 to Route 90! Â It takes you through several local Eastern Shore towns - like Easton and Cambridge and Salisbury. Â None of them are particularly scenic - just groupings of every day communities with the store fronts providing the day-to-day residential needs and stop lights.But this time we followed a more easterly route to the shore that took us through a lot of farm lands. Route 404 is less congested with fewer cops monitoring out-of-towners.Â When it was time for a stop - a charming farm store attached to an orchard popped up just like we had ordered it.Â Â Â Besides the fruit and vegetables they had some specialty vinegar and olive oils, like white balsamic peach flavored vinegar and garlic olive oil. Â Using their selection of bottles, we got both of those.Â They also had wonderful bakery items and sandwiches - made to order. Â We decided this was great place to stop and have lunch.When we left - we carried with us about 5 different desserts to share at the ocean and dog cookies. Â Since we would only be 3 on this visit, we may have over-did-it on the desserts.Before you knew it we had reached the condo - The Phoenix - owned by my cousin. Â One of the big advantages of this condo is that it was built before the time when Ocean City regulated just how close to the sand dunes you could build! Â As a result the building is built further out near the sand dune by a number of yards. Â And it is built right beside access to the beach.Â The balcony for the condo is on the right. Perfect view.Perfect view for this! Â Hello, beautiful!And because it juts out being an original building, this is the view to the left off the balcony. Â Unobstructed view of the dunes on the deck.Â The weather was beautiful - but, truthfully, there is no such thing as a bad day at the beach.Â Next up: The View ...

title: A Trip - the prep and the 'all important' list!
text: I donâ€™t get away from home often. Â When the opportunity presents itself and my calendar is open, I go! But because I am not a frequent traveler, I probably need more preparation time than most people.Â My â€˜trips' can be as simple as spending the weekend at my sonâ€™s house for house dog-sitting to traveling to a destination as far away as 2 1/2 hours. Ocean City, Maryland is about 2 1/2 hours away. Â I had a chance to visit my friend, the ocean, ... and, oh yes, my cousin and my sister. ğŸ˜„But it does take a bit of preparation for me to be gone. Â Just like anyone else, I have to pack stuff. Â I leave my canvas tote open in the dining room and drop stuff in when an item pops into my mind. Â That is really helpful because lately my mind works like a ping pong ball bouncing off one idea and shooting off in an opposite direction to another. Â I follow a check list I wrote up years ago. Â I review that list the day before travel and right before I leave.Â As you can see, my check list needs to be updated, as I have run out of room to check off items for future trips. Â  It might seem a little over kill on the details, but I hate remembering what I missed while traveling on a fun trip. Relying on my memory has proved to be pretty unreliable.Then there are the things that must be done for my husband who is blind. Â While some spouses are independent enough to do simple stuff like make a meal or perk the morning coffee, my husband canâ€™t manage that without preparation on my behalf. Â I also make sure that the floor and surfaces are picked up so he isnâ€™t left to maneuver around lots of random objects in my absence. Â And finally I remind my â€œback upâ€ coverage (my kids) that I am gone so if he calls they are responsive. Â He never calls - because he is fairly independent within the condo - but knowing I have that back up relieves my mind. Â  So my pre-departure list needs to be detailed since two of us are depending on it. Â I donâ€™t own any real luggage. Â Various totes or bags work well enough for someone who doesnâ€™t travel much. I donâ€™t travel through airports so I donâ€™t need luggage with wheels. Â But the number of bags I use can get out of hand pretty quickly.There is the bag for clothing, medicine, and my pillow. Â Yes, I canâ€™t go anywhere without my old, very flat, soft pillow. Â I have had that pillow for probably 15 years. Â There isnâ€™t much of it left, but it fits my head and keeps my neck from getting stiff. Â And yes, my pillow is on my list!!There is the bag for my knitting projects. Â I carry two current projects and sometimes a 3rd something - all relatively small. Â No sizable projects like blankets or nearly done sweaters. Â  The knitters among you are probably scratching your heads. Â "What? Â Only 3 projects? Â Arenâ€™t you afraid you will be left with nothing for your hands to do?â€ Ha! And sometimes my single project bag spills over into another bag with finished objects to show fellow crafters. But the goal is to keep it simple and carry only one bag.And then there is the bag for the food I bring as most of my trips involve a sharing food responsibilities.Â The contents of these bags (however many) are typically on the list - and if not, I find myself stressing days in advance about forgetting something.While not related to prep and packing - I notice that I donâ€™t sleep well in advance of a trip. Â Maybe if I traveled more - getting a good nightâ€™s rest before travel might not be an issue. Â Practice makes perfect after all.Maybe I should add a few other things to the bottom of my list likeStop worrying. Â (Check âœ”)Shut your mind down.Â (Check âœ”)Get some sleep.Â (Check âœ”)Nope, not a good idea! Â Leave no evidence behind that you are THAT anal! Â (except on the blog!)Next up: On the road!

title: Stupid Stuff
text: As if focusing a post on my left thumb was not stupid enough -Â here are a few other stupid things cluttering up my time and my mind Â -Â Â so when I take my next blog break of 2 or 3 months,Â you will be able to say - â€œOh thank God, she has gone blog-post-dark for a bit.I canâ€™t take any more stupidity."DRINK MORE WATERCorrect.
