Â Drinking more water is not stupid. Â But in my case I should really say - Drink water - Period! Â Stupid is the â€œgame" I play to make it happen. Â Without the game I drink next to nothing. Â I could go all day on a cup of coffee in the morning and a glass of wine at nightÂ and ... IÂ never - I sayÂ N.E.V.E.RÂ get thirsty in-between. Â In fact, I could go out for a humid summer walk, work up sweat, and think - Gosh a glass of water would taste great right now! But by the time I open my front door to return, my thirst alert disappears entirely. Â Yes, yes, I know, that is not normal, but a majority of my life was lived just like that. Â Now as a senior, my water intake has become more important. Â Hence the search for a fix ....Meet my new water bottle! Â Or I should say, my latest new water bottle. Â Lots of "almost new" water bottle clutter my kitchen cabinet and are failures for one reason or another. Â What I really need is a water bottle with authority ... that has a hand that reaches out, grabs my collar and says â€œDrink!!â€ Â  But failing that feature, here is what this new bottle does provide that the others missed.It divides the water into time periods. Â I can look at the bottle and think - oh, I am 2 hours behind. Â So I drink down to the current time.It has a â€œwaist.â€ Â I can get my hand around it. Â Many bottles are so fat that it isnâ€™t comfortable in the hand.It has a handle that lets me carry it easily when walking.It has a tight seal so it doesnâ€™t leak.It has a wide mouth that easily accepts ice. Â Water without ice is still impossible for me.Nothing is perfect, so here are its 2 short-comings so far.It has a fat bottom so it doesnâ€™t fit into my carâ€™s cup holder.It sweats because of the ice. Â It would be nice to have a thin insulation to prevent sweating.I certainly demand a lot from a water bottle, donâ€™t you think? Â The question is ... has it worked.Â Day 1 - Â I drank my full 64 ounces of water or the required 2 fill ups!! Smashing success! Â Day 2 - Â I drank 32 ounces - only one fill up. Hmmm, ok ... more than the â€˜noneâ€™ which is my normal.Day 3 - Â The next day I drank only 16 ounces and I managed to forget the darn bottle at my sonâ€™s house.Â *sigh*. I was half way home when I discovered it was missing so I Â turned around to get it. Â I wouldnâ€™t have done that for any other bottle. Â I am not giving up.But seriously, isn't it stupid I canâ€™t seem act like a grown up, go into the kitchen and fill a glass with water several times and day - and drink it - voluntarily?HOUSE PLANTSI finally have a cat who doesnâ€™t eat plants! Â Way To Go, Aja!! Â Just a short detour on the plant news. Â Here is a picture of Aja sleeping out in the living room. Â She finally just this week showed she is comfortable sleeping near us outside the bedroom and by an open window with street noise - but only if there are no others about.And just now, for the first time in 17 months, I watched her clean herself! Â She is always clean, so I knew she was grooming, but I never actually saw it. Â  Today ... another forward baby step in our relationship.Just Amazing! ğŸ˜And now the plants ....After 52 married years with cat companions and being forced to choose between cats and plants - I can now have both. Â I live on the sunny side of the building. Â This summer I got a few flowering geraniums that love the sun. Â They remind me of my student teaching days in early 1969 when I had a mentor teacher, Mrs. Miller, who was still teaching at 70 (I am in my 70â€™s and just canâ€™t imagine managing a class of 30 2nd graders at 70). Â She had a row of geraniums that stretch the length of her class room along the windows. She pampered them every morning.These are hardy plants but sometimes have problems adjusting to the indoors in the fall (or that is what I read on line.) Â Hoping these few will winter well enough indoors.What is the stupid part! Â I obsess. Â Every morning I check all the leaves and pick off the ones that look like they are failing. Â I remove blossoms that are at the end of their blooming cycle. Â Check the dirt for watering. Â I move some indoors or move some out - looking for a stress reaction caused by changing locations. Â Ever - single - morning. And while I am doing this I am pondering names for them. Â Yep, names!You see, one of my geraniums came with the name: Â Mrs. Pollock on her plant tag! Â That is the actual name of the version of geranium she is. Â She has the most beautiful tri-colored leaves. Â  Then I looked at the other plants. Â Nameless! Â So ... do YOU know anyone else who considered naming their plants? Â I havenâ€™t done any naming yet, but the thought crosses my mind now. What would be a good name for a geranium! Â Here is a picture of Mrs. Pollockâ€™s leaf. Â She doesnâ€™t need flowers for me because her leaves are so pretty. Â But she is having the most trouble transferring to the indoors. Â I am pretty sure there is a Giovanni somewhere in my group!! Â Giovanni Geranium has a certain ring to it. Â Or maybe Geronimo!! And then my mind drifted to ... those are male names. Â hmmm ... Â I wonder if Mrs. Miller had this problem.Can things get any more stupid?Â Â MY NEIGHBOR (no pictures but a sad story)I live in a 55+ condo community so I live very close to other people. Â Many original owners have died or moved away, but we still have a small percentage of the population well past their abilities to live independently. Â And that was the case of my neighbor, (Iâ€™ll call her Jane.). Jane was a nice lady, but a little foggy. Â She didnâ€™t seem to have friends in the community, never attended owner meetings, never out for walk, hardly every made trips to the trash dumpster. Â Once she mentioned watching her sonâ€™s children at his house. Ahh, I figured ... that's where her life and connections are. Still, it seemed odd that family or friends never visited her in her condo. Â When we moved here neighbors shared that she liked to shop by mail. Â It was common for 3 or 4 packages to be waiting in the foyer for her several times a week. Â They whispered the word â€œhoarderâ€ to me. Â I felt bad that they shared this with me - a virtual stranger at that point. I was uncomfortable with this talk and would often pick up her packages from the first floor and set them by her door out of sight of judgemental eyes. Â After all, she was hurting no one. Â But over the 5 years she and I lived side by side, we were barely acquaintances.Â Three weeks ago I noticed big changes. Â She had been gone for a long time it seemed. Â Others were going in and out of her unit. Â Many very large black trash bags filled the hallway. Those disappeared. Â And more re-appeared, but disappeared again. Â Later a junk truck pulled up behind the building and started to fill. Â It arrived many more times that I noticed and was always full to the brim. Â But I never saw Jane. Â I began to worry that she had passed away. Â At one point I stopped a lady going in - turns out it was her daughter from Florida (wow, I didnâ€™t know she had a daughter ...Â who apparently never visited ... Â sorry, that was unkind of me.) She assured me Jane was fine, had been hospitalized, and was in rehab. She would not be returning, but moving directly to Florida, and they (her brother and her) would be selling the unit. Â Ok ... I felt some relief that family was finally stepping in to help her.So what is the stupid stuff? Â For a woman who I barely knew - I felt sad. Â In moving, her life and stuff, that she had so carefully hidden from the neighbors was suddenly on full display. While I am sure she could not participate in the condo clean up without saving everything, Â it appeared that literally every decision regarding her stuff was lifted from her. Â  Of course other residents noticed this activity. Â Word of this move passed beyond my building. Â They commented on a single truck load of flattened boxes. Â I heard the truck staff were pawing through other truck loads, pulling things out for themselves. Â I am glad I didnâ€™t see that. Â Some residents were checking with others - how many trucks did you see? I wanted to shut down that talk. Â But I kept my mouth shut. Â I have to live here for probably another 10-15 years. Â A neutral stance is better.But I did ponder my own future. Â My over riding goal when cleaning out and downsizing - is that I take care of shedding my belongings myself and not become burden to my children (and after this experience avoid being the topic of idle discussion by the neighbors.) Â You can be very sure, this episode planted thoughts in my mind that will not easily fade. Â I guess, ... as I type this story for you, I realize this concern for a near stranger isnâ€™t stupidity, but just common, run-of-the-mill, compassion for another human being. Â It is compassion for an aging woman undergoing a big change imposed on her for her own good - but beyond her ability to contribute or control. Â It is advancing age robbing a person of their independence. This is an emotion am very familiar with as I lived with this thought every day when caring for my own aging mother. Â And it is a reminder to me that I still have control - for now. Â Hereâ€™s hoping Jane is in a better place in Florida - with a fresh start at life and new neighbors who donâ€™t know all her secrets and a daughter nearby for support.And as for myself, I wonâ€™t raise any â€˜red flagsâ€™ for my family to worry about - like putting name tags on my geraniums. Â We will just keep that little secret between you and I. ğŸ˜‚

title: My Left Thumb and Aja
text: Here is a bit more of what has filled my time since JulyÂ from the perspective of my Left Thumb.(Yes, my left thumb!)My left thumb has registered a significant objection recently. Â Who knew that it had opinions!?! Â That is an unfortunate evolution because I am in the thick of crocheting 2 sizable projects which I have every intention of finishing and I suspect my new craze - crocheting - is the cause of this thumb revolt. All my other fingers are agreeable to my creative needs. Â Since my thumb seems to be full of opinions lately, I thought I would give it an opportunity to express some of them now.So here we go!Annie Crochet Striped Afghan Club in Plumberry - almost done. Â (Vote from the thumb ğŸ‘)I am nearing the end of this project. I was really drawn to this club because not only did you get a the yarn and pattern instructions for 3 different stripes once a month, but you are given access to the video tutorials. Â For me the video tutorials were invaluable.Â I have learned a lot using this club, but I am still not comfortable with the written instructions or the crochet charts with all the odd ball graphic designs the look like Chinese picture writing to me. Â Regardless, I love working on this blanket and would consider another Annieâ€™s Club - maybe a knitting club. (from the thumb ğŸ‘)One last pleasant discovery. Â The acrylic yarn used is Premier Anti Pilling Everyday Worsted. Â I had never heard of it before, but the colors are pure, the feel is very natural, there is no splitting and the stitches are sharp in definition. Â My favorite acrylic now. Â And it can be found at various yarn websites.Queen Blanket (vote from myÂ thumb ğŸ‘)Â This blanket made with mosaic crochet looks intricate but really it is so simple. The technique of mosaic crochet is a bit time consuming and the size makes this a long term project. Â Still, the result is eye catching and very enjoyable to work on. The will be a very big project and will take more than a year so more crocheting is in my future (from the thumb ğŸ‘!!!)Shelley Scarf/Wrap (vote from the thumb ğŸ‘)My left thumb loves this project so Iâ€™ve made a lot of progress on this knitted project.Â This project has a simple 2 row repeat and one row is a purl row. Â How simple can it get! Â Apparently, for me, the simpler the pattern, the more likely mistakes occur. Â Luckily, it is fairly forgiving pattern as it is pretty easy to correct a mistake in the previous row from the purl row. Â In fact, if you use the right yarn - mistakes can be corrected anywhere in the pattern. Â I had to make 2 corrections by actually sewing up errors Â (almost like darning) with a separate piece of yarn and weaving in those ends. Â Once done, it is pretty invisible. Â In a solid color, that might not work, but my yarn has variations of shades.And now on to my little Princess ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘:AJAAja is so much fun.  Little habits that she repeats and trusted moments that she dispenses (when the time is right for her, of course) are lovely to see.  Her latest game is playing catch with our feet as we walk..  Claws are in - and she does a tap tap on our ankles.  If you turn, she stops, looks, then runs away. Sort of a version of the game of Tag. At first we didnâ€™t know what she was doing.  But she does it frequently with both of us. Â She also is fond of jumping onto my lap in the evenings. Â It is pretty much the only pictures I get. Â And she doesnâ€™t really care if you have knitting or a computer on your lap. Â When she is coming up - she is coming!When Aja was new to us she was a little 'black box' that was filled with mystery. Â When you get a kitten, their black box is totally empty (sort of like their kitten brain - totally empty.) ğŸ˜ Â Adult cats have stuff hidden in their black box. Â  In her early days with us I made contact with her previous owner through Facebook. Â We had a few lovely messages back and forth, and I learned a lot about Aja that she was keeping hidden. Â From those Facebook chats there is a phrase that is stuck in my head. Â But her previous owner said, â€œThank you for giving her a chance.â€ Â Awww ...Â "Giving her a chance...â€ Â I guess that is what it looked like we were doing. Â But what Aja and her previous â€œmamaâ€ could not know was - this wasnâ€™t a â€œchance.â€ Â There was no chance that it might not work out. Â There was no â€œchanceâ€ that we would return her to the shelter (which I am quite sure does happen.) Â Even if we would only have a marginal distant relationship with her, she was staying. Â Aja landed in a home that didnâ€™t rely on chances. Â She was ours - for better or worse! Â That is how we roll.Thatâ€™s all folks!! Â When she is done, she is done. Â I get tapped with her tail a few time in departing and then she is off to other things.I am a persistent person - if it takes a year - if it takes 10 years, if I want to do something, I am going to do it. Â And I wanted to conquer this little catâ€™s fear and distrust. And I think I have. Â But that one comment has stuck with me anyway. Â "Thank you for giving her a chance.â€ Â Aja has proved she is worth many, many, chances. Â As many chances as it takes - and almost all pets deserve that - unlimited chances because the circumstances of their past lives are really not of their making. She was lucky on several counts. Â She had a good life before us and she has a good life now. Â We love our little Aja, and I think she finally loves us.I checked on Facebook and her former mama has removed her Facebook page content. Â Only her name is there. Â I left a message for her hoping she gets it. Â I got the sense she really loved this little cat and was upset that Aja was in the shelter 2 weeks before someone took her. Â I canâ€™t imagine how hard it was to know her little Aja couldnâ€™t make the move to another state with her. Â I am hoping she remembers to check in on this blog to see how Aja is doing. Â She is doing just great. (from the thumbÂ ğŸ‘).ğŸ‘Â Now that I have given the stage (so to speak) to my left thumb, I am hoping that it will start to settle down. Â A compression glove, cold packs, no crocheting for 3 weeks and regular applications of Penetrex (an inflammation cream) have had limited success. Â Maybe giving it the opportunity to get a few things off its chest (do thumbs have chests?) will do the trick!So what have I learned today. Â Thumbs have opinions, perspectives and chests. Thumbs hate crocheting, but thumbs canâ€™t speak so they are limited to emojis. Â I have also learned to be grateful that this little 2-3 inch portion of my body is the only part putting up a fuss. Â At my age, that is a fact to be celebrated.(Now hunting around to find some wood to knock on!!!)

title: Maybe a New Title
text: I am thinking of changing my blog name toÂ â€œMy Next 20 Years of Living: A Year at a Time.â€ Â I am slipping into the habit of posting only a few times a year! Â I often think maybe I should just close the blog down. Â I can see how it will all play out in my mind. Â Do a graceful exit speech ... Â you know ... taking a bow, wishing everyone well, throwing kisses to the crowd (if anyone is still out there reading - ha!), heading off to new but unidentified adventures, and drawing the curtains on this blog. Â Then I remember, when I started in 2010 I thought 20 years was forever into the future. Â But from where I am standing now - my â€œnext 20 yearsâ€ from 2010 takes me out to 2030. Â Wow, that is pretty darn close. Â It isnâ€™t â€œforever.â€ Â And I will be 83 in 2030. Â  83!Â  Hard to wrap my mind around that number. Â hmmm .... isnâ€™t 83 the â€œnew 63?â€ Â haha! Nope, not even I believe that.So I talk myself out of quitting.After all I still have things going on. Â My wonderful kids are in the prime of their lives. Â Professional and personal success. Â Living comfortably, raising an amazing new generation and just generally improving the world with their presence. Â I still have a life partner of 52 years and counting. Â Turns out he needs me now more than he did when we first married. Â (Its hard to express just how important vision is until you lose it.).Â Then there is Aja, our adult 'Covid Cat adoption.' God knows she keeps us amused and engaged. Â And I still have not knitted through ALLLL my yarn stash yet (which means - if that is a goal - I will need to live to 115!) Â Topping all that off, there is this amazing grand daughter in my life who is 3. Â Now that is one little human being who is going to change the world. Â If I live to be 115 - I might just get to see it.Nope! Â Not quitting. Â So what has been happening since July.First off my darling, amusing and smart-as-a-whip grand daughter is a regular part of my life. Â Here she is carrying her Minnie Mouse leather purse her father (my talented son) made for her. Â She thinks her dad can do anything (and I am hard pressed to disagree with her. ğŸ˜)Here she is getting ready to go out on a boat with her dad.Â Her honorary uncle owns the boat is putting her life vest on.Â (That face says: Yah! I am cool.)And here is a special cookie her grand mother (me)Â got for her loaded with icing. Â Yummy - so she says.A sugar high (and low) in the making!And here is her first day of preschool picture - the first of many!What to say about this little person! Â She is not only smart and can talk circles around you, she is a competitive 3 year old. Â In August she went to the beach with family and extended family for the first time. Â In that group was Will, her cousin, who is 4 years old. Â The age difference of 6 months was nothing in their relationship. Â Some conversations that were overheard were:Will: Â I am 4 years old.Esk: Â  Well, I am 5! Â (Poor Will lost that one - even though it was based on an exaggeration of theÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â truth. Ok, a lie. But still ... )Will: Â My dad can jump on one leg.Esk: Â  Well, my dad has 2 legs!!! Â (Sorry Will. Â Looks like you lost that one, too. Â But the dads hadÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â fun with it. Â My son reminded Willâ€™s dad ALL week, that HE had 2 legs. Â And Willâ€™s dad has 2Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â legs as well, but letâ€™s not let a little bit of logic get in the way of winning one! Â Right, Esk!)I wish I could have been there. Â Watching and listening to the 2 of them together would have been truly priceless. Â My first video upload is below and I sure hope it works for you. Â This is a movie of Esk and Will dancing together by the pool. Â When I am feeling low, I watch this 1 minute and 20 second video and I feel myself smiling and laughing. Â Hope you feel that way too.So I guess the question is why wasnâ€™t I there? Â Well the Outer Banks is 5-6 hours away from home and I feel uncomfortable being so far away leaving my husband with no back up (both my kids were on this trip.). So I made myself useful and stayed with my son and daughter-in-laws two dogs. Â A dog week for me - I used to do that kind of house and dog sitting all the time before the pandemic - but the pandemic changed all that. Â So here are my pictures from that same week.They like to stay close. Â Very close. Â Sometimes it is a little claustrophobic, but they need more attention when â€œtheir peoplesâ€™ are gone.They have a beautiful side porch that the dogs and I completely enjoyed sitting on.This bulldog is Ragnar - Rags for short. Â Getting a front picture of him is hard when he was determinedÂ to put his butt on my lap keeping me close.This is Olivia - Livvy or Beansie for short. Â She isnâ€™t quite so clingy but loves attention just as much.Yes, that is 60+ pound Rags running full out down the hill in their fenced in yard - directly at me. Â I have learned never to move when he does that. Â He darts to the side at the last minute and invariably he darts in the direction I have chosen to move - taking me out! Â He hasnâ€™t master stopping all that well! He is such a character.Â The location of their house is wonderful - acres between houses, lots of green and trees, neighbors are far enough away that there is tons of privacy and lovely silence.I did lots of reading and knitting and crocheting and TV Netflix watching - and mid-day visited my husband till after dinner. Â Sort of a mini-vacation for me as well.This was a long post and Iâ€™ll close it for now. Â Iâ€™ll be back because I have pictures of my projects to share and Aja pictures to include. Â And who knows, maybe some other stuff as well.Nope - not quitting yet. Â Who would I bore with my pictures if not you wonderful people!Till next time ...

title: Still Here
text: I am still here ... just not very productive in the blog world. Â But life has marched on regardless ... and here is a summary of me running to catching up to it.Â MiloA sad event. Â Although I donâ€™t own a dog, I have been an active participant and â€œgrandma" to my childrenâ€™s dogs. Â The 3 dogs shown in this picture grabbed my heart for the whole of their lives just as securely as if they lived with me full time. Â From left to right: Meathead, Milo, and Grimace in much younger days.Meathead and Grimace passed away many years ago taking pieces of my heart with them. Â Milo died last weekend at the age of 11 after a long struggle with pneumonia. Â He was the last of this trio to leave us and my heart aches for him so much. Â I hate that he is gone. Â As searingly painful it is to let them go ... and to stand with them as their heart stops and they take their last breath ... it is a final loving gift of comfort for them surrounded by "their peopleâ€ in those last moments. Â This was my daughterâ€™s first experience with euthanasia. Â So the pain was particularly intense for me watching her part from her most beloved best friend, Milo.Â You lived a long life fully devoted to my daughter who is now missing you terribly.Â Your grandma is missing another part of her heart.Rest In Peace my sweet boy.Â AjaAja continues to surprise us. Â This past May she passed her one year anniversary with us. Â Just when I think she has reached her full level of comfort with us, she moves forward another step. Â I donâ€™t think people realize (or in some cases accept) the amount of time that is needed for an adult pet adoption.Â If she is looking a little chubby in that picture - it is because she has gained some weight. Â When she came she was a gaunt 7.8 pounds. Â I suspect she didnâ€™t eat much during those 2 weeks at the shelter. Â At her last check up she was over 10 pounds. Â She loves her meal times. Â And we carefully cater to her likes and dislikes.Here are her â€˜achievements' since I last wrote (No photographic proof, of course. Â She avoids any documentation that she is evolving. Â She would loose her â€œcat credentialsâ€ if she allowed pictures of her exploits.ğŸ¤£)Jumps on the bathroom counter top. Seriously, I didnâ€™t think she could jump at all - she did it so seldom. Now she leaps up like it is no big deal! Â How she disguises her abilities!!Â Jumps up on the bed when my husband and I are both on it - big WOW!Lays beside my husband when he is lying on the bed - not for a long time and not all that frequently - but Aja is all about baby steps. Â My husband was so stunned when she did this the first time, he didnâ€™t want to move - or even breathe, fearing he would scare her off. Â She was definitely â€œtestingâ€ the waters. Â Always testing!Roams the condo many times a day. Â A bit skittish when she does it, but is learning to be daring!Has picked a living room window to watch the world from that is not in the bedroom. That would be her â€œchubbyâ€ picture above.We are really happy she is our â€œspecial girl."EskarinaWe have finally reached the point of normalcy in grand daughter visitation. Â  Â What an amazing little person she is becoming. Â Although she is not vaccinated yet, being only 3 years old, everyone around her is vaccinated so the circle of protection is safe for all.Her use of language continues to astound me. Â Such sentence structure and complexity of thought coming from that little mind! Â Of course, now that she can parrot back everything she hears, adult speech has to be carefully monitored. Â No â€œfâ€ bombs - as my son recently discovered! Â ğŸ˜‚ All words are fair game in the mind of a 3 year old. Â Knitting /CrochetFor me, this is the Year of the Blanket apparently! Â No pictures yet but soon. I am working on two afghans now, and one or two more are waiting in the wings to be started. Â And ironically they are ALL crochet!! Â I also want to knit a sweater for my grand daughter. Â She has finally reached the age where she wonâ€™t outgrow a handmade item in 3 months.In other areas ...As I grieve the passing of Milo, my normal reaction is to clean, declutter, re-organize. Basically just keep moving. Â Action and distraction lifts me out of obsessing out of my sadness for a time. Â Sitting still and thinking about the loss makes the whole grieving process so intense. Â Walking would do the same thing, but the heat outside right now would sap my strength, so staying busy inside air conditioning is the next best thing.Yesterday I vacuumed and steamed cleaned the carpets. Â It is a job that takes hours because I also try to move things to reach areas that normally donâ€™t get cleaned. Â As much as I would like to replace this 18+ year old wall-to-wall carpeting, it cleans up beautifully when it has been steamed cleaned. It is just a lot of work to do it. Â Next up - the pantry and the fridge. Â Both need attention. Â And in my walking around I routinely simplify the spaces and surfaces in my condo. Â After years of having tons of bricka-a-bracka all over every surface, I now find peace in cleared spaces. Â As it turns out, it also helps my blind husband who would find maneuvering around â€œstuffâ€ very difficult.We also did a few big things this year. Â This winter we replaced all the windows. Â Part of that process was stripping them of the double hung drapes the previous owner had installed. Â I am not fond of curtains or drapes but I kept them for 4+ years while doing other big improvements. Â I am very pleased with the blinds we installed this spring. Â They are the traditional size - not mini - and they are white with gray highlights similar to the markings of wood. Â My carpet is gray so it works well. Â They have a nice header and are complete as they are without the trappings of additional drapery. Â Simple clean lines.This coming August we will be in this condo for 5 years. Â The list of condo improvements seems enormous when looking back. Â New windows and window treatments throughout, new kitchen appliances, a new bathroom toilet in the guest bath, a new garbage disposal, 3 new lights/ceiling fan combinations, a new screen door for the deck, a new deck light, 3 new10-year smoke alarms, and a new air conditioner. Â With each change this condo feels more like my space and less like someone elseâ€™s space I am visiting - a feeling that still haunts me at times. Â Next year we will probably tackle the flooring. Â And there are other items that need a more current update. But I may change my mind on all these future changes. Â They will be expensive and very disruptive. Â When I was 30 or 40, or even 50, I could anticipate staying put in a home and enjoying the improvements for another 20 years or so. Â Now, at 74, our future is harder to predict. We may have reached the point that condo improvements would not be a good use of money or time. Time marches on.If I could just slow down that marching of time ... or even just roll it back a bit so I could give that dear dear grand dog Milo - one more hug.Thatâ€™s all for now. Â Hope it isnâ€™t months before I write again. Thanks for stopping by.

title: Commenting on the Comments
text: I rarely respond to comments and questions on my blog now that I use the Pop Up commenting. Â I canâ€™t reply in real time on the same post unless I choose to add a separate comment of my own to my post. Â I am not sure if that method of reply would be seen since most people never look backwards on the blogs they follow. Â Then I got to thinking ... why not have a â€œReply Postâ€ that follows the main post a few days later. Â So here is my Reply Post. Â We will see how this goes.â€Have you made a date [to see Esk] with dear Eskarina and her parents?â€ Â YES!! Â I should have mentioned that in my previous post. Â In fact, the date was scheduled on my calendar the very first moment I snagged the first shot date!!Â  I went right to my calendar and counted out the days and marked my â€œLiberation Dayâ€ in bold red print. And there will be a blog post, Michelle, when it happens. â€œLiberation Dayâ€ is April 20 around 12:30 pm (yes I know the time as well) - Â not that I am counting the minutes or anything. Â  However, she goes to day care during the workweek so we are holding off our reunion until the weekend when we have a â€œSleep over at Grandmaâ€™s" condo all planned on April 23. Â It will be joyous in the extreme. Â I hope I can get through the first hour of the visit without crying. Â Even in the Google Video calls with her - which do happen frequently - I can see that she has grown and matured. Â During one of those video calls Esk asked me if I could show her the toys and her bed at my house through the phone ğŸ˜¢. Â As I "walked herâ€ on the phone into the guest room, I was fighting tears. While it is lovely she remembered these things and wanted to see them again, Â it made me so sad that the only way we could do that was through a cell phone. Â  And although I am looking forward to seeing her parents as well, I know they are just as eager to have some time to themselves - even if it is just to get some sleep. Â ğŸ˜„And as for Aja! Â She is definitely a female, Cynthia. Â And I can assure you that the difference between female and male cats is like different solar systems. Â The males (we have had 9 of those) are the party, party, party animals. Â Pretty much happy-go-lucky! Â More dog-like than cat-like. Â The females (we have had 2 counting Aja) are the business end of the species. Â It is natureâ€™s way of assuring that kittens will survive. Â Even in the wild, the female lions are the hunters and the male lions are the â€œfigure headsâ€ who wait for the meal to be brought down by their female mates. The true power is in the female. Â It is probably true of most mammals. Â It is just more evident in animals like cats - who are unlikely to hide their true nature.I also learned some interesting things about orange female cats yesterday. Â Orange females are relatively rare. This info came from another female orange cat owner who asked if Ajaâ€™s personality was â€œspicy.â€ Â Why, funny you should ask. Â Yes! Â What a perfect description of her personality. Â Spicy. This informal source said spicy personalities are a common trait of orange females. Â So off I went to Google to do a little research. Â Yes, Â pretty much all sources agree - about 81% of ginger cats are male. Â Ginger females carry the orange gene on both X chromosomes. Â Both her parents had to be orange according to the sources I read. Â But the â€œspicyâ€ personality observation was not supported. Â In fact, it was suggested be Â the reverse. Â While the strongest influence on personality tends to be early socialization, males tend to be the â€œspicierâ€ of the two. Â That observation does not appear to be based on any science like the color of the fur. Â You canâ€™t help but wonder, however, ... since there is only observational evidence on personality, maybe there is something to it - just not proven. Â Everyone agrees, however, that orange cats are very friendly. Â And Aja is. Â She just doesnâ€™t always know how to contain that joyous feeling at times.Terra,Â Leigh, Marie and Lefty, thank you for your kind comments on the crochet. Â I am definitely a novice in crochet. Â The actual stitches arenâ€™t hard but knowing where to begin and end rows still is sometimes a mystery. Â Last year I started a crochet blanket and got about 5 inches done when I discovered the blanket was getting wider. Â Obviously I had been unintentionally increasing on the edges. Â I ripped it all out and decided crochet just wasnâ€™t for me. Â Then I discovered the Annieâ€™s Club Kits - I liked the patterns and each kit came with video assistance. You could see quite clearly where the hook needed to go to begin or end. Â While the cost of the total Kit is pretty high for what is acrylic yarn, the assistance and knowledge building more than make up for the cost. Â And when you commented on the colors in the blanket I had to smile. I like browns and tans also, but there are no browns and tans in the blanket. Â I tried so hard to capture the colors and failed miserably. Â The colors are in the plum family with a pop of turquoise for contrast. Â Even the professional pictures that came with the directions donâ€™t show the colors correctly.Finally to my walking friend, Karen, Happy One. Â I think of you often and how lucky you are to have such a beautiful place to walk every single day (for 6 miles - yes, folks, she walks 6 miles every day - my hero!) Â While our move to this condo was perfect in many ways, walking paths or even just sidewalks are in short supply in Elkridge. Â It is not Columbia, where the developers were following the vision of James Rouse with pedestrian friendly neighborhoods. And Sandy, your idea for audio books while walking is something I used to do when I was on my own walk. Â It does pass the time. Â I am trying to get out later in the evening by myself when he has gone to bed. Â He is an early to bed (7:00 pm) but late to sleep (10:00 pm) person - listening to his audio books for a few hours before sleeping. Â With the longer days this works ok. Â I get in a short walk around my condo development. (boring, but walking). But I miss wandering around randomly and spontaneously like Happy One does.Â Not sure how this worked for you guys. Â I feel like I closed the loop on the last post with responses. Â I probably wonâ€™t be back blogging again until I see Esk - in the flesh - on the 23rd - with a box of tissues in my hand and my other arm around her slim little body. Â  Â Stay well all!

title: A "Donâ€™t Fence Me Inâ€ Update
text: The habit of writing seems to be lost on me of late! Â The thought of writing pops up at regular intervals but the action seems absent. Â Lately, if there is a structure to anything in my life - I seem to resist it! Â Regardless, I am here now, so update time.COVID-19 VACCINATION updateI am within a week of being fully vaccinated - meaning that I will soon pass the 2 week waiting period after the 2nd shot. Â I wonâ€™t be barred from seeing my family anymore (specifically my dearest grand daughter.) Â FREEDOM! Â ButÂ I have been fortunate in this pandemic. Â No illness and little to no reaction to either shot. Â  But I will continue mask wearing and social distancing until we are closer to herd immunity ... because that is the sensible, logical and the â€œadultâ€ thing to do - until we ALL can be free!!DIET updateÂ I spent time thinking about my diet - not for weight loss but mostly for health. Â I finally settled on a mostly Mediterranean diet. Â  But it isnâ€™t really â€˜mediterranean' if you arenâ€™t being semi compliant! Â In the end I settled on listening to my bodyâ€™s needs! And what is needs are smaller meals, more veggies, less meat, lower carbs and no 'no-nos!â€™ That is as much limitation as I am willing to do.EXERCISE updateI miss walking. Â  Walking "my way." Â And during this pandemic, Â any kind of walking has been scarce. Â I refuse to blame the pandemic. Nothing has kept me from going outside and walking during these months. Â Nothing but myself and one small deterrent.What is most satisfying about walking is the solitary time, walking by myself. Â Setting my own pace, viewing the scenery, thinking about things - mind drifting, no socialization or expectations. Â But my husband also needs to walk and due to is disabiity, he cannot walk alone. Â Oh I know there are blind folks who can do absolutely everything independently, but those kind of people are very rare when you lose vision as a senior. Â That means when I walk (with him) I am "on duty." Â I have to be on alert the whole time to make sure the obsticals are announced or avoided, always checking our pace since he has exactly one speed - fast - but he doesnâ€™t have the heart and lung capacity for that speed any more. Â His mind drifts, he forgets to â€œlistenâ€ to the messages his cane gives him. Â  I know it sounds (and feels) a little selfish to want to have some alone time on my walks. Â But the only fix for this is to find time for 2 walks a day. Â Working on this.CLEANING OUT updateI joined a blog event last fall called Making Space. But as I suspected, I found the discipline of blogging about it hard. Â I enjoy reading the posts of others, but I am happy to clean out on my own when the spirit moves me. Â My current decluttering has focused on exercise tapes and cook books. Â I get absolutely NO satisfaction out of exercising indoors. Â If I am forced to exercise inside, I prefer to have a list of exercises that I can do while I watch some sort of distracting TV. Â And yet I had a shelf and a half of exercise disks - each one I thought would be â€œthe oneâ€ that helped me get in shape indoors. I am down to about 5 disks. Â Big declutter there. I hardly ever crack open a cookbook. Â Same logic - I buy the book thinking this is â€œthe oneâ€ that will help me enjoy cooking. Â I will make wonderful tasty things from that book. Never! When I want a new recipe, I just hop on my computer and print something out. Â I have several loose leaf binders of recipes I have pulled from the internet that I use when menu building. Â I have donated a great number of cookbooks, and now I am in the process of cannibalizing a few - pulling out any recipes I made that were good, but never repeated because ... well ... hardly ever crack open a cookbook.Funny, I never thought I would get rid of exercise tapes and favorite cookbooks. Â And here I doing both.KNITTING AND CROCHETING updateScarf - my only knitting project right now. Finger weight yarn and it will take a long time finish because ...... I started an Annieâ€™s Club project called Plumberry Sampler Afghan in crochet. Â This is an indoor shot of the first 6 rows of this Afghan. Â The colors are hard to capture correctly.This is an outdoor shot and the colors are closer to normal. Â And even with natural light, the colors donâ€™t show as true.I am enjoying working on this - it is a great crochet learning project. Â And the yarn they use for this is wonderful stuff. Â Acrylic, but hard to tell without the label.Queen blanket, also crochet,Â is well underway. Â This is the most satisfying project I am working on at present. Â No pictures to share yet but the finished object should look something like this.My colors will be somewhat different, but you get the idea. Â It really is a fun and easy project.And then there is this little lady, Aja.Yes, that is a smug and self-satisfied face. Â Donâ€™t those eyes say it all. Â She has made large strides with my husband. Â And he has put great effort into it. Â Several times a day, he goes into the bedroom to â€œvisitâ€ Aja. Â He sits on the bed and she jumps up and rubs and rubs and rubs - and he pets - and usually it ends peacefully. Â She gets herself over stimulated ending in a hiss or a swipe, but that is more rare now. Â Oh, she does come out of the bedroom and wanders around the condo regularly, but she is most comfortable where her two beds are and food and litter - and she has safety behind the gate at the bedroom door (it has a cat door in it - and no one but her can pass through.) So she can come out any time she wants.Here she is behind my recliner. Â And if you look close, Milo is in the recliner. Â Guess she felt the coast was clear if he was asleep.Next month it will be the first anniversary of her adoption. Â She has come sooo far since that skinny frightened and distrustful cat came to live with us. Â Change is hard for her. Â Not everyone could give her the time and distance she needed to adjust. Â I kind of feel like she was just meant to be with us. Â We love her so much and she has shown in her own way that those feelings are returned.I think I hit all the topics. Â Until next time ...

title: February Wrap Up!!
text: Slipped off the blogging radar again. Â The whole month of February - just gone! Â How does that happen.Thankfully nothing negative was involved. Â Just time getting away from me. Â Lets see what I can do to catch up.I finished the knitted blanket I made for my grand daughter - it is a blanket she will use here - should we ever get back to normal times and she can visit again. Â I was glad to be done with it. Â It was huge and easy to work on in a mindless fashion, but I had other stuff I was itching to get to!Then we had a little scare with this old man â€œgrand child,â€ my daughterâ€™s dog Milo! Â He had some breathing issues and she got an initial evaluation from her vet with an X-ray ... the vet thought he had lung tumors - probable cancer - and at his age, extensive testing was just not an option. Â Quality of life care was the recommendation ... and maybe some steroids to slow down the tumor growth and make him comfortable. Â Her vet wanted him seen by a vet internist to evaluate and make suggestions since he is already on pain meds for his back issues. Â That visit provided a different opinion, thankfully and it is not cancer. Â But without expensive testing and maybe some uncomfortable treatments involving anesthesia, (also not an option), a definitive diagnosis could not be given. Â At present we are just content that it is not cancer. Making him comfortable in his very senior years is now the goal.And after the scare of maybe losing him, I found this charming picture of him when he wasnâ€™t so gray. Now his is the wall paper on my computer screen. Â My daughter isnâ€™t going to be the only one devastated by his passing. Â We just need to enjoy him now.This month my grand daughter turned 3. Â We, of course, could not be with her so her parents held a virtual Birthday Party using Zoom. Â All her family joined her on the computer and we enjoyed watching her open her presents and eat cake. Â (Have I said recently just how much I HATE this pandemic?). I think I could tolerate it better if I had full access to my family.And here I am in line (6 feet apart, of course) at CVS waiting to get my first Covid VAX shot just yesterday. Â The effort required to get that appointment was just too much. Â So many people and not enough vaccines. Â But I am grateful I managed to get onto a schedule. I have had no reaction to this first shot, but I understand that the second shot does produce some fatigue. My second shot is scheduled for the end of the month. Â Of course, now I start all over again trying to get my husband on a schedule for his shots. Â I check the schedules for 3 pharmacies, 2 max vaccine mega sites and the health department when I wake before I even have coffee and about 6 more times during the day and last thing before I go to bed at night. Â It just never ends.I have started 2 more new projects - both are crochet. Â The first picture is a sample of a technique called mosaic crochet. Â This is new to me. Â The pattern is from the Queen blanket (on Ravelry) that I plan to make very soon. Â This Queen blanket was part of a CAL last fall and it has extensive video support on YouTube. For the sample I chose 2 light colored yarns - which was stupid. Â The patterning would be so much more dramatic with more contrast. The yarn I have purchased for this pattern has plenty of contrast so it should be more fun - and the pictures will be better.The second project is from Annieâ€™s Craft Club. Â I kept getting ads for this club in my Facebook feed. Â I finally just gave up and started the club. The blanket is striped and each stripe is a different crochet stitch. Â The acrylic yarn is called Premier Anti Pilling Everyday Worsted and it is my new favorite acrylic. It doesnâ€™t split, the colors are really lovely (although my photos donâ€™t do it justice) and it is very soft. Â Feels nothing like typical crunchy acrylic. Â This project, too, has video support which I follow very carefully. Â I am mostly a knitter and I know the basic crochet stitches, but I have learned so much from watching both videos. Â Being able to â€œreadâ€ your knitting or your crochet is so important. Â I understand the structure of the knit stitch very well - and these projects with their video support are helping me understand the crochet stitch at a much better level. Â I am really enjoying both very much.Anyway, that is my February all summed up in a single post. Â Hope that all of you are doing well - and staying well. Â We are so close to the â€œfinish lineâ€ of this pandemic now that a vaccine is finally available. Â Everyone, keep wearing your masks and stay 6 feet apart ... and if you are able, please get vaccinated so we can all return to a normal life with herd immunity in place.

title: Puzzles - Winter Themes and Current Challenge
text: Seems my puzzle completions have gotten ahead of my blogging!I finished this winter puzzle called After The Snow Has Fallen by artist Joseph Holodook purchased through Bits and Pieces. The theme of snow matches what I see outside my window right now. Â SNOW! It was fun and not very hard. Â Maybe a week to complete. Â I do enjoy these simpler art pieces where the colors and the lines are pretty well delineated without out much guessing involved as to where they should go.The second puzzle I finished is another wintery scene called Home Again, artist H. Hargrove and purchased through Bits and Pieces as well. This one was little harder due to the blending of colors but even so ... not hard.Left side of the puzzle.Right side of the puzzle.This puzzle, however, had a tricky element to it. Â Pictured below on the left is a bush that appears to have need of more bush pieces to complete the image. Â There were no more bush pieces! Â I got out my magnifier to see if the pieces I put into place really look like they belonged. Â They did, line, color and shape. Â But obviously not right because I had no free bush pieces left to place. Â (Images below) Then I started mixing up the arrangement of the pieces based on shape alone ... and the picture on the right shows the finished bush. Â What I have noticed with the Bits and Pieces puzzles is that the way they cut the pieces sometimes results in incorrect placement - even if the shape and picture seem to match. Â Not sure if that is common across other puzzle brands or not, but it has soured me a bit on Bits and Pieces puzzles. Â I have a few more to complete but will be interested in seeing if this if this is true with other brands.Currently I am working on a Disney puzzle called Tangled which is the Disney version of the story of Rapunzel. Â I plan to glue the pieces together, frame and give to my grand daughter for her play room.This 500 piece puzzle is only 14â€ x 18â€ and the pieces are measurably smaller that the other 500 piece puzzles I did which ran 18â€ x 24â€. Â The pieces show small bits of blended colors and is making this much more of a challenge. Â But the picture is beautiful. Â Tangled is part of a 4 puzzle set - all 500 pieces and all 14â€ x 18â€ and all painted by Thomas Kinkade Studios. The other 3 puzzle themes are Lady and the Tramp, Mickey Mouse as the Sorcererâ€™s Apprentice from Fantasia, and Winnie the Poo. Â I suspect they all will be somewhat challenging because they are all done by the same artist in the same size pieces.

title: Aja and The New Windows
text: Time for another Aja update. Â I donâ€™t think I have ever done this with any of my previous cats ... regular updates to share adjustment progress. Â Nope! Â But all those cats came to us as kittens - moldable as clay! Â No big deal. Â Aja came fully formed with a life and experiences before us ... and as such, she has been evolving on her own schedule with every month that passes! And, of course, she had an owner who loved her before and wanted to know how she was doing! Â She is doing great!Â Â And then I threw a sledge hammer into that delicately built relationship we have worked on.Â I decided to do something very big, very messy, very noisy and somewhat cold! Â The big event that happened this month were window replacements - all 10 windows in the condo were ripped out in what appeared to be a very noisy demolition. Â See, I got this great idea in October (when the weather was moderate) that a major home improvement project during a pandemic made perfect sense. Â But what I didnâ€™t count on was a January instillation. Â All ten windows were removed at once - letting in all the wonderfully cold January air (not!). Â And, of course, there was noise!!! Lots and lots of it. Â And there were 4 strange men walking in her condo, walking in her sacred bedroom where even the dog isnâ€™t allowed. Â And they were making very big holes in her bedroom walls. Â And they were here from 8:30 am until 3:00!! Â And it was cold. Â As this was all going on, all I could think was ... we are going to lose all the â€˜brownie pointsâ€™ we had accumulated with our little Diva, and we would be starting ALL OVER AGAIN! Â Sigh!You canâ€™t see her but she is hiding behind the laundry basket.After all, we had achieved a lot ... â€œlap timeâ€ on both our laps! Â Yes, she had even taken to visiting my husband - the blind guy who stepped on her the very first night! Â Whatever was I thinking when I scheduled this back in October. Â Well ... what I was thinking was that the windows would be installed as promised in early December when it would be warmer. Â And I sincerely didnâ€™t understand that ripping out old windows was such a destructive process.Â As the work was going on, I started to worry that Aja, who was hunkered down in my husbandâ€™s closet might decide to come out and sit on the window sill - where there WASNâ€™T A WINDOW THERE ANYMORE. Â I was fixated on that thought. My God. Â She could fall. Â I tried to encourage her to come out so I could put her in our bathroom - where it was warmer, and had litter, had food and her comfy cube bed. Nope! Â She wasnâ€™t moving. Â In fact, she looked at me as if she didnâ€™t know who I was!! My husband assured me that Aja was definitely not leaving her hiding place to sit on any window sill - not with all these men and the noise! Â The condo temperature surprisingly didnâ€™t drop below 50 degrees. Â We sat around in our coats freezing but the temperature really was reasonable.New and Improved.When all was said and done ... the job was completed, the 4 men left, the heat was back on and the quiet returned ... out she came!! Like nothing had happened! Â All was right in her "Diva World!" Â Amazing. Â How she recovers from stuff is one of the measures I have used to see how she is really adjusting and how confident she is. Â How well she â€œrecoversâ€ from a trauma. Â In the first few months any interruption in the routine took a day or more before we saw her again. Â Now ... within the first hour ... she struts out like she is reclaiming her kingdom!All in all - I think she has decided this is definitely her homeand we are definitely her servants! Â And she is definitely right on both counts!!

title: The Diet Game Decision
text: After days of reading, researching and experimenting a bitÂ ... I have come to a sort of decision.At my age and with my long experience with eating - (ha!) - I know that my ability to adhere to a strict eating regimen will fail eventually even if I am successful for months and months. Â It comes down to a simple fact. Â I need listen to my body better to feel better - and a structured regimen change with lots of rules and no-nos just never works for long. Â Thankfully the current messages coming from my body fall in line most closely with the Mediterranean diet way of eating, but with a few modifications that I know are realistic for me. Â So, let the transition begin.What does transition look like for me:There will be no "kitchen purging" - an activity I typically did in the past when I attempted to eat differently. Â Items we would normally eat will stay and get used up. But the â€™seedâ€™ change will happen in the grocery store - by purchasing the right options recommended. Â That means simply, that I will be weaning myself off what I do now.Finding new recipes to make that are appealing yet simple are a serious transition goal right now - a cook I am not! Â For example: Â Crushed avocado mixed and chopped hard boiled egg with lemon juice, a little hot sauce, and salt and pepper on whole wheat toast filled the bill perfectly for the traditional egg salad (with mayo) I was craving this morning. Â Tasty, simple and somewhat nutritionally improved!Â I love vegetables and can make of meal out them with no effort. Â This is the biggest plus of moving in this direction. Â I even discovered a website (thank you, Michelle, of Boulderneigh Blog) called A to Z Alphabet of Vegetables - A Veggie Adventure at aveggieventure.com. Â It is a grand site for vegetable identification and ideas for cooking them (like 1300+ ideas!). I was stunned that there were soooooo many vegetables. Next summer visiting farm stands will be more exciting.Backing away from most animal proteins will be easy for me. Â  Iâ€™ll experiment with plant based proteins. Fish and chicken will be my occasional options. Â I still will have a tablespoon of evaporated milk in my coffee in the morning. Â But my body wonâ€™t miss beef or pork at all. (Although full fat bacon will beckon me I am sure Â ğŸ˜€)Â My favorite bread is Sour Dough - and that showed up on Mediterranean diet lists as a good choice along with high fiber choices in moderation. Healthy breads are ok for me, but Â making bread the â€œdevil" will never fly for me. Â I already use Olive Oil - with almost everything. Â I love it especially with bread! Â Yum.I can move away from my high sugar desserts if I substitute another sweet item when my tongue says â€œDonâ€™t you want to top off that meal with a sweet thing?â€ - which happens all the time! Â I just discovered dried figs as a substitution - knocks out that â€œgimmy a sweetâ€ reaction. Â Fruit sometimes does the trick but not always. Â Sometimes a teaspoon of honey tricks my mouth and brain. Â I need to retrain this auto reaction to top off meals with a sweet (even breakfast, haha.)I love red wine and red wine is on "the ok listâ€ in moderation, but most wines upset my GI system. Â Vodka with diet tonic (quinine) and diet coconut water (potassium) is my cocktail of choice (in moderation as well - being the daughter of an alcoholic who is extremely careful to avoid that illness,) but vodka is not on â€œthe ok list.â€ Â I did find one wine that was GI acceptable from Black Box called Red Blend - yes, a box wine! Â Significant changes in this area probably will not happen.Â And, finally, there will be no calorie or carb or fat or points counting at all. Â For some reason, that counting and tracking triggers the strong desire in me to eat up to and sometimes just over my permitted levels regardless if I am hungry or not. Â It focuses me too much on food, and not enough on eating just enough to avoid hunger.I really want to â€œeat to liveâ€ rather than â€œlive to eat.â€ Â In fact in my researching I found a book called Eat to Live by Joel Fuhrman, MD. Â Reading about things I want to do is always inspires me to stay focused. Â I havenâ€™t begun to read this book, but one statement in the 2011 summary of the book on Amazon really rang true for me. Â It referred to a new added chapter in the updated printing:Â It explains how and why eating the wrong foods causes toxic hunger and the desire to over consume calories; whereas a diet of high micronutrient quality causes true hunger which decreases the sensations leading to food cravings and overeating behaviors.Toxic hunger!! Â Now doesnâ€™t that paint a descriptive picture. Â I know that sugar causes a toxic hunger in me. Â After the blood sugar â€˜high' is over, the blood sugar â€˜low' takes over ... and I am at the refrigerator once again looking for a snack. Â Carb rich foods do the same thing. Â Once I have read this book I will update it here on the blog.Anyway, I think I have a plan that just might be sustainable.Â Â And that is the real crux of the issue, isnâ€™t it.

title: The Diet Game
text: After months of self isolation (and no real end in sight), no access to my senior gym and no logic to my food intake - I am feeling pretty sluggish! Â My go-to methods to combat that feeling are not cutting it now. Â I am a big fan of Weight Watchers as a healthy and successful method for losing weight BUT I am not a big fan of the tracking you needed to do for the long term. Â I am not a fan of the low fat diets, low carb diets, low calorie diets or the restrictive â€œbuy your food from usâ€ diets either. They all require some form of tracking and tracking is what I canâ€™t do for the rest of my life.Then, on the TV last night there was a story about the best and healthiest diets from U.S. News World Report ... you know, one of the many topics typically covered in January. Â They mentioned the top 3 diets for health and weight loss.#1 Mediterranean Diet#2 DASH#3 Weight WatchersI did a little research on the internet ... and depending on the site, #2 and #3 could be exchanged for the Flexitarian Diet. Â BUT, the Mediterranean diet is always part of the top 3 on all the sites I visit.Feeling like I need to take some action to combat this sluggish feeling, I am going to give the Mediterranean diet an official â€œtry" while I am stuck at home with time on my hands. Â I have often said I could be a vegetarian if I was feeding only myself. Â And the Mediterranean diet is heavy on fruits and vegetables, and low on red meats, sugar and saturated fat. Â Since I am still feeding one other person - who is a meat and potato man - it will mean more food prep for me (who hates cooking, ha!) Â But it seems that my body chemistry is changing anyway, and I frequently crave a lettuce salad and chicken or salmon over eating a burger or a steak. Â I often prepare two different meals now because I donâ€™t feel like eating what he is eating. Â The other biggie in my mind ... besides the lack of tracking is ... Â because this is an eating pattern - not a structured diet - youâ€™re on your own to figure out how many calories you should eat to lose or maintain your weight, what youâ€™ll do to stay active and how youâ€™ll shape your Mediterranean menus. Â Good.I really need to do more reading on how to stock my kitchen and what to make. Â Anyone else on a Mediterranean-style diet and have feedback about it? Â Any resources you know of to round out my knowledge of this subject? Â As luck would have it I have Americaâ€™s Test Kitchen, The Complete Mediterranean Cookbook already. Â Iâ€™ve been attracted to this eating plan before apparently - must have bought the book! Â Ha!

title: A Sad Day We Will Get Passed!
text: Dear Blog Friends,I know that all of you share my shock at the events of this day at the Capital of the United States. Â I was watching the senate proceedings on TV when I saw the live events unfold on TV before my amazed eyes. Â The Trump demonstrators pushed passed the Capital guards, breaking windows, entering the Capital. Â It was unbelievable to behold. Â I kept hearing someone saying â€œoh no, oh no, oh noâ€ not realizing it was my voice I was hearing ... until my blind husband who could not see the TV - said â€œtell me, tell me, ...what!â€ Â And I had to tell him the terrible truth that my eyes were seeing.This evening I am hearing the reactions from our elected representatives and other countries - â€œan attack on Democracy,â€ â€œpraying for the country,â€ â€œan insurrection,â€ â€œPresident Trump holds responsibility for this event.â€ Â And of course, there was a death. Â Reactions of disbelief.Later pictures arising on the news from within the Capital ... of the demonstrators in the senate and house chambers, in the offices, pawing through papers, posing with feet propped on desks, offices vandalized, guns raised, Trump flags waving ... So many disturbing images. Â These images will be hard to forget! Â Â To those outside the US - the unrest at present is only at the Capital. Â Videos might lead one to think this violence was more wide spread. Â  It was only at the Capital, but this was a strike at the heart of our country. Â A desecration. Â A kind of terrorist attack. Abhorrent because it was orchestrated over the last 4 years by a sitting President through his words and attitudes. Â A final crescendo to overturn the will of the people. Â Historic. The worst possible type of historic event. Â After the rioters where cleared from the Capital, the Senate and House returned to complete their work - the confirmation of the vote count for the next President of the United States.Â Remember - what doesnâ€™t kill us makes us stronger. Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  I believe we will be stronger as a result of this event.The voice of the people has not been overturned!Â The man who was chosen by the people ... Â Joseph Bidden ... will be our President!And prayers ... yes ... we could certainly use them.

title: Another Puzzle - Early Stages
text: Felt a little lost not having a puzzle in the works this morning.Â So I started another one. Â The next puzzle up is a little more seasonal! Â This one is called - After The Snow Has Fallen from Bits and Pieces (link), artist Joseph Holodook. Â It looks like fun.Â Â This puzzle is only 500 pieces - like the first one I did - which was also from Bits and Pieces. Â The initial dump of pieces is like looking at a pile of building blocks for me. Â The first thing I noticed was the size of the pieces are larger! Â My first impression after a month of smaller pieces is - this is a puzzle for kids! Â Ha! (the box says 14+ years of age.)The photo above shows 6 pieces from two puzzles to the demonstrate the difference.Â Â The Macabre Mansion puzzle are the brown smaller pieces. Â The 6 blue pieces above are from the snow scene.Â Â Big difference. Â The snow scene has a far less detailed picture as well. Â Guessing this 500 piece puzzle will be easier.First step - sorting the pieces is done. Â Next step is constructing the edge pieces. Â One of my regular visitors and readers, Michelle of Boulderneigh Blog (link), suggested trading puzzles with others who enjoy this pastime. Â That idea has a lot merit - especially if you are not a â€œrepeaterâ€ like me - someone who doesnâ€™t typically get enjoyment out of doing the same puzzle again at some point. If there is any interest is something like that let me know. Â It would be fun to organize a group interested in Â sharing puzzles. Â It would involved sending puzzles to others ... so trips to the post office, but a nice idea to work out.In my shopping around on the net, I found most puzzles fall into the $10 to $25 dollar range in cost. Â A reasonable expense for a monthâ€™s worth of enjoyment. Â The Macabre Mansion puzzle was expensive as puzzles go - about $35 to $40. Â I enjoyed doing the Mansion puzzle - even though it was pretty hard and it took about a month to do, but I donâ€™t think I would do it again. Â I purchased the Mansion puzzle off the artist's website (HollyCarden.com). Â Probably more expensive because of that and I might try to avoid stuff over $25 since it seems I will be doing more of this until we are virus free. Â  I hear that Costco sells jigsaw puzzles which might also be a good source to find puzzles at a discount. Â And Amazon as many options. Â And there are thrift stores an dollar stores and even some box stores like Walmart and Target that are options - if it is ever safe again to visit those places. Â Oh well, I have about 8 puzzles in my collection now and that should keep me going for awhile.I love having a puzzle in the works. Â In looking through various websites for puzzles I discovered that doing jigsaw puzzles right now is HUGELY POPULAR! Â Sometimes a puzzle sells out before I even discover it. Â It is just one of those things that makes passing the time at home (while socially distancing) bearable. Â I can attest to the fact that it does eat up time, does fill a â€™needâ€™ that I canâ€™t find the right word for, and it is relaxing (at least during times when I am not fretting that a pieces are 'certainly missing'.) Â Iâ€™ll spare you the progress stages going forward. Â It was just fun to share those observations with you.

title: Edger Alan Poe - Macabre Mansion
text: This is the second puzzle I have attempted since returning to jigsaw puzzles as a past time and this one was a doozy. Â Hard, hard, hard.Â It is called Macabre Mansion and each cut away room of the mansion represents one of the stories of Edger Alan Poe. Â He wrote pretty dark stuff and that is why the house looks haunted.Box CoverI learned pretty early on that if I wanted to feel like I was making progress on this puzzle I needed to take pictures at various stages and compare. Â It was too easy to imagine that a puzzle about dark stories might be â€œdarkâ€ itself - putting in pieces and never getting ahead. Â And sometime it felt just like that.November 29, 2020I couldnâ€™t help the feeling that I might have bit off more than I could chew with this puzzle.After all, the first puzzle was only 500 pieces and it moved along consistently. Â This puzzle I took many breaks from. Â I would get 4 or 5 puzzle pieces in and then it would just dry up. Â Nothing. Â I would take a break and come back 5 or 6 hours later - and put another 2 or 3 pieces in - and again, it would dry up.And so it went for days.December 8, 2020It was between December 8 and the 25th that I inspired myself to keep moving forward by playing a little mind game. Â With each piece that I put in I reminded myself I didnâ€™t need to sort through THAT piece again if it made it onto the puzzle board.December 25, 2020At Christmas I could really tell a difference. Â Christmas, being what it was this year (quiet with no demands) I pushed forward wanting to finished before 2021.December 30, 2020I could see progress if I looked at the board, but finding the correct pieces didnâ€™t get all that much easier. Â I decided that the pictures were small and the pieces were small and the visual clues of the surrounding pictures didnâ€™t seem to help all that much finding the missing piece.January 1, 2021Ok, so I didnâ€™t complete it by the end of 2020! Â But it is complete.I canâ€™t tell you how many times I decided that a piece was missing. Â That I looked through all the remaining pieces and could not find the one I was looking for. Â I would have bet moneypieces were missing. Â Nothing was missing. Â Glad I didnâ€™t express that thought out loud.In the last week of completion I found myself running my hands over the finished areasenjoying the feeling of being so close to done.A few close ups to show the complexity of the images. Â DONE!!It stayed like that overnight and I enjoyed looking at it again over coffee this morning.Now it is broken apart and into its box. Â I did hold out the edge pieces and put them in a separate baggie just in case I repeat this puzzle again.It is hard to know if I will repeat making any of the puzzles I have. Â I donâ€™t re-read books, or duplicated knitted items. Â I am not much of a repeater. Â But you never know.

title: Making Space #3
text: I am joining Beckie atÂ http://www.Fieldlilies.blogspot.com)Â on an informal challenge calledÂ Making Space.Â My ability to stick to any kind of schedule is near impossible so I have decide to forgo the idea of a regular schedule. Â Don't know if it is stubbornness on my part or just a growing lack of discipline, but there you have it! Â Despite few regular posts in Making Space, I am still working towards decluttering. Â I just haven't shared my progress. Â Of course, part of this event is blog sharing - so here goes.A picture, 2 cook books, a cat and dog hair shaver, a set of 9 miniature metal vehicles, a canvas bag, a candle, a plastic Chinese carry out container (heading for the trash like it should have months ago).A free standing floor fan by Casablanca that is beautiful but doesn't work any more and the cost to fix it was ridiculous ... and most importantly it was a very heavy fan and hard to lift ... so it is history. Â Â And a whistling tea kettle that has never whistled! Â Not from day one! Â And 4 days ago, I tried to use it for a cup of hot tea and promptly forgot it! Â By the time I returned to the kitchen the water was all gone. Â There was no damage to the stove or the kettle, but as a future safety measure this tea kettle had to go. Â I love the look of it on my stove, but forgetting things seems to be a risk at 73 that I need to compensate for. Â So I purchased a replacement.My new tea kettle!Whistles like a dream. Â It took a bit of effort to find this replacement - the one I ordered from Amazon came broken. Â I wasn't willing to try for a second delivery with the Christmas delivery rush now upon us and delays rampant. Â So I went into a brick and mortar store to buy one - got in and out fast! Â  The choices were surprisingly slim. Â Black was not my first choice, but it looks fine with my black appliances - and it whistles!! Â  Fire hazards I don't need. Â  Now I won't burn down my condo - or other condos - at least not with a tea kettle!That makes 18 items this time around that have gone on to 'other lives' with someone else (or were laid to rest in the trash), and with this post a grand total of 39 in 3 posts. Â Funny little mind game in the challenge: Â Knowing the grand total of items decluttered since I started this challenge has resulted in an unanticipated positive realization. Â Although I am not moving car-loads of items out the door almost everyday like I did in my major downsizing effort to move to this condo, the grand total reminds me each time of the full scope of items that no longer are in my way - items I no longer have to live around! Â A good feeling each time that number grows.

title: The Look of a Pandemic Christmas
text: We are all facing some version of a Pandemic Christmas! Â I thought I would share how mine looks this year.As many of you know Christmas traditionally has been a hard time for me. Â Some big and sad events have negatively colored my of enjoyment of Christmas. Â Those sad memories center around losing my dad decades ago 3 days before Christmas and my mom in 2014 ... 3 days after Christmas. Â And then there were the Christmases that my mom could not make it to our home - which had been her home for 5 years - forced by the circumstances of dementia - to stay in Assisted Living and finally in a nursing home during this festive time. Â And let's not forget the military service families - my son spent time in the military and missed several Christmases with us. Â That 'joy vs sadness scale' I struggle with every year always seems to tilt toward sadness. Â While there are those who can set those memories aside - like putting them into a box and sticking them in a closet, I cannot. It is part of my life experience. Â Yeah ... the holiday is short on cheer for me. Â Most years I would have just skipped the season if I could. Â But family traditions pulled me forward even when I didn't want to go.This year, however, was going to be special. Â My grand daughter is 2 3/4 years old Â (3 in February) and is now learning about Christmas in a way that will set the stage for many happy years to come! Â She wrote her first letter (with her mom's help) to Santa and she decorated her own felt tree with felt ornaments. Â Her letter was totally charming - asking for "a toy" for her and some treats for her dogs. Â I knew that the joy of experiencing this Christmas would add some pluses in the joy side of the scale putting some balance back into this holiday for me.Except - now we have this pandemicÂ I won't be seeing my son, daughter-in-law or grand daughter this year. Â I kind of expected that might be the case - with the virus surging. Â So I prepared myself emotionally for that possibility. Â  Ok, Â I told myself. I can do this Pandemic Christmas. Â Â I shopped on line for Christmas - no different from other years, so the Pandemic didn't change anything for me in that regard. Â Ok, I told myself - no big change here. Â I usually have stockings filled with incidentals but not this year. Â I shopped for those in person at a brick and mortar store ... but not this year, no stores, unless it is the grocery store. Â Ok, I can let go of that kind of fluff. Â Â No Christmas sleep over with 3 dogs and one cat squeezed into a 2 bedroom condo with 5 people. Ok. I prepared for that as well - family gatherings being discourage while we are in the peak of this pesky pandemic. Â My daughter and her dog, Milo, will be here (hopefully) and a scaled down celebration is appropriate.My Christmas decorations are not out yet - decorations that are mostly just a Christmas tree. Â We are waiting for a delivery date on our new windows and the installers need space to work. Â Having the tree up - against the living room windows where I like it - would be a problem. Â I'll give them until a few days before Christmas. Â Then - that tree is going up, and they can schedule us in January. Â Burr - I wanted to avoid January for changing out the windows. *sigh*Gifts are wrapped like normal, but without bows. Â I would have needed to go to a store for ribbon and it just wasn't a good enough reason to risk catching anything. Â Besides ... the gifts will need to be transport to another house before Christmas and they will travel best without big puffy bows. Â No biggie.I was doing very well with the needed limitations for Pandemic Christmas this year, until ...As I wrapped my grand daughter's gifts I could feel my eyes filling with tears! Â Crap!! Her first real Christmas - the one where she discovered what Santa brought, the one where she experienced the excitement and joy of Christmas morning. Â I wouldn't get to see that. I reached for tissues. Â I was caught off guard by these thoughts. Â I kept wrapping, faster now, because I needed to get past this.Of course, the discovery that I really wasn't ok with all these changes could not be ignored.As I moved on to wrapping gifts for others I got control of my emotions and scolded myself for such selfish self pity. Â There are people who are missing family members for all Christmases into the future. Â People struggling with the sadness of being separated from loved one in the hospital or nursing home ... loved ones struggling to breathe, maybe dying alone, and not even being able to be at their side to hold a hand. Â And as I thought about those things I replaced my sorrow with anger! Â Some Americans have made this pandemic more serious than it needed to be because of their self-important opinion that masks and social distancing aren't necessary. Â That no matter the number of deaths (in the US as of this writing - 300,000+ deaths), and no matter the number of pleas seen on TV and on social media from weary, overworked and emotionally exhausted doctors and hospital staff, their personal opinion and desires "trumped" every other consideration [quoted word used intentionally.]I am pretty sure the replacement of sorrow with anger is not an improvement! Â I certainly don't want to add anger to the catalogue of emotions I experience at Christmas time.And then I saw on TV the first people - healthcare folks - get the new vaccine for Covid-19! Â I felt my eyes tearing up again. Â Not in sorrow or anger, but joy!! We finally have something to be joyful about. Â A first 'punch' back by the human race to fight against a virus that had taken so much from all of us. Â My mind drifted then to all the truly unsung heroes - Â researchers - scientific heroes who are faceless and seldom heard from, but sacrificed so much for 9 months to get to this point. Â And the manufacturing entities and transportation teams that moved this virus from the laboratory to the patient with wartime speed and coordination. Â And finally to all the doctors and nurses, who worked diligently under massive stress and sometimes massive sorrow - breaking at times to step outside and cry - but always returning again and again to their jobs! Â Ok, so now I am not angry anymore. Â We all have a gift to be grateful for - every single human on this earth - and it came at the gift giving time when many of us honor the birth of Christ (Coincidental? I don't think so.) Â It didn't come with any wrapping paper or bows, but I think we all got what we needed this holiday season - hope and a one-two punch against Covid-19.Â And just for the record ... this is a "Gorilla Size" joy - Â may just have moved that lopsided 'joy vs sadness scale' in the right direction.Â I will have a husband and maybe a daughter with me this Christmas. I still have that amazing grand daughter ... Â and she is the light of my life - whether beside me or not. Â I still have all my family members even if we are not all together. Â I am blessed beyond words to live in a time when science can be heroic!

title: A Promised Land by Barack Obama
text: If you are a Trump supporter,Â out of respect to your feelings,Â you might want to take a pass on this post. Â I am a very regular reader / listener of books. Â But I rarely review them for my blog. Â I enjoy reading the reviews of books in other blogs ... it is just not my thing to do. Â Another thing I try to avoid on my blog is political lecturing. Â This post is not really a review of a book, but it will have my political views rant.
