title: Slipping
text: So much is slipping past me these days.Imagine my shock when I discovered that time had slipped so far from my last post of August 31st. Â  Â We have also slipped into Fall in my little portion of the earth. Â The colors aren't in full bloom yet, which seems odd as we are facing Halloween. Â The weather has been so odd. Â Guess Mother Nature is confused. Â But the days are getting shorter - so there is no missing what is happening. Â I like Fall, but my very favorite season is Winter. Â And I have totally slipped off my 'knitting mojo' this summer. Â I blame it on the pandemic. Â The picture above shows my garter stitch blanket I started in March 2020 done in double worsted weight acrylic. Â We finished I just couldn't keep it. Â It was too heavy, too big, and filled with too many thoughts related to being Covid 19 home bound. Â Just not happy thoughts. Â It is now on it way to a thrift shop.Â As much as I like to think this world event hasn't impacted me all that much ... it has. Â Something inside me has slipped and my focus on my usual passions like knitting has shifted to more pensive pursuits ... no deadlines to meet, no forced expectations. Â Â The picture above is a sport weight silk scarf for my daughter. Â Very soft and squishy - and almost done. Â Â It is like I have given myself permission to back away from artificial structures like a to-do list and just go with the flow of doing what seems right at the moment. Â Eventually I get around to doing things that actually needs doing (like laundry or vacuuming) - but the world doesn't end because I let something slip to several days later. Â Is it the pandemic or just my age that makes me rebel against expectations. Â Probably both. Â Taking time to just "be" has worked pretty well in noticing Aja's continued transition. Â She is spreading her 'imaginary wings' and claiming her rightful place in our home - more and more every day. Â The picture below is proof positive Aja visits the living room - looking out the living room window at the night.Â When Milo comes for a visit, she makes a point several times of day of coming out of the bedroom - sort of a 'statement' that she is the rightful owner and Milo is the guest. Â That is true, of course. Â She runs Â back to the bedroom if he starts to walk to her - but she continues to make the effort. Â Maybe someday they will be friends. Â Here she sits on my lap - brief visits but frequent. Â At some point she will relax, I am sure.She gets on my lap almost every day - sometimes twice in the period of an hour. Â She still struggles with feeling comfortable there, but just like everything else she will grow into it. Â She has found her perfect hiding place in a plush little bed I put in the bottom of my husband's closet. Â She still enjoys her sunny out-in-the-open bed by the window. Â And just this week, I found her sitting by an open window enjoying the fresh air - I think she has finally adjusted to the outside neighborhood noise. Â The biggest leap has been her adjustment to my husband. Â She will always be a "woman's" cat, but she allows him to pet her as long as he doesn't extend that petting session for too long. Â He is the 'cat feeder' and she loves her food - so as time goes on she will include him into her circle of trusted people.She is kind of camera shy so getting good pictures of her is a challenge.Â My other priority during this time of Covid has been my grand daughter. Â I see her less often now that she has returned to day-care, so when we finally get together I can readily notice how quickly she is advancing in her language skills, her imaginary play and her concept development. Â And for some darn reason she looks forward to coming to my house - 'grandma's house!' Â Last time she visited she was scheduled to come to my house for a sleepover after her nap! Â When she awoke she told her mother she would pee and have her apple juice at my house rather than doing it before she left. Â hahaha! Love that kid. Â It couldn't be that I have something new and different when she comes every time. Â Last weekend, she got to be a "princess" in this dress I bought her - complete with a crown, long gloves, necklace and wand! Â Best $25 I ever spent!! Â I love this picture of her in her princess regalia - holding an iPad! Sort of a mixture of two worlds!I keep telling her to aim for Queen - don't mess with this princess stuff. Â Be the one in charge! Â She is only 2 so we have many molding years ahead of her! Time slips pretty darn fast, however, every time I see her and discover how quickly she grows and develops. Â It is a joy to witness but also a sadness. Â I want to hold her back just a little to enjoy the beauty and wonder of every stage. Â Some day her grandma might be too old her for, not able to keep up with her, or her friends are more important that this old lady ... it is the way of things as they grow ... so these times now are precious in my heart.Everything is not "sweetness and light." Â I hate this new blogger platform. Â Why can't they just leave it alone!! But I hate the thought of starting over on another blog system more than sticking with this one. Â So I will soldier on ... complaining all the way.And then I discovered today that about 50 emails in my gmail account were incorrectly directed to Spam. Â That is where blog posts from others are directed - to my gmail account. Â I thought my blog friends were particularly quiet recently, but I didn't wonder if it was an error. Â I read many but too many to try and comment. Â Can't help wondering if my computer has a bug of some sort.Â So that is my story here on the East Coast of the USA. Â We are 2 weeks from our Presidential Election. Â The heat of that has become as hot as the sun! Â We need a change back to civility ... we need to return to Country First - not Party First! Â I think we need new leadership to make that happen. Â I am so tired of all the hate talk, the acts of violence and the insults. Â We need to be civil - and we need a leader who at least knows the definition of that word. Â I am tired of seeing out Democracy slipping away! Â Hoping for a change at the top!

title: No ... I didn't get a picture ... but I SWEAR it happened!!
text: That Aja. Â Just when I think she has stopped evolving, she surprises me.I know I have been absent from my blog for over a month. Â It has been a busy summer and there was just no time. Â But things are slowing down now and just today, a miracle happened.I mean we have seen a number of smaller miracles in her short time with us.Over all, she does a lot that tells me she is happy to be with us. Â She likes to rub against us, she enjoys a short scratch or rub around her cheeks and neck, and she joins us for short visits into the living room, kitchen or dining room. Â Home base is still our bedroom, of course. Â But she always runs out of the bedroom to welcome us when we come home. Â She is very interested in her meals, escorting us in a "short parade" from the kitchen to the cat food trays in the bedroom and enjoys looking out the bedroom windows at the birds and people. Â Small miracles all ... considering how stressed out she was when she arrived 3 months ago.But she still has her limits. Â Does she let me pick her up? Â Oh, no. Â Does she come into the living room and sleep on the furniture or visit with guests? Â Nope. Does she want to cuddle with us? Â Most definitely not! Â And just last week I attempted to place her on my lap! Â I told my husband that she probably will never be a lap cat! No matter. Â She gives what she can and we are happy to oblige her.And then today she came out into the living room - arrived at my chairÂ and jumped onto my lap! Â It wasn't entirely a relaxed action. Â She was resting on her feet for about 20 seconds. I tried to act like she did this every day. Â Ha! And then she settled down on her side and let me rub her cheeks. Â And she was purring. Â At some point I pulled my hand away to rest on the arm of the chair - and she hissed and smacked my hand with her paw. Â I have learned that this hiss reaction means one of 2 things: Â Don't stop! Â or Stop! So I started scratching her cheek again. Â And then after another minute, I could tell she was ready for me to stop. Â I pulled my hand away again. Â And after about another 30 seconds she jumped down with a parting hiss. Â That hiss in most cats is a warning sign of significance. Â But not in Aja. Â It is just like another way of talking along with her chirps and purrs and meows! Â It all fits into the context of what is going on - whether is is negative or positive.She is a complicated lady!

title: Some of this ... some of that!
text: For some reason getting a post published lately to this blog has been difficult. Â My days have gotten busier I guess.FAMILYÂ Recently family time has increased. Â Not seeing my adult kids and my grand baby really began to weigh heavy on me.My son and his wife work from home now and having a 2 year old around make for difficult productivity. Â So I have been spending 3 days from 9 until 2-ish, at their house playing with Esk.Here she is 'cooking." Â I love seeing her use her imagination. Â She really does imitate what she sees.And, of course, there is swing time in the yard. Â They recently moved to a larger house and with that move came more space inside and out. Â There is a lovely swing set in the yard. Â Esk loves to swing. Â She is big on saying "faster, faster, faster" until she is going as high as the swing allows. Â And if she doesn't think she is high enough, she gets grumpy! Â She also loves to play hide-and-seek - her own version of the game, of course. Â Her favorite spot to hide (her only spot to hide) is under the covers in the center of her parents' bed, then she tells me to go to her bedroom - which is down the hall. Â Then I am instructed to come back and 'find' her. Â She doesn't grasp the fact that I helped hide her. Â ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ It is hysterical.So as I walk down the hall from her bedroom to 'find' her, our game goes something like this:Me:Â  Â Where is Esk? Â I can't seem to find her.Esk: Â (no sound)Me:Â  Â Is Esk in this bathroom? Â I don't see her.Esk: Â (no sound)Me:Â  Â Is Esk in this closet? Â Nope, not there!! (as I get closer to her parents' bedroom.)Esk: Â (little giggle)Me:Â  Â Is Esk in her parents' bedroom? Â hmmm ... I don't know.Esk: Â (more giggle and a little shake of the blanket)Me: Â  Maybe I should check under the bed! Â Or maybe daddy's closet! Â Or maybe mommy's bathroom!Esk: Â (small squeal and squished down to make her bump smaller)Me: Â  Or maybe, just maybe ... she is under this COVER!!! Â (Lifting the cover to reveal her.)Esk: Â  (Big squeal and laughter.). Esk want more hide!!! Â Help me grandma! Â And when I suggest that it is my turn to hide, she is most distraught - so the game is really Esk Hide and Grandma Go Seek!Â I'll play the game anyway she wants!!Â Â We are keeping the social distancing bubble in place by associating only with those who have minimal contact with others.Â So far that has worked well for my son, daughter and daughter-in-law.Â AJAAja's personality is becoming more known over time. Â She is friendly. Â She purrs. Â She loves her food! She talks all the time. Â And when she is not happy, we are getting better at reading her body language. (A very important skill. Â Ha!)She loves her bed by the window!!I think she has even put on a little weight.She lets you pet her (within reason ... within "her reason" ... so knowing when to stop is important.) Â She is exploring the condo more and more. Â But holding her in your arms or on your lap is not high on her list ... yet. Â She is learning to live with 2 humans in her "family," but not big on company of others - human or dogs (although she seems to like my daughter.) Â Yep! Â She is on my bed - even without an invite! Â We have taken to calling her "our little diva." Â Just like a "diva"we try to judge her 'boundaries' - giving her just enough but not too much of anything. Â That expression says "Yep! Â I own this bed, too!! ğŸ˜It has been hugely helpful to be in semi-regular contact with her first "mom." Â I discovered just last week that Aja's birthday was in July 2016 - meaning she is just now turning 4. Â Occasionally touching base with this lady has made Aja less of a mystery to us. Â We are very lucky to have made contact! Â Aja's previous mom has been our "user's manual" for this feline!!DE-STRESSINGLow level stress with the pandemic, the combative political climate (an election year) and the heart- breaking images of the race issues has a been a constant.Â In some ways the rise of personal cells phones has made it clear just how ugly the underbelly of our country is right now. Â And that is a good thing! Â You can't change a problem if you don't think there is a problem. Â Changing our leadership in November is the first step. Â No ... let me correct that. Â The first step is peaceful protest! Â Which is our right!! And a LOT of it. Â The second step is getting leaders in place that will correct all the wrongs of the last 4 years. Â There is a lot of work to do.But how to de-stress from all the terrible events of 2020!! Â I always seem to fall back on "making space in my environment." Â Declutter! Â Nothing else does that trick for me. Â Not even knitting. Â Spending so much time at home now - thinning the belongings has become a regular routine rather than a single seasonal binge event. Â It started with downsizing my yarn stash which began to feel like a burden. Â If you had told me 10 years ago that too much yarn would be burden, I would have thought you insane. Â But as time has passed that thought weighs on me ... I couldn't possibly live long enough to knit it all. Â And that mind set spreads into other areas of the condo. Â Each day I put one bag together of stuff and carry it out of the condo to ... somewhere! Â Ironically finding ways to donate stuff during this pandemic has been challenging now that Good Will is closed. Â Thankfully I found a Church Thrift Shop not too far from my condo - and they are happy to receive new "inventory." And as I have discovered many times before, I seldom think about the things I get rid of ... once they are gone... so how important were they anyway??PANDEMICThis virus is going to be with us a long time. Â Building habits now on what can be sustained is how I Â think about this summer.What I can sustain is:Hands washing, hand sanitizer, social distancing and masksSmall groups only of folks who follow #1Eating carry out - no eat in restaurantsBeing content with home based pursuits Â Since I don't work outside the house - those 4 points are do-able. Â What I can't maintain is keeping a 'sterile field' in my home like I did in March. Â Sanitizing all the groceries that came into the house, wiping down frequently touched surfaces in my house every single night, using disposable gloves all the time - too much, too much too much! Â Certainly everything carries some risk - but building habits that you can consistently do for a year and half or more - is the goal for me. Â  Getting burned out by living in a sterile bubble and breaking that bubble for "one fun filled weekend" - like some have done - well, it just doesn't make sense. Â As one reporter stated, it takes just one exposure at a bar - during one fun night - to undo all the things you did for months previously.Â Nope! Â Not me. Â Especially when people are still dying such miserable and lonely deaths at such high rates.So that is my This and That for now!

title: Unveiling Aja - Chapter 3 - Little Victories
text: One morning, as my body began the process of waking, I turned over in my bed and saw THIS!!Seriously, I couldn't believe my eyes. Â Aja, laying in the bed we bought for her. Â I slowly reached for my glasses on the night stand. Â She looked over her shoulder at me. Â I froze not wanting to disturb this little victory. Â She returned to sleep. Â Even with my glasses on she was STILL there. Â I wanted a picture. Â I needed a picture. Â I slowly reached for my phone and as I drew it towards my body, she looked over her shoulder at me again. Â I froze again - Â my eyes closed pretending to sleep. Â She set her head down again. Â I then took about 20 pictures of a cat that was not moving one little bit!! Â Hahaha! Never in my wildest dreams did I even think I would get such a sense of joy from seeing a sleeping cat. Â After all, sleeping is what cats are masters at. Â I have 50 years worth of cat sleeping images in my brain!! Â But none gave me a feeling of success, like that image.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  And then there was today - she did THIS!!!!Yes, she is laying beside me on the bed. Â  She still keeps to our bedroom normally, so periodically I go in the bedroom and spend time with her. Â Today I pulled back the covers of my bed and sat on the mattress. Â She has become confident enough to jump up and sit by me, but today was the first time she laid down beside me. Â Another victory.She won't jump to my lap when I sit in the chair. Â She did that exactly twice on her own. Â And when I lift her onto my lap she doesn't seem comfortable and sometimes hisses letting me know, "Not now!!" Â So I have stopped trying to lift her or hold her. Â She just isn't ready for that. Â But laying beside me was a pretty big step for her. Â Relaxed enough to lay on her side. Â I will say her tail was wagging a bit - like she knew this action was new with me and she was feeling a bit unsure. Â But she stayed for about 10 minutes. Â And then she jumped down.Â I am still learning!The first few weeks I made all the advances with her. Â Half the time she was receptive and half the time she wasn't. Â In the last few weeks I have let her make all the moves. Â She needs to seek me out - and she does. Â That method has worked very much better. Â What I REALLY want to do is pick her up and give her a great big hug! Â But I resist as I know that would end in disaster. Â And my goal is to avoid disasters - and even hissing episodes! Â Bonding is the goal and trust takes time. Â Peace is the path to both. Â And I love this little lady enough to do all the steps her way.I keep forgetting. Â Its been only 5 weeks. Â We are on Aja's time schedule and not mine! Â And she likes it that way. Â Now that this approach is bearing fruit - I like it that way as well!

title: Unveiling Aja - Chapter 2 - Two Steps Forward.  One Back.  Repeat.
text: I have come to the conclusion that of the 10 cats that previously shared our lives,Â Aja is the only one who was raised to be an actual cat! Â ğŸ˜Â Â All our other cats came to us as kittensÂ and although we didn't realize it at the time,Â I am kind of thinking we probably raised them to be dogs! haha.Sorry for the poor quality! Â Aja, hunkered down under the bed!That look is not "trusting." Â Ha! Â She had good reason.Last weekend was hard on her.First off, the weather was beautiful and cool. Â Our air conditioner was off and our bedroom windows were wide open. Â The curtains were billowing with a wonderful breeze. Â The road noise (and we have some road noise), is a constant to our ears at times. Â So constant that we just don't hear it anymore unless it is a noisy motorcycle or a fire truck - but Aja hears every sound. Â And the billowing curtains??? Â Her look was "My Gosh!! Are they supposed to do that??" Sunday, when I entered the bedroom and called for her - she didn't come. Â I think I was getting the cat equivalent of a cold shoulder. Â I checked under the bed. Â No Aja. Â I checked in the bathroom and under the rocker and under the dressers. Â No Aja! Â My little 'worry worm' started. Â I checked my husband's closet. No Aja. Â Finally I moved his shirts on the lower level ... and there she was - snuggly hidden from the dog (more on him later,) and the street noise, and the breeze and the curtains. Â Poor baby. Â I wanted to pick her up in my arms and reassure her. Â But I knew it was too early in our relationship for such familiarities.She spent most of Saturday and Sunday in my husband's closet. Â I shut everything down Sunday night. It got quieter. Â She got calmer. Â Later I opened one bedroom window .... two inches only. Â Air and some noise was allowed in but not at the same level as the weekend. Â I know with time she will adjust to all this - because this is part of her reality now and there is really no choice - Â but currently - she is not fan.How can you not love a sweet old face like this one!Then there is this old guy! Â Milo, my daughter's French Bull Dog - one of my grand babies. Â He had been here since Thursday and returned home Monday. Â He only looked at her through the gate - never barked. Â But his presence has been worrisome for her. Â Milo can't get past the gate so the protective space barrier was solidly in place. Â She calmed a bit. This morning I moved the new donut bed into the area of the closet she likes to hide. Â That was a mistake! Â She decided she doesn't like me messing with her hiding places. Â Now she is back under the bed.Her hissing responses increased in a really schizoid-like way. Â She rubs against my legs purring, back and forth watching out the bedroom door, then she smells my hand (I am sure Milo's scent is on me), she hisses and then turns and rubs against my legs again, then hisses, and repeat. Â She is very confused. Â I look and sound the same, but my smell is not quite right. I go and wash my hands. She calms. How to explain all this to her. Â I thought I was speaking "cat" all this time, but maybe I was actually speaking "dog," and she speaks only "cat." Â All my previous cats apparently understood "dog." *sigh* - have I totally lost you all yet?Or maybe, there are just gaps in my understanding! Â Yes, that is it. Â I need more educating.So I spent time on Amazon looking at cat behavior books and found this one, highly rated, current and focused on feline behavior. Image from AmazonThis is the way I love to hold my cats! Bet Aja would think this is too familiar.Â The book is authored by Jackson Galaxy - a cat behaviorist and Mikel Maria Delgado, Phd, a behavior consultant for Feline Minds at the Davis School of Veterinary Medicine. Â Apparently Jackson hosts an Animal Planet hit showÂ and is the author of other books related to cats. Â Mikel studied animal behavior and human-animal relationships at the University of California, Berkeley. Â This book had the focus on behavior I was looking for - rather than just dedicating one chapter to behavior and other chapters all other cat care topics. Perfect! I also downloaded a few free Kindle offerings. Â I am determined to not make too many backward steps with Aja.Then I checked the calendar! Â She has been with us just about 4 weeks. Â Only 4 weeks! Â Gosh ... I have heard adjustment time spans of up to 18 months!! Â Maybe I am just rushing things. Â Maybe I am speaking "cat" after all - and she doesn't like what I am saying.Maybe I am over thinking this!! Â hahaha.Oh well, can't hurt to check out a few references. Post Script: Â Just before publishing this post, two major Aja advancements happened. Aja left the safety of under the bed and rubbed up against my husband's legs. Â Let me tell you!! Â THAT made his month! Â I knew ignoring her would produce a positive reaction. Â Cats typically seek out anyone they 'think' doesn't like them. Â It is one of the signature traits of felines - across the full spectrum of the cat world. Â A little reverse psychology works wonders.And around dinner time she walked right out the bedroom and made her way into the living room - in front of us - while we were eating dinner at the table. Â I cautioned my husband:No sudden moves or loud noises,no coughing, sneezing,Â or swallowing that food you put in your mouthÂ ... Â just act natural ...Â maybe stop breathing for a minute or two while she checks things out!! Â ğŸ˜€And she did just that! Â She walked right up to my husband's chair and did her side rub back and forth! Â A typical cat method of sharing their scent on things to "make it their own." Â It lasted for all of 5 minutes! Â But, hey, that was brave, brave, brave on her part. Â And after she ran back into the bedroom I told her that!!So maybe I don't need a book. Â Maybe I am speaking "cat!" Â Or maybe she is learning "dog!"Or maybe we are just developing a new language between us ...Â Aja Language!I sure do love this crazy cat!

title: Unveiling Aja
text: Our journey with Aja has been like a grand "unveiling." A slow, deliberate lifting of the veilÂ she uses to cover her personality.She is a beauty!You see, when you adopt a kitten, there is no veil or curtain. Â It is all typically about play and adventure and wonder and fun and discovery and cuddles and sometimes mistakes and craziness. Â Kittens are "all out there." Â Being cautious lasts about 5 or 10 minutes. Â Tops! Â Finding your 2 pound fur ball hanging from a curtain rod or off your jeans (while you are wearing them, of course) or pitifully caught in a tight place, or darting between your legs in sudden fits and starts ... all of that is just Kittenhood 101!Favorite spot!Adopting an adult cat is none of that. Â It more like studying for a Phd without books or lectures and Cliff Notes. Â You don't even get a syllabus or an advisor. Â Adopting an adult cat is like purchasing a "surprise package" where you don't know what's inside the box until you open it up. Â And the first order of business is gently picking the virtual scotch tape off the wrapping paper without upsetting the contents (otherwise known as 'the cat.') Â And that is where we started with Aja.The first thing she shared with us was how talky she is. Â Many meows, trills, purring, short little squeak sounds that have meaning only to her at present. And she loves to be talked to! Â All that aside, she isn't shy at setting you straight with a hiss, either. Â Although we have no rules when it comes to cats, she apparently has a few rules when it comes to owners. Â Haha! Â Good thing I am a fast learner!!Husband spending time trying to make friends.Look at her beautiful markings.The next discovery was the sinuous rubbing of her body against our legs. Â She loves to do that. Â She is friendly - in the extreme at times - happy to be scratched around the cheeks and ears and neck. Â And when she has had enough - She Is D-O-N-E. Â And don't ask for more. Â It's her time table - not yours. Â When her 'happy dance' is over, she is on to other things.Gate is wide open - but unless it is dark and quiet - she typicallywon't come out. Â At least not yet. Â Can't help but wonderwas is going on in that tiny mind of hers.But as the owner, it is important that I control the narrative (or at least give the illusion that I am in control. ğŸ˜†) Â For example - lifting her onto the bed, onto her cube by the window, and onto my lap has shorten the time she would take to do these things independently on her own. Â  The first time doing anything she is tense and anxious. Â Her picture is in the dictionary next to the word CAUTIOUS! Â Tail is intensely whipping back and forth, eyes darting every which way before she jumps down. But within a short time she spontaneously returning to that scary "whatever" and shows off her mastery of it ... acting like it is no big deal! Â Ha!One of her beds - the cube. Â A hiding place and a perch place in one.She still sleeps under our bed! Â *sigh* Â  My other cats never used a cat bed. Their bed was where we slept and they graciously shared 'their bed' with us. Â Maybe she will do that someday, but 'someday' could be a ways off. Â So I bought 2 pet beds. Â One bed is the donut shape placed in my husband's closet (she visits there), and the other one is the cube that functions like a bed she can hide in and perch on while watching out the window. Â She has checked out both, but use them?? Â Not to sleep in. Â She still creeps under the bed. Â The vet said to give her time. My friend who has homed feral cats said the same thing. Â It may take her 18 months to sleep in one of those beds. Â Or maybe never. Â Cats do what they want to do, when they want to do it. and how they want to do it.Half the time she looks out - and half the time she looks in.She loves sitting on our window sills. Â Since she is half the weight of our other big male cats - her little butt actually fits on our window sill. Â Half the time she is watching out our windows at the world outside ... and half the time she is looking at the world inside! Â I guess we haven't gotten boring yet.Poor picture due to night lighting, but she is on the left technicallyin our kitchen which is right outside thebedroom door to the left.Another poor lighting picture. Â She is looking into the denwhich is right outside our bedroom door to the right.Her current big adventure is the condo space beyond our her bedroom. Â Under her own steam she has stepped outside the bedroom almost every day for the last week ... a few inches more each time. Â Usually she makes these forays when the house is very quiet and dark, and we are quietly reading. Â But yesterday I was standing in the kitchen (during the bright light of day, TV blaring, and microwave humming - you know - normal stuff) and I looked down and found her almost standing in the kitchen. Â We were both surprised. Â Her eyes were huge like saucers - mine too! Â Then the ice maker did its thing and dropped a load of ice in the bin!! Â  Too much, too much, too much! Â Gone. Â Being female, (and the business end of the species,) she knows instinctively that monsters may live out there! Â Can't be too careful - that is clearly a motto tattooed in her tiny cat brain!Milo, my French Bulldog 'Grandson' looking into the bedroom at Â Aja.Aja acting causal as she carefully extracts herself fromunder the rocking chair while being observed byMilo.This weekend we raised the level of excitement a bit. Â My daughter's French Bulldog, Milo, came for a visit. Â As you can imagine, Aja was not amused. Â There was a return to hissing and tail swishing! Â All behind the safety of her gate and under the rocking chair. Â She stayed in her "safe zone" while Milo peaked in through the bars. Milo is an old guy and has little interest in cats. Â He just wanted a look-see! Â After a few hours she settled down. Â She made the connection that the gate protected her from the "monster" that had just arrived. Â Now she sits calming staring out at him. Â Maybe one day she will be as comfortable as Wally was with Milo.Feeding time. Â She gets both dry and wet. Initially we weren't surewhat she preferred to eat. Â Now we now she likes wet foodbut snacks on dry. Â My husband is the feeder - hiseffort to make friends with Aja - who is still very unsure about him.She still seems to favor me, much to my husband's chagrin. Â The last 2 cats favored my husband. Â He doesn't give up easy and keeps trying to win her over. Â I tell him to just ignore her. Â Cats can't stand to be ignored! Â If you try too hard, they can't be bothered. Â So he is doing his best to give her space and time. Â And he is the official feeder! Â You know, just to show off his good side to Aja. Â Meanwhile, she is all over me! Â Haha! Another truism about cats - they pick their people and you have no say in the matter.She like the little laser light (left little bright spot on the carpet.)Her first visit to the vet was May 22. Â We anticipated a "betrayal of the shaky trust" we had carefully nurtured. Â Cats normally don't equate good vet care with loving pet ownership. But we do. Â As it turns out it wasn't that scary a trip for her. Â I had to stay in the parking lot, of course, pandemic protocols, so she had to brave the vet's office on her own. Â Apparently she did fine. Â I warned them that she is a hisser and a smacker when anxious, but not known to be aggressive. Â And sure enough the vet got one of each after micro chipping her!! Â Our vet agreed with the shelter and our assessment that she was not aggressive. Â Just frightens easily. The ride in the car was uneventful. Â That is a big improvement over Wally who would vomit all over the inside of his carrier and yowl the whole trip. Â Poor boy! Â Nerves and maybe car sick. Â Not her! Â Not a sound. Â Considering she hisses at a bunch of little things and 'talks' up a mean-streak at home, I was surprised the car ride was so quiet. Â She looked all around! (Monsters could be anywhere you know!!)She has finally got comfortable enough to pose and let me take pictures of her.Finally, I had the good fortune to communicate with her previous owner. Â The Surrender Form included that information. Â Since Aja was a mystery wrapped up in orange fur, I wanted to know more. Â I plugged the owner's name into Facebook on the off chance I could find her. Â Success! Â I took a chance and shot off an email. I know that some might have not appreciate a message from the new owner. Â But I wanted to share that Aja landed in a good home and was doing well. Â Thankfully, she did respond and was very happy to hear from me. She was grateful that Aja was with us - patient and experienced cat parents. Â Although she had to give Aja up due to a distance move, she had kept tabs on her through the shelter website and knew she had been adopted. Â Not knowing how Aja was doing was hard. Â Hopefully now Aja's first 'mom' has some peace of mind about Aja's future. And for me, it was nice to have confirmation that the Aja I am getting to know is pretty much unchanged from her former life and that she had a good home with her previous 'mom.' Â I invited her to visit this blog occasionally to keep up with Aja as she begins her new life with me."OK, I am done for today! Â Please go away now!" Â hahahaAs each day that passes, Aja is a little less of a mystery. Â We are past the 'virtual scotch tape and wrapping paper' stage. Â We have opened the lid to look carefully at the contents - at least as much as she is willing to show us now ... and she is carefully looking back!The adventure continues!

title: Memorial Day
text: Remember what Memorial Day is for!From Facebook

title: Aja
text: So here she is ... all 7 or 8 pounds of her! Â The smallest full grown cat we have ever had. Â And getting pictures of her has been a challenge. Â She can be ellusive.Aja actually entered our home under the name of Asia. Â That is what the shelter had for her name. Â But when we got home we noticed on the previous owner's surrender form - her name was Aja! Â After about 24 hours we decided to keep her name as Aja.Aja is our second female cat (out of 11) and our first orange tabby! Â She is also our first adult adoption.She has beautiful markings but you can see here that herstomach sinks in. Â This picture is from day 1.Our first evening at home with Aja was fairly quiet. Â She came out from under the bed to visit the litter box - once. Â No food or water, but the box got a visit. Â Ok, normal. Â But around bedtime my husband and I were both in the bedroom together and I think that made her nervous. Â She couldn't watch us both at the same time. Â At one point my husband - who is legally blind - stepped on her. Â The very first night!! Â He was devastated. Â She was pissed!! Â Hissing and swatting at him as he tried to get on the floor to 'apologize.' Â She didn't know what he was doing and that was upsetting her too. Â I said to stand and just ignore her. Â Give her space to recover herself. Â That night she let me pet her. Â But it was a troublesome start.She sleeps during the day ... and under the bed. Â Periodically each day I would slip my hand down between the bed and the wall and she would rub against it. Â And then she would come out. Â On day 2 she began to eat. Â That was a great relief to us.We are now at day 5 she is making strides at trusting us and we are making strides at reading her body language. Â She expresses anxiety with rapidly wagging tail, then a hiss, maybe a short growl and finally a paw swipe (nails retracted) ... all in that order. Â Once I figured that out, we were golden. Â Thankfully the things she is anxious about are reducing. Â  In fact, that sequence has almost totally gone away - as she has relax somewhat in her new environment. Â Poor little girl. Â She must have hated the last two weeks in the shelter. There have been a bunch of fun mini steps in her adjustment. Â Like the night when I was sitting in the bedroom rocker. Â My husband was asleep, the lights were out and I was reading my Kindle. Â She had been rubbing my legs when suddenly she jumped up into my lap. Â I think we were both stunned!! Â She sat there watching for my reaction and I was doing the same with her. Â Her eyes were on me and her tail was waving. Â Anxiety! Â I gently rubbed her under her chin. She relaxed and the tail settled. Â Actually we both relaxed! Â Hahaha. Â She lasted for about 45 seconds, then jumped down. Â Next time it will be longer.Now she comes out from under the bed (where she still sleeps) at the sound of my voice calling her. Â She looks for affection. Â She is checking us out for any rules - little does she know - there are no rules!! Ha.The gate separates our bedroom and bathroom from the rest ofthe condo so that our cat has a safe zone when company isaround. Â We kept is closed the first 3 days.The last two days we left it open. She still chooses to stay in the bedroom.And just so you know, the gray cat in the picture -lower left corner, is a wood carving door stop. Â :-)It sure looks interestingout there. Â L-)She still self-contains herself in the bedroom. Â She is familiar with the space now, and food and litter are readily available. Â She sometimes sits and looks out the gate at the rest of the condo, but her tail starts to wave and I know she is still unsure. Â One time she stepped past the open gate and crept out about 4 steps - stopped - and ran back with belly to the ground. Â With time she will be a bit more adventuresome, but for now she is happy to stick in her "safe zone." Â But she does continue to look.But even with the gate openshe isn't sure the time is right!Today I decided it was time to see if she could tolerate me lifting her. Â So I lifted her onto our bed. Â It was a fast movement and she did not object. Â I picked her up two other times today. Â All to the bed. Â She did fine. Â  Later my husband and I were on the bed, he was listening to an audio book and I was talking to her. Â She jumped right up on the bed - without an invite. Â And she stayed with us a bit.So all in all ... she is doing great!! Â The rate of her adjustment is progressing! Â We got lucky. Â I think she is a great cat with a recent bad experience. Â And she got lucky to. Â We have 50 years of cat ownership under our belt. Â We can be patient and understand the language of "cat" very well.As I fall in love with this little creature, I can't help but remember that she is a heartbreak waiting in the wings of my life at some future date. Â I wonder why I do this to myself when their lives are so short compared to ours - and then she rubs up against my legs purring and I remember. Â Love from a pet holds no judgement. Â Yes, you must earn it, but once earned - you are their 'person' until they take their last breath.Here's hoping you keep breathing for a long time, dear Aja!

title: Our Small Miracle
text: After 2 weeks without our dear cat, Wallace, we knew we wanted to adopt another cat. Â This time an adult. Adults are sometimes hard to place. Â It would be our very first adult adoption. Â We thought it would be easy - since there are so many wonderful pets needing a home. Â Generally you just needed to whisper ... hey, I might want to adopt an animal ... and the array of choices is made available to you.Not so during a pandemic. Â All the rules change. Â Not only can you not just walk into a shelter without an appointment, but the selection of animals is much reduced. Â Apparently adoptions are way up in this time of self isolation according to the shelter we used. Â That bit of knowledge I found concerning. Â After all, we aren't always going to be self isolated. Â This is a temporary measure. Â But pets are not temporary. Â What happens after everyone returns to work??To spread the adoption net as far as I could I let everyone know we were looking - including our vet. Â After 3 days of waiting for a nibble on my Â 'adoption fishing net' I started looking at shelters online myself.I found a site near us called Small Miracles. Â They had four adult cats - all female - between the ages of 2-4. Â I sent an email. Â No response. Â I filled out the online application form and sent it with a second email. Â No response. Â I called and left a message. Â No response. Â (Seriously - how serious were they about finding homes if I had to work this hard?) One of my neighbors works there as a volunteer. Â I emailed her. Â She said she would contact them - and sure enough the shelter emailed me back. Â We made an appointment.It was at Small Miracles where we met Asia. Â She is a 4 year old orange tabby - a tiny little beauty. Â As we walked toward her cage she was sitting in a haunch position in her litter - a sign that she was not at ease. Â When we reached the cage and poked our fingers through - she came to us and began rubbing and purring. Â The shelter rep said she seemed friendly, no sign of aggression, does hiss at times but they interpreted as an anxiety response. Â From the look of her body language at my first sight of her, I agreed. Â When I asked how long she was there - they said 2 weeks. Â My heart fell for this pretty girl who was obviously not at ease there and had been release by her previous owner (she was moving) from a home environment to this painful impersonal situation. Â At least her owner took her to a "no kill" shelter, but I can't even imagine what Asia was thinking during those two weeks. Â Two weeks is a long time when you are miserable.I should say, I am terrible at shelter visits. Â I am motivated to adopt everything in sight. My heart goes out to any animal that is forced to stay there more than a few days. I hate the look and feel of animal shelters. They are noisy, not terribly clean and personal interaction with the animals seems limited to meeting just physical needs as opposed to emotional ones. Â And that is the situation for all the animals that shelters deem as 'adoptable.' Â You usually don't see the ones who aren't adoptable. Â I get it ... I really do ... no time to give full attention to any one little being. Â Just a sad environment all around for me.Asia came home with us that very day.The shelter staff said she hissed at them when she was put in our carrier. Â Pretty sure it was anxiety, they said.The trip home was pretty quiet. Â She tried pushing against the carrier, but mostly just sat still looking all around. Â When we got home, we took her right into our bedroom and bathroom combination - her home until she was relaxed enough to explore the rest of the condo.Upon being released, she did a fast scan of the two rooms (looking for monsters I am sure ğŸ˜Ÿ,) took note of the litter box and the water, and then slipped under the bed.Next up ... pictures and her first 24 hours.

title: Listen and Push Back
text: Without detailing the current state of our wounded world ...Â Â a need grew in me to push back.I have had my fair share of "hits" this spring. Â The pandemic started this tsunami of hits beginning with isolation protocols (even from family) and fears of infection for ourselves and our loved ones, followed by the health decline of my cat, Wally, continuing to his death ... and finally topped off with the very serious news that a close family member is being placed on a Transplant list due to kidney failure ... well, the hits just seemed to keep coming this spring. Â The last "hit" is not totally unexpected as our family has dealt the kidney disease for a long time - but it is a particularly difficult when you can't put your arms around them. Â What I can do is see if I am a compatible donor - my very personal and determined way of pushing back on a personal tsunami. Â For now - enough said on that.Â At the very basic level - my first "push back" is with my knitting. Â Unfortunately when I am very upset and distracted, I don't get that positive bump or settling feeling from sitting and knitting (or any other craft) during tough times like so many others. Â I usually lose the desire to knit entirely. Â I do better getting up and cleaning. (An aside: my condo is now cleaner than it has been in a long time.). I also like to declutter because that down feeling creates a very realistic filter to my 'pitch it out' decisions - do I care enough to keep an item in my current upset state? Â It is amazing how much a down attitude crystalizes my "keep it or pitch it" decision making. Â But this week I decided that I would push myself beyond cleaning into knitting. Â After all, I have a room full of yarn and it isn't getting smaller just by sitting there.It started with a cable vest pattern for my grand daughter and even though I am almost half way through it, I kept putting it down after one row. Â A little voice in my head said, "Maybe this pattern isn't the right thing for you to knit right now."I had been thinking to work on a blanket small enough to use in a child's bed so I picked out a selection of CaronÂ Simply Soft acrylic (my go-to acrylic when I knit for kids) and started out with an appealing crochet pattern (you know how fast crochet can be), but I found myself making the blanket wider and wider with each row. Ha!Â  I don't really understand the crochet stitch well enough to be any good at it and now is not the time to add complexity to anything.Â  I ripped it out after 4 inches. Â I needed to go back to the thing I know best. Â Knitting.Looking through Ravelry at patterns and saw a bunch of beautiful blanket designs, but instead of feeling excited about them - I felt dread!!Â  Can you believe it?? Unbelievable. No sense starting a project with such negative emotions just by looking at the pictures. Â My emotions are so mixed up right now.Then I stumbled across Purl Soho's Super Easy Lap Blanket.Â  Basically, cast on a bunch of stitches, knit every row, slip the first stitch for an even edge, and if you are changing colors just knit until you finish the first skein of color and change colors.Â  FINALLY I found something I can do. Â And no dread!What is hysterical, there are actualÂ instructions on theÂ PurlSoho website for this pattern. Â haha! Â The instructions take up 1/2 page. Â Mine took up 4 lines. Â I decided to double the yarn and use 10.5 knitting needles to add speed and body to the project. I am happy with it.Â  I love Caron Simply Soft as an affordable acrylic and it is working up beautifully. Â Something that would usually bore me to tears is now giving me peace. Â And it will make a substantial dent in my yarn stash. Â Win-win.While working on it I thought about Elizabeth Zimmerman and her love of garter stitch patterns. Â I have several of her books. Â I need to take a second look at those projects. Â IÂ remember they were simple in design but classic in style. Â In fact, I remember reading one of her books written in her own words and discovered how much fun it was to read her thoughts. Â She didn't stress over anything and all things knitting were do-able. Maybe I should open one of those and read a bit.And then I remembered the Sally Melville books: Â The Knit Stitch (Book #1), The Purl Stitch (Book #2), and Color, (Book #3.). I have all 3 books - they survived the declutter purge from moving. Â I pulled them out and decided that maybe IÂ would make anÂ Einstein Jacket - an older pattern found in The Knit Stitch Â book - I remembered a yarn in my stash that just might work for that pattern. Â I got up and searched to the yarn of my memory. Â Yep! Â I still had it. Â Top right skeins are sock weight and will make a nice matching scarf.The yarn band said it was bulky weight yarn best used with a #10 knitting needle! Â Eureka!! Â Exactly what the pattern said was needed. Â  And in a stunning twist of serendipity - the rust color used in the book is exactly the color of the yarn I have for this project.Â It was like starting a small fire by rubbing 2 sticks together, getting a tiny spark, adding some kindling, blowing on it to build a small fire and finally creating something that could keep you warm!Â Nothing has changed, of course. Â I am still self isolating with little family contact and will continue probably another 4 weeks, Wally is still gone forever and we are cat-less for the first time in 50 years of marriage, and my family member still needs a kidney for a quality life - a life I dearly want to preserve. Â But I have found a small bit of peace in a world that seems to be spinning out of control all around me.And maybe (a small voice in my head keeps repeating) just the act of pushing back - doing something that seems right is what you need to do now. Â Maybe listening to that small voice in myself was the goal to begin with.While not a traditionally spiritual person, I do believe in God, but I don't believe in waiting for God to save me from life. Â I believe in a God who gave me two amazing gifts to handle life: a brain that sits atop of the animal kingdom in complexity and free will. Â He expects me to use my gifts. I don't wait around for God to fix life for me.Â At the risk of offending someone with this cartoon, I feel it nails exactly my relationship with God and how I am handling this pandemic!Grabbed from FacebookListen to the small voices and push back ...

title: Wally
text: Rest In PeaceHandsome BoyJune 2006 - April 2020

title: Keep Your Parachute On
text: Found on Facebook - no idea who to really credit!The StruggleSo, here I sit 4 1/2 weeks or so into this 'Stay at Home' thing we have been ordered to do - and I thought I was nailing it mentally. Â Note - the Past Tense!I'm not. Â I'm restless. Â This new antsy feeling, however, won't change a thing regarding Covid-19 protection guidelines. Â I will stay home bound for as long as it takes - just like everyone else should. Â  I am keeping my 'parachute' on. Â But ... one night I went to bed feeling fine being home bound - and the next morning I woke up and realized ... Â not fine. I tried to sort out why this is so. Â I have a lot to keep me occupied - my life within these 4 walls is good. Â And no job to worry about, no lack of food, no heath issues (thank God, because now is not the time to have a health issue of any kind!)I thought the simple answer would be "gratitude." Â Just be grateful. Â It is sort of the new buzz word for changing your perspective on things and making you happy. Â To be honest, it didn't work. Â Because "gratitude" for material things (which I have in abundance) is just a way to fool your mind about what really feeds your soul.I determined what I was missing was my kids, my grand daughter, my grand dogs, my friends, visits to public places without fear. Â It is like the mountain of 'things' available to me within the four walls of this condo are just not cutting it - a diversion for sure - but not as positive and life sustaining as I thought.I miss is seeing with my own eyes that my adult kids are happy and healthy, hugs from my grand daughter who shouts "grama" over and over again, Â explosive rush of excitement and love I get from my grand dogs who run around like their pants are on fire for the first 5 minutes after I walk in the door, the laughter and the sharing in person with friends .... heck, even time spent with strangers without the constant reminders of masks and gloves that say - "Stay back!! ... you might have germs." Â That is what I miss! Â It is an interesting personal discovery. Â And that old life I miss might be on hold for another 12 to 18 months.What I wouldn't give to be able to just hug a complete stranger!!Upside - DownsideOn the upside - my carpet got steamed cleaned this week - looong overdue! Â On the downside - the inspiration for steam cleaning is because of my cat Wally broke box training this week (almost always a sign that something is wrong.) Â On the upside I got him to a vet yesterday to receive the care and meds he needed, but the downside is I spent that vet visit in the parking lot while they took care of him without me. They didn't even want my credit card - said to call when I got home. Another downside - his appetite has been way off for months and losing weight. Â So in a last ditch effort to save his life, I have been force feeding him some high calorie dense nutritional value food and soon I will be manually feeding him a liquid diet - a special food on order. Â Not much fun for either of us. Â  Â He has 2 ongoing medical health issues and is getting treatment for those, but his chances of making his 14th birthday in June are fading fast if he won't eat. I think the downsides within the walls of my condo are outnumbering the upsides right now.Other stuff:I finally got my kitchen floor washed. Â I hear that is a thing now! :-) Â I won't embarrass myself with how long it has been - but it took 3 complete washings to get it clean. Â I didn't choose the ugly kitchen flooring pattern - the previous owners did. Â The only positive thing about it - it doesn't show dirt! Â But if it takes 3 washings to come clean - I really went to a new low in the housekeeping department.I food shop by myself now. Â Most people do normally - but it is one of the things my husband enjoyed doing over the years and we always did it together. Â Now that he is blind in a pandemic living in a world with many government imposed restrictions (in this area only 1 family member at a time allowed in the store) Â - he doesn't even get to that simple trip. Â He is the one who enjoys food shopping, but I am the one forced to do it.We are getting out for a walk several days a week. Â It is for mental health more than anything. Â But my legs are feeling better with exercise. Â And I started taking Eggshell Membrane capsules daily and they may also be contributing to the improvement. Â While this is not meant to be medical advice for anyone, it was worth an experiment for me. Â Thank you, Michelle of Boulderneigh Blog.And what to say about knitting! Â I have spent the last 25 years preparing for this moment. Â A time when I have an enormous stash of yarn and unlimited time to sit and knit! Â But focusing on any craft right now is really hard. Â I probably do about 5 rows in my latest project - done while I watch TV. Â But I often find myself sitting staring at the screen with my knitting in my lap - idle. Â It is like my entire life - down to the littlest actions - has been interrupted and getting back on track is not on my radar either.There is a saying that you can't teach an old dog new tricks. Â I used to bristle at that statement feeling in minimized senior adaptability. Â Everyone can learn new tricks. Â But when you have to learn new tricks for every single action in your life - that is when the truth of that saying begins to make sense.To ConcludeKeeping my parachute on,missing my loved ones,refusing to let my cat die,cleaning stuff I can't stand to look at any more,forcing myself into a grocery store,walkingwatching TVJust the same as everyone else,I guess!Stay Well Everyone!

title: Another Week - Upside Down
text: Change is the only Constant in the Pandemic!On March 30 our Governor decided that too many of the population were not taking the pandemic restrictions seriously and our numbers of deaths and infections are rising quickly. Â So he has locked down all but the most essential activities - "Stay At Home" restriction enforced now by law and punishable. Â Our Governor has just lost patience with these stupid citizens and now has put some consequences in place.Amazing really. Â Must be an American "thing." Â Some people just can't be told what to do no matter what the consequences! If they aren't careful, they could be fined or see the inside of a jail - where, by the way, the Covid-19 virus has made an entrance! Have fun, you ridiculous humans - sitting in jail AND feeling as sick as a dog!!Although it won't mean much difference to me and my out-of-condo activities (which has been limited to groceries for 3 weeks,) my life has turned upside-down once again. Â My grand daughter will be staying home with her parents until the "Stay-at-Home" order is lifted. I suspect that will hold for some number of weeks until we hit our high point on the illness curve and begin to slow on new infections.First thought ... What does that mean for me! With a startling awareness, weeks just magically opened up completely with no child sittingğŸ˜, no family ğŸ˜, no dog sittingğŸ˜, no social engagements, no company, no meetings, no nothing! Â It has been decades (literally many decades) since I have had a spell like this when I wasn't recovering from surgery or some such thing! Â Just think on it ... it took a world pandemic for that to happen in my life!!When the kids left on the evening of March 30 - and I finished picking up the toys and food and various other stuff - my mind starting churning. Oh My God! Â You have weeks of total uninterrupted timeto do all the stuff you have kept on the back burnerfor YEARS!!Â I used to keep a long term list of big stuff - nice to do stuff - stuff you do every 10 years so (maybe) - if the time is ever right (or not! and it is usually not.) Â It was such a 'long time list' that I long ago tucked it away somewhere and now it cannot be found! Â Ha! Â What are all those things? Think, think.With out much trouble a list of stuff to do began to develop - and it is becoming very impressive. Â Over ambitious, of course, but what the heck. Â If some of it doesn't get done in the next 3 or 4 weeks, it isn't the end of the world. Â It didn't get done for more than 10 years and nothing bad happened. Â Oh wait ... there is this pandemic!! Â You don't suppose ...What did I do with my days last week - the week with all the free and open time? Â I started cleaning. Â Yes, vacuuming, cleaning bathrooms, sanitizing, etc. Â In my mind I wanted to be ready. Â Ready to be sick. Â Ready to step back and do nothing. Â I just couldn't do that if my house needed cleaning and picking up. Â I would probably drag myself around the condo still doing stuff while coughing and filled with Covid-19 germs - because I can't be sick when there is disorder around me. Â I.JUST.CAN'T. Â I think I am ready now. Â The house is picked up and clean. Â The pantry is packed, the fridge and freezer are bursting. Â I can now get sick with a clear conscious. Â Ha!And because of that - all that prep - I probably won't get sick! Â But I swear to you, if I didn't do all that stuff, I would probably be on a ventilator somewhere struggling to breathe and worrying about the mess I left behind.Signing off for now from this upside down world! Â Hope you all continue to be well in your little space on this earth. Â Just stay away from everyoneÂ and you will be fine! (Oh ... and for double protection clean your house!)PS - I love the free unstructured time but I hate, hate, hate not seeing my family ... my kids, my grand daughter, my grand dogs!!
