title: End of Week Two of Self Isolation
text: So far so good! Not sick.Not bored.Not crazy.Yes, not sick. Â I am sort of self-isolating to avoid anyone who is not self-isolating and should be!! Every day that I wake up ok I am grateful. Â I don't want this new icky virus and I don't want the flu either - which I am quite sure is still circulating and killing people as well - although we don't hear those totals. Â So keeping away from almost everyone and disinfecting stuff every 24 hours kills two birds viruses at one time - I hope. Â And so far I don't know anyone who has come down with Flu or Covid-19.Thankfully, not bored. Â  My grand daughter is with me and there is no such thing as boredom when a 2 year old is around. Â Fatigue, yes. Â Boredom, no. Â My usual pastimes are lagging. Â Not much knitting or weaving going on. Â Even progress on Community Board things has slowed. Â I am cooking more. Â And ironically I don't seem to mind. Â This is astounding because I generally hate cooking. Â But there is something satisfying knowing what I am putting in my body most likely doesn't have any nasty viruses on it. Â I am caught up laundry - because I just have the time. Â Watching TV and reading fill about the same amount of time as before. And crazy? Â Probably not! Â Usually when forced to stay in the house for a long time like during a snow storm, within 3 or 4 days I get 'cabin fever.' Â None of that. Â But I did start thinking about seeking out some fiber events during the summer and fall. Â I am pretty sure that plans of vendors and shoppers are heating up and will explode when we are finally set free to gather in groups of 10 or more and return to normal living. Hmm ... 'normal living' in this new world. Â I do believe the world has shifted in subtle ways - and will never return to a previous normal. Â I don't think I will ever think about public surfaces the same way ever again. Â And once the new normal returns this summer, I will get ahead on some supplies like hand sanitizer and hand soap and Clorox wipes and all those things that I will need again next year - because, yes folks, we will be doing another repeat for winter 2020-2021. Â Maybe not a full shut down of society, but Covid-19 illnesses will be with us again next winter. Â Even with the speedy speedy development of a vaccine and discovering meds to mitigate the illness if you catch it - it won't be available until after the next 'bloom' of this virus. Â When it is available I am going to be very cautious about getting that vaccine. Â Even with adequate testing, new vaccines can have hidden consequences and at my age - it is best to avoid all the consequences until more is known.Meanwhile I am keeping myself busy learning to make a diluted disinfectant cleaning solution from bleach, learning to keep my hands off my face (my God, that is hard to do), and learning to treat everything outside the little sanctuary of my condo as suspicious. I celebrate the finding (like a treasure hunt) of items rare and valuable - like toilette paper, Clorox cleaning supplies, Tylenol, meat and chicken. Â I am learning to live without my good friend Amazon. Â *sigh*. That is the hardest lesson of all. Â I didn't realize how much I relied and getting stuff by the single click of the mouse. Â Delivery times on some items are long and or just simply out of stock and may not return. Â I know, I know ... these are First World Problems! Â I think it is good that First World folks get a peek at what Third World folks already know. Two weeks down ... ?? many more to go!Â Â It is a marathon folks. Â Be a long distance runner and make it to the finish lineÂ where ever the heck that is!!

title: Narrow and Wide
text: Twelve short days!How the world has narrowed down!And how it has expanded.At first it was all about "awareness" - watch where you put your hands, don't run short of anything, don't forget the hand cream for those over washed sore hands, keep your distance even from everyone outside your front door, Clorox wipe down surfaces at home every night, and watch your calendar disappear before your very eyes. Â Very narrow close to home pursuits. Â Awareness becomes habit after a bit.But the narrow focus of a 'home bound' person is new to me. Â I am not clamoring to get in the car and go somewhere ... so I am not exactly suffering. Â Staying at home day after day might be a problem for some, but I enjoy my home and I like the feeling that it is safe (hopefully.)There is the down side ... being kept within 4 walls with TV and the news as your wider view of the world - which is dismal still.The latest news flash this morning is a story out of Denmark - a message to the US - "Do More -- Fast. Â Don't Wait." Â And India has locked down it's country. Â Imagine that if you can! Â But the latest "news flash" from our President (if you want to call it that) is - "We can do two things at one time and we must 'open up our country.'" Â That is 'code' for we must get our economy opened up in the next few weeks because when the economy looks bad at election time - he might not get re-elected. Â It is all about him after all. Â He wants everything open around Easter! Â Maybe he hasn't been paying attention to the medical professionals, the scientists or the governors - or even other countries. Â But always thinks he knows best of course. Â Experts be Damned!! Someone with no governing experience, no scientific experience and no common sense - knows better than anyone else! I will continue to listen to the medical professionals and the scientists (like all responsible normal adults should do) - and let the "stable genius" in our White House be proved wrong! Â Unfortunately proving him wrong involves hurting others, but there is no way around it if he follows through on his mis-guided path.So what am I actually doing with all my time?Right now baby sitting my grand daughter. Â Day care is closed and my kids are working from home - which is impossible if a 2 year old is about! Â I am thrilled to have this time with her. Â But my child care juggling skills are little rusty. Â The latest example of my short comings involves potty training. Â Not mine but hers!! She is almost potty trained and gets it right most of the time but when she is deep in thought it becomes chancy. Â Suddenly she raced to the toilette yelling "potty, potty, potty." Â I, of course, race after her, saying "hold it, hold it, hold it." Â Ha! Â Neither of us is consistently good at this. Â She was very wet by the time she reached the toilette, so I lifted onto the seat and left for a moment to get some dry panties, pants and socks (very wet). Â Sincerely, I wasn't gone long. Â And when I returned she had unrolled a whole roll of toilet paper onto the floor - with a BIG smile on her face - a "loving life" smile. Â Yikes! Â Now-a-days toilette paper is like gold, so I wrapped it back up - laughing at myself.Then there is Country House Gent presents Travel's By Narrow Boat! on Amazon Prime.I googled the description of this 7 season show:Back in early 2016 and with his 50th birthday around the corner, Kevin Shelley (AKA CountryHouseGent) could feel the longtime stresses and strains of his modern lifestyle beginning to have a very real and serious effect - both mentally and physically. So by early 2017 and with almost all of his worldly possessions now sold, he packed the remainder into his camper van and set off to purchase what would become his new home - a canal narrowboat called Aslan. Thus began an amazing journey, not just along the UK canal network but also in the body and mind of Kevin. Watch as, episode by episode, he slowly transforms from an overweight, red faced, eternally exhausted and unshaven figure of a man, into a leaner, tanned and rested unshaven figure of a man. Along the way, he'll visit many new and undiscovered (by him) places, as well as demonstrating a penchant for the occasional pork pie or bacon and egg sandwich.I LOVE THIS SHOW!! Â I could actually see myself doing this! Â How wonderful. Â Very interesting, relaxing to watch, images of England I will never ever see on my own! Â I love life style shows and this is one of the best. Â So yes, there is more TV of the wider world - that has not Covid-19 virus in it.And I have been asked to fill a position on the Board of Directors of my community until more than "10 people can gather together again" and we can have an election. Â Ha. Â I have volunteered a bunch of time for them this past year ... so not much has changed when I took this position. Â Still doing the same stuff. Â But I feel committed to helping and making a difference in the place that I live! Â This is how I do it.Other stuff such as knitting and weaving are mostly done in very small batches. Â Maybe once day care opens again I will find more time for these hobbies. Â Widen my narrow world a bit more!So that is it from my little 1375 square feet of space in the mid-Atlantic in the USA!How are things in your little piece of the planet?

title: Real Life - that feels like fiction
text: It has been a week since the worldÂ turned upside down for me. Â God knows, the whole world is reeling from the spread of this virus - we are ALL upside down now.Was it just last Thursday when I dithered about if I should go to a weekend Fiber Fair just hours from my house? Â Spend some down time at the ocean. Â Or maybe skip the fair but spend quality time only with the waves and the sand. How can it be that thought process was only one short week ago?I have binged watched all the coverage of this pandemic and now it feels like I should take a break. Â My head is weary from all the bad news - and I just need to hit the 'pause' button. Â But how do you do that when each and every day the pattern of our lives changes yet again - new cautions, new closures, new restrictions, new predictions (dire ones), crashing stock market, death numbers climbing - it would be irresponsible to turn away when you need to stay informed. Â But, oh the weariness of it all.Today I realized exactly what this feels like. Â I am a huge fan of end-of-the-world fiction. Â You know, apocalypse stories, pandemics, survivalist fiction, zombies, Electromagnetic Pulse (EMP) events that interrupt the societal norm ... stuff that never happens, but is so interesting to read. Except - pandemics do happen as it turns out and other stuff in that genre can also happen. Â Ok, maybe not zombies, but real life right now feels more like fiction. Â What I want to do is just close my Kindle book right now - and everything returns to normal - until I pick up the Kindle again.Can we just have a 24 hour 'pause,' please?Maybe if we politely took a vote and everyone raised their hands for a pausewe could get one.I am getting quite good at washing my hands, wiping down surfaces (inside and out) that I might touch with Clorox wipes, making sure I stay many feet away from others, and cancelling commitments for the next 8 weeks or so. Â I am buying ahead like everyone else - maybe not enough to last months, but certainly if I buy one of something normally, today I bought two. Â Two or three of almost everything. Â Except the stores have gotten wise now - after they were totally cleaned out last weekend - and they mostly limit you to two of stuff! Â My household foods and supplies are now at an all time high. Â And I don't feel guilty about it at all. Â What I hear (since I can't seem to stop listening) is that the next 5 to 7 days will see a dramatic rise in Covid-19 cases (despite the efforts that have been put in place to slow the spread.) Â So if I don't have to go out to the store next week - that would be just fine.The first few days I was constantly reminding myself to do all the protective stuff. Â It was exhausting to be so focused on everything single action. Â But I discovered today that these cautions are becoming part of my normal way of behaving. Â I never touch public surfaces now if I can help it - and when I do I whip out the hand sanitizer. Â Yes, I have some of that golden liquid that everyone seeks - from last spring - when I got the flu. Â  And I have 3 boxes of disposable gloves spread around the condo - some in the pockets of my coats or in my purse. Â I hope all this effort makes a difference. Â I can't imagine going through an illness that can make me more ill than that flu did last spring.What I can't seem to wrap my mind around is that these practices probably will be part of our lives until a vaccine is available. Â That is at least a year away. Â We might get a break during the summer months, but this little bugger virus will be back. Â We are talking at least a year or more of vigilance as our only protection!Is it possible to be that regimented in your personal practices to maintain that level of protection for so long? Â I guess the answer must be a resounding YES!What we are really talking about is a permanent new reality!!Or, we are all living inside a novel - permanently trapped - with no way to escape!Am I just over reactingÂ or do others feels this is a unreal world right now?

title: Judging has no place in a viral pandemic!
text: Have you experienced it yet?AÂ subtle judgement because you choose self isolating behavior in this pandemicÂ even if you aren't sick?I will say that the last few days have been devoted to getting informed, make decisions, changing plans and preparing! Â In the "changing plans" arena, I have noticed there is an unexpected sea of opinions circling around every individual "self isolation" decision acted upon.No matter the subject, there can be a range of opinions all professing to be the "right one" - with little flexibility to admit that there may be no "right" decision for all - just a "right" decision for you.And so it has been with this Covid-19 virus. As the world experiences this virus intimately (at the personal social circle level) - it becomes evident very quickly that judgement plays a part. Â Person A decides everyone is over reacting and goes on as before ... while Person B decides that if you aren't distancingÂ yourself from others and changing your behavior you are irresponsible. Â Judging, judging everywhere.Maybe an example describes this situation best. Suppose you have dinner plans with a large group of friends. Â One or two decide to drop out due to the virus - and choose to avoid restaurants for awhile. Â Pay attention to the comments of others who still plan to attend:"Well, we can't stop living our lives." Â Isn't that a kind of judgement upon the person who put caution (staying home) over persistence (going out)? Â Wouldn't it be better to say ... "Everyone must decide for themselves, of course." Â "Well I have been going out to restaurants for weeks with no problem." Â Isn't that a kind of judgement ... one that really says, "See, I am well and nothing has happened to me. Â So it must be ok." Â  Â *sigh* - Oh ... if the contagion issues were just that simple.Or someone says absolutely nothing - Â offers silence as a response. Â After all - that doesn't seem judgmental, does it? Â While total silence doesn't appear to be judgmental on the surface - it can be perceived as is a negative response. Â Wouldn't someone normally respond "Hey, we will miss you this time around. Â But I understand if you need to do this."I am sure there are many little episodes similar to this one playing out in our nation right now. Â After all, our illness and death rates do not yet look like China, Italy or even Europe. Â So it is easy to wonder why this is such a big deal!!Another example of judgment is a statement like this: "Well, you can recover. Â Not every Covid-19 illness ends in death." Â True. Â Actually, most recover. Â After seeing a comparison of flu symptoms and Covid-19 symptoms, I admit thinking, "Gosh - no sore throat - my Flu swollen throat last spring landed me in the ER. Â I needed steroids to get past that. No sore throat with Covid-19! Â Ha! Â I could nail this illness with no sweat!" Â Well - I have come to the conclusion that my narrow-minded, self-absorbed and selfish thinking self is all wrong. Â It is not all about ME and my throat! Â It is about US - Â and US, folks, is a whole lot of people that could get sick (hospital level sick) at the same time. Â The rate of serious reaction and death with Covid-19 is higher than the Flu. Â We could break our health system if we didn't lower the speed and spread of infection through simple self isolation. Â I also have re-thought that symptom list - shortness of breath? Â Yikes! Â I like breathing. When this new virus popped its ugly head in my awareness - back in January - I was one of those who kept saying ---"Hey everyone, the flu kills. Â It kills thousands every single year. Â Fear the Flu!!Â This new little virus is just a blip! Â What is the big deal? Â There must be something they aren't telling us! Â Ridiculous over-response to a blip!"Â Â Well, it is now March - and I have changed my tune. Â And now when authorities (and science - let's not forget science) asks me to change my way of acting, responding, preparing - my way of living ... I listen!And here is a thought! Â If we don't take all the appropriate and cautious actions recommended by authorities,Â do we really want to end up like Italy?Ok, I am off my soap box now. Â I am heading to the kitchen to wash my hands again! Â I am sanitizing surfaces because we are expecting company this afternoon and I will sanitize again after - I want to protect others as well as myself - even if they don't believe as I do.And no judgements!

title: Indecision Resolved
text: So ... I did not go to the OC Delmara Fiber Fair - scheduled for this weekend.A lot can happen in 24 hours. Â Wednesday afternoon I dithered about whether to attend a Fiber Fair about 2 1/2 hours drive from me. Â I had it all planned out to attend. Â I started packing. Â I spent the previous 3 days getting organized so my absence from my husband was minimal. Â I was ready with only one tiny little reservation - Covid-19 was heating up on the national and international stage. Â But locally it was just a small blip. Â I would go, arrive Friday morning (a work day for most) when they opened and stay a short time at this small fair. I went to sleep Wednesday night looking forward to the weekend.Thursday morning's news was concerning.Reports of imminent school closings were repeated on the news and from friends. Â Hmmm... that may impact me. Â I don't have any school age kids, but I am my grand-daughter's back-up for day care. Â Day care establishments follow public schools in some announcements. Â Right then I decided to go to the ocean but not attend the fair. Â I could have 2 days of just me time: the ocean, my audio books and my knitting. Â And I would minimize my own exposure to this virus so I could baby sit my grand daughter.Later Thursday I heard from my daughter - who is in a leadership role in a Continuing Care Retirement Community. Â She asked if I could pick Milo up on my way home Sunday. Â There was a chance she might be working long hours and she was worried about her dog. Â Well, of course. Â Fits perfectly into my schedule.Late Thursday afternoon our Governor held a news conference. Â He announced sweeping changes - closing the schools for 2 weeks and canceling all gatherings of 250 or more people - for government, parades, religious institutions, entertainment venues and social gatherings. Â  He closed our ports, encouraged work from home and other measures designed to protect the citizens. Â While the number of reported cases remained small compared to other areas, he was taking these steps to get out ahead of the expected increases - and maybe disrupt the contagion cycle by severely limiting gatherings. Â I was proud of his actions. Â Compared to our President's methods - our Governor looked like a knight in shining armor - ready to do battle.I still could go to the ocean since I didn't plan on attending the fair anyway.Then my daughter called again. Â Her community was on lock down - meaning no visitors. Â She wondered if I would be willing to return from my weekend early to get Milo if needed. Â She was drafted into working the weekend with expected long hours ... Â for all available staff - specifically staff without children - as they expected big absenteeism due to child care concerns from school closures. Â And to complicate things, 2 members of her resident community were currently being tested for Covid-19. Â Should any one test come back Positive, she would be quarantined a long with everyone else - and not allowed to leave for 2 weeks - not even for her dog.Within 24 hours - I went from:going away this weekend and attending the fair,Â to going but not attending the fair ...Â to, finally, not going at all.It was a crazy 24 hours.Today it is beautiful outside. Â I am sure it is amazing at the ocean. Â I am spending the day getting my grand dog (who I love and would hate to see caught up in any possible 'quarantine drama,' as well as relieving my daughter's mind) and unpacking my many bags of things I was taking to the ocean.After all is said and done - I am just a little bit disappointed. Â Getting away would have been nice. But these are exceptional circumstances and require exceptional actions. Â And I would never put anything ahead of my kids needs if I could help it.But ...Â here is a message to you, Covid-19. Â Stay away! Â I am washing my handsÂ and disinfecting stuff,Â and buying ahead,Â staying out of crowds, practicing social distancing,Â and changing my personal schedule! Â It would add insult to injury if I got this stupid virus now.

title: To go or not to go!  That is the question!
text: This stupid new virus has everyone tied up in knots.Stores have bare shelves where Disposable Vinyl Gloves, hand sanitizer and face masks used to be. Â Ok, I get that! Â Kind of a helpful barrier to ward off causal exposure to this new virus - that NO ONE has resistance to! Â And then there is the bottled water and toilet paper shortage! Â What is with that? Â Someone please explain those two items to me - and why I should be hoarding them. Â That reaction seems to be connected to extreme weather events - not illnesses! Â Unless I am missing something ... that is just crazy behavior!And washing your hands! Â Well, yes, we should have ALREADY been doing this because of the flu - which I think I am at greater risk of catching even with my flu shot from last October!But still the warnings about this virus are rampant and listening to them just makes good sense. Â It is highly infectious with a higher mortality rate especially among folks my age. Â So I listen and make some changes! I upped my hand washing. Â I believe social distancing is a good idea. Â I buy some appropriate items when they are available: a box of disposable gloves and some antibacterial soap. Â I am pretty much set with hand sanitizer because of last spring's flu event! I always have an ample supply of Clorox wipes. I try (in vain) to keep from touching my face! Â (Seriously, is anyone completely successful at that?) We always have too much food in the house (I am a food hoarder who hates to cook ... go figure!) So I think I am prepared should COVID-19 pop up in my local county - which it hasn't yet! Â But who is to know - the thinking is that COVID-19 is already present in the population generally at lower levels and the only "popping up" that will be reported will be someone who gets really sick, is tested and maybe hospitalized.But here is the REAL dilemma. Â Warnings abound about avoiding large crowds. Â Events are being cancelled. Â Schools are making arrangements for 'distance' learning in our area (despite the fact that there are only 20 confirmed cases in our state. Â Flights are being cancelled because they are empty.And I have plans this weekend to attend an event. To go or not to go! Â This weekend I have plans to go to Ocean City where the Delmara Wool and Fiber Fair is held. Â This is a yearly event - small in nature - maybe 35 vendors. Â I'll be driving (no public transportation) and I planned to attend the event on the first day - Friday - when attendance will be smallest as it is a work day for most. Â In fact I am hoping to arrive as it opens. Â In the past it is not a 'sardine event' like Maryland Sheep and Wool in May where people are shoulder to shoulder at times. Â Social distancing should be easy to achieve at this March event. I so look forward to going to these kinds of Fairs - especially since they take the place of any real vacationing - Â my husband won't travel any more. At present I intend to go as planned. Â After all, COVID-19 will be with us probably now as a regular "visitor" like the flu into the future. Â I can't lead a life that is always filled with avoidance until a vaccine is available! Â My practical voice says that a few simple measures at a small event should be enough. Â But then you turn on the TV or radio and the news seems a bit grim. Â And my practical voice Â changes its message saying - is it worth the risk?But ... oh, woe is meÂ if this impacts Maryland Sheep and Wool in May!How are things in your small part of the world?Â Â Are you spending any time'preparing,'Â fretting,Â assessing?

title: Change or Crumble or ...
text: My grand daughter turned two in February. Â It was a fun and joyous event even if she was over-tired from staying up late at my house the night before. Â (You do know ... at grandma's house the rules are pretty flexible - like bedtimes!) Â Ha! Â Her cute little self is pretty much as pure as the day she was born! Â Too soon for any real negative 'foot prints' to change that little soul - because she lives in a happy loving home with two caring parents and extended family who loves her with a passion that I never knew as a child.Opening Birthday Gifts with her MomIt got me thinking about how 'life' changes you as you walk gingerly through it - stepping over or side stepping difficulties until they can no longer be avoided - and you have your very first negative 'foot print' on your child-like self. Â It could be the addition of a sibling that divides your parents' attention from you. Â Or an early form of bullying from a peer who is too young to know empathy or compassion. For myself it was at age 6 when an alcoholic father did something that forced my gentle mom to warn him away, or she would push the baby bottle she was using to feed my infant sister "down his throat." Â At age 72 I still remember that scene like it was yesterday. Â I think that was the first foot print on my child-like self. Â Other memories - less clear - followed over my childhood years - probably not retrievable as a self protective mechanism. Â But early changes such as these made me more docile than my true nature probably.School years were a struggle as well. Â I was not a good student - maybe not academically gifted or maybe just too impacted by a less than happy home. Â My memories are jumbled but I remember making friends easy - certainly not part of the "in crowd" but not an outsider either. Â Inviting friends into my home was infrequent and sleep overs never occurred because in an alcoholic home you couldn't be sure it would turn out well. Best to cover up that fact. In addition bullying is not limited to just this generation. Â But I managed to side step those issues by being willing to mold my self to the will others. Â I'd learn how to side step difficult personalities thanks to my father - it was just as easy to side step difficult peers the same way. Â Many many foot prints were stamped on me in those years by my father and by my peers. I emerged my teen years as a person who was liked but not necessarily popular, content but not necessarily happy and eager to be independent without necessarily knowing what I would do with my life. Â A middle of the road person who finds the 'middle' less foot stomp worthy.When I married I managed to side-step repeating history - no heavy drinking spouse for me. Â Chronic drinking would be a 'deal breaker.' Â And, to this day, it would still be a deal breaker - even after 50 years of marriage. Â I guess that was the first time in my life that I ever put my opinion and my desires ahead of others. But marriage at 22 years of age is a "crap shoot." Â The person you are at 22 (in many ways not fully formed) may not resemble who you are at 72! Â So it was for me. Â Lots and lots of foot steps trampling Â me forcing me to Change or Crumble. Â I chose Change. Â And change made me harder. Â Those 50 years were filled with the highs and lows of children of my own, professional challenges, and heart breaking elder caregiving for 3 family members. Â I learned step by step, that I couldn't be all things to all people. Â I learned that I was a limited resource and if I wanted anything of me left of me for me - I needed to draw lines in the sand in each and every relationship. Â Boundaries were my survival mechanism. Â Even with my own children - for whom I would give my life - alcoholism would not be tolerated. Â Thankfully - that illness has not found its way into their lives.Even my spouse - has planted footprints on me that has changed who we are together. Â Small little red flags that waved gently in my face at 22 before marriage are still waving glaringly in my face at 72! Â It is true that you should never assume you can change anything about anyone. Â Those red flags have formed me. Â After all ... it is Change or Crumble! Â I don't Crumble! Â Not in my nature. Â I got tougher, more willing to stand up for myself, less willing to choose the middle ground. Â And the changes in our married relationship that those constant red flags have forced ... have changed the nature of our married life. Â I have often commented that I am not the person he married 50 years ago. If I was, he may not have married such a firmly formed me at 22. Â He, however, is very much the same person I married all those years ago. So I guess there is a third response to life - Change, Crumble or Static!Wrestling with her dad! Â I think she is winning!My grand daughter - how I wish I could protect her from all those negative kicks in life that change who you are. Â Or maybe I should just wish that the changes in her life will all be positive ones... ones that make her a better human being as she grows. Â Strong, compassionate, smart, brave. Â Shield her from those things that make her hard, selfish, cynical and judgemental.Reading a book with her Aunt.Or maybe I should just be grateful that she has the strong foundation of 2 loving parents and close loving extended family - and with those few vital building blocks she will be able to weather all the footprints that want to stamp her out - she won't need to Change, or Crumble or be Static.She will ... Flourish!

title: My Alien Knee and My Aries Body
text: There are just some things that you have to accept about an aging body - things that can't be fixed by modern medicine or exercise or ... even magic I would guess. Â And I hate these little "reminders" that parts of me are not working like they once did.I should preface my post with the reality that my health generally is pretty good - my limitations are minimal and my mental abilities have not yet begun to decline. Â Maintaining my mind is a major consideration when dementia runs in my family. Â So I am blessed, blessed, blessed - over and over and over again to this point in life.And, yet, I find little resentments creeping up because of a left knee problem that has dragged on for more than 8 years. Â It's a nuisance really. Â A torn meniscus that has had a surgical repair and a total of 4 long sessions of physical therapy, not to mention all the money spent on hot and cold packs, wraps and over the counter medications to support and sometimes mask the off-and-on symptoms over the years. Â I was cautioned by a Ortho doc years ago that you might repair a torn meniscus, but it can tear again and again. Well heck, there should be a 'recall notice' or something on such a weak piece of equipment. It is silly for me to go on so, when I have friends and family who have had full knee replacements, debilitating arthritis, cancer treatments, and/or died early because of serious illness. It is embarrassing to admit that I have just this little nuisance issue and I can't seem to accept that.So why is it I have so little patience with this little (sometimes big) knee. Â I thought long and hard about this - my resistance to even one little medical limitation that can't seem to be fixed by anything medicine has to offer or by my own force of will. My daughter would suggest that it is because I am an "Aries." Â Sincerely, I place no validity in this astrologic stuff. Â It is fun to read and try to compare it to personalities that you know, but is it true? Â I just can't buy it. Â And when I told my daughter that, her response ... "Oh mom, that is such an Aries answer." Â Haha!!So I looked up my sign on the internet for this post and found this stuff.*****Strengths:Â Courageous, determined, confident, enthusiastic, optimistic, honest, passionateWeaknesses:Â Impatient, moody, short-tempered, impulsive, aggressiveAries likes:Â Comfortable clothes, taking on leadership roles, physical challenges, individual sportsAries dislikes:Â Inactivity, delays, work that does not use one's talentsAs the first sign in the zodiac, the presence of Aries always marks the beginning of something energetic and turbulent. They are continuously looking for dynamic, speed and competition, always being the first in everything - from work to social gatherings. It belongs to the element ofÂ Fire.Â  Aries is one of the most active zodiac signs. It is in their nature to take action, sometimes before they think about it well.*****So ... crap! Â That pretty much is me. Â  Ok, to be brutally "honest" (one of my qualities), that statement is ALL me!! Â What to do ... what to do...I have come to the passionate conclusion (a strength) that my left knee must belong to another sign! Â Yes, that is it. Â All of me is Aries except this stupid left knee and I am going to have to beat it into submission. Â And I will do so by continuing my leg exercises (which I hate doing by the way ... but no matter). Â My left knee is surrounded by Aries muscles and tendons. Â I will aggressively (a failing) continue those exercises because there is a physical challenge (a strength) there. I need to resist inactivity (a dislike) and remain determined (a strength) to make this knee fit into my of my body - a body that is Aries 'proud.'I still don't believe in that Zodiac stuff! Â But if I have to be like any of those signs - I would have chosen Aries. Â Ha. Â I don't believe, I don't believe, I don't believe. Photo Credit: Topping.comAries sign is the RamI bet all the Ram's knees work just fine!How's that for an Aries-attitude post!!

title: Finally Grown Up
text: It had to happen sometime.Â I am finally a responsible mature adult!Â Â Glad it happened at the grand old age of 72.Â Â I would hate to have gone through my whole life and never reached that state.It took a Flu bug back in April 2019 to force this evolution upon me. Â It was that illness that made me realize I wasn't made of steel - that a little tiny virus, randomly planted in my system, irresponsibly ignored and in the end, allowed to spread to its full potential in me, and then in my husband, and in who knows how many others when I was acting like I was indestructible ... that tiny virus could be very very distructive. Â I was sent to the ER by a local minute clinic because my throat was so bad - and my eyes were blood red - that they feared I would have a respiratory obstruction if left untreated! Â Of course, that immature person who is actually made of clay had to sleep with cold packs on her throat for TWO WHOLE NIGHTS before she thought of seeking help from that minute clinic. Â Too stupid rather than immature ... Â was the real problem.And I can hear the question - did you get your flu shot last year? Â Yes, I did. Â The flu that I got was not part of the flu shot cocktail for season 2018-2019! Â But as my daughter-in-law said (she has a doctorate in Biology and works in the Bio-tech industry) - the flu shot didn't protect me from Type A flu - but it did reduce the severity of my illness. Â God help me if I hadn't had that flu shot.)This winter season I have carried this newly matured me to the opposite end of the pendulum. Â I went from "Oh well, oh hum, I am sick. No problem. Keep on going" ... to Â ..."Listen up Stupid. Â This is a warning shot over your bough. Â It can be something serious if you ignore it." It started with a runny nose and a killer sore throat on Monday morning. Â My April 2019 flu began exactly the same way. Â Out came the thermometer! Â It wasn't working. So bought a new and improved one right away. Â One of flu's hallmark symptoms is fever. Â I began checking my temperature. Â Was checking it every 30 minutes too much? Â haha! Â I looked in the mirror at my new adult self and said yes. Â So I checked it every 60 minutes on Monday. (Probably still too much but I wasn't going to miss that 48 hour window when an anti-viral medication would give the best fighting chance of beating a flu bug.) Â Twenty-four hours later - still no fever. Â (And no, I didn't get up every hour over night to check my temperature. Â I did think about setting an alarm, however. Â Ha!! After another conversation with my reflected self in the mirror decided it would be counterproductive.)I have the very best conversations with myself!Â Probably not mentally normal, but that is for another post.Â ğŸ˜ŠI did other things too. Â I didn't take any cold or pain meds in the first 24 hours. Â I wanted to watch that little bug's progression in real time through my body rather than trying to judge what was going on through a mask of medications. Â That was a big change for me. Â I really believe in medicinal fixes if there is a fix! Â I love living in the 21st century when modern medicine can help reduce or cure many problems. Â But I held off to let the possibility of a fever show its face. Â I also pushed lots of ice water ... and, of course, I had my medicinal chocolate milk shake. Â That felt so good on my painful throat. Â If you are unsure what a medicinal chocolate milk shake is - check out this post. Then I started canceling all my commitments for the next 2 or 3 days until I could figure out exactly what I was dealing with. Â I was not going to spread this around even if it was just a cold on family and friends or even total strangers. Â How's that for mature!!Finally, and most importantly, I rested and rested and rested. Â I actually listened to my body that said"Stop moving, for God's Sake.Â I am sending you the 'fatigue' signal.Â You know fatigue is another flu symptom.I can't get you well AND keep on going like I have done in the past."Â Â That was probably the BIGGEST change of all. Â The former steel-made me would have just kept going, and going, and going!! Â After all - not giving in has always worked for me - until it didn't in April 2019. Â But in the past I was never 72! Â I didn't have a body that was 'less' due to age. So the outcome?? Â As of this writing four days outmy throat is still somewhat sore but improving,my nose is still a little runny but improvingand no fever!My energy is returning.Â This is not the Flu!Hahaha! Â How is that for a blow-by-blow of a simple cold!I am treating this episode as a 'dress rehearsal' so when the real thing comes along - I am ready! Â And the real thing can be darn scary. Â As I was writing this post I had the radio on. Â They reported that a 16 year old in my area had just died from the flu. Â That 16 year old had been seen in the emergency room on a Sunday and died at home on a Wednesday. Â Sixteen years old - folks - with a normal immune system, and bursting with health and youth, just her lost the battle against a small flu virus! Â I am finally grown up - better late than never. Â  Â Listen to your body and take care of yourself!It is a war out there and some of us are losing!Get your flu shot! Â It is never too late.Medical Disclaimer:This post is notÂ meant to be medical advice. Â Check with your doctor to see if the flu shot is right for you! Â But ME is telling you:Checking with your doctor is just the right and mature thing to do.Â Â Don't assume you are made of steel.Â Â No one is - not even if you are only 16 years old.

title: Rescue Buttons
text: Yes, Rescue Buttons!It took me awhile to find a child's sweater for my niece's baby due in March. Â Searching took a lot of time. Â I finally settled on Wee Envelope by Ysolda Teague.Â  It looked simple to do and speed to the finish line was an important consideration. Â Then I hunted for the right yarn. Â I hunted only in my stash because I just have so darn much!! Â I like acrylic for small children's items. Â I know the knitting community favors wool even for children ... but the reality is that working mothers already have their hands very full. Â Acrylic is wash and dry. Â Easy peasy!! Â And Caron Simply Soft has a very nice acrylic and I have a bunch in various colors. Â So I hunted and nothing seemed quite right ... until I saw this multicolor in shades of rose. Â The yarn is called Ambre and the color is called Rosewood! Â I bought this yarn probably 10 years ago on deep discount so it was deep deep stash yarn. Â I love the colors.This yarn never found a project because although I love Caron Simply Soft and I love this color called Rosewood - the long runs of color seemed to be a challenge. Â The sweater had to be simple enough to not detract from the color changes but not so simple as to be completely boring.So I took a chance - with a short turn around time for finishing - and began the sweater in Rosewood. As I worked on it - I ran "hot" and "cold" on if it was turning out ok. Â The sweater was worked from one cuff to the other cuff - and the body picked up at the bottom of the yoke and knitted down to the hem. Â It had an interesting yoke construction. Â And the designer had 'picture support' on her web site to help those who didn't understand the written directions for the yoke. Â I was one of those who needed help.But the big challenge were the colors and the way they switched. Â I was worried that it was too busy, too much emphasis on the colors ... just too much of everything. Â I stopped working on it several times. Â I considered ripping it out and starting over in a solid color. Â Something safer, where the pattern gets a chance to shine.Then I decided to complete the sweater and give it to charity. Â I would buy a gift for this new baby. To finish it I needed buttons. Â The buttons I finally settled on I overlooked at first. Â They weren't striking as they sat on a white card. Â At some point I found these - but I kept looking. Â I wasn't exactly what I wanted but it was something. Â I took them to a bright light in the sewing section - and put them against the sweater. It was magic!!The color in the buttons seemed to pick up the colors of the sweater as you moved them. Â They are sort of pearly so as you move the sweater, the button colors seem to slide between the dark and swirly colors in the sweater. Â It is hard to catch that in still photography. Â But take it from me ... they are perfect. For a busy sweater with busy buttons, Â it seemed to work. Â I sewed them on before I finished the body. Â Glad I did. Â The more I worked with the sweater ... the more I loved it. Â One of my knitting friends suggested that I get baby jeans to go with it. Â Brilliant!!All that self doubt, and starts and stops, all gone. Â Because of buttons.They areÂ "Rescue Buttons."And, yes, the sweater is going to my niece's baby girl!! Â Now I need to go get jeans for her!!

title: Wallace
text: I don't post much about the animals in my life. Â Not sure why that is.There are some wonderful pet soul mates in my past andpresent.But these past 6 months definitely belong to my cat Wallace,Â Wally for short.Max Left, Wally RightAt 13 years of age we consider ourselves luck to have had Wally that long. Â He started out life with his brother, Max - Maximillan. We adopted them together, wanting a bonded pair. Â After years and years of 4 previous cats at odds with each other, we wanted the next set to be peaceful.I think these boys are the best looking of all our cats over 50 years. Â The first two weeks we had them, we spent $2,000 to get them healthy. Â Shelter cats typically come with various problems and we were committed to giving them a fair shot at life. Wally was underweight and ill due to lack of nutrition. During that time I had to force feed him. Â His brother Max was 'the dude' in charge - he ate first and didn't care who else was hungry. Â Max was a sweetheart, but food was his God! Â Wally was docile and waited his turn to eat! Â Once we got this pair in our home and discovered the situation, food was abundant for both. Â But old habits die hard and Wally continued to defer to his brother.MaxFor 3 years things were great. Â Wally was always "second banana" to his brother, but we kept tabs on that relationship and no one ever suffered. Â But at 3 years of age, Max was diagnosed with degenerative kidneys - a common condition for cats, but way too early in his young life. Â Between prescription food ($$$$) and subcutaneous fluids (injected under the skin of his ruff) every other day ($$$$) we kept Max alive for another 8 years. Â He died at 11 years of age from kidney failure - finally. Â But for such a long life, he should be in the Records Book somewhere! Â When vets hear Max's story they are astonished. Â "Unheard of" ... is the frequent comment.WallySo that is the back-story of the two brothers.Now we were down to 1 cat - Wally. Â Initially we worried that he would pine for his brother. Â Nope!! No pining here!! Â In fact he actually flourished. Â He was no longer the second banana. Â Wally was loving and happy now that he was the star of this household!!In August of 2019 - 4 years later - when it was discovered that he was hyperthyroid - another common condition for cats. Â Over the course of the last 6 months we struggled with medication at various strengths and appetite problems. Â We tried a large range of prescription foods and grocery store food. Â All efforts cost many dollars. Â But this guy is family so we plowed on as we did for his brother. Getting food into him was the greatest challenge. Â I had visions of my force feeding sessions with him as a kitten. Finally his eating trickled down to almost nothing. Â Was it his thyroid meds or was it is teeth. Â We moved forward with the dental and they discovered the probable cause of his loss of appetite. Â His teeth were a mess. Â After the cleaning, we took him to a recommended Vet dentist - where we were told his poor gums and teeth were not the result of improper care - but a condition called Tooth Resorption. Â His body was "reabsorbing" his teeth - breaking them down right to and into the root. Â When cats in the wild get this condition they starve to death because they cannot eat. Â It is an internal process separate from regular tooth care. Â And he was in a lot of pain as you can imagine. Â But, typical of cats, he never showed that. Â Just couldn't eat. Â Not showing pain or illness is a survival technique for cats in the wild - they don't want to become prey! Â Cats are only partially domesticated and predators by nature, so it all fits together.WallyThe total visit with exam, X-rays, surgery costs, recovery costs, extraction of 8 molars, injectable meds for pain and antibiotics ... (drum roll ... ) was close to $1900. Â Did we wince at that cost?? Â Absolutely not. Â He is now comfortable - eating soft foods - and returning to good health. Â We hope to have him for many more years. Â He is a fabulous cat and we love him dearly.WallyNon-pet folks I find don't understand our willingness to do whatever we can for our pets. Â My response is that pets are family. Â If you look into those eyes, how can you not see a beautiful 'soul' staring back at you? Pets 'give' more than they 'take.' Â And if good health and a quality life after treatment is possible - I will do it no matter the cost. Â If they are in pain and treatment will not fix the cause - like with cancer - we painfully and sorrowfully say goodbye to them, release them from their pain, and give them back to God. Â We have done that 9 times and it never gets easy! Â But for now this beautiful creature belongs to me. Â He hopefully has many more years ahead of him. Â Now that he has those pesky teeth out of his mouth, he can enjoy living again.My husband and I have lived with one or more cats our 50 years of marriage. Â I think life would be less without one of these graceful and independent animals!Rest on my dear Wallace. Â You have earned your place in our home and hearts.

title: Apologies to my children
text: Have you ever felt like a deficiency in your personalityÂ is beyond your ability to fix?Do you struggle with a "just nuts" personal behavior and you fear it will be part of your life until you draw your last breath? Â To make matters worse, could this unwanted 'whatever' behavior be a burden to your family after you die. Â And because you can't seem to change that 'whatever,' all you are left with is an apology?!?Think on it! Â I'll give you a moment. Â What would you apologize for after you are dead?It can't be the typical stuff like losing weight, exercising more or leading a healthier life, because that lack of self control only impacts you - and not those left behind after death! Â Deficiencies in kindness, consideration, generosity, gratitude or love don't count either ... because, again, after your death, it doesn't impact anyone else. Â In fact, if your are a selfish, insensitive clod in life, others might be glad when you are gone. Â Ha! But give it some thought. Still no ideas?Here is a hint!You come into this life with absolutely nothingÂ and you leave it exactly the same way.I have told this story before but its worth repeating. Â My Uncle died suddenly in his 90s. He died within a month of my mom's death. My cousin (his son) called me to offer condolences and to share a family story or two. Â One story that made a BIG impression was the positive 'gift' he left for his children after death. Â In settling his estate, his children entered his house to prepare it for sale. They discovered a house almost totally devoid of everything, except the actual items he needed for living. Â  Closets and cabinets were bare, counter and furniture tops were clear ... Â the basics of living were all that was left. Â Simplicity in its purest form.Now why do I go through this elaborate exercise to only end up with an apology?I don't believe my children follow my blog. Â They may never receive this apology in the present. Â But after I die and they are summing up all the little details of my life, (which I intend to leave as neat and tidy as my Uncle's house,) Â they may come across this blog. Â They may read the title - Apologies to My Children. Â They might read and understand that I wasn't totally insensitive in the burden I left behind for them.You see, despite all my other good intentions, there will be this mountain of yarn that will greet my children when they come into my condo. Â Beautiful colors and wonderful fibers and luscious to the touch ... Â all just waiting for someone who knits to pick them up and ease them into a perfect project. Â *sigh*. Â It pains me to know that much of my yarn will 'out live' me ... still waiting in their turn in balls and cakes and skeins ... patiently waiting and waiting.I have long since accepted that I can't fix this yarn hoarding problem. Â Yes, I downsized yarn, books and knitting tools when we moved. Prior to that I did a massive inventory of exactly how much yarn I had. Â That was an eye opening and embarrassing experience. Â It did slow the flow of yarn into the house. Â I even revised that inventory a second time - only to discover that despite my best efforts, I couldn't knit faster than I could buy yarn. Â But still I struggled manage this. Â I deleted yarn vendor emails. Â I stopped buying knitting books. Â I didn't visit local yarn shops. Â I only shopped for knitting patterns that would work for yarn already in my stash!!But there were some exceptions to this 'yarn fasting.' Â  I did go to Yarn Fairs during the year - only 2 fairs and yarn was purchased there in very modest amounts (read: normal amounts for normal people.) Â And when babies joined our family, cashmere, merino and silk just didn't seem quite right for children's clothes. Â So acrylic yarns were added to my stash. Â I also added a small amount of fat yarn to my stash - I needed a palette cleansing after almost a year of skinny yarns. Â And in my defense, the acrylic and fat yarn did get used.But then this month I saw this pattern.Nuallan Cape by Jen PierceKnit PicksDarn!! Â I bought the pattern only - 'cause I love it. Â  I was sure I had something in my stash that this cape would work well in. Â  I didn't!! Â Double Darn! So I went out to Knit Picks just to look at the yarn they used. Â Knit Picks yarn is very reasonably priced, but I would need 2200 yards of it for my size. Â That's a lot of yarn. Â I hesitated. Â I set the pattern aside. Â I tried to forget about it for now. Â I talked myself out of purchasing the yarn. Â Focus, focus, focus. Â You have enough yarn! Then Knit Picks ran a 10% off sale on that very reasonably priced yarn - with free shipping. Done!The yarn is sitting my condo ... waiting and waiting! Â *sigh*.So ... to my children!! Â I am very sorry that when I die you will have to plow your way through so much yarn at my death. Â I will leave detailed instructions on how to proceed with clearing out this stash and getting it to good homes with loving knitters. Â You might consider burying some of the better choice yarns with me and some knitting needles - just in case there is no yarn in heaven.So sorry, so sorry. In an effort to redeem myself, I will work on my list of project for 2020. Â I will do my best to avoid these impulse purchases. Â But I won't go into any 12-step program to fix this problem. Â I just don't wanna!! Â I will apologize over and over again - probably until the day I die. Â And I will keep knitting.Dear children. Â So sorry. Â Love, your mom!

title: The Quiet Month
text: Finally I have reached the best month of the yearÂ that I earned by surviving the previous two months. Â The Quiet Month ... January!I love everything about January.I love the absence of holidays, the routine of each day, and peaceful weather that has done all its contortions to change the seasons. Settling into the placid pace of winter is the reward. Â Even when there is a snow storm - it usually approaches quietly no matter how intense it becomes. And a snow event leaves behind a beautifully clean white blanket ... hiding many of the ugly signs that man has passed this way.Even my frantic decluttering mojo that struggled to make space around me has passed, as I knew it would. Â It will return, but for now it is hibernating. The whole of January is like a pause that allows time for rest and recharge. Â No distractions from the chilly outside world or demanding holidays.For me - January is month made more special because of the full display of all the seasons in my area. Â How fortunate I am to live where the four season equally share the spot light. Â Folks who crave heat and love living in more southern climates miss out on some of nature's best displays of energy and wonder. Â How sad it would be to never enjoy Fall's breathtaking colors, Spring's budding and waking, and only have Summer's showy lush greening and growing day after day after day. Â And those that live in areas where Winter is King and night never seems to end also miss out on some of the qualities that Summer contributes. Â  Without all those experiences, January might lose some of it luster for me. Â Because of the seasons, January makes its own quiet statement.As interesting and celebratory and visually stunning as those other seasons are ... I always look forward to the rest and recharge month.Let's hear it for the Quiet Month!!January.

title: Connections and Mojo
text: The restraints are off!! Â No Goals or No Resolutions or No Guidelines or No AnythingÂ that speaks of a yearly intention.Â  BUTÂ I have plowed ahead regardless - one connected link at a time in "making space"Â  just like I always seem to do every single January.And yes,all the actions were curiously linked.It started with a walk-in closet. Â This closet holds 'stuff' - paint, rags, wrapping paper, Christmas decorations, cleaning supplies, tools ... it is a catch-all closet. Â When the door is closed - it is OK. Â When the door is open - it is not. Â When I decorated for Christmas I had to practically empty the closet to get to the right boxes. Â Same struggle when I needed wrapping paper. Â Ugly! Â God forbid I should need a hammer or a nail. Â When Christmas stuff returned to storage - I did a big clean out. Â Now I can walk into the closet. Â Fancy that! Â I can actually walk into a walk-in closet!! The closet clean-out produced two bags of donations. Â My first thought - two bags - not enough to make the trip to Good Will, so I easily created a few more bags from my "guest/yarn/book/hobby room." BUT ... while tootling around in the "guest/yarn/book/hobby room" for donations ... I remembered a problem that needed my attention. Â My knitting notions and needles were in total disarray after 9 months of marathon Christmas knitting. Â The disarray was so bad I was forced to buy several circular knitting needles in sizes that I already owned but could not find. Â *sigh* Â Now I have an organized knitting notions bag - an actual tote size bag. Â (Yes, I have a knitting notions problem.) Â  And finally, all the knitting needles are back in their 'homes' ready for the next project. And speaking of the 'next project,' after wandering around in my knitting supplies, I pulled out all the knitting projects that I set aside to get Christmas projects completed. Â Yep! Â I did a little line up of things that needed finishing.Finally I was done. Â 'Stop looking at stuff' I cautioned myself. Â It never ends. Â Best to do something that really need doing ... like bill paying.Ha! Â I am so naive. I set myself to working on bills. Â Of course, my wandering eyes drifted towards the 5 inches of filing that I put off for months. Â At the same time, Â I remembered that I needed to find a specific proof of warrantee that my previous searches didn't turn up. Â  Filing followed bill paying. Â And a search for a specific paper followed filing.Filing done! Â Warrantee info found. Since I am not a fan of filing, I decided to distract myself with a cup of hot tea. (Seriously, a cup of tea ... where could that lead, right?) See, I am a coffee drinker, but for some reason I have boxes and boxes of different kinds of tea. Â And much of it never gets consumed because most teas upset my reflux. Â (Bet you know where this is going ... ). So with a ton of tea taking up space - most of which I cannot drink - I decided to thin it out. Â I made several cups of tea to taste, and I pitched near 100 tea bags in the trash. Â I still have a life time supply of tea, but it felt good to get rid of the stuff I couldn't swallow.NOW I am done!!(Does anyone believe that?)My knitting activities will probably lead to a much needed reduction in knitting patterns and books. Â My tea tasting adventures will definitely lead to a much needed clean out of my messy pantry. Â Who knows where this 'clean out fever' will connect to next.January always seems to trigger this fever in me. Â List or no list - ironically downsizing and cleaning out usually makes an appearance in my New Year. Â  This year it popped up spontaneously without a set of New Year goals. Â It felt wonderful to just do what was in front of me rather than what was on goals list. Â  All that was needed was the mojo to do it!But here is the really satisfying thing.Â If the mojo goes away - oh well. Â I got a lot done while it was here. Â It will return. Â It always does!Â MeanwhileÂ Â "Clean Out January" - a very satisfying thing to do!!Â Â A lovely way to begin the New Year!

title: Grand Master Plan for 2020
text: This is the time of year forÂ goal setting,Â project development,Â and resolutions! Â Newspaper, magazine, blogs ... all seem to have some version of those elements displayed in their recent issues/posts. Â All provide inspiration and sometimes guidance for making next year count!! Â Make it the Best Year Ever kind of thinking.Â I have been guilty of all those year-end activities in previous years! Â And I have relished reading about others goals as the clock rolls over to a new year. Â In fact, I built a successful professional life around being organized and goal-driven. This year I have a **New** Â Grand Master Plan for 2020. Â It is a brilliant and daring idea - and a 'first' for me!! Â Potentially life changing and yet simple. Â It belongs on a magazine cover!! Â Drum Roll, please. There is no Grand Master Plan. Â No goal setting.No project development.No yearly to-do lists.Â No nothing!!Deep breath! Â Trying to wrap my brain around that single idea.But saying and doing are two different things. Â What does 'the doing of nothing' look like?Since I have never done this before I couldn't help wondering if there were guidelines for such a decision. Â You know ... a "how to" for planning nothing!! Â I have never seen anything that comes close to implementing that course of action. Â  With no guide or sample of how to do nothing successfully, how does one get started?? Â  And once started, how does one keep it up?Of course, my brain is having trouble imagining such alien concept and it was looking for a crutch!! Â Go figure. Â It takes a type-A personality like mine to look for Â the "right way" of starting and doing nothing. Â Ha!For starters ... I am pretty sure that doesn't mean the death of daily to-do list, or weekly menu planning, or shopping lists, or weekly calendar management. Â I am all for breaking out of my rigid mold a boldly following a new direction, but a 72 year old brain still needs some structure after all. Â To me it means I have no overlying goals or "special words" or New Year's resolutions or lists of major projects ... to achieve for the next year. Â None!!Summed up in a single sentence:I am not layering on top of my everyday lifeany more expectations than I currently have to get through each day.Â (I wonder if I should write a book about that.)Â ğŸ˜†While I glory in the newly minted feeling of freedom that planning nothing for the new year provides, I have a sneaky suspicion that some people have approached the New Year with this attitude for a long time. Â For me, however, it is ground breaking. Â It might even be another level of maturity or increased confidence! Â Maybe just a new way to live my life.Me ... without a plan!Â ğŸ‘€ğŸ˜§ğŸ˜³ğŸ‘€Â Will anyone recognize me?Since I am not breaking out in a sweat or trembling or hyperventilating ... it must be the right course of action for me! No goals, no problem!2020 isÂ lookin' good!!!HAPPY NEW YEARÂ EVERYONE!!
