title: Christmas and the finished objects pictures ...
text: I have finally ...Â (this is the most recently 'finally' ... )sworn off knitting Christmas gifts. Â This year was a busy year for planned knitted Christmas gifts. Â I knew I had to start early. Â Is April early enough? Â I knew I had to remain focused on the goal. Â I did. Â And I knew I must not knit right up to Christmas Eve ... Â early December was a good deadline! Â Why? Â Because knitting Gods are quirky and can place obstacles in your way to finishing on time.The last time I had such a heavy knitted gift list was 2003. Â I planned 8 projects. Â EIGHT!! Â I started in October! Â OCTOBER!! Â For the non-knitting readers out there, that is insane! Â Who does that??? But I made my deadline in 2003. Â How? Â The knitting Gods stepped in - this time with 'help.' Â In early December my gallbladder blew up putting me in the ER - followed by a surgery, and 3 weeks off from work with the instructions to lift nothing heavier than knitting needles. Â Done!! Â I had to give up a body organ, but I made my deadline. Â That year I swore off Christmas knitting forever. Â I only have so many disposable organs!!Forever came and went however ... and here we are in 2019!I didn't plan 8 projects this year - only 3. Â A dress and sweater set for my grand daughter and a sweater for my grand nephew. Â A reasonable number in 9 months. Â What I didn't plan for was how much knitting thin yarns and small needles really is or how time consuming (and thumb injuring) some fancy knitting stitches are to old thumbs.Grand daughter's dress and sweater (Projects 1 and 2)I am very pleased with how cute this set turned out. Â Items knitted in fine yarns (fingering weight) with small needles have a wonderful finished look and drape. Â Of course, I moaned and fussed about how long it took. Â I probably won't go that thin with yarn again for a child's garment - it takes too long, they grow so fast and the use of the item is limited. Â But it was an effort of love for a child who holds my heart in her tiny hands. Â I'll knit fine yarn items for her again one day when she is older and her growth isn't so dramatic.Grand nephew's sweater (Project 3)It took me a long time window shopping through Ravelry to find this sweater pattern. Â I loved it the moment I saw it. Â While this yarn was thicker (sport weight,) the stitch creation was slower and it just about robbed my thumbs of fixability. Â The basket weave stitch in the body is interesting with a density that speaks of jacket weight verses sweater weight. Â  But I was forced to switch to stockinette stitch for the sleeves - out of the desire to avoid injury. Â When I purchased this uni-sex pattern, I planned to make one of these sweaters for my grand daughter too, but those plans went out the window quickly. Five cowls (Project 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8)I made 2 of the silver gray cowls.The thick yarn cowls were a knee-jerk reaction to so much thin yarn knitting. Â The fat yarn captured my eye in Joann's weeks ago and I purchased enough for 2 cowls - one for my daughter and one for my daughter-in-law. Â They turned out so well, I returned and got another color for me. Â Fast, fast, fast. Â One evening and one cowl is done. Â I have seen others wearing cowls made of thick yarn so I suspect this is in vogue right now. The other two cowls were thinner yarns. Â Larger cowl loop designs that are meant to wrap around the neck an additional time. Â The red cowl was a Mobius design, but I twisted it an additional time so that the front of the stitch would remain outward. Â Not sure it achieved what I was going for, but once wrapped around the neck, it is a non-issue.Son's hat (Project 9)My son has never requested anything knit. Â He did ask me to crochet matching Viking helmets for him and his daughter which I did. Â Esk has outgrown hers, and I need to make the next size up for her (January project), but I thought I would make a quickie hat for him. Â After all, I had more than met my deadline. Â And he shaves his head - so cold weather needs more than a ball cap.I finished his hat with 2 weeks to spare. Â I briefly considered looking for one other project (crazy thinking). Â Then I got sick and so did my husband. Â The knitting Gods had stepped in and smack me across my head to bring me to my senses.If anyone is counting ... I knitted 9 projects - exactly one more than in 2003. Â And I only meant to knit 3 projects. Â I wasn't trying to break any records and I sure as h*ll didn't want to give up another organ ... so next year we are aiming for moderation and no deadlines. Â That should keep the knitting Gods happy.Onward to 2020Â and the freedom to knit whatever!PS - Looking for pictures of Christmas Eve?? Â There are none! Â Can you believe it? Â It was crazy bedlam here with 5 adults, an almost 2 year old and 3 dogs in our condo (two who do not get along and have to be gated separately!). But it was fun. Take it from me, next year I won't make this picture mistake again. Â We are attending another extended family Christmas party on Saturday. It is at my sister's so the pressure is off me and I can focus on pictures. Â Promise.

title: Begone December 2019
text: That's right!I want December to be gone from my sight!Call me a Grinch! Â If I remember correctly,he wasn't all bad.It has been a hard month health wise. Â It started with a cold for me - minor, but still a bug that weaseled its way into my body. Â I think I called it Cold Number 1 in my December 3rd post. Â No sooner did it leave me, then my husband started with a GI bug that got into his body. Â You know the kind ... nausea and other unmentionables better left unsaid. Â But his GI bug was accompanied by a fever, and then losing consciousness, (a new twist on an old problem for me), and then a call to 911, and then a visit from the nice EMTs. Â He recovered his consciousness and refused a hospital visit, but was sick with this bug for about 4 days total.During that time my daughter needed my assistance with transportation to a dental appointment that might have ended in conscious sedation for a procedure ... it didn't, thankfully. Â Small blessings. Â But no sooner did I return from that then my husband's bug jumped ship and decided I was a good candidate for further havoc.Nine ugly hours after it started with me - I finally began to feel human again. - no fainting and no fever, but me and my toilet .... well, we are 'buds' now, and my ribs still hurt 48 hours later from trying to empty my stomach that was already empty when I started.In between all that fun and frivolity I was busy making appointments for my husband for lab work, a CAT scan of his brain, a new patient appointment with a Neurologist and the EEG that doctor wants him to have, and a new patient appointment with a Cardiologist. Losing consciousness gets everyone's attention!Here we are on December 22 and my daughter calls. Â She feels sick. Â I am desperately hoping that while I was helping her with the dental appointment I wasn't also infecting her with whatever that GI bug that might have been hiding in me when we were together.Oh, and did I mention that my cat, Wally, was diagnosed with a hyperthyroid condition last month? Â He stopped eating the prescription food for this condition this month, which had the condition under control, and he isn't been interested in taking the medication no matter how I disguise it. Â Cats are so particular. Â So we are at a stand off at present - but that is only for this month. Â Untreated hyperthyroidism kills if not treated. Â I may have to force feed that pill down his gullet to save his darn life!!And to add insult to injury, I am not a big fan of Christmas anyway - my dad died 2 days before the holiday and my mom died 3 days after the holiday. I struggle at this time of year.Probably the only thing that is keeping me from totally checking out of this whole terrible month - is my dear grand daughter, Eskarina. Â She has reached the age where the wonder of the season puts a sparkle in her eye, and this grand mother would rather die than snuff out that light. Â Those tiny little 20-month old shoulders shouldn't have to carry even an ounce of burden because of my bad luck.My husband's GI bug is gone but he thinks he is starting with a cold. Â I am better from my GI bug. Â  With any luck Cold Number 2 will hit me around New Years. Â My daughter is still an unknown as of this evening. Â My daughter-in-law mentioned that Eskarina seems to be starting with a cold as well. Â She awoke this morning saying, "Buggers in nose." Â (Buggers!!! Â Who taught her the word 'buggers'??). Â But day-care is just one big cold-virus factory, so the fact she has a cold is not too shocking!So everyone ....Happy Holidays!!(Aren't you glad you aren't anywhere near plague central?)PS - I promise to stop in again before the end of the year to provide pictures of my finished projects (shots are in the camera), and a few pictures of Christmas Eve with Eskarina. Â And to provide proof that I participated 'joyfully and fully' in Christmas - despite everything!!

title: A Journal Of A Different Type
text: Weeks ago I became aware of a type of journaling that I never considered.Like a seed, it got planted in my brain and has bloomed into a new possibility.Years ago I wanted to keep a traditional journal. Â You know ... the hand-written kind using paper and pen. Â I think of it as an analog version of blogging - but a private one. Â Five days into the process, however, I decided it was too cumbersome for me. Â My brain did not engage with my pen well at all, and when it did, the first words would be not quite right, crossed out, erased, edited, ending in ... a mess. Â I wanted to be neat and clean, but my writing is neither neat nor clean. Â I deeply edit over and over until my brain narrows things down. Â Blogging on an electronic platform allows all that massaging I need and is why it has been such a consistent practice for me - even if only episodic as of late. But recently I discovered a journaling method that won't leave my brain. Â It is called 5 Year Journal.A 5 Year Journal typically presents as a normal diary that assigns each day of the week to a full page, but each page is divided into 5 equal sections - one section for each year. Â As shown below - all the journal entries for January 1 are shown on one page. Â The first year of this journal you are writing only in the top section. Â Then when January 1 of the next year rolls around again, you return to the January 1 page once again drop down to the second section for your entry. Â Obviously these are short sections - usually only 5 lines. It is just a short snap shot of what is on your mind on that day. Â Brief, concise, specific entries.Doesn't sound like me at all, does it!! Â Ha!In my research of these journals, I discovered that some versions offer a one sentence prompt per day. Â I was intrigued by that idea as I don't feel my personal life is all that eventful or interesting. Â Then I drifted into the possibility of only one word prompts - something to comment on as it relates to your life. Â The choices of journals are beyond describing. Â Some of the books are leather bound creations of great beautiful. Â Some books' pages are stitched into the book while others can be refilled or switched out. Â There are small books and large ones. Â There are expensive and cheap ones. Â Believe me - if you have problems with choices, don't Google a topic - it can be overwhelming.But still it attracted me.I tried to determine why this type of journaling was haunting my thoughts and why did I feel like I must begin one this January 1. Â It was hard to put my reasoning into words - maybe a sign that I was attracted to the materials rather than the practice of a 5 year journal. Â So I Googled "Why keep a 5 year journal" thinking maybe someone's words would capture my thoughts. Â Hahaha. Â Like Googling something EVER made anything more clear. NOT! So after much thought, here is what I have come up with from my own brain!If I looked back over my last 5 years - if I had started writing a 5 year journal in 2014 and I was writing in the 5th year of December 2019 section today - I could look back at all the Decembers - specifically I would see that in December 2014 I struggled with mom's last days, facing her death, struggling to do the right things for her. Â I would find it interesting to see what my mind and heart were dealing with at that time 5 years ago - the things I felt important to put into words. Over the last 5 years other changes have happened as well. Â Big ones. Â We moved. Â I became a grandmother! Â I reconnected with a childhood friend. Â I lost 2 dear friends. Â I had knee surgery. Â The list goes on. Â My life was eventful in many ways. Â I think as time passed, and I approached this book to post another entry, I would find interest and remembering of things that happened to me on those dates a year or more ago. I sort of wish I had that book today.But looking back is only half the story. Â My next 5 years will also be filled with events - some sad and some joyful. Â I think about the next decade or so - and at 72 it is a daunting thought. Â My brain shies away from what the future might actually hold at this point. Â Might it be a good idea to put pen to paper now in an abbreviated way to capture these last important years for myself?Why doesn't the online blog do this? Â Well, for me, the blog is a public forum, but a written journal is a place where only I will visit - a private thing. Â I seldom look back in my blog to past entries, but in a 5 year journal that snap shot entry would be evident every time I opened the book. Â Is that important? I am not sure - but I wish I had the previous 5 years recorded in a useable way.I think if I were younger and had the expectation of many years ahead of me - I might not see a value in this kind of journaling. Â But time passes by very very fast the older you get and sometimes the brain starts to stutter a bit. Â Somehow putting pen to paper puts more stability and continuity into my daily living than launching a blog post into the great electric unknown of the web. Â I will still blog because there is a social interaction in that type of journaling that is good for the soul. Â But once the post drifts into the distant past ... it fades - no matter how important the topic was. Â The 5 year journal seems to fill a different need.Will I still have problems putting pen to paper? Â Probably. Â I guess it is time to exercise a 'mental muscle' that hasn't been used since the 90's - 'from brain, to hand, to pen, to paper.' Â It will be hard at first - but new skills are good for old folks like me.So I think I am going to start this for 2020 and hope it goes to 2025! The journal is ordered. Â Leather covers, but mid-priced and refillable as opposed to pages stitched in place. Â I might change my mind on that after I see the book in my hand. Â I loved some of those leather imprinted covers. Â I have opted for blank pages - knowing I can set up the dates and the years easily. Â I might change my mind on that as well. Â I may use one word prompts for each day of the year Â - but who knows, I might ... you know, change my mind on that as well. :-)Have you kept a paper journal?Â Have you heard of 5 year journal?If so ... Â how has traditional journaling worked for you?And why did you keep a journal?This 'journaling mind' wants to know!!

title: Little Discoveries
text: You would think after 72 years on this earthI had these simple discoveries under my belt!#1 Medicinal Milk ShakesYes, there is such a thing! Â While I was recovering from my first (and shortest ever) cold of the season, I made a wonderful discovery. Â Medicinal Milk Shakes. Â I am sure that any flavor would do but for me it was a Chocolate Milk Shake at my local Chick Fil-A drive thru. Â I was on my way home from shopping for Christmas and decided to pick up some grilled chicken nuggets - no sauces or breading - just the grilled chicken nuggets. Â Yum! Â Waiting in line I decided to "balance" my healthy choice by adding a little treat. Small Chocolate Shake. Â My head was stopped up tight and mouth breathing was what was left to me - so to reward my mouth for doing double duty with at milk shake! Photo credit - Chick Fil-ADiscovery - the cold of the milk shake against the roof of my mouth suddenly shrunk my sinuses cavities enough that I could breath normally! Â Wonderful discovery - worked wonders. Â Try it! You're welcome!Â Â ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹I am thinking of experimenting a little further ... using milkshakes to ward off head colds! Â I believe that in a world filled with useless studies (just listen to the news most nights), this question has never been explored. I am willing to "take one for the team."#2 Fatter is better!This discovery is a little more troublesome. Â You would think after 20+ years of knitting, I would intimately understand the importance of gauge and needle size. Â Apparently I felt after you passed size US10 knitting needles ... fat is fat no matter what the pattern says.The third color is a cream andÂ not available for pictures as it is on the blocking board.I finished all the "tiny-knitting-needles-and-skinny-yarns" knitting for Christmas projects. While I was adding buttons, care labels, and sewing all the loose ends, I got the desire to "go-fat." Â (And this has nothing to do with the milk shakes, in case you were wondering.) Â Weeks ago I picked up two skeins of Bernat Mega Bulky yarn in cream and silver gray at Joann's ... Â I was drawn to the big stitches, the softness of the acrylic (they have really made great strides with acrylics) and the desire to have instant gratification project in my near future. Â The 'near future' had arrived.Silver Gray and PlumColors are truer to the actual colors.This yarn is so thick the pattern calls for size US 19 knitting needles. Â The largest size I had was US 15. Â No matter ... 15 or 19 .... both are fat! Â (Knitters and crocheters - I give you permission to cringe right about now!) Â I charged into a one skein cowl pattern in this squishy soft wonderful yarn! Â So fun! Â And as expected I had a finished a cream colored cowl in a matter of a few hours. Â Boy, I needed that!! Â Start to finish in one sitting. Â I tried it on! Â Hmm .... Â Seemed a little tight. Go figure! Â Gauge counted!! Â Ha! Â A fatter needle was needed, I returned to Joanns to purchase more of the cream - Â I would just add to the cowl till it fit better. Â Of course, the cream was sold out. Â I wanted 2 cowls for gifts so I decided to buy yet a third color (for me) and the (very important) US 19 knitting needles.This plum one is for me.What a difference it makes to use the right size needles! Â The cowl fits as it is supposed to - with the right amount of ease and drape. Â I decided to take the lazy man's way out on the cream cowl and try to block it a bit bigger. Â The jury is still out on that effort. Â Blocking acrylic usually is not suggested but since THIS acrylic is "hand wash, lay flat to dry" (unusual for acrylic), I am hopeful that blocking adds the needed positive ease.So lesson learned. Â Fat is good. Â Fatter is better!How I wish that was true in my body one other area of my life.Â ğŸ˜Â #3 Â Learning from my experiences is not my strength!This fall while racing to complete my Christmas knitting projects, I fretted internally that I would not meet the deadline. Â Retired to me means - a deadline is 'four letter word.' Â Deadlines are meant for other people who live their lives by the clock - as I did for so many years. Â I cursed my deadline setting.All that frantic knitting and worry meant that I was done earlier than I expected. Â Hence the interest in knitting a cowl, then 3 cowls, and if that wasn't enough ... a man's hat! Â This hat is for my son who wears his thinning hair military style - shaved close to the scalp. Â He isn't one to wear a hand made sweater, but maybe a hat. Â I can get that done before Christmas, right??The color is called Blueberry!Â And if I am reeeaaallly fast, I have enough yarn for a scarf ... before Christmas!!! *sigh* Some people just never learn from their own experiences!The yarn used is one of my all time favorites called Waterlily by Classic Elite Yarns, an extra fine merino wool made in Italy. Â It was discontinued years ago, but before it left the market I stocked up and my sister stocked up. Â Then my sister moved to mostly weaving. Â She traded all her Waterlily to me for my most of my weaving yarns since I am not weaving - well .... not at the excellent level she weaves. Â My Waterlily stash is now huge and making this hat has reminded me just how much I love this yarn. Â It is soft, easy on the skin for wool and has a lovely bounce back when squeezed. Â Stitch definition is perfect. Â It boarders on an Aran weight, but can pass for Worsted Weight. Â And it has subtle colorations - reminiscent of a kettle dyed yarn. Why this yarn was dropped from production baffles me! Â In all my years of knitting, I have never found a yarn I loved more.ğŸ˜ğŸ˜My next post will be all the knitted projects I did for Christmas - before they are wrapped.

title: Head Cold
text: So ... let the winter 'bugs' officially begin their romp through my immune system - (even though we are technically a few weeks away from the first day of winter.)ğŸ˜·ğŸ˜·ğŸ˜·ğŸ˜·ğŸ˜·Last year I had a grand total of 5 colds of various descriptions. Â It was a record number for me for one season. Â And just to top things off with a grand flourish, in April I got the flu despite getting the senior flu vax. Â Spring was in full swing, sun was shining, flowers blooming, temperatures exquisite - and I was down with the flu. Â Not a touch of the flu either (is there such an 'animal'?) but the full-blown 2 to 3 week variety that actually landed me in the ER at one point so we could get my swollen throat under control and avoid airway obstruction kind-of-flu!!!Yeah ... Â believe me, I was glad to see the end of that cold and flu season.Fast forward to this merry month of December!Symptoms began on Sunday and I chalked it up to allergies. Â By Monday I was sure it wasn't allergies but the beginnings of a head cold. Â Oh Joy! Â It isn't even winter yet. Â No fair starting early. Â I kept going with my to-do list - except I cancelled my night out with friends. Â Friends don't make other friends sick - especially when the friends you are seeing are all around your own senior age!Today, Tuesday, I got up at my normal time and decided... hey, this head cold isn't advancing - it is just stuck in my sinuses. Â It is pretty much the same as yesterday. Â Great news! Â Really!! I had breakfast and then decided to lay down for just a bit before getting dress. Â I awoke at 12:30. Â Yikes! Â I got up, got dressed, had lunch and answered some email, and before you know it, it felt like nap time again! Â Literally I was standing for about 15 minutes and sitting the rest of the time. Â Another nap was ridiculous. Â I cancelled today's activities.I did think b*tching about this cold was not ridiculous. Â So here I am. Â I cancelled tomorrow's activities. Â Being pro-active.This minor cold counts officially as Cold #1 of the season.One down, four to go. Â I think I will skip the flu this season.Â I wish I had thought of doing that last year!!My 2019-2020 goal: Skip the Flu.

title: Getting in under the wire!
text: Here I am slipping off the November calendar into December without leaving a post! Â I am fixing that right now.November has had its ups and downs. Â It started out UP! Â Going into November I was eager for the coming season. Â Winter is just around the corner! Â My favorite season. Â But then it began to slip.It began with several sad announcements that always seem to come in threes: the death of a long time friend from cancer, the death of my mom's 94 year old Long Island friend who became my friend as well, and a second cancer diagnosis for another long time friend. Â By the time we heard the third bit of bad news - I was ready to say "uncle." Â Please, please stop. Â My husband made the observation ... now that the generation before us is gone, we and our peers are the next in line - and I should get used to it. Â Sadly true. Â My mom outlived most of her friends and it was sad to watch. Â It does, however, put perspective on how I spend my own time - shedding things that really don't make a difference in life and putting more energy into family and friends. Â  Simplicity in life still remains a value for me. Â But being there when it counts for those you care about is worth the complexity it adds. Â The friend with a second cancer diagnosis is a single guy with little extended family. Â His friends will be pitching in to drive him to his treatments. Â I will be on that volunteer list. My physical therapy sessions continue but reduced to once a week. Â Progress I guess. Â The leg is now stronger. Â Maybe too soon to expect the symptoms in my knee to be resolved. Â But the exercises do make my leg feel better. Â It is just frustrating to know that I will have to do these exercises (in both legs) for the rest of my life. Â Falls for seniors are the #1 cause of hospitalization ... and in older seniors - #1 cause of death. Â It was true for mom and it was true for her Long Island friend. Â I have added a 5 pound weight routine for my arms to my regular exercise. Â My grand baby is growing and gaining weight - although she is still a string bean - and I want to be sure I can continue to lift her.My Christmas Tree and Esk's chair with Santa Cat!Christmas preparation is well underway. Â My daughter helped me put up my Christmas tree the weekend before Thanksgiving. Â That is a record for me. Â I actually dislike decorating the tree and put it off 'till I have no choice. Â It is a small tree so there is no excuse for it. Â And I do enjoy it while it is up. Â Thank God for beautiful and helpful daughters. Â Shopping is happening mostly on line so it is not too painful. Â The next big goals are gift wrapping and party prep for a December 15 event at our condo for some friends - and finally, Christmas Eve prep for the family at our condo. Â Christmas Day is usually a day of rest for me - but this year I will either be sitting in a chemo clinic with my friend or visiting my parents' grave site. Â They both died within days of Christmas - so that is always part of my holiday.And .... Ta Da!!!! Â Big announcement. Â My grand daughter, Eskarina, finally calls me "ga-ma" ... her version of Grandma. Â It is music to my ears. Â In fact, we had a sleep over last night and I got to hear that over and over and over again. Â Ha. Â I would be standing in the kitchen and she would be coming from the living room chanting Ga-ma, Ga-ma, Ga-ma, Ga-ma, all the way into the kitchen. Â I, of course, came to meet her half way - asking what she needs. Â She smiled up at me and just said "hi." Â Its like she is making sure that this is the best word to get my attention! Â It works and I love it!! Â She went back home this afternoon and the house is like a morgue. Â The quiet makes my ears ring! Â She will be 2 in February ... the adventure is just starting! Â Thank you God for giving me this grand baby!!Knitting is happening at a snails pace. Â Oh, I am not knitting slowly. Â I am knitting fast and a lot, but the projects I picked were designed for thin yarn and small needles. Â What ever was I thinking. Â I won't ever make that mistake again. Â All the knitting is done - except for one sleeve which is 25% done. Â Then I have to add buttons, sew in the loose ends and block. Â I'll make it but I hate the pressure. Â It takes just one unexpected "something" to throw everything out out wack! That pretty much sums up my life. Â Hope all is well in your world. Â I'll be back in December!!

title: The Difference
text: (Looks like this will be my October post -Â now that I appear to have dropped back to only one post a month.)Time is passing at an almost incredible speed ...While I seem to be slowing down at about the same speed.Â I am more aware of time passing than at any other stage of my life. Â  In all other stages I was just too busy with other things like jobs, and kids, and hobbies, and travel, and caregiving, and whatever - to ever seriously recognize the speed of time. Â Now a lot of those things are behind me and gosh ... why is it passing so fast!!At the same time it seems I am slowing down - naturally slowing in what I can physically accomplish, mentally juggle and emotionally handle. Â In fact, although I still maintain a to-do list (a crutch for a brain that has a 30 second hold time), I generally don't feel obligated to spin my wheels getting that to-do stuff done. Â I guess that includes blogging. Â Haha! Â  I still want the list to exist so the items aren't lost into thin air - as so often happens, but I am comfortable letting them sit on that list for as long as it takes.Ten years ago ... everything I just said would be characterized (privately - in my brain) as just crazy talk. Â I would move heaven and earth to accomplish everything. Â Now I find "heaven and earth" can wait ... I am busy doing ... well ... sometimes nothing at all - just rambling around in my own thoughts.And then there is that image in the mirror.My image has changed for sure when I look into the mirror. Â I remember a time when that image got spruced up every single morning, with blow drying my hair, adding making up, and clothing myself in stylish clothes that suited my frame. Â Now I accept the fact that my image is who I actually am - and I am not so hell bent on changing it. Â In fact, that acceptance has been very freeing. Â No matter what I do ... there is little chance I will be mistaken for someone 30 years younger. Â So my focus is more how I feel from the inside out rather than the outside in. Â Comfortable clothes, moisture cream for my skin and good sanitary habits are good enough.Is it laziness on my part that I don't try to control all these things as I once did? Â Or have I just managed to accept my current stage of life?Still some of my peers resist relaxing into senior years. Â I have watched a fewÂ expound on about "never give in!!" or "never give up!!" or "push back that clock"? Â  Believe me when I say I have seen a few versions of that kind of aging ... and is far from attractive. Â If that is what they are going for - attractive - it is an epic fail. There is a trite but true little prayer that comes to my mind more and more. The Serenity PrayerÂ God, grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change,Courage to change the things I can,And wisdom to know the difference.And there is the rub ... knowing the difference!What are the things I care enough to make a difference on! Â If I accept the natural limitations of my age like ... I wake slower, I walk slower, I heal slower, I think slower ... really, what is it that I don't accept.Getting off the floor can be a struggle. Â I don't want to be that person you see in TV ads that can't get up off the floor and needs an emergency button to call for help.I want to move freely without discomfort. Â  I welcome PT and the regular leg exercises to keep myself walking on 2 legs (not 3 legs - a cane, or 4 legs - a walker.)Endurance - easy to lose, hard to get back. Â Yeah ... Â a work in progress.Â I now call my "to-do list" a "suggestion list." Â To-do lists are so over rated! Â After all - nothing comes to a screeching halt if I don't do it. Â (Gosh that was a hard lesson for my thick head to accept.)And ... I encourage the reality that everything I have just said will probably change as years pass and I am ok with that! Â Is that grace in aging? Â I don't know. Â But I am spending precious (and speeding) time rambling around in my own brain at times to figure out if 'grace' is the right word. Â I am also stepping outside myself just a bit and to observe my own travel through aging. Â Accepting some things, pushing back on other things. Â And figuring out the difference.Â Knowing the difference!I think that is my major accomplishmentÂ in this stage of life!

title: Angry White People - 8 New Rules
text: I am fairly critical of Facebook. Â I still have an account, despite my sincere effort to deleteÂ that account severalÂ years ago (by the way, they may say they will delete your account at your request - but they lie.) Â But sometimes I find really worthwhile things on this site. Â This piece is one of thoseÂ worthwhile things! Â Attention Angry White People: 8 New RulesKC ComptonFollowAug 25Â Â·Â 7Â min readA few days ago I had a great margarita at my favorite Mexican restaurant, where I visited with the wait staff , all members of the family that owns the restaurant.Â La abuelaÂ doesnâ€™t speak English, so explaining to her that no, really, that was all of theÂ queso fundidoÂ I was going to eat and no, there was no problem, got a little complex. But with sufficient broken Spanish on my part and her grandsonâ€™s help, we got it sorted out â€” and enjoyed a moment.A couple of days after that, I met a young woman from Ukraine whose English wasnâ€™t great, but we managed to have an interesting conversation anyway. She told me she wants to start a YouTube channel for immigrants to share their getting-started stories. I told her it was brilliant â€” and I think it is.Last week, I had a couple of medical tests; two of the technicians were Latinx, one was Chinese and the other looked as though he might have had a Viking up the family tree. My doctor is Japanese. My physical therapist is from India.Yesterday in Target, a young mother wearing a hijab was checking out in front of me and taking longer than her adorable toddler daughter thought was necessary. The little girl started fussing and Mom was getting frustrated, so I played peekaboo with her until Mom had completed her transaction. As she was leaving, she mouthed â€œThank you!â€ over her babyâ€™s head.Today, I went for a mani-pedi and the young technicians were laughing and talking in Vietnamese as they tag-teamed my fingers and toes. The one who spoke the clearest English asked me how long it had been since my last pedicure. I shrugged, rolled my eyes and she wagged her finger at me, scolding, â€œYou come sooner next timeâ€¦â€ and we laughed.In the past couple of months, I have eaten food from at least six nationalities (go, Seattle!) and have had personal interactions with black people, white people, Latinx people, transgender people, Asian people, gay people, Jewish people, Hindu people, Christian people, Muslim people, unaffiliated reprobates like myself, male people, female people and people who have chosen not to pick sides. And probably a number of other categories Iâ€™ve forgotten by now because I donâ€™t care. This is just how my life rolls in a diverse city, among a diverse community, with a heart that is richer for all of them.I recently read aÂ Washington Post article about the shortage of labor in Maine â€” where the population has now grown sufficiently old that the World Bank terms it â€œsuper-agedâ€ â€” and the crisis theyâ€™re dealing with because there are not enough young workers to care for all those old people.This imbalance is a harbinger of things to come for all U.S. states, the article said, butÂ particularly for those who have fewer immigrants.Derp.People from other countries have long filled the ranks of medical professionals and caregivers in this nation, but with harsher immigration policies and a public sentiment that makes the U.S. less inviting, the immigrant population will, predictably, dwindle. Not having sufficient professionals and workers to care for elderly people will be a social and economic catastrophe in a decade or less (itâ€™s already happening in Maine and another dozen states). One of the recommendations for the future is to â€œreshape the workforceâ€ and Iâ€™d bet my hat, ass and overcoat that will involve â€¦ you guessed it! â€¦ more immigrants.I wonder how some of the horrible white people we are seeing on a daily basis these days insisting in the local Starbucks that the people a table away (who werenâ€™t talking toÂ them) SPEAK ENGLISH!!! or castigating the waiter in the MEXICAN restaurant where they were buyingÂ tacosÂ (!!!) to GO BACK WHERE YOU CAME FROM (â€œUnh â€¦ itâ€™s my restaurantâ€¦â€) are eventually going to deal with the fact that their lily white bum gets wiped by a foreigner or it doesnâ€™t get wiped at all. That should be a day of reckoning, for sure.I understand that some people are convinced â€” possibly by a 30-year diet of Fox and Rush â€” that they are the master race and every one not their particular shade of beige and of their particular pedigree should bow down and make way. If thatâ€™s the way they want to play it, OK, I guess. You canâ€™t make people not be hateful. But there need to be some guidelines.Â These wannabe white separatists need to fully understand the dimensions of the narrow little world theyâ€™re condemning themselves to.If I were named Queen for a Day, these are a few of the new rules I would hereby order for all those angry white people:If you donâ€™t want immigrants to live in the U.S.A. and/or you think brown people of any type are your inferiors, you will be required to wear an indelible stamp across your forehead (not a tattoo, because we want you to have a change of heart) with a big, fat purple B for Bigot. If you are sporting this stamp, you cannot purchase anything brought to this country by an immigrant ever or made by a brown person. Food, clothing, jewelry, electronics â€¦Â nadaÂ (or in English, for you, â€œnothingâ€).If you are wearing your required B-for-Bigot stamp and you become ill, you will not be able to access care by anyone brown or from another country, especially Muslim or shit-hole countries (is â€œshit-holeâ€ hyphenated or one word? Whatever). You may die, but youâ€™ll have the comfort of dying while being right about race.You have to give up any food that any immigrant group has ever introduced here. No Mexican food, no Chinese, no Thai hot, no sushi, no Indian buffet, no soul food â€” no nuthinâ€™ but potatoes and whatever some Native American might be kind enough to cook up for you. They will retain the right to refuse. You cannot eat anything harvested by any immigrant ever. You will starve, but again, youâ€™ll retain your righteousness on the way out.You will not be able toÂ sellÂ anything to anyone from an immigrant group or with skin darker than copy paper. If youâ€™re a business owner or manufacturer or a tradesperson or â€¦ oh hell,Â anyoneÂ â€¦ youâ€™ll notice the economic impact quickly because immigrants and brown people are, you know, drivers of our economy.You must relinquish all access to any music imported from any immigrant group or via brown people. This leaves â€¦ unh â€¦ gosh â€¦ hmmm â€¦ still thinking. Even bluegrass or old-time country are out because that came to us courtesy of that pesky Irish/Scot invasion and, even though these were my people and they borrowed heavily on the African traditions already taking root in the South, they were, you know, nasty immigrants. Certainly no blues, jazz, rock & roll, hip-hop, classical (all those Eye-talians, doncha know). Maybe you can listen to some nice Native American flute music, indigenous to this country, but again, youâ€™ll have to rely on the kindness of the original residents of this continent and, frankly, some of them are weary of your bullshit.You will never be able to enjoy any electronic devices again â€” iPhones, tablets, laptops, PCs. According to the Census Bureau, despite making up only 16 percent of the resident population holding a bachelorâ€™s degree or higher, immigrants represent 33 percent of engineers, 27 percent of mathematicians, statisticians, and computer scientist, and 24 percent of physical scientists. According to the Partnership for a New American Economy, in 2011, foreign-born inventors contributed to more than 75 percent of patents issued to the top 10 patent-producing universities. Immigrants and brown people have been all up in the development of all of the electronic stuff for a long time, so â€¦ sorry. Itâ€™s not easy being racist. Buck up.Alas, no sportsball. Given the preponderance of players of color in basketball, football, tennis and such, no B-for-Bigot can enjoy the sportsball games anymore, either in person or on TV. Theyâ€™ll have NASCAR â€¦ hockey â€¦ lacrosse, so thatâ€™s something. Bottom line, you donâ€™t get to enjoy the fruits of other peopleâ€™s labor if you arenâ€™t willing to grant them as much humanity and value as you grant yourself. Very simple, actually.I could go on and on, but you get the drift. So you go ahead and sit over there in your little whitey-tighty corner, wrapped in gauze and buffered from any encounter with anyone not on your list of approved races, ethnic groups and/or gender expressions. I havenâ€™t seen this list, but I assume youâ€™ve all gotten together and worked it out, right? Because you seem to have such a clear picture of who is and isnâ€™t a human being entitled to the full rights and respect one gives to others, I figured youâ€™ve put your heads together and gotten very clear about whoâ€™s in and whoâ€™s out. Ohâ€¦ that reminds me of Rule â„– 8.8. You have to spit in a vial and/or swab your cheek and get that DNA sorted out. I knowÂ Iâ€™mÂ white because I did that and was quite disappointed that the results came backÂ white-white-whitey-whiteÂ â€” British Isles all the way, yo. I was raised being told that for sure we had a Native American ancestor (I feel you, Elizabeth Warren) and probably an African American one. So imagine my chagrin to discover Iâ€™m â€œpure.â€ You, on the other hand, may not know your pedigree and itâ€™s essential that you do. If youâ€™re going to be such a hate-weasel about racial purity, you will need to scientifically verify that you are actually pure. Otherwise we add the orange H for Hypocrisy stamp to your forehead. Itâ€™s gonna get crowded up there if you donâ€™t lighten up.Meanwhile, the rest of us are going to go about our daily lives, enjoying each otherâ€™s company, benefitting from mutual relationships, taking pleasure in varieties of flavor and music and accents and skin colors and ages and religions and hair styles and personalities different from our own.Just being, you know, decent human beings who are grateful for each otherâ€™s presence in this delicious world we get to live in together.K.C. Compton is a journalist living in Seattle. She has worked as a columnist, reporter and editor at newspapers throughout the Rocky Mountain region and is a former editor withÂ Mother Earth News. title: What I remember - 9-11!
text: This is my 9-11 post from 2015! Â I am repeating it again - as it is my only statement on this tragic day! Â This is what we must remember. To remember only the sanitized patriotic images that float around the internet does a disservice to those who suffered and died!This is what I remember!9-11Every anniversary of this terrible day the TV, the blog-sphere and social media is flooded with 9-11 remembrances.I support remembrances. Â We must remember.What I don't support are the images that emotionalize, sanitize or minimize the truth of that attack. Â Beautiful waving national flags, a tearful statute of liberty with the smoky towers behind her, the struggles of the heroes to save lives ... those images do not show the terror, the desperation and the horror experienced by the innocent lives trapped in those burning buildings. Â To remember that day with vanilla patriotic images fades the stark truth. Â It separates us carefully and gently from the actual ugly event.I don't think we should do that.This is the imageÂ we should hold in our minds.RememberÂ this man!RememberÂ that some people jumped to certain deathÂ rather than stay in the inferno of those buildings.RememberÂ that as our innocent citizens fell from the buildingÂ  they knew with certainty that these were their last seconds of life on earth ...approximately 10 seconds ...RememberÂ that those on the ground belowÂ willÂ neverÂ forget the terrible thudding sounds of bodies hitting pavementone after another - over and over - about 200 times.If this post makes you upset, uncomfortable, angry, or sad, then I have achieved my goal.We must never forget the real images.This is how we do honor to those who died in that attack.Remember.Post Script:My last blog post on 9-11 was September 2012. The title wasÂ Jumpers.From the reading I have done - it appears that the New York chief medical examiner's office does not consider these people "jumpers." Â Jumping indicates a choice and would imply suicide. Â These people did not have a choice probably because of the force of the explosion, the fire behind them and the lack of breathable air. Â Because of these conditions the deaths were ruled homicide. Â It is a small but merciful distinction. Â  They most certainly were murdered.

title: My Left Thumb!
text: Will I ever learn! Â Never, never knit to a Christmas deadline!During the Stay-cation with my grand dogs I set a goal to finish the two kid sweaters I am trying to complete for Christmas. Â With hours and hours of knitting time available, I felt this goal was do-able. Â After all - my grand daughter's sweater just needs two short sleeves and 3 buttons. Â My grand nephew's top down sweater was almost to the point where you split out for the sleeves. And I have 10 whole days available!! Â I can do this!!!Sadly, my left thumb feels different. Â For me lots of knitting does not create over-use problems in my hands. Â I feel lucky ... especially when reading about the repetitive use injuries of other crafters. Â But my grand nephew's project requires more left thumb effort than normal. Â My thumb is a little cranky right now.Photo Credit: Ravelry.ComDesigner's sampleThe pattern is called Miracle Sweater by Nicole Montgomery. Â I love the gender neutral look of the garment, the dense feel of the fabric created, the jacket-like style, and the unique stitch itself. Â I also love that the proceeds of the purchased pattern are donated to a charity.Up close Twisted Basket stitch pattern.The first thing I noticed was that although the stitch was uncomplicated to create - for some darn reason "unknitting" the stitch (a function often needed to correct mistakes) was difficult to do. Â I did several gauge swatches - to get gauge - but also to learn and practice unknitting the Twisted Basket Stitch so I could fix errors when they occurred. Â I never reached a level of comfort in that unknitting effort for this stitch (actually not one single time.)My progress to date. Â Sleeves will need to be pickedup and knitting at some point.Regardless, I was not deterred by that failure. Â I started the sweater anyway, determined to avoid mistakes. Â I, of course, made a mistake within the first 5 rows of the woven pattern and made the problem even worse trying to correct it. Â So I ripped out those 5 rows and started again - learning from that mistake, convinced I would, at least, not repeat that particular error again.And I didn't. Â I made a different mistake! Â You see, the stitches are stacked on top of each other in a very specific order. Â Within 5 rows I made a stacking mistake - and one whole row along the back between the sleeve sections - was wrong. Â And it clearly showed! Â I couldn't unpack even a single stitch successfully and now I had a whole row of stitches that were wrong. Â Damn.So I made a creative decision to hide that row of errors under the generous collar by tacking the collar down so the wrong row can't be seen. Â It was an option I considered before I made the error because the collar had a lot of "bounce" in it and probably wouldn't rest easily on the shoulders when worn without tacking. Â Now that decision was finalized and it killed two birds with one stone! Â Excellent!!Second problem solved (without ripping out my progress.) I plowed on.But there are limits. Â At this point, if I cannot fix or hide an error that can only be corrected by ripping out, I will stop this project and choose another pattern ... I don't want to start completely over. Â Finding this pattern took a lot of time at the beginning. Â And I still like it.When the third error rolled around (surprised? ... not me) I somehow miraculously managed to de-construct the stitch - and mostly get it right. Â Right enough to be acceptable to the casual eye. Â Not perfect, but acceptable.Is that the end of the errors knitting this beautiful stitch? Â No chance - the risk is still very very much there. Â But if I can avoid the blinding frustration that grows with each error maybe I can avoid pitching this project deep into my trash can. Â It wouldn't be the first time I pitched yarn, a partially complete project and the pattern into the garbage.I secretly planned to maybe make this same sweater for my grand daughter at some point. Â I really love the look of the stitch, and I love my grand daughter beyond all measure, BUT, no second sweater in this pattern for me - I also love my left thumb because without it - knitting would be very very hard.Finally, there is one other small problem with this stitch. Â Besides eating up a lot of yarn (which I was prepared for), it eats up lot of time. Â  A . LOT . OF . TIME. Â In the picture above, the middle white markers show where I began 5 days ago. Â Each day was about 4-5 hours of knitting. Â That is 20 to 25 hours of knitting on a child's size 3T sweater. Â While I was knitting the gauge swatch I could see it was time consuming - but I figured that as I got better with the stitch, I would get faster ... and I did. Â But now I see how grossly off I was on time needed. Â I still have 4 inches of body to do beyond the lower edge - and 2 full sleeves!When I researched this pattern in Ravelry I saw comments like "beautiful," "worth the effort," "heirloom piece," and "appealing." Â The other observations were "tedious," "time consuming," "patience needed." Â All the statements are true. Â My mistake? Â I put more importance on the positive statements rather than the negative ones.And my thumb? Â It cramped a bit this morning. Â A sign that I am pushing it too much? Â You betcha! Â So today I am blogging about knitting and not knitting - giving this vital appendage of my body needed for knitting - my left thumb - a day off!Did you know that if you are a touch typist like me -Â the left thumb does absolutely nothing when typing?Â Ha!

title: Stay-cation with my grand dogs
text: Well, here I am on another Stay-cation with my grand dogs ... and extended 10 day stay-cation ... and I am on day 5 as I write.On a previous stay-cation with my furry grand babies I waxed poetic on how restful and free these stays are. He is a little large to sit on my lap, but his head fits just fine.Liv is even larger. Â She seldom sits by me, except for the first 24 hours when she is feeling abit lost by the absence of her owners.I sleep at my son's house, I stay until about noon each day, when I drive to my home (about a 20 minutes away) to check in on my husband and to see he has dinner - then I return back to the dogs around 5 or 6 to spend the evening till noon the next day. Â During these times, the only things scheduled are making these trips, making dinner and maybe a load of laundry. Â The rest of the time is mine. Â Knitting, binge watching TV series and dog love.Except this time!We have had a few problems medical problems - dog medical problems - this time.Olivia, Liv for short, takes these absences of her family very personally. Â She is a rescue. Â She has abandonment issues I am sure. Â She gets diarrhea - sometimes bloody diarrhea - when her owners are absent on trips. Â This time it was 'normal' diarrhea, because they started her on medications before they left - and - also an additional medication should it be needed. Â It was! Â This problem is under control and she is adjusting. Â She loves grandma (me). Â But I am second best. Â She can take second best when she has no choice. Â On a scale of 1 to 5 with 5 being a scuzzy scum-ball of a human who hates dogs ... I will be raised from my normal position of 2.0 to 1.5 by the time her 'parents' return. Â She is also the smart dog. Â Very very smart. Â Scary smart. Â So I will never be #1 because she will never forget her resucers! Â My son and daughter-in-law. Â She will never be abandoned again. Â If something should happen to my children - I would take her! Â But she doesn't know that. Â Poor baby. Â I am happy with being 1.5 in her life for this 10 days. Now, Rags! Â The total opposite of Liv. Â He has never been abandon. Â In fact, my son paid thousands of dollars for his little butt from the breeder - his little English Bull Dog butt! Â He is a lot of things: Â very self confident, very energetic, very determined, very stubborn, VERY Bull Dog! Â Except that as a full blooded English Bull Dog, he comes with all the typical inherited English Bull Dog medical issues. Â I arrived 5 days ago to dog sit. Â He was fine. Â Three days ago he was licking his paws. The start of a swelling in his left foot between the toes.I noticed a swelling between his toes on one foot. Â He has had these before, Interdigital Cysts. Â I also noticed that one of the face wrinkles was red and weepy - and not a pretty color when spread open. Â Two days ago I got him into his vet - a family vet who knows us well. Â Three feet had cysts - one foot was infected and his wrinkle was infected. Â We left with an antibiotic shot - good for 2 weeks - ointment for the toes and face and instructions. Â Orders to return in a week. Â Today things look little better, but one of his feet had some bleeding. Â It has stopped now but ...So here is what he looks like when I am gone - visiting my husband! Â Pretty sad!It is the only way to keep him from licking his toes in my absence.And when I return - there is much joy!They have a very large fenced in yard where they can safelyrun and be crazy.So this Stay-Vacation has included some nursing duties! Â Good thing I have previous medical training - and I am not shy of diarrhea, blood, or icky green fluid build ups in a facial wrinkle. Â And I am as determined and persistent as he is ... He sees me coming with tissues and he knows its wrinkle dab clean up time - and he goes in the other direction!! Â Ha! Â Grandma the enforcer is on the job! Where do I rate on that 1 to 5 scale with him? Â Remarkably I am sitting in #1 right now. Â He is a smart bulldog - a fact he keeps hidden. Â He is a forgiving bulldog - a fact he demonstrates all the time. Â He is not worried about being abandoned. Â He doesn't even know what "abandon" means. Â He looks better today! Â 'Looks' are all I have to go on - because he acts very self confident, very energetic, very determined, very stubborn, VERY Bull Dog - even with his problems! Haha!I know I will slip to #2 when his mom and dad return. Â I am ok with that.A Solid #2That's me!

title: Picture a Prairie Dog
text: I seem to have fallen into another blogging slump. Â I guess my writing mojo just becomes dormant with some regularity. Â I have come to see this behavior as "learning" and "accepting" things about myselfÂ rather than a fault or lack of consistency!Ha! Â How's that for talking my way out of somethingÂ I characterized as a failurein the past!The slump is not over, but as I trek a round reading and commenting on the blogs I follow, I realize that connecting occasionally with my own blog is probably a good idea. Like the Praire Dog that pokes his head out of his hole to take a look around ... this post is my head poking out. Â Consider it a mini update and an indication that I still live!I am fine. Â Not moody or depressed or over busy. Â Just not blog inspired.I am still knitting like a banshie. Â Christmas is coming and my gifts need to be completed. Â Next year - if I am crazy enough to insist on knitting for Christmas - I am NOT going to use those fingering weight yarns no matter how alluring or temping the project appears - sport or worsted weight knits up so much faster. Â Pictures of finished projects will take their place in their own blog posts at some point in the future.I made another trip up to Long Island with my sister to visit my mom's friend who is 94 years old. Â She is still mentally pretty good and the trip was great fun. Â She is plagued with some medical issues, but her brain still seems to be working just fine. Â This trip left me pondering if I could choose only one life status in my very senior old age which would be better: mental alertness or physical well being. Â A remarkably few people have both in their 90s so it stands to reason I won't be one of the "very few." Â In fact, if personal family history is any kind of predictor, I won't have either one. Â Could it be a kindness to one's self to not mentally know your are physically failing - rather than witnessing the total disintegration of your physical self - while your alert mental self watches? Â Ugh! That is pretty depressing now that I think on it. Â Better start pondering something else - like when does "Dancing With The Stars" return to TV. Â I feel better all ready! Â My grand daughter continues to grow in leaps and bounds. Â A joy to all my senses! Â These first two years in a child's life are just miraculous. Â Looking back one year ago - the changes are amazing. Â It may be time for another grand daughter post.My exercise mojo has its ups and downs as well. Â My left knee (surgery 2017) gets cranky at times. Â The heat here is brutal - thank you Climate Change. Â And my very expensive (but old) walking shoes don't seem to be giving me the support I need anymore - resulting in sore feet if I am standing too long. Â I can fix the shoes and will do so this month. Â Just wish they didn't cost $150. Â  The weather should break positively starting next month - and if I ice my knee before and after walking, it is manageable. Â I even re-joined the senior gym so I could use the treadmill (which I hate with a passion.). The facility is air conditioned, new and cheap by gym standards so my excuses are pretty few for not going. Â So "struggle" is the right word to describe my efforts to stay reasonably fit.Eating wise - this is my absolutely favorite time of year. Â Produce is flavorful and abundant. Â Some meals I just eat vegetables. Â So good. Â And my very favorite is corn on the cob and tomatoes. Â I think I could live on just those two things alone. Â Throw in a few garbanzo or kidney beans and it would probably be pretty healthy as well. Â And coffee. Â Need my coffee.So ... there you go! Â All caught up on my boring life! Â And just to clarify ... boring is A-OK for me. Â I have lived a long enough to have had my share of "events." Â I discovered that is better to figuratively live in the middle path of life rather than to soar high and sink low.Back again when my mojo returns or a "prairie dog poke out" seems appropriate.

title: Time to look Up rather than Down
text: Why is it that looking "Down" is so much easier than looking "Up?"Â Is it a matter of habit or is it just human nature? Â I find its too easy to look 'Down' into the daily frustrations of the current political scene, into the daily challenges of caregiving (for the third time in my life), into the realization that the plans I had for my own retirement are far from the life I live now. It is crazy thinking to look Down when Up is so much better. Â I am SO really blessed at this stage of life. Â Time to make a list and post it somewhere (oh, yes ... Â that's right - I have a blog!!) where I can page back and remind myself of one simple constant truth:My blessings are someone else's strongest desire!So here goes my Up - (in no particular order.)I am 72! Â Yes, I am grateful for that. Â The other option doesn't appeal!I am retired! Â That condition is not a given for everyone. Â I would enjoy being completely retired (retired from cooking, house cleaning, laundry - opps - look up, up up! Â Looking up ... I don't work!)I am comfortable in retirement. Â No need to baby sit every penny or eat hotdogs instead of steak. Â (Of course I prefer chicken and fish ... but you get the idea.)I have a close immediate family that is a regular part of my life - not geographically or emotionally distant.I wear the title of Grandmother proudly!! Â An Alpine-level size Up. Â A husband. Â A life partner - of 52 years duration. Â While he adds to my stress at times (like all spouses can do) he is in relatively good health and still standing by my side.I am healthy. Â God knows ... No serious life threatening illnesses. Â For my age and my "on-again off-again" focus on health - it is remarkable that the expiration date on something in this body hasn't come due. Â (Excuse me while I find some wood to knock on.)I have friends of long and short duration. Â I must not be too much a drag on them - as they keep coming back!! ğŸ˜€Hobbies and interests abound. Â I'd be lost without knitting and reading. Thank God for my hands and my eyes.Â My blog ... where I can dump thoughts that rattle in my brain and then pop out like a "Jack in the Box" explosion of angst (like my Democratic Debate Post - opps - looking down again - look up, look up!)Â Death and loss has been a rare visitor in my life. Â My husband's disability has prepared me to stand independently if I should be left widowed. Â No excuses like 'my spouse handled that.' Â (How's that for making lemonade out of lemons.)Downsizing a life is in my rear view mirror! Â My condo doesn't require a large expenditure of cash or life energy to maintain.Finally, I have my brain ... a major plus, having watched my mom's brain slowly and painfully disintegrate into nothingness ... until it finally snuffed out her life. Â Dementia runs in my family. Â That is a genetic pre-disposition bullet I hope to miss.Sure, I fret about not being able to travel, or participate as a couple in some activities we used to take joy in, or even go to the movies without feeling guilt about my husband left at home. Â But would I change any of the above pluses for yearly vacations, broadway shows, Â beach trips or hiking adventures? Â No ... I really do have more than my fair way share of good things.Â AND I am ever so grateful that while looking 'Down,' in the past ... nothing on my 'Up' list disappeared yet. Â I know that at my age, big changes can naturally be expected on that list ... but for today ... which is all any of us have ... it is all good!Do you ever do that? Â Look Down too much rather than Up. Â Or am I the only one who has to make a list and post it somewhereÂ so that my aging brain doesn't get stuckÂ in Down mode rather than Up mode?

title: Anonymous - PUBLIC SERVICE MESSAGE
text: Hello blog readers.I think I need to alert some visitors to my blog about my personal practice of handling "Anonymous" comments.In the near future, I will stop accepting Anonymous comments. I think I have 2 "real flesh and bone" readers who comment that way. Â But because of the bad behavior of a "few" - I will be ending that option in the next month or so. Â In April, while I was participating in the A-to-Z Blog Challenge, the number of Anonymous comments jumped dramatically. Â I guess that level of exposure to the internet opened me up to more JUNK comments. Since the Challenge - I checked out the Anonymous comments regularly - deleting almost all. Unfortunately the Anonymous comments have continued to grow in number and as a result, they eat up more time to sift through. Â I don't regularly review them now. Â I just delete them without opening them. Â Sometimes when the onslaught of Anonymous comments are fewer - I will open them - but generally I don't - they go right to Trash. Â So if you are an Anonymous commenter and your comments didn't show up - sorry - it is becoming just to hard to find the real visitors from the "fake" ones.Anonymous commenters - please find a way to set up a google account that will allow you to comment with an identity. If you do comment and do not use Google as your platform - and your comments typically get through to my blog - because you identify yourself in some manner - please share your method with others in your comments today. Â I hate to block regular readers (and sometimes commenters) by taking away the Anonymous option, but it will come to that at some point.Thanks.

title: Democratic Debates
text: I generally keep to the premise that my blog should be politics free. Â Politics like religion has a tendency to polarize people. Â When these topics are discussed, it often leads to "I am right and You are wrong" black and white kind of thinking. Â So I have opted to keep my personal opinions about religion between me and God - where they should be, and maintain a mostly a-polictical stance by registering as an Independent and stepping out of the loop of political discussions in all settings. Oh, make no mistake, I have very strong opinions about both - but until recently I felt my own peace-of-mind was more important than trying to sway others to my way of thinking on either of these topics.Now ... Â here I am - talking politics with these questions.Did you watch the first two Democratic Debates this past week?What did you think?Is there a candidate that can challenge our current wreck of a presidentÂ and bring our country back to sanity?Â I watched both nights. Â I know these are 'early days' in the election process. Â But the issues facing us are gravely important. Â An attack on our democracy from the inside out is happening every single day. Â We must right our course as soon as possible. Â Another four years on this self destructive path may damage us permanently.My goal in watching the debates was two-fold: Â Who the heck are all these people AND, most importantly, is there a candidate among them that can confront and stop the re-election of the worst President in our history?You will notice that I said nothing about their policies. Â Sadly, we have moved away from that kind of intelligent discussion. Â It isn't about the issues any more for most of us. Â It is about selecting a leader who will not be an embarrassment on the world stage, who will recognize our international friends and enemies without Cliff Notes, who can speak with intelligence and in complete understandable sentences, who gives thought and research to issues before Tweeting his mouth off, who will respect our democracy, our constitution, our laws, our institutions, and ALL human beings. Â We have none of that now.That was what I was looking for. Â Was there someone like that on the debate stage?There were several candidates I thought could do the job, had great ideas and could be groomed to demonstrate the qualities I listed! Â But there was only one who I believe would remain cool under the sizzling glare and auditory assault of Trump that would shower down on them in the campaign ... only one who might be able to turn the tables and make Trump look even more foolish than he is now.My pick is not the front runner - Joe Biden.Joe Biden - is a likable, well known, knowledgeable and a courteous gentleman. Â We hunger for those qualities in our leader - after 3 1/2 years of Trump. Â However, Trump will walk all over Biden in the campagin. Â Our electorate has become more combative and argumentative under Trump and would probably see Biden's positive qualities as weaknesses! Â I guarantee Trump would hammer that assessment over and over again into the electorate's psyche until voting day (and after, remember "Crooked Hillary?" Â We will ever get passed that!!) Â Don't get me wrong. Â I would be thrilled to see Biden win a general election but I don't think he could win against Trump. Â I also believe that although Biden looks good for his age, we need the energy and focus of a younger leader. Â As one debater repeated several times - It is time to pass the torch! Â I agree.My pick is Kamala Harris.I think Kamala Harris has the steel spine needed to beat Trump. Â She is direct, focused, and intelligent. Â I watched her question Justice Brett Kavanaugh during the hearings. She is like a laser beam that cannot be distracted or deflected. Â During the debates Harris was more likely to speak calmly and deliberately - something Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren can't seem to do when expressing a point of view. Â Both of them seem to slip toward the unfortunate stereo types of 'older man bonbastically talking' and 'excitable female.' Â Kamala Harris appears to have no 'skeletons in her closet' to trip her up during the campaign. And she is not an 'old white man!'Does it seem like I am focusing on cosmetic qualities rather than the real substance of a candidates' message? Â Yes ... I am. Â After 3 1/2 years of a President who is filled with warts and puss-festering talk and actions - we could do with a little polish in our leader. Â The quality of anyone's 'message' won't beat Donald Trump. Â What will beat this President is someone who can 'give as well as they get,' who can turn Trump's snappy slogans back on him to demonstrate his empty promises, and someone who can remain steady as a rock (and Presidential) while doing it! Â So far ... Kamala Harris seems to be that woman.While I typically don't care about age, race or gender in picking a leader,wouldn't it be just the MOST delicious situation EVERÂ to see Trump taken down by a strong qualified mature Black Woman!I think she could do it.I'd like to see her do it!!What do you think?

title: Apparently ...
text: Self discoveries are always interesting.I am a person of 'routines' ... apparently.When one routine 'hits the skids,' it avalanches into other routines and then I am doing pretty much nothing ... apparently.And then when I notice that nothing is happening, despite a long to-do list, it leads to a lot more nothing getting done since the world didn't fall apart when I did nothing ... apparently.Oh yes, I am still feeding myself (and my husband) but meals could not be called 'cooking.' Â Soup, sandwiches, salads, pan frying, left overs ... easy stuff. Â I am still knitting - three projects are in the works. Â Since knitting has not dropped off my radar - I know I am healthy and emotionally fine. Â The house gets marginally cleaned of dirt and clutter. Â I could probably do "clutter," but my husband couldn't because he is legally blind. Â He could probably do "dirt" because he is legally blind, but I couldn't because I can see. Â Ha!But things like exercise and blogging and dieting - things that require a routine to build on - those routines seemed linked together some how and when one of them falls - they all fall! Â As a result, there are fewer blog posts, Hersey's Chocolate Bars with Almonds are a viable food group and walking to the lounge chair from the bedroom comprises almost all of my exercise ... apparently.*sigh*I have been reading my Kindle, listening to my Audible library and binging on Netflix and Amazon Prime TV shows.My latest binge TV is The Sopranos. Â It is pretty good. Â Like The Godfather series of movies, I find myself hoping that the Soprano family (at least the wife and kids) does well and that no harm comes to them.My latest Kindle completions are:AWOL on the Appalachian Trail by David MillerandWolfhunter River (Stillhouse Lake Book #3) by Rachel CaineBoth books are excellent. Â Check out the story summary on Amazon if you are interested.My current Kindle read is:Cold Waters by Debbie Herbert. Â Too soon to tell if this will be good but I have passed my "80 page" mark which means I care about something in the story enough to finish.Then my Audible library (which was over 60 titles and now is down to about 7) is currently filling my ears with the following:Curse of the Pharaohs by Elizabeth PetersThis is the second in a 20 book series that can be called archaeology adventure and romantic mystery with Amelia Peabody. Â This is an older series of books that were hugely popular maybe 15 years or more ago and continues to have a dedicated fan base even to this day. Â The stories are fun and the 'clean' romance story line adds grace and enjoyment to the story. Â But the real star of the Audio versions is the narrator, Barbara Rosenblat. Â She handles all the accents, genders and ages of the characters with Oscar level performances. Years ago I read or listened to this series - and I have decided to do it again (rare for me to re-read anything.). I highly recommend this series.But the wagon train of exercise, blogging and healthy eating have been pretty much stalled.I am here now hoping with baby steps to get back on all those wagons again!!

title: Walking, Watching, Weight Watchers
text: WalkingMy walking life took a hit last week. Â All the Game of Thrones binge TV watching and all that knitting time resulted in low step counts (about 8,000 on average - so I guess not so low.) Â Yes, I could have watched TV and walked in place at the same time. Â But what doesn't work is walking in place and watching TV and knitting - all at the same time. Â Last week wasn't a total 'slug fest' as I did get out for a few walks, and I did my Leslie Sansone Walking Indoors DVD about 3 times (my grand dogs thought that was pretty funny to watch), but reaching 10,000 steps each day just didn't happen.However, I am now off the couch! Time to get back on that walking wagon - hmm - wagons are for sitting ... time to strap on those walking shoes and get stepping again.And I am doing that - but carefully! Â My left knee (2017 surgery knee) has been complaining a bit. Â The answer to that problem is simple - continued walking and the return of the PT strengthening exercises Â Thankfully my knee seems to warm up to the exercise if I slowly push through and step carefully. Â It almost feels normal after 15 minutes so I know nothing serious is going on. Â For now ice packs after walking, Advil and a knee brace are 'my friends.' Â (And, let's not forget the PT leg exercises to strengthen.)On the plus side - (a very BIG PLUS), Â I have discovered the many of my 'age related' complaints are minimized with all the extra movement. Â I can get up in the morning with little stiffness in my legs. Even my knee feels normal again. Â I don't seem to need that early morning 'adjustment' period of letting all my body parts 'wake up.' Â My leg cramping problems are much reduced. Â My energy levels are so much better. Â And when I feel down - going out and taking a walk fixes that problem.WatchingI don't think I ever sat and watched so much back-to-back TV as I did this past week. Â Game of Thrones episodes is like eating potato chips - you can't watch just one! Â Although I did read the books years ago and saw most of the seasons when they first aired - that was a long ago - 8 years to be exact. Â I forgot a lot of the details. Â It is fun to catch up and watch them again. Â But all that sitting is just too much after a bit. But I am not done with Game of Thrones. Â I am still watching the back seasons of Game of Thrones through the library loan system. Â Once that is finished I will be done. Â I will really really miss this series. Â Amazing production values, great story, total escapist type experience! Â It will be hard to replace that series with something else. Â After 8 years it is like saying goodbye to old friends (good guys and bad guys). Weight WatchersI started Weight Watchers in July 2018 and I went on a Weight Watcher break in December! Â I was within 3 pounds of my goal weight. Â That break was supposed to be a few weeks - ended up being a few months. Â  I guess you don't really call it a 'break.' Â It is more of a stop! Â Thankfully I haven't regained more than 3 pounds. Â Guess my eating habits have changed for the better. Â Thank you Weight Watchers.I have tried to get back on the Weight Watcher Wagon twice since December - getting on that wagon involves actually tracking what I eat and sticking to the program limitations. Â The limitations aren't the problem. Â I can't seem to consistently track any more - I never really enjoyed that part of it. Â But I know it is an important part of the plan for success.Since I am paying a monthly fee - and not really using the program, I am sorting out if I want to just stop paying for now. Â To stop paying means that I will lose access to the online features that make tracking easy. Â But if I am not tracking ... *sigh* ... I guess those online features aren't as important right now.Struggling with this idea. In truth, I don't see myself tracking what I eat forever regardless of my decisions right now! Â But the diet is a healthy one and very user friendly - so it is hard to just let go. Â Except - I think I have already let go ... by default! Â *sigh*. My enthusiasm now is walking. Â The positive feedback I get from that activity is massive. Â I think walking (and keeping generally to the Weight Watcher program without tracking) - if kept up will be the answer to holding my weight stable for now. So ... I have talked myself out of this monthly charge and moving away from formal adherence to the program. Â We will see how it goes.I can return at any time - the time is just not right now!

title: My Last Week
text: I have to say - the last week was pretty darn wonderful. Â I know I set the bar pretty darn low on the "wonderful" scale, but it was.My son, daughter-in-law and grand daughter were on a trip to Disney World in Florida. Â As the official dog grandma, I get to spend quality dog sitting time with their funny and crazy dogs when they travel. Â The white English Bull Dog is Ragnar - Rags for short. Â The mixed Hound and Mountain dog mix is Olivia, Livvy for short. Â They live about 20 minutes from me.Rags - a photogenic little guy!And a busy guy - always on the run.They are good friends generally.Olivia is the smart one - like really smart!Scary smart! Â Since these wonderful creatures are yard trained dogs vs leash trained dogs, I find it easier to pack my bags and move in with them for dog sitting. Â I travel back home every afternoon to spend time with my husband and make him dinner - then I travel back to my exuberant charges who are always over joyed to see me.What makes this time so special - beyond getting quality time with these mutts? Â The answer is easy. Â I do NOTHING. Â Beyond making sure they are fed, medicated, and loved - and yard time of course, the time is my own.And yard time does not involve just opening the door and letting them run! Â Oh no. Â If I do that, they pee and then return to the door looking in with sorrow in their eyes. Â Yard time must include Grand ma standing in the yard and watching them. Â The 'watching them' is critical to them having fun. Â It is like they are performing for my enjoyment! Â And, in truth, I do get enjoyment watching them run and play. Beyond that - I do nothing. Â Absolutely NOTHING. Â It is grand beyond measure. This visit, however, I had two very selfish goals! Goal #1: Watch as much as I could of Game of Thrones on their cable connection (I did see the final episode in really time with the rest of the world. Â Thrilling!) Â And I was re-watching the previous episodes. Â I made it through Season 5! Â I will check out season 6 and 7 from Â the Library.Goal #2: Finish knitting Esk's dress while I watch Game of Thrones. I am at the hem. Â Almost!I didn't complete either goal - and you know ... that was ok!I don't answer the phone, I don't talk to anyone, or do any household chores. Â I eat and snack when I want to and what I want (sharing, of course, with my mutts), but except for my time at home in the afternoons with my husband, my time is my own.
