Â I hate to lose and I hated watching her lose!There are a few blessedly lucky and genetically gifted seniors who live independently and in good health well into their 90s. Â THEY are the exception. Â We all hope we can win the 'Age-Well Lottery!'I no longer mourn my mother's dead. Â Everyone will die. Â It is the way of nature.I do continue to mourn my mom's losses. Â She deserved better from nature in her last years.She was cheated!One last sincere request from the heart of a caregiver.Â The next time you feel annoyed with a senior ... any senior ... try to remember -Â  almost all seniors are losing slowly with everyday that passes. Â Try to show patience - understanding - compassion. But most of all - patience!You have not yet walked in their shoes.Â Â I guarantee,Â it will be harder than you can imagine.LIS FOR LOSSTHE ABSOLUTE WORST LETTER OF THE ALPHEBET!

title: K - Kinks
text: K is for KinksIf you are under 50 you probably don't know what I am talking aboutwhen I say "kinks." Â Over 50?Â I bet you do! I remember being a morning person in my 20s and 30s. Â That sunny morning disposition died miserably somewhere in my 40s. Â  Mornings became a periods of "adjustment." Â Could I get out of bed without injuring myself, without talking to anyone, without losing my way to the coffee pot, without burning myself with hot coffee - and - without spilling it on my way to my LazyBoy recliner to sit take that first sip ... Â all those individual victories without caffeine.Much of my morning routine now is based on avoidance activities - honoring the messages my body sends about little "kinks" that must be eased out gently before anything too demanding is done ... like answering the telephone.And after about age 65 - those "kinks" need to be considered at other points during the day as well ... like ...Like when I attempt to turn over around 3:00 am and my calf muscle seizes up with excruciating screaming pain. Â My actual 'favorite' experience (NOT) was when BOTH legs seized up at the same time. Attempting to jump out of bed to break the cramp looked like I was trying to balance on 2 broken legs! Â My husband is legally blind so he missed my herculean effort. Â Like when I get out of bed in the morning and my body says "Not so fast. Walk carefully and deliberately no matter what your bladder is saying."Like when I attempt to get out of my car after a long drive, and my back and knees remind me - "Hey, you must be kidding, we've been sitting quietly for over an hour - and NOW you want us to jump into action??"Like when I have been knitting for a few glorious hours stress free hours, binge watching my favorite Netflix shows, and I decide to release my fingers from a knitting needle to scratch my nose and I hear the message radiating up my arm from my fingers - "You can knit or you can scratch but you can't do both so close together!!"Â These are the "kinks of my 70s."Â Â I can hardly wait to experience the future kinks.The Kinks of my 80sThe Kinks of my 90s

title: J - Juggling
text: J is for JugglingIf you are older, try to remember the many tasks your 25 year old self juggled in one day. Â  If you are still young - take a moment in your busy day to check out your future. Â Let see ... I pick a typical Friday when I was 25 years old, married, a grade school teacher and pregnant. Â Friday looked like this:Pop out of bed before 6 amDress while sipping coffee (thankfully set up the night before.)Feed the cats before breakfast - Clean the litter.Feed myself breakfast standing at the counter making a bag lunchMake a quick grocery list for food shopping (budget for the week was $20, ha!)Quick review of Friday lesson plansÂ Commute to workStop for weekly gas fill up on the way(We will skip the school day where I juggle the hundreds of things grade school teachers do in 8 hours.)Gather up next week's lesson plan materials and papers to grade.Â Commute to grocery store - Fridays were food shopping day right after work - and stop by the liquor store to pick up some cheap wine fizzy something. Â Liquor wasn't a no-no for a pregnant woman 45 years ago.Do a fast unpack of groceries, a quick clean up of the apartment upon getting homeFix dinner, eat quick, and clean upPrepare a few dips for chips and veggies for visiting Friday night friends.Slap out board games and snacksGrade a few papers while waiting for guests to arriveEntertain until say midnightSpot pick up after company leavesSet up the coffee for Saturday morningHit the sack at 1:00-ish am.Inserts bunches and bunches of bathroom breaks in-between other things (remember - pregnant!)SaturdayOff and running again for weekend fun activities and school work prep.This is the 72 year old me - trying to remember what the 25 year old me juggled 45 years ago. Â  Exhausting to my eye now - but I don't remember being all that tired then.That was then!Today!Some demands are gone, of course, and some are changed - no job, no commute, not pregnant for sure. Â Still married - however, husband is disabled (legally blind), and needs more assistance. Â Today a 72 year old me might prepare for a Friday - with company like this. Â Wednesday (Yes, Wednesday!! Â Give me a break - I am older.)First off, there is absolutely NO POPPING OUT OF BED on any day of the week!!Â Make a list of everything I need to do - without the list I would just sit and knit or read.Vacuum and dust.restPrepare the menu and grocery list for the next week and for Friday company. Â This prep is exhaustive - checking cookbooks for recipes and reviewing grocery store sales.restCook Wednesdays dinner, eat and clean up.Assist husband with finding an item he has lost, or searching Amazon for something he wants to purchase, or sending an email on his behalf, or problem solving a computer issues he cannot find on the screen, or picking up prescriptions on his behalf.Â ThursdayFood shop - this takes all morning now - no fast spin through the grocery store. Â There is more checking for cheapest prices, reading food labels to insure a choice is healthy, doubling back to previous aisles to get things I missed the first time through. (Lots of doubling back. Â Sigh.)Unpacking groceries and repacking certain items - freezing, labeling, reorganizing - making sure things are where my legally blind husband can find them independently.restBegin to prepare food for Friday night company dinner.Order take out dinner - which I pick up because my husband doesn't drive. Â Reality check: Â No standingÂ and cooking tonight's dinner after food shopping and cooking for the next day. Â Assist husband again with something.FridayCompete food prep for companyrestDo a pick-up sweep through the houseDo a liquor store run - for company and for us Â - Yes, we have a nice cocktail once a day - one of the benefits of aging and not giving a sh*t. Â (See? Â It isn't all gloom and doom.)Clean the guest bathroom so it isn't a health risk, ha! (I don't think I ever worried about health risks at 25 - remember, young ... I was going to live forever!)restSet out appetizers (now I call them appetizers instead of snacks ğŸ˜)Serve dinner and entertain until about 10:30 - fading out occurs about that time after company prep.Pick up after guestsCollapse in bed around 11:00 pmSaturdayRecover! Â Schedule nothing!Â So what lessons have I learned about juggling all the balls of life with this exercise? Â Thank God I am not trying to juggle a job as well. Â Yea!!! For Retirement!Lists were never part of my 25 year old life - my brain retained everything. Â Everything I tell you!! Â  Today? Â My brain still retains stuff like before, but the retrieval window is extremely short.I can't abuse my body by eating crap appetizers only! Â We serve dinner. Â (Sigh, those were the good old days, when dips and chips were good enough!!)Â The cost of living is crazy more than almost 50 years ago. Â Weekly food budget has increased from $20 to $120!!Question of the Day: Â When do I get to retire from cooking dinner!!! Â My next life: Marry a chef, who wants me out of "his kitchen.".Still taking lots of bathroom breaks - 72 years old, you know!Â I remember laughing at my mom who would schedule exactly one thing a day on her event calendar! Â One thing!!! Â I couldn't imagine why!Â Â Â I get it now, mom.Â Sorry.

title: I - Incentives
text: I is for IncentivesIn our society where becoming a senior citizen is not a 'badge of honor,' how can businesses, vendors, governments and others demonstrate through action (rather than just words) a desire to respect the citizens who are now in their older years? I believe Incentives to make life easier for our seniors is one way to correct the current conception of seniors as some how - less - than everyone else.Here are a few incentives that could be or have been made available to seniors.Shopping discounts - grocery stores, gym memberships, movie tickets, vacation travel, vehicle purchases. Â These are good and probably available in some areas of the country already, but the efforts should not be limited to encouragements to spend money - which these are.More walking paths and side walks in communities. Â I moved from a planned city into a local suburb - that isn't well planned. Â I never ran out of side walks in my former neighborhood - I always run out in my current neighborhood. Â This suggestion is good for all citizens.Book Mobiles to make regular visits to senior living facilities. When I was a kid, the Book Mobiles from local libraries visited our apartment development. Â What a wonderful way of keeping the written word in communities where seniors frequent - thereby reaching some citizens who don't drive and don't have access to good public transportation.Hospitals could provide senior wings for the elderly. One hospital in a neighboring county has a senior wing! Â I understand from others that it isn't well managed, but what a great idea. Â Big Brother-like programs for seniors now in nursing homes - something like Adopt-a-Senior Â or Adopt-a-Grandparent for local young families - expose children and seniors to each other. Â Seniors often outlive many of their family support members and are isolated. Â Children can be taught from a young age to enjoy and respect the elderly. Â Both benefit from the effort.There are some rare nursing home and child care combinations in my state. Â Expand that program. Â  The facilities are divided but connected for easy of visiting. Â Managed well, this could be a boon to both age groups.Build more neighborhoods that allow for cross-generational residential structures. Â More mother-in-law suites, more relaxed coding of land to allow for senior structures on family owned property. Â Why not encourage the development of extended families!More volunteer and job opportunities for seniors - let those who want to work have an equal chance in the candidate selection process - age discrimination is against the law but humans are inventive creatures and can easily find ways around that law.Â We protect minorities, against sex discrimination and the disabled with laws. We encourage special incentives for active service members and veterans. Â Why aren't seniors - who have lived and contributed for a life time - encourage and protected?

title: H - Hobbies
text: H is for HobbiesÂ The most beautiful word in all of the English Language.KnittingSo much of our lives are spent in doing stuff to make a living - a roof over our head, food on the table, heat, water, food, cell phones, TV, education for a child. Â This list is exhaustive if carried to completion. Â We are often tied to jobs/professions by our need to provide the basics and a few of the nice-to-haves. Â A responsibility of sorts, an expectation of society that we are self-supportive ... not relying on the charity of others. All of that eats up decades of our lives.WeavingHow wonderful to FINALLY be in a position to do something for ourselves that feeds our souls, that doesn't have to be squeezed in between doing laundry or driving to work.Maybe it is something that provides no practical outcome other thanto make us or others smile like painting a picture or setting up miniature train layouts,to relax us with the repetition of the movement of our hands like knitting and crocheting,Â to distract us by watching sporting events or reading a book,Â to inspire us with music and theater and travel,Â to give us joy and satisfaction through volunteering and mentoring. Â CrochetHow wonderful is the world with such non-essential activities in it!How amazing it is to reach the time of life when you have the opportunityto do those things full time!!!I feel sadness for folks who express a serious concern about filling their time as retired individuals. Â They typically are people who are defined by their professions. Â They have allowed their lives to be jailed within the box of 'work' only. Â Once retired by stepping out of that box, they are at a true loss at what to do with their own precious hours - hours now that have a more visible expiration date somewhere in the future.A lace shawl I knitted for my daughter.Is it possible that in their professional lives they never once day-dreamed about doing fun stuff - stuff that has no real useful purpose other than to give us joy?I believe Habit (another H word) plays a big role in how we conduct our selves in later years. Â Habit is a non-thinking, non-decision making behavior. Â If you are in individual who habitually thought 'outside the box of work' and squeezed Hobbies into your precious non-work hours - you can slip into retirement more easily. Â If you segmented your life into work-and-more work ... for years ... retirement will be an effort, an actual stressor, and a time of confusion or total inactivity.A knitted shawl for myself.Make room in your life for Hobbies now - whatever your age!You are worth it!If you have long retirementyou will be glad you made theÂ effort.Note: Yes, all the pictures of my work - knitting, crochet and weaving!

title: G - Grand Child
text: G is for Grand Childok, ok, okI know!!Being a grand parent isn't a universal experience in life like aging!You don't even need to be retired to become a grand parent!But if you had a grand child like this one ...Seriously ...Â wouldn't you take any excuse to show her off if she was yourÂ grand baby?In addition, it shows off my knitting and crocheting projects - a hobby in retirement!!Any excuse to show off this beautiful little person!As long as I am a little bit off topic, let me share with you just how much of a miracle this little girl is to me.I am the mother of two enormously wonderful and successful people: a son and a daughter. Â I have always said - raising children is like walking through a mine field - some of us make it successfully and some of us don't. Â I think I made it successfully. Â Through my kids adult years - having children of their own never seemed to be on their radar - at least not that they shared with me. Â Both of them now are in their 40s. Â The paths of their lives seem set - and I was content. They are happy, successful and responsible people. Â What more could a mother want for her children. I accepted the fact that I would not be a grandmother.When my son announced that he and wife were expecting a child - I remember initial feelings of disbelief, needing to take deep breaths, covering my face with my hands to absorb this new bit of unbelievable information in private - while tears began to form. Â My God .. could this be happening!!When this beautiful little person was born (and she was beautiful and very alert at birth) - all I could think of was ... There is a God and I guess I did something right in my 70 years on this earth!Just learning to sit. Â She was pleased with herself!Eskarina is always fascinated with her granddad's glasses.He is legally blind and wears them to control bright light situations.Grand children are the icing on the cake of life! Â I was happy with just the cake.I am thrilled beyond measure with the icing.

title: Sunday Brain Dump: Walk, Tears, Comments
text: Sunday Brain Dump: Peeping Tom, Tears, CommentsWI promised to swing back to the blog on Sundays (even though the A-2-Z Challenge skips Sundays), Â to give a walking update! Â I will give that update. Â BUT ... I discovered that my fingers began itching to write about some non-Challenge topics. Â  I felt stifled ... like mouth gagged and hands tied because I already wrote and scheduled all these other posts!!! Â So it is Sunday and now that the gag is off - here is what came bubbling out:WWalking in My Neighborhood and the Peeping TomThink - hamster in a wheel. Â Think - treadmill without TV.Think - circular track camouflaged as a neighborhood.Â Think - mental torture masquerading as a healthy activity. Â That is what walking in my immediate neighborhood is to me. Â When I am desperate and time is short - I am left with no choice.So here is what is good about my neighborhood walk:Safe - in a boring kind of way: no traffic, no scary people, no crime.No uneven surfaces. Â I am not new to falling on public sidewalks.Â  Not a graceful fall either. Â Pretty much a 'fall-flat-on-your-face" fall. Â Not once unfortunately. Â I can count 3 times. Â  On the up side - falling is never boring.Always available - even at night when it is dark - the boring areas is well lighted.Gently hilly.Neighbors/friends ... we visit.Can be interesting in a "peeping tom kind of way" - not that I walk up to windows and look in. Â  Â But if you have your blinds up, lights on, and it is night, guess what. Â I can see in! Â Really ... the walk is boring - nothing to see outside. Â Inside views ... who knows. Â Of course, there really is nothing to see inside either. Â I live in a 55+ community, and we are not partying nude with loud music and mixed drinks! Â But if there is something to see from the side walk, I will look.Â Here is what is bad about it:Boring.Very boring.Intensely boring (unless someone has their shades up, then it is only 'very boring.')This unintentional walking track, however, is used by a lot of the residents. Â One morning as I was getting into my car, I stopped a couple who regularly walks this route around the development. Â I smiled and offered a casual greeting, "Nice morning for a walk!" Â They agreed. Â So I continued, "So how many times around do you go," thinking they probably didn't go this route for distance - just a few times around till their exercise time was up. Â They quickly responded, "Nine times around is a mile." Â Oh my. Â They worked out the distance. Â They knew exactly. Â Okay, then! Â And how boring - it was morning ... so peeping in windows for them!I decided to skip my walking stats - except to say I have not yet reach 10,000 steps in one day. Â That is actually my first goal. Â There are other goals waiting in the wings - if I don't die before that.I am adding some incentive to my steps by tracking them on the Walking4Fun website. Â This site has a number of well known walking trails - one is the Appalachian Trail. Â It tracks your step count against a number of well known walking trails - one being the Appalachian Trail. Â Below is the map of the trail with the start marked with an S. Â My marker is pretty much hidden by the start marker. Â Guess I have just a few more steps to take before I even show up on the map! Â Ha.Walking4Fun - AP Trail"Make the Babies Cry" WednesdayOh, so you didn't know there was such a day? Â There is!I visit my grand daughter in day care almost every Wednesday. In the beginning she looked at me with that unblinking stare ... like she had never set eyes on me before. Â Ok, I get it. Â She isn't going to just give away smiley greetings (like some babies do) without you earning that smile. Â I respect that! Â She has standards. Â I agree - you can't smile at every Tom, Dick or Harry that crosses your path! Â  Yea for a female who knows her own mind!!Time passes, I see her most weekends. Â I see her most Wednesdays. Â She warms up after the initial visual assessment of my worth (like always), and we play and she smiles and laughs, and life is good.About a month ago, I walked into day care - she took one look at me and her face resolved into red blotches, tears, and crying! Â  uh ... Okay ... so not exactly the welcome I was going for. Â But after she pulled out of it, the visit was fabulous. Â When I visit her house, or she visits my house - we have no tears. But ok. Maybe having a bad day in day care.The next time I came - same reaction - only this time she gets her good friend, a little boy in her group, crying too. Now they both are crying. Â And not just little whimpers - No, these are dramatic heart felt sobs, with head down to the floor in total despair. Oh.My.God! Â What ever could the care givers be thinking!!!Seriously, folks. Â I am not making this stuff up.But, I am not an easy person to deter! Â This is my grand baby - probably my only grand baby!!! I will persevere. Â (Actually - stubborn and persistent is a good description.)So last Wednesday I visited again. Â By now I have labeled this day of the week, "Make the Babies Cry" Wednesday!! I arrive at the day care and peek from the hallway into the infants room. Â I see Eskarina standing in the middle of the room. Â She is fine. Â She spots me. Â Nothing. Â I enter. Â Nothing. Â I move closer - the face gets red, tears form, crying starts. Â (In my brain: damn, damn, damn.). Â I whip out my phone and take this picture:Â *Sigh*Thankfully it didn't last long and the caregiver didn't need to pick her up to comfort her. Â  She got control of herself and then I snapped this picture.A slight improvement I guess. Â I'll take thumb over tears.We shortly got to this. Â Much better. Â The visit was successful. Â So mark your calendars folks, and remember me on "Make the Babies Cry Wednesdays" around 11:00 am - when I am out in day care making babies cry. Â (See? Â Retirement can be interesting.)Commenting DramaFinally, as regular readers know, I had problems with commenting on some blogs and some readers had problems commenting on my blog. Â I made an adjustment to my browser and the problems are fixed - at least from my perspective. The details of that problem and the fix - can be found at this location on my blog. Â If you have similar problems, please check out my post and the link located within my post that instructs you on a possible correction.The past week I changed my commenting feature back to Embedded Comments and Comment Moderation.Â  Responding to comment on my blog is easier with Embedded Comments and I really enjoy the 'conversation' with readers. Â And I have noticed some other annoying problems as well (caused by trouble makers - with no life of their own except to cause problems for others) Â - and I need to put back Comment Moderation.Please send me an email if you are having problems leaving a comment on this blog. Thanks all.

title: F - Friendship
text: F is for Friendship"It's easy to be friends wheneveryone's 18. Â It getsharder the older you get,as you make differentlife choices."Zadie SmithIf that quote is true, then friendship that lasts 60+ years or more must be very very rare, indeed.Friendships are important at any age. Â My 1 year old grand daughter has a friend in her day care. Â But for seniors, friendships are as about as important as air is to all living beings.Having been at my mom's side during the last decade of her life, I had a chance to see the circle of her friendships. Â Mom made friends easily. Â She was a friendly, cheerful, compassionate woman. Â It was easy to be friends with my mom.But as she reached her late 70s, changes occurred. Â She was still the same friendly happy person, but some friends move away, death claimed others, health issues became barriers, and some just slipped through the cracks of life. Â Changes to the social circle happen in later years and they are similar across the elderly population.What I do know is that without careful nurturing, social networks dramatically shrink in the elderly. Â Almost universally, if a senior lives long enough, they outlive some, if not all, of their peers. Â It is hard to develop new friendships at that point in life. I kind of think luck or maybe just good karma plays a role in sustained friendships for seniors! But here was one exception in my mom's circle that I have been honored to witness and am eager to share! Mom had one 'tried and true' dear friend. Â Mrs. R was a friend mom made in 1954 - a neighbor in our apartment development. Â Through all the years they remained close friends. Â Phone calls, visits, keeping in touch ... even right up to my mom's last days in the Nursing Home. Yes, there were many obstacles. Â They both had health issues, both became widows, Mrs. R. moved back to her home state of New York. Â Mom also had the problem of a troubled marriage being married to an alcoholic. Â But those things did not seem to matter to mom and Mrs. R. Â They maintained a close friendship. Â Even when mom was in the depths of her dementia - and recognized few people - Mrs. R made a visit to the Nursing Home to see mom (from NY) and continued to keep in contact with me to find out how she was doing. Â At mom's death, despite the fact her own health failing, Mrs. R. made sure she was represented at the funeral by other family members. She reached out to me on occasion over the last 4 years. Â She just never forgot my mom.How often does that happen in life? Â Friendships that spill over the divide of generations.Last fall Mrs. R. invited my sister and I to her home in Long Island. Â In the last year, my mom became at Great Grand Mother - twice. Â Mrs. R. was excited to hear about mom's expanding family - 4 years after mom's death - she was interested and happy about these babies. Â So, yes ... my sister and I hopped on a train and spent the weekend visiting this dear friend who more than earned the title of 'Best Friend Ever!!' Â In the photo above we were sharing an photo album we brought as gift for her filled with pictures of mom's Great Grand babies!For myself, I am blessed to have two friends of very long duration. Â  (Picture below: Left to right. Â R, L and me.) Â We all met at that same apartment in 1954. Â As children we played together. Â But life did take us in different directions. Â Over the years we would bump into each other. Most people don't typically have these long term relationships.The picture below was taken at my mom's grave site on the day she was buried. Â These childhood friends both came to her funeral. Â And the most amazing fact of all was that my mother had been friends with their mothers for a life time.Friendships are important to all people because humans are social beings.Â But friendships for aging adults are a reward you give yourself for living a long life!I am reaping that reward!

title: E - Entitlement
text: E is for EntitlementIn my previous professional life, I work for a multi-speciality medical group of considerable size. Â The Psychiatry Department was lead by Gordon Livingston, MD. Â Our paths crossed when serving on a committee together and I found this psychiatrist to be a wonderful individual - admired by peers and patients alike. Â He espoused a common sense approach to mental health. Â He suffered great losses in his personal life - but 'walked his own talk' through it all. He is the author of several small but powerful books filled with down to earth thoughts of the human condition and a level of compassion that is not often seen. Â I highly recommend all his books.One book - Too Soon Old, Too Late Smart: Thirty True Things You Need to Know Now - has a chapter called: The problems of the elderly are frequently serious but seldom interesting.That chapter begins with this statement:Old age is commonly seen as a time of entitlement. Â After long years of working, the retiree is presumably entitled to leisure, social security and senior discounts. Â Yet all of these prerogatives are poor compensation for the devalued status of the elderly. Â The old are stigmatized as infirm in mind and body. Â Apart from their continuing role as consumer, the idea that old people have anything useful to contribute to society is seldom entertained.He continues describing further extensions of his thoughts on this subject. Â But my own thoughts got stuck on the word "entitlement." Â Entitlement! Â Yes, I do have feelings of entitlement now that I am retired. Â But I hate that this word sounds somewhat self-centered and selfish. Â Entitlement shouldn't feel that way. Â In my mind it has elements of an earned benefit - like Social Security. Â But said outside of this context, the word 'entitlement' is often used to describe individuals who think more of themselves than they should. Â I really don't mean that at all.As an older citizen should I feel entitled? Used in the proper context - Yes! Â I earned my years as an older citizen throughout life - education, Â profession, raising a family, staying healthy, contributing to taxes and social security, preparing for my retirement.Yes, I do feel entitled to at least the same respect, compassion and understanding as I had when I was 20 or 30 years younger. Â Why should those basic considerations be ignored because one is older? Â Yes, I do feel devalued at times because I mark the box on forms that identifies me as "Retired" - not employed. Â Why is aging and retirement not valued as the next stage of life that has been earned?Yes, I do sometimes feel resentment for assumptions made about my aging ... when this just a natural stage of the human life span. Â Why make any assumptions at all ... when the course of each creature's aging is determined by nature?Everyone ages and no living thing is designed to live forever.Our society elevates youth andÂ does devalue elderly. Â Take one tiny example I heard that illustrates preference for youth over age. Â I met a woman recently who described herself as 80 years young - rather than 80 years old. Â I have heard that before, and it is an in-thing to say to make advanced years seem less ... old, I guess. Maybe she was trying to say compared to her peers - she was more active and younger at heart. Â Maybe she was saying she was as young as she was ever going to be. Â But when I hear that phrase, '80 years young,' I hear the cultural bias come out. Â Everyone wants to be described 'younger' (except for the very young). Â The word 'old' is only positive if you are under 21 and you want to be 'older.' Â Each birthday makes you better, more adult, more activities you can participate in, more of just everything. Â Being 'older' is good then.Do I think that 'young' is a bad word to use? Â Absolutely not, young is a good word, however, it is not the only good word. There are primitive societies in the world where the elderly are viewed with esteem and revered for their advanced age and wisdom. Â Primitive societies - for God's sake!!As I warmed up to other arguments of that nature, Â I paused .... My own frustration and anger seeped out of the print of this post. Â I thought back over my own life - all of it - and admitted to myself that I was guilty of the same insensitivities and ignorance when I was younger. Â I, too, valued youth over aging. Â I didn't 'get-it' till I watch my mom struggle with aging issues - literally inside my own home - up close and personal. Â Is it possible that our current society created this huge generational divide by separating the elderly from the family nucleus? Â Maybe those primitive societies aren't so primitive - keeping their elderly inside the family circle rather than outside it.Maybe that is how the feelings of "entitlement" in the elderly are born. Â Did our society create the emotion of entitlement as defense mechanism in the elderly because we devalued the standing of the elderly among us? I firmly believe that the elderly should not shy away from feelings of Entitlement. Â Their rights as members of society have not diminished just because they are old and/or retired.It should be recognized that even the newest of human beings - if luck is with them - will be very old some day and carry in them the wisdom of all those years. I think we can ALL agree,Â our world needsÂ much more wisdom today.

title: D - Dementia
text: D is for Dementia"The baby boomers are getting older, and will stay older for longer. Â And they will run right into the dementia firing range. Â How will a society cope? Â Especially a society that can't so readily rely on those stable family relationshipsÂ that traditionally provided the backbone of care?Terry PratchettDementia (in all its ugly and life-shattering forms) is the Elephant In The Room - for retirees. Â It is a tough topic that no one wants to face - a bullet everyone wants to dodge. Â For anyone who has seen dementia in a loved one, it is more than just an unpleasant topic. Â  And it is a growing health care concern for everyone in our society.Both my grandmother and mother had dementia. Â I got to stare dementia right in the eye and face the fact that with my familial history - I could be looking at my own future.Â When I think about that possibility too long, I want to stop typing - like right now! Â Get up from the computer and walk away - and tell myself over and over again ...Â No, Not To Me. Â This will not happen to me. Â Â No!It is my gut reaction to dementia. Â It is the scariest, saddest and most depressing of all diseases. Â Well, maybe not for the person who has dementia. Â But for the family watching it progress, it is devastating. Â It slowly rips up your relationship with a loved one - one day at a time for years and years - until the elder doesn't even know your face!If memory was the only thing lost - it would be almost a kindness. Â But in the end - if dementia continues its normal slow torturous progression through the human brain, it impacts many of the body's systems ... even the inability to swallow a sip of water.Â Â The pain felt by family members doesn't easily pass either. Â Now, almost 4 1/2 years from my mother's death from dementia I tear up at her suffering. Â  I still remember to this day - every single microbe of independence and humanity that was stripped from her.So my advice to all is this ...Enjoy your lifeÂ while your brain is whole!Nothing is promised in the future.Nothing.

title: C - Caring
text: C is for Caring."To care for those who once cared for us is one of the highest honors."Tia Walker,Â The Inspired Caregiver: Finding Joy While Caring for Those You LoveI often ponder the idea of how one human can dedicate a significant portion of their own life to care for another human while others approach this topic with "can't" sprinkled liberally through their vocabulary.In this post I am focusing the scope of 'caring' to meet the physical needs of another human who cannot meet their own needs. Â In those terms most people immediately think of caring for infants - who obviously, when born, would die without direct care of another mature human. Â Nature has hard wired "caring" into most of us with infants and children so our species continues. Â (Very wise, Mother Nature.)The best example of this 'caring' reaction was demonstrated when my grand daughter was born. Â My son became a father for the first time in his 40s - later than most. Â When his daughter was born, he shared with me an interesting personal discovery. Â "You know, I generally find the sound of crying children annoying. Â I don't know if it is biological or not - but I don't feel that way with my daughter when she cries." My immediate thought ... Yes, son, it is most definitely biological! Â ğŸ˜ƒ That's why I let you live through your teen age years. Â Biology!!What does this have to do with retirement and aging?RetirementMy own retirement was launched prematurely - at age 59 - due to the needs of an aging mother with dementia. I was fortunate that my financial foundation allowed that choice. Â But still, it was a choice. Â I chose to take care of her. Â I could have chosen differently. Â  The caring impulse that was activated in me at the birth of my children was triggered again with my mom when she started to fail. Â I had to step in and actively provide assistance and care. Â In my brain, it was simply something I had to do.My first 8 years of retirement - I "worked" without pay for her benefit - Â my heart and my soul would allow nothing less. But ... was it biology - some hard wired caring reaction? Â And how many folks take that step into retirement for reasons of elder care or care of grand children? Â How many early retirees risk reduced incomes in their own futures because of choices like these? Â I have no doubt my own retirement income was impacted by retiring early, but I also consider myself fortunate to have had those 8 years at mom's side. Â Was it a good trade off? Â I think so. Â There are lots of things we can't afford to do now, but could I have lived with the choice of continuing to work and let the chips fall where they may with my mom? Â No. Â I would do it all exactly the same way again.And yet ... there are many who feel very differently. Â I have had many conversations on this subject, only to find that my choice to care for my mom would not be their choice with their parents. Â Oh yes, if it was their adult child - they would set their lives aside to provide care, but not for a parent. Â It is a very complicated decision for some when addressing elder care issues. Â But for me - the choice was clear.AgingIn my caregiving years with mom, I was exposed to tons of other senior citizens in all stages of independence or dependence. Â I had a chance to see 'world class caregiver families' who surrounded and cared for their failing relatives from the moment they became aware there was a problem. Â Obviously the caring response was alive and well in their family nucleus.I also saw a range of other reactions to failing elders - that swung all the way to absence entirely. Â The memories of those isolated elders break my heart when I recall them ... and I wasn't even related to them. Â Where is that caring response - the one that erupts without hesitation for an infant, but cannot be found for an infant-like elder who can no longer safely take care of themselves? Â Maybe Mother Nature only inserts the caring response for the purposes of continuation of the species. Â Maybe what is needed for elder care is not a caring gene.Maybe what is missing is:Â Compassion!(another C word)

title: B - Beginnings and Baloney
text: B is for Beginningsand Baloney!Â (definition: Â The word Baloney comes from the sandwich meat called bologna,Â which is typically made of leftover scraps of meat. Â Briefly 'baloney' means "nonsense."BEGINNINGSRetirement means different things to different people. Â In my parents generation, retirement was seen an end of work, trading activity for inactivity. I am of the Baby Boomer Generation. Â I think the definition of retirement is changing. Â Certainly there are the 'sit-in-the-chair' types among my peers, but just as many are so active ... catching up with them is hard.My own Beginnings in retirement were at the early age of 59 - not exactly elderly by today's definitions. Â Holding down a full time job outside the home and a full time job inside the home as a caregiver for my mother proved too much for me. Â But true 'retirement' - my time - free time - sit-in-the-chair time - was not really mine until 8 years later, at my mom's death.True retirement came at age 67. Â There was no announcement in a company newsletter or big send-off party or 'gold watch' or anything like most folks get when stepping out of a full time job. Â Just a quiet transition from total dedication to another person's welfare to ... well ... it was a mystery for me at the time.BALONEY!Within a new short months of true retirement I discovered that some commonly held belief were ... Baloney!I heard a number of opinions on retirement from those in my 55+ community - ranging from the 'sit-in-your-chair' version to 'dropping-dead-at-work' version. Â I think there should a happy middle ground.So ... what is 'retirement baloney' in my opinion!BALONEY #1I won't be able to fill my time when retired. Â What the heck will I do?There is a measure of truth in this statement if you are 'married' to a demanding profession with no hobbies or external interests. Â When mom died, I worried about that as well. Â My focus in retirement was gone. It certainly was a 'job' that did demand ALL of me. Â So I get it when I hear that excuse. Â But it is not a balanced life - all work! Â You are capable of having so much more!My Truth:Retirement might be the time to seek out that "so much more" for yourself. Â If a life absorbing profession had been your experience, now is the time to balance out that deficiency. Â Don't waste another minute being married to a job - a job that would replace you in a nano-second if you died tomorrow. Â NOBODY should be all about a job ALL of their life. Â Almost without exception, once folks step into retirement they fill their time with no effort - nature abhors a vacuum - and before you know it, you hear "Gosh, how did I ever fit a job into my day?" Â And, if this isn't your truth - after trying the retired life Â - return to work, by all means.BALONEY #2I love to work. Â Why would I stop working if I love to work?There is truth in this statement, as well. Â Some folks just love the routine of work. Â  But most folks over 65 admit maybe working a professionally demanding job would eventually be too much to sustain physically after a certain age, regardless of desire. My Truth:Â In my own case, I always thought I would return to some sort of job after mom died. Â And then she died. Â I started thinking. Â I had been tied down with a profession for tons of years, then I was tied down with caregiving for 8 years ... and honestly, at age 67 I was ready for a little freedom. Â I was ready for retirement. Â But that is my story. Â  If you aren't ready for that freedom, you should work. It Â still feels, however, like you are cheating yourself. Â Why give that late-in-life energy to a job when you could give it to a person, or a hobby, or a cause? Â Opportunities abound in fun jobs or rewarding volunteer opportunities if you find yourself falling into Baloney #2 thinking.BALONEY #3I can't afford to retire! Hmm... here, sadly, is a a lot of truth. Â It is scary to hear the statistics about what is needed in resources for retirement and how many people are running short in that area. Â Yes, they probably will be forced to work well into their senior years. Â At some point no matter if you can afford it or not - many seniors will be unemployable due to any number of failing physical or mental conditions that beyond their control.My Truth:If you are many years away from retirement - prepare now. Â I am no financial advisor, but it is basic good sense to live carefully and below your means at all stages of life. Â My husband and I started planning for retirement in our 40s - late by some standards. Â But we buckled down and started plowing funds into our nest egg - we lived far below our means, abhorring all kinds of debt. Â It can be hard to take that backward step in spending during the high earning years - after all the Jones' are living the high life and you can afford that too (at least now). Â After years of simple and careful living to save that retirement nest egg - the transfer to a relatively frugal retirement was possible and easy for us - we still live careful and below our means, and we live a 'smaller life' than some of our peers, but we didn't have to say - We can't afford to retire. Wonder if the Jones' can afford to retire?

title: A - About
text: A is for AboutHello!Welcome new and returning visitors toMy Next 20 Years of Living Blog! Â It is day one of the A-to-Z Challenge - where participants publish a series of blog posts following the order of the alphabet during the days of April (except for Sundays.) Â Today bloggers post using the letter A as a guide.At the risk of being unimaginative ... I have chosen the wordÂ About for the letter A - a bit About me and a bit About the theme of my posts for the month of April. Â A brief introduction of sorts.ABOUT ME!Retired Knitter is my blog name, but regular readers know me as Elaine. Â This blog you are 'standing' in was born in 2009 - and it truly felt like a 'birth,' because it was created during a time of exhausting caregiving 'labor' for my mom. Â It is a journal-type blog where I share interests, observations, wonderings (from over- thinking stuff), my time as a care giver, and just about anything that settles in my brain and won't let go!I am a senior citizen, a wife (50 years this June - Yikes), a parent, a new grandmother, a knitter, a reader, a thinker, a TV series binge watcher, and a lover of living. Â You are visiting my online home - a place where I visit with friends and where I try to return the favor by visiting their blog homes - and we chat! Â Almost like the pen pals of old, we get to know each other.ABOUT THE THEMEI have chosen Retirement - and its companion topic - Aging. I find satisfaction and gratitude at reaching this later stage of life. Â Despite the negative impressions our culture gives to getting older, aging and retirement are 'gifts.' Â It is like completing the full circle of life. Â Sadly some never experience those gifts. Â My posts will be my story and some of my mom's story. Â My thoughts, observations, opinions, and experiences. Â I am no authority. Â I can give no advice. Â I know that each person's aging and retirement experience is different. Â .I won't cover every possible retirement and aging topic in the challenge - just the ones that are important to me and I can speak from my personal experience.Â  I started this aging journey with my mom as her caregiver. Â I became her voice, her 'warrior/protector,' and her constant companion as she moved through her last years of life with dementia until her death. Â Now I am walking a similar path (without the dementia I sincerely hope) and I am pleased if you want to come along this month with me - no matter your age.I have a perspective to share. Followers of all ages are welcome.Â Â For the young, it may be your future if you are lucky. Â For the not so young, it may be your present.Thank you for stopping here.ElaineRetired Knitter.

title: Walking - Hello AGAIN.
text: Now that all the sitting and writing is done for the A-2-Z challenge, I have the luxury of writing (once again) about other day-to-day stuff. Â Before those April posts launch starting on the 1st - thought I would share my initial efforts at getting a walking routine started - AGAIN!It seems like I am always starting over to establish the walking habit. Â (It could be described another way - I have developed the habit of starting walking programs. Â Ha!)I was walking somewhat regularly several years ago, but then had a major setback in 2017. Â  I spent a lot of time in PT trying to get my left knee well, resulting finally in a surgery repair in September 2017 - which was followed by yet again more PT until December 2017. Â But as anyone can tell you who has had any kind of surgery on the knee - the knee isn't back to 'real' normal for about a year. Â I noticed in fall of 2018 that I could finally kneel on that knee. Â It was sort of the last test of normalcy - and I passed.This spring I decided to take up a regular walking routine. Â I began last week.Interesting bodily discoveries. Â My knee does well - it is a bit touchy at the start but 'gets over itself' within a few minutes and cooperates with no complaint. Â My heart and lungs still do just fine. I find that a bit surprising. Â Not much of a set back after a nearly 2 year break. Â So a 30 minute walk is no problem. Â I am, however, focused mostly on steps and time - and not on speed and distance - but my walk speed is pretty good. Â Close to 3 miles per hour I would guess. Â Woo Hoo!!! Â I expect all those indicators to improve. Â I am encouraged.One problem still remains - that my current neighborhood of 2+ years isn't really walker friendly. Â Sidewalks disappear, traffic is awful and visual interest is null. Â So while I am still driving (at 72 you never know), I can get to wonderful walking paths and lakes and other areas of interests nearby. Â I guess I will make lemonade out these lemons by taking you with me on my walks and sharing pictures of my area - new places all the time. Â It will give me the incentive to get in the car for that walk (harder) rather than just stepping out of my condo for a walk (easier.)I am using my Fitbit for tracking time and steps. Â If you also use Fitbit - and want to be 'friends' on the Fitbit site - so we can check each other's progress and encourage each other - drop me an email. Â I would love to have you as a virtual 'walking partner' on Fitbit. Â  'Friends' on Fitbit Â can see each other's step counts. Â Just knowing that info often inspires me to put in just a few more steps and a bit more time.So on the Sundays in April (no A-2-Z posts on Sundays), I'll feature one of my walks. Â And share some of the progress - not that anyone really cares about the stats except me - but it will give me the incentive to not embarrass myself by sitting too much and then being forced to admit it to you!Till next time.

title: When Privacy Keeps you from Commenting
text: One of the many beneficial rewards of joining a large blog challenge - like A-to-Z Blog Challenge - is the chance to share information across a broader range of people than normal. Â A-to-Z Blog Challenge emails are being received from the Challenge Coordinators - and one of them was about how to make your blog friendly for receiving comments. Â They do encourage use of Pop Up Commenting and removal of the Prove You Are Not A Robot function - at least for the course of the event.I offered up some of the problems I have been having with not being recognized consistently as Â signed into Google - and how Embedded Comments and the "Robot From Hell" function blocked me from commenting.Another participant, Jemima Pett, responded to my problem. Â Apparently she uses Safari, as I do, and after a Safari Update, she started having the same problems as I described. Â She discovered that the browser update was the cause - and that a Privacy setting had been changed in the browser.Below is the link to that article - and following her recommendation - my problem with commenting has totally gone away!!! Â I encourage you to read her post.http://jemimapett.com/blog/2018/11/14/privacy-stops-blogging-comments-safari/I am thinking of putting Comment Moderation back on my blog at some point - because I have already found some spam. Â But until this event is over, I will keep the settings user/commenter free of frustrations.So it really wasn't a Blogger problem at all - it was a problem in my browser.My apologies to Blogger for all my ill will thoughts and words over the last few months. Â It wasn't their problem at all. Â But the courtesy of a response to my email requesting their help would have been appreciated. Â I can't help but wonder is Blogger manned by any living and breathing individuals. Â I am thinking - not!

title: 26 is a BIG number
text: Hello allSince announcing my intention to participate in the A-to-Z Blog Challenge (start date April 1), I have been busy creating blog posts on my theme of Aging and Retirement!I am pretty excited about this theme - it is a topic I have developed some pretty strong opinions on from my experiences as a caregiver and from my own aging. Â But I am not an authority on anything - except my own opinions - so you won't find financial planning advice, or medical advice or even advice on the best places to live in Retirement. Â No, sir, those topics are pretty well documented by other knowledgeable folks.My posts will be based on "insider" experiences of being an older person. Â And since my experiences are as valid as the next guy - I feel pretty comfortable sharing my perspective. It will be one person's story.But . Oh . My . Golly . Gosh !!!! Â ... 26 posts is a big number when you are trying to crank out all of them in advance. Â So far I have 13 finalize and scheduled to launch on various dates. Â I kind of feel that I have been doing nothing BUT blogging since March 1 - but have nothing actually showing on the blog at present! Â Ha!There are over 200 blogs participating at this point. Â The list grows. Â But my goals are pretty specific with regards to finding new blogs to follow and subscribing to them.They need to use Pop Up comments. Â I can't comment on blogs that use Embedded Commenting. Â That is a Blogger problem that has not been addressed by Blogger yet, as far as I know.I am most interested in journal type blogs - rather than writer blogs or photography blogs and the like. Â Personal preference is an expected outcome. Â My goal is to develop new "blog friendships" - a mutual blog visiting relationship. Â I enjoy blogs whose readership is listed below 500 followers. Â Some blogs have thousands of followers - but it is impractical to expect relationship building when you have gobs and gobs of followers. Â Some of the most fun blogs are those less than a year old - where the writer is still in the "honeymoon phase" with blogging and are actively engaged with the whole process.Â I am beginning to get excited about the challenge. Â This will be my 3rd effort over its 10 years history. I'll be back again before the beginning of the challenge. See ya'!!

title: Going Deep - Update
text: In January I discovered a blog post calledÂ  Â Go Deep Not Wide. Â That post plugged into a theme that was trending in my brain. Â Since that first exposure to Go Deep, Not Wide, it has not been far from my thoughts. Â If you missed that post I encourage you to check it out by clicking on the link above.For me thought has become action in subtle ways - not an intentional change, just sort of like watching another person (me) do things differently.Using the words "Go Deep" to navigate 2019 generally ... theoretically ... Â fits companionably with my desire to declutter and lead a simpler life. Â Said another way ... Go Deep is sort of like a string that holds together many different beads. Â And so ... I thought I would share some observations of "this person" who I have been watching Â ...Email:I get a lot of email for a person who doesn't work. Â Most are vendors who want me to spend money. Â I usually delete without opening and sometimes un-subscribe. Â But every single day I would have about 30 emails - only 5 or so were real. Â So I reversed things. Â I now un-subscribe as my usual action - and delete a few without opening. What a different!! Â This morning only about 8 emails - and most were blog posts I keep up with. Â Excellent, Excellent, Excellent!Kindle and Audio books:I think I am the fastest downloader east of the Mississippi!! Â See it, want it, download it! Â Done! Â I justified it by telling myself that 'electronically having it' didn't create actual clutter. Â True, but clutter isn't only objects.My Kindle library of books waiting to be read is large. Â But I pretty much read my Kindle only when eating and before going to sleep. Â The pending titles grow faster than the completed ones. Â I now delete offerings from Amazon for Kindle titles without looking further. Â If I do happen to see a title I want I just put it on my Wish List for later. (*sigh* next in line will be shortening by Wish List. Â Ha!)The first time I counted the audiobooks on my phone there were 61 titles waiting to be heard. Â Today there are 54 books. Â Some were deleted because I wasn't interested in them any more, but still ... progress. I will keep my Audible membership but stop buying additional new titles - even at the cheap "daily deals" price Â - till the list gets down to about 10 books. Â I picked that number out of thin air, but it seems reasonable.Real Books:Surprisingly I am reading a few 'actual books.' Â You remember what they look like - paper, glue, ink. Â I occasionally purchase books - new and used - 'cause I think I want the actual paper copy of a specific title. Â Of course, I don't seem to get around to reading all these purchases. I have a collection of maybe 30 books. Â No more buying. Â I'll read what I have and pass them on when I am done. Â  The books I am reading right now are:The Minimalist Home by Joshua BeckerA Stash of One's Own by Clara ParksI'll try to use the library in the future. Â We have a great library system. Â Taxes pay for that. Â May as well make use of it.Electronic Social Media:Now here is a brain-drain and time-suck I can probably reduce dramatically ... social media! Â  I am registered with 4 sites and I seem to participate with only 2.Instagram - Joined this recently, but seldom visit. Â I instinctively don't like the Instagram messages I get that tell me "So and So is now following you." Â I don't know So and So. Â Why would So and So follow a stranger (me) that isn't famous, isn't selling anything, never contributes anything to the site like a picture or comment, and never even visits Instagram anymore? Â Just creepy. It goes.Facebook - I am a frequent visitor. Â My family is out there with pictures and stuff, and several craft websites are there as well. Â I have blocked all the religious and political extremists, and the advertisements. Â There is a Go Deep Facebook Page. Â Reading others' interpretation of this Â idea has been interesting. Â As long as I can mold my experience by blocking and refusing unwanted people and sites, it stays (even with the bad press recently.)Pinterest - I get their emails all the time - lately I seldom open them. Â I remember when I joined Â up, I told a family member how expansive the world of ideas and projects are on Pinterest. I remember her response - I want less not more! I get it now. It goes.Blogger - I put blogging and reading blogs in this category. Â It eats up more time than all the others combined, BUT it is important to me - as Marie Kondo would say - It gives me Joy! Â It stays!Where it goes from here I do not know. Â Guess I will just have to keep watching "this person" to find out.

title: Front Row Seat at a Fire
text: Rarely am I the first person on the scene of anything. Â But it can happen ... like the time I was driving on a heavily traveled, multi-lane highway at the speed of 50 (which was the limit but to some that means 60 is ok) Â - and the light ahead had turned green - a light that could be seen from a distance. Â Traffic surged with our right of way established ... but a fire engine was attempting to cross in front of on coming traffic with his siren and lights just coming into view. Â  Â I stopped ... at the green intersection ... as did others on either side of me ... and then watched in my rear view mirror with anxiety in my stomach at oncoming cars barreling towards me at speed right behind me. Â  It was a terrifying moment - that ended ok, (for a change everyone was paying attention) but it was memorable.A more recent event was memorable as well. Â It happened right on my street. Â I was heading out to the store.As I got closer I saw this. Â I was the only one on the scene. A vehicle in full flame.Fire crews had arrived.But I was alone for only seconds.I pulled up to the curb and reached for my phone to call 911.But before I could do so, the fire truck in full siren - could be heard.I could see no one around the car but rescue workers.I prayed no one was in the car. Since no police arrived I assumed there were no deaths.It was about 15 minutes before it was safe to pass.

title: Happy Birthday, Mom
text: Today is my mom's birthday.Â Â She would have been 91 years old today if she had lived.Happy Birthday, Mom!I haven't written about her recently. Â As her birthday approached, Â I realized that there was a time when this blog was almost totally devoted to our experience together as she aged reaching end of life, and as I cared for her. Â I think it is time to make a return trip to the life of a woman I admired and loved.If you are curious about caregiving generally, or my time with mom during those difficult last years, you can find those posts listed under the Label - Through My Caregiver's Eyes. Â Labels can be found on the right side of my blog and if you select that label, the blog will sort out all those posts. The caregiver part of my life seems like a far distant memory - even though it only ended four years ago. Â But I am so very glad I documented that time on this blog. I hold the memories (good and sad) securely in my life through this link. Â I consider that experience to have formed me into the person I am today. Â I am stronger and more understanding of the road ahead of me as I age. Â I am indebted to my mom is more ways than I can count.Mom and her younger sister.They were very close.Mom was about 12 years old.This post is not about the caregiving experience. Â It is about the woman I called mom - who was raised in a loving family as a child, who was beautiful and smart, and appeared to have a bright future ... and who made one misfortunate choice - a choice sealed with a vow before God in a church - and who lived for 24 years honoring that vow at great expense to herself.My mom and dad when they were dating.She is about 19 years old.My mom's name was Elaine. Â I was named for her by my dad. Â In the stunning random spin of Â genetics, I have favored her in many ways over all of my life. Â I thought we were different in only one way - the way we approached adversity. Â She would live around it and with it. Â Despite many terrible life experiences, she remained an easy-going sweet person all her life - even into dementia. Â I have a tendency to meet adversity head on and fight through it. Â I used to believe that difference separated us. Â But as you will read later - maybe we were more alike than I ever thought.Mom with her father, her grandmother and me. Â She wasa dedicated and loving motherbut also strict in her child-rearing.Sadly, by the time this picture was taken, she knew her marriage had been a mistake. Â My dad suffered from alcoholism - an issue that I guess wasn't evident before saying "I do." Â Now-a-days folks typically live together before marriage and some of these issues can be discovered before taking that vow. Â I am not a big proponent of 'living together,' but I understand the value it holds in really getting to know a person. Â Of course, this was the 1940s - a different time.Our young family.So much is hidden behind those smiles.Mom was the glue that held us together. Â She raised two girls to be completely whole and worthy citizens of this world - no easy task in the environment we called home. Â As a young child and teen, I never understood why she continued this marriage. Â But as I grew I began to see the whole picture somewhat differently. Â She was a stay-at-home mom with 2 girls to raise, she was hundreds of miles from her extended family, she was raised to believe that once married - you were on your own - help from your parents was not to be expected, and because of her sweet personality, she did not appear strong enough to make such a difficult break in the family. Â What I didn't understand at the time was that my mom took the difficult path ... the path that involved great strength. Â At my dad's death I learned the true nature of her choice - it was simple. Â  What held us together wasn't glue - but the bedrock of her personality and her love for him. Â Love is a powerful bond. My dad loved us as well - and he was a good man beneath the alcohol, but addiction is also be a powerful bond. Â She chose to stay in her marriage until death. Â Mom took the more difficult path in life. Â I see that now. Â Hindsight is 20/20 - or so they say. Â It is most certainly true in my case. Â After dad's death, mom's life bloomed. Â She really was better without him. Â She had a satisfying full time job, she became a grandmother several times over, she traveled to Europe with friends, and she had an active retirement. Â She earned the peace of mind and fun experiences she had in the last half of her life. Â And as I looked back at her married years - many married years that I was old enough to remember - I saw the raw strength she mustered to be a mother and wife. It is only as an adult myself that I could have judged that.Mom and I during one of her first rehab experiences.Her declining years are well documented in my caregiving posts. Â When I saw mental changes that made me suspect she needed help - I stepped up. Â She resisted, of course, but I didn't back down. Â She eventually lived with me and then in the very last years she needed to be moved to Assisted Living and Nursing Care. Â Her end was not kind to her. Â Dementia is not a kind disease. Â Her mom also had dementia so the genetic link I have to that line of the family is at times worrisome. Â But - I have absolutely no regrets about the 8 years devoted to this woman's care. Â Her gifts to me were the gift of life and her guiding hand to normal adulthood despite a dysfunctional father. Â Her gifts cannot be topped by any care I gave her in the end. Â It was a debt I owed.I believe that sometimes life creates a mountain for you to get passed.Some of us go around it.Â Â Some of us go over it. Â Some of us go through it. Â I am a 'go through it' type of person.I think I chose the more difficult path.I see now so did my mom.Until you have had a mountain put in your wayyou may not really know what kind of person you are.Dear Mom,I miss your smiling face every single day. Â It is hard to write those words without tears even after 4 years. Â Rest in peace dear mom. Â Your legacy lives on in your daughters for whom you gave up much. Â  Happy Birthday!Love,Elaine
