title: Do You 'To Do?'
text: I think I have been down this path beforebut it is an ever evolving journey soI am visiting it again.I am a list maker.And as I get older, I don't trust my brain to keep things for very long.("very long" being 5 minutes - andsometimes as short as the time it takes to get across my condo.)*Sigh*It is fair to say that if it isn't on my To Do list,Â it doesn't have a chance of getting done.In fact, I have had to resist the impulse to put Get Dressed on the To Do list,Â because somedays if I am not stepping out the door -Â I get to 2:00 in the afternoon, look down, and find I am still in my PJs and slippers.It just wasn't on the list!!My way of keeping organized has changed over the years. Â Maybe it is a reflection of age, maybe it is a consequence of a less busy life, or maybe I just get bored with one way of doing things and want to try another.I am always curious about how others maintain order in their lives. Â While almost all keep some type of a list, it looks different for each individual. Â I thought I might share my 3 step process to an orderly life and would love to hear what yours is.Mine starts with the Step #1 - the bedrock Â ....The Big Wall CalendarThe appointments, engagements, baby / dog sitting, shopping trips, birthdays ... all go on a large wall calendar. Â This works pretty good if I actually LOOK at the calendar! Â Ah, that's the rub. Â Looking. Â Sometimes I wish my calendar was actually the size of a wall or so big as to be impossible to miss from space.Without this calendar hanging right in my face - the future is just a big black hole. Â And very very important ... those dark daily strike outs help me keep track of exactly what day it is! Â Sincerely, once you have been retired for a number of years, knowing the day of the week without a prompt can be chancy. Â I live in fear that one day I will sit across from a Neurologist who is checking me for dementia and he will start his little check list of questions by asking me what day it is. Â If I didn't check my calendar before leaving the house - my response will be, "Can I get back to you on that?" or "Who cares what day of the week it is. Â That is just a label and I am not into labels. " or, my personal favorite ... "Do you know what day of the week it is? Â You first." Â I am pretty sure that none of those responses will be good answers. Â Just to paint a complete picture of this - my son or daughter would be sitting beside me rolling their eyes!!In fact, I remember just such an appointment with my mom 10 years ago - the doctor asking various questions, and I was sitting beside mom who was attempting to answer them, and as I listened (not rolling my eyes) I realized with a little anxiety - that I would need to study up for this dementia quiz myself!!! Â I won't stop rehearsing my deflection responses to this question - you know, just in case!!So a big bold calendar is step #1. Â (Checking it every morning is step #1.5.)Step #2 is the heart ...The To Do Lists"To Do" lists are different animals entirely. I used to keep daily To Dos in a bound book similar to the Bullet Style Journal - where you hand write in the daily To-Dos and checked them off as 'complete' or marked them as 'forwarded' to the next day if not completed. There were many other symbols to use on each 'to do' in that system of organization. Â But mostly I completed or finished an item. Â I used that method when we bought and sold property and it was a life saver that year. Previous to that in my professional life - before the world went crazy over electronic options - Â I kept a large 8x10 loose leaf binder book in a leather case - very expensive if I remember correctly - like a Steven Covey or Day Timer book - with my entire life within its covers. Â Lots of fancy pre-made inserts with many many spaces to fill. Â It was an Epic Tome that was inches thick and very impressive!! Â It sort of announced to all - I am a busy important person with so many balls in the air I must write them all down inside this expensive leather binder that has my name on it!! Did you ever have one of those? But life changes and so does your perspective on stuff. Â I have reverted back to my old friend - the simple Â 3 x 5 index card - for the day-to-day stuff. Â Almost everything goes on the card. Â My life has become so simple - no job, no property transactions, no nothing - (thank God!!) the index card works just fine (as long as I don't lose it.) Â Besides - on the index card I can be brutal. Â Putting a small X or a check mark beside a completed item just isn't good enough. Â Even a line through the words isn't good enough. Â For me 'completed' has to be a Statement of Fact - an emphatic bold magic marker crossing out the existence of the To-Do entirely so it cannot be seen ever again. Â Â "I am done with you To Do ... never to see you again." Â "You other To Dos ... live in fear ... you too will be entirely obliterated with a bold line very soon." Â Well ... as soon as I get off my new LazyBoy chair. Â :-)When a card is complete - full of bold strike out marks - I rip that card up in a bunch of tiny little pieces and pitch them into the trash - a final assault on that offending list. Â Of course, another to-do 3x5 card list has already been born so the process starts all over again.The 3x5 card is a flexible tool as well. Â It starts out with the day of the week on top (mini-dementia quiz to see if I remember without the big calendar, Ha!) with my list of to-dos. Â If I don't complete them on Monday, I simply add the next day to the top of the card. Â The card might start out as a Monday card, but end up as a Monday-Tuesday-Wednesday card. If the to-do card (step #2) gets stalled, (like I lose the card), then I try to recreate the list from memory - and you can imagine how well that goes when I sometimes need prompts for identifying the day of the week.(I sure said a whole bunch of stuff about the simple 3x5 card!! Â Maybe I should write a book! Â Ha!)Lastly - step #3 - the big picture ...The Reference BookMy big picture is smaller these days! Â But I still need a slightly larger and more permanent tool to house it in. Â  It is called the Reference Book. Â This book is still in development. Â I keep forgetting to develop it - but I have purchased the book - all new and shiny - with many lovely blank pages just waiting for me - in lovely bright orange cover which should be easy to find if when I misplace it. Â I even have a matching orange case to store it in (the case is not new but how serendipitous that I had it and the color was a match.). The cover doesn't have my name on it. Â I consider that a plus and a minus. Â The plus - that I have evolved from needing any status symbols. Â The minus - if I forget my name I have no prompt!! Â Ha! Â But it does have all the lovely pockets for stuff - and a place for pens. And it zips closed. Â The book will house all the information that is spread over the course of a year - or longer - stuff like big projects, items in development, plans for hobbies, future goals or big tasks, activities that need tracking, budgets, birthdays, anniversaries, quotes I love, or stuff that is just stuff and fits no where else.While Step #3 isn't as important as the first two steps in getting through a single day, it would be a big loss if misplaced or destroyed. Â It would be like losing detailed road map while on a trip in a strange Â large city.So ...Â Do you Calendar or To Do?Do you use a specific method for organizing your activities like To Dos?Do you talk to your To Do List ... threatening it ... like I do?Do you know what day it is?Â (and no cheating by checking your calendar.)Â ğŸ˜„

title: In Love Again
text: Before Christmas I fell in love again.It wasn't with a being - human or animal.It was with a thing!Again.Once was with a vehicle I named Maxie! Â She was a beautiful, fast and comfortable car - a Maxima. Â I saw her as the fancy lady with pearls and lipstick and running shoes. Â She and I had been through some eventful parts of my life. Â She served me well. Â Tears came to my eyes when I found out she had an oil leak that would cost more to fix than her total worth at age 11 years. Â She had body and internal wear and tear - not particularly the beauty she started out as. Â But after 11 years of road experiences with her behind her steering wheel - it broke my heart to trade her in. I was forced to buy a new car. Â Am I attached to that new car? Â Not at all! Â It is just transportation. Â End of story. Â I wasn't making that mistake again!And then there was a beautiful mature Japanese Maple in my townhouse front yard - Â the showiest tree in my neighborhood - admired by all .... until we had a broken water pipe in our basement. Â The fix involved digging up my entire front yard - landscaping and all- to lay new pipe. On the day they needed to remove that beautiful tree, they cut it in pieces and then pulled out the trunk with some large equipment. Â It was brutal. Â I had to shut my blinds while it was going on. Â It hurt my heart to watch the tree's destruction. When we planted the new landscaping did I fall in love with any of the new plants? Â Nope! Â Stupidity shouldn't be repeated.The biggest love loss of all was my townhouse of 30 years. Â That was 2 years ago and regular readers know how hard that was for me to part ways with that home. Â So much love, and sorrow and happiness and joy were imprinted by our family into its very foundation. Â When we moved into this condo, did I fall in love with this abode? Dear God - No! Â That way lies madness!I learned my lesson!Â Â No more loving objects!It is stupid!It is insane! Â Then my new Laz Boy recliner rocker was delivered.My husband and I had talked about getting recliners for a long time. Â Our 50 years of marriage was filled with furniture that had minimal fabric. Â Cats, you know. Â They love fabric for their claws and we loved cats. Â So the choice was easy. Â Get sturdy, wood type furniture - and keep the cats. Â Comfort was never a consideration. Now we both have these ever so comfortable chairs - all padding and fabric. Â Very very comfortable. Â So far our cat Wally has shown no interest.I can hardly believe that at age 71 - I have finally gotten real grown up furniture!Here she is!! Resisting the temptation to give her a name. Â But I am open to suggestions! Â ğŸ˜‚Please ignore the clutter that is to her left! It is all my knitting stuff. She is electric - buttons on the side - and she has a port for charging electronics!Woo Hoo!!!She just reclines - no heat, no vibration and she doesn't lift you to a standing position! Â Just reclines. Â She is electric so all I have to do is push a button and she lifts my feet up and tilts me back into the most comfortable of positions. Â She supports my back perfectly when it aches from standing in the kitchen too much (You will never find me falling in love with anything 'kitchen.') Â She also has a USB port so I can charge my electronics. Â I know she like me - because I always feel hugged when I sit in her.My husband got the same chair in a darker color. (left)Sorry these pictures are so dark.And, yes, she is a 'she!' Â I checked.Â Â ğŸ˜Â A 'he' wouldn't make me feel this comfortable.So I have gone and done it again. Â Jumped into the deep end of insanity.At least it will be a comfortable landing.Legs propped up looking at my Christmas Tree in December.Also you can see the kind of furniture we usually got - mostly wood.Isn't it ironic that I should follow up a post on exercisewith a post about my new LazyBoy recliner chair?Did anyone notice that? Â Ha!

title: Eyes on 2019: Exercise
text: !! Exercise !!It should be one of those bad 'four letter words.'And yet when I do it I feel so much better.At my age - exercise is not an option.And I am not happy about that.Â Various parts of me stop working well when they rest for too long. Trite but true - Use it or lose it!Don't you just hate it when 'trite but true' is ... well, true!In 2018 I had no exercise goals, but I did do stuff. Â I participated in an aerobic class 2 times a week and on the weight machines 2 times a week. Â Routine - magic word.But all that fell apart at the end of last year. Â  I hurt my shoulder and was advised by my doctor to leave the weight machines alone for about 8 months. Â Toning - gone. Then my aerobic class changed from Mondays Wednesdays to Tuesdays Thursdays. Â I can never do Thursdays. Â Aerobic activity - gone.There goes my routine.Couch potato time!!For 2 months I did pretty much nothing beyond thinkingon the couch -Â (by the way ... thinking is not an aerobic or toning activity ... just in case anyone was wondering.) Â Everything needs to change in 2019. Â And man ... do I hate change! Â  I found a Monday Wednesday class called Power. Â It uses free weights, a step lift, exercise ball and bands ... and is designed for toning and muscle strength. Â I have givenÂ Power a try and I like it a lot.I rented two DVDs from the library. This DVD does not use weights but I thought I would purchasewith this one to begin with. Â I discovered in class that getting down on to the floor and get up againwas so much easier using a step up of about 4 inches. Â There aregraduated risers just like in class to increase effort.In fact I liked it so much I got a step lift for the condo - and an exercise DVD to use when I miss going to Power. Â The work out is similar. Â Now to just work it into my day. Â One problem solved.Aerobics is a stickier problem. Â The DVD I purchased does address aerobics as well so maybe I can kill two birds with one stone. Â Or I'll go back to walking. Â It won't be an ideal solution in my neighborhood because it isn't really walker friendly. Â  But no matter. Â I have a blogging friend who walks in her basement on bad days. Â If she can walk in her basement Â (for 6 miles of steps, I might add) I can walk in my neighborhood. Â If you don't believe me about 6 miles a day, check out Life is Good - a blog by my friend HappyOne - Karen. Â She inspired me to blog.It is a plan, at least, for now.Â Â Without a plan or a routine, I will do nothing,(and doing nothing is not toning or aerobic activity ... just in case you were wondering.)ğŸ˜

title: Go Deeper Not Wider
text: So I have been tootling around the blog world looking for interesting blogs - blogs with ease of commenting. Â In my search I discovered this one:Â Raptitude.com - Getting Better At Being Human. (Just a tiny point of clarification: Â no one should think I am interested in getting better at being humanÂ - and that is the first sign that 'bettering' is probably needed!!)Â Ha!!Â Â No, I was pulled into the blog by the current post called Â Go Deeper Not Wider.As I read this post I can honestly admit I felt a "wow factor." Â  It was like this guy was peeking in the window of my brain and finding something growing there that I was aware of but did not or could not express. Â And he expressed it so well.In his own words his thoughts on Go Deeper Not Wider:*****No new hobbies, equipment, games, or books are allowed during this year. Instead, you have to find the value in what you already own or what youâ€™ve already started.You improve skills rather than learning new ones. You consume media youâ€™ve already stockpiled instead of acquiring more.You read your unread books, or even reread your favorites. You pick up the guitar again and get better at it, instead of taking up the harmonica. You finish the Gordon Ramsey Masterclass you started in April, despite your fascination with the new Annie Leibovitz one, even though itâ€™s on sale.The guiding philosophy is â€œGo deeper, not wider.â€ Drill down for value and enrichment instead of fanning out. You turn to the wealth of options already in your house, literally and figuratively. We could call it a â€œDepth Yearâ€ or a â€œYear of Deepeningâ€ or something.Â *****I encourage you to read the post completely. Â I believe it reflects and compliments a lot of current thinking in areas of minimalism, anti-consumerism, finding joy in what you have, and other growing ground swells of thought. Â Â I am not sure I am up to any formal challenge or experimenting (his term) of 'deeper vs wider.' Â But it does feel comfortable in my brain - and it is nice to have this image in my mind. You see, I recognize the pattern of 'going wide' as a common pattern in my life.I have a room full of yarn and about 5 three inch binders full of patterns - and I need to stop that expansion. Â I won't live long enough to use all the yarn and patterns I have now. Â That is not an idle statement. Â I have counted the yardage and averaged the usage. Â There is yarn in my yarn room that will outlive me!! I have three weaving looms. Â I am not weaving. Â I have two tapestry looms - I do have plans to do that. Â I have fiber spindles and fiber - I don't spin. Â I used to have a spinning wheel but in a moment of mental clarity I gave that to a cousin who was interested in spinning.Adult coloring was all the rage a few years ago. Â I got hooked. Â I have several types of color pencils (not the cheap kind either) and probably 6 books - beautiful books. Â I have colored about 2 1/2 pages ... only!!! Â When I look at this hobby I think - yes I would like to return. I really enjoyed it. Â But seriously, 6 books with only a few pages completed?!?!I have a iPhone phone with lots of memory and 61 audio books are housed there. Â 61!! Â If each audio book averages 10 hours a piece of listening time and I have 61 - that is over 610 hours of listening or about 25 days of listening round the clock! Â Ridiculous! Â My Kindle library is about 6 screens long with titles just waiting to be read. Â I kindle read only before bed and while I eat - at that rate I could read these titles probably for a year without adding to them.My Craftsy account has 9 previously purchased classes. Â I have viewed a few, but when Craftsy went to Bluprint they offered a one year membership - at a reduced rate - which would allow you to select 12 classes to keep permanently - AND a year to view any of their classes on line for free. Â Wow - great offer - a large savings on their class costs - so I joined right up because this would be the year I would take some instruction. Â I can't travel to it - so at home instruction is PERFECT! Â But ... really, now instead of 9 classes that I haven't fully viewed, I will have 12 more. Â I probably went 'deep' with some advanced instruction in current hobbies, but I think I went 'wide' by expanding of the class numbers I have yet to view. Â *sigh*Â I have a pantry that is a hard-hat area! Â And yet, my grocery shopping adds more to the stack of food stuffs then I use up. Â What's with that?? Â I HATE cooking. Â Sometimes I feel like I am unconsciously preparing for the apocalypse.I could go on, but the bald-faced truth is this - I need to go 'deep' Â ... Â not 'wide.' Â  I think I have been moving in this direction unconsciously over the last year. Â I avoid yarn stores, and yarn websites and I try to limit my purchases at yarn fairs. Â I have de-stashed yarn and books and patterns, but to the casual eye - the dent is hard to see even with a microscope. Â I did give away a full size spinning wheel Â and a lap loom and that felt wonderful! We will not even address the pantry issues here (but I am ready for Zombies - in case you are wondering.).Final thoughts on the Raptitude blog:He has a deep inventory of posts on various subjects. Â He currently does about 2 posts a month - and many of the titles are intriguing. Â I have only read this one, but I know I will visit again to look at his other posts. Â I did subscribe to his blog.His blog is not a personal life sharing blog like mine or like so many I follow. Â He does have a tab where he documents individual experiments (on himself) and logs the process. Â And I noticed that while there is some commenting, he closes his commenting after a bit. Â Finally, the blogger doesn't claimÂ to have any professional expertise - and that is fine by me. Â Sometimes when a blogger has professional creds and lets you know what they are - I can't help wonder what they are trying to 'sell.' Â This blog appears to be just his thoughts and ideas. Â He appears to be just a writer-guy out of Canada that thinks a lot about these subjects and wants to share his thoughts. Â Not much different from us other bloggers, I guess. Â In previous years I picked a word to point in the direction I wanted to go. Â It is a popular habit among bloggers. Â I didn't plan on picking a word this year, but after reading this post - 'Go Deep' fits me like hand to glove.Â Â  Check him out - or at least check out this postÂ and let me know what you think.Do you prefer going 'deep' or going 'wide?'

title: Winter
text: Here we are in my favorite season.WinterYes, I know I am odd. I look at this seeming perversity this way ... Â no sense in joining the fan club a season that is already crowded with tons of fans - all those folks that love Â ğŸ’• spring, or live for the heat of Â ğŸ˜ summer, or are blinded by the beauty of Â ğŸÂ  autumn. Â The fan base for those seasons ... just too crowded.â›„ğŸ”ğŸ‚I love winter.â„â…â†And I think winter loves all its fans special because we are so few.My holiday season passed without problems - thankfully. Â Family and friends filled the days with happiness. Â It is always a hard season for me, but my reward, as always, is reaching Winter. Â Lovely, cold, crisp air, at times white, wet and pure. Â Weather that draws one inside for indoor activities - like reading, hot coffee, knitting, binge TV shows, blankets and shawls, soups and stews, and ... time to think.Think on it! Â Who wouldn't love sitting by a warm fire, with comfortable fuzzy slippers on, a tasty drink beside you and a favorite book or favored hobby on your lap - while Nature covers the outside with a dressing of white snow. Of course, it would help to have a fire place, which I do not. Â But you get the idea.Forecasts for our area promise an 'active' snow-filled winter. Â Living in a condo means snow is not a problem. Â I can enjoy the beauty of this season without effort. Win-win!When I was younger and working - snow was still beautiful but a challenge. Â First I would fight my way shoveling down my short sidewalk from the front door, then down 20 snow filled steps filled with the shovel Â - then across another short side walk until I reached my car - and then (not done yet ...) dig out the car and the space behind it until I could reach the plowed areas. Â I get exhausted now even talking about. Â So glad I left that behind.I am a good snow driver even though I don't venture out much now. Â I was taught to snow-drive by a father who was raised in Pennsylvania. Â Those Pennsylvania folks know what they are doing in snow. Â I learned the survival techniques of not getting myself stuck as well as how to avoid all those nutty drivers who have no skills and no snow capable vehicle. Â Those skills saved me more times than I can count. Â Working in health care I was one of those folks who needed to get on the road and arrive at work no matter the weather. Â My boss was a Cardiologist who arrived at work on skis and if one of his heart patients showed up in bad weather (and they usually did) he would see them. Â I personally would have thought driving in those tough conditions was enough of a cardiac 'stress test' and that putting them on a treadmill was redundant!! Â Ha. So I am looking forward to my exciting weather season ... just as I do every year!Welcome Winter!â„â…â†Your small but dedicated fan base is faithfully here.

title: Blog Soul Searching
text: Blogging has grown from a solitary activity, where I wrote for myself only, into a community activity where I visited folks' blogs, and they visited mine, and we converse through commenting, and a friendship of sorts develops, and the sharing of life experiences deepens the whole experience for everyone.Unfortunately that process has totally stalled for me. No matter what approach I take, I am not recognized as logged into Blogger or Google when I visit most blogs. Â I used to be able to leave a comment if I was persistent and stepped through pages and pages of screens matching "cross walks" and "cars" and "buses" and "bikes" to prove I am not a robot. Now even that option is gone. Â After many tries it dumps me out of the system.The only way I can participate on your blog is if your blog uses 'pop up comments' rather than 'embedded comments.' Â Only one or two blogs in my reading list use pop up comments.I thought long and hard about quitting blogging. Â An important piece of the process has been taken away. Â Then I remembered how I started! Â Just me and my computer and this blog. Â Nobody else. Â So actually I am back to step one - but with readers now that I cannot return a visit to any more. Â That makes me sad, but until something changes in blogger I am stuck with it.So after thinking long and hard, I am going forward. Over time, if I am blocked from commenting because I am unable to prove I am not a robot ... I will unsubscribe. Â I'll build another reading list of folks who use "pop up commenting." Â I have no choice. I want that 'give and take' of conversation back again. I don't want to visit your blog like a ghost and pass on without saying hello. Â My reading list will be substantially smaller, I fear, because I think the default when a blog is built is "embedded commenting." Â But that will have to be OK. Starting again!I'll be back to blogging again soon.

title: Eyes on 2019:  Crafting
text: Did you make crafting plans in 2018?Did you check back to see how much you completed?Or are you a spontaneous soul - that likes doing things on a whim?Really, either approach has its pluses and minuses!I am a planner. Â I start thinking about the next year in November - not intentionally - but my brain starts percolating. Â Plans firm up more in December. Â By January I usually have a fleshed out list - a map for the New Year. Â Do I get it all done? Â Nope, but it gives me satisfaction to see the road ahead.After all, January is kind of a natural beginning. This post is focused on my crafting life. Â I looked back at my plans for 2018 and here is what I found:KnittingRed hoodie for grand daughter (Done - and I did a pink shawlÂ collar sweater and matching hat so it counts as 2 sweaters.)A cable sweater for grand nephew (Done - No cable sweater but a sweater and hat combination for this Christmas. Â In fact, I did 2 sweaters for him ... could anyone forget the first defective sweater I ranted on about? I think thisÂ counts as 2 sweaters.)Â A knitted toy for grand daughterÂ (Nope)A summer something for my grand daughter. (Nope - decided she was growing too fast to aim for this summer)Baby blanket for my grand daughter. Â (Done - The Zookeeper's Blanket.)A sweater for myself (Nope!)Shawl - with beads - for my daughter-in-law. (Nope)Shawl - with beads - for my daughter. (Nope).Â CrochetAmigurumi toy (Started, but ... will finish in 2019)SpinningSpindle spinning (Nope)NeedlepointSelect canvas and yarns to ending in a finished project some in 2019. Â (Nope)See what I mean ...a road map of sorts.********2019 projects are firming up.Knitting and Crochet(All sample pictures below are pulled from Ravelry)Joyal - Dress by Taiga Hillard. Â Dresses for grand daughterJoyal by Taiga HillardI love this little dress: simple, feminine and practical. Â It can be worn in the summer as shown, or in cooler weather with a long sleeve shirt under it - and as the child grows it can be worn as a tunic with pants. Â I have two yarns chosen by 29 Bridges Studio of Maryland: Â Coral Reef - a cream with speckles of red and rust and Prue - a solid red. Â This is a Super Wash Yarn.Spring Garden Tee by Alana DakosSpring Garden Tee by Alana DakosThis garment is a feminine tee perfect for spring and summer. I have Cascade yarns Sunseeker yarn, cotton and acrylic - that is machine wash and dry. Two colors: Â a light orange and a light green (two tops) with very subtle sparkles in the yarn. Â Perfect for a child. Three sweaters for me.This goal seems a little indulgent. Â ThreeÂ sweaters? Â I have hand made sweaters and I seldom wear them. Â There is always something that is not quite right about them. Â But ... ever hopeful me, I will find the perfect pattern for me. Â Here are my choices.Shibui Knits - Cirrus by Nancy O'Connell. Â This is described as a poncho. Â It is poncho-like. Â It has a cowl neck, wide sleeves and a curved hem. Â The pattern was a bit pricy ($10) but free if you purchased the Shibui Knits yarn. Â Unfortunately that yarn was well over $200 to purchase and I was pretty sure I had just the right yarn in my stash. Â Obviously, we shall see. Â I usually get into trouble when I substitute yarns. Â *sigh*. The yarn I have chosen is Brooks Farm Yarn Mas Acero in a black/gray/dark lavendar color ways - the colors have very short runs.Â Cirrus by Nancy O'ConnellHarley by Jenny Williams. Â I purchased the yarn this pattern for different sweater 2 or 3 years ago and discovered before I made the whole darn sweater ... the first pattern would not be right for me. Â I picked this new pattern. Â The yarn is by Purl SoHo and is 75% Extra Fine Merino and 25% Cashmere and it was expensive so I don't want it sitting in balls in my stash. Â The color is called Tidepool and is not far different from the color in the picture - except that the Purl SoHo yarn color seems to look somewhat green in certain light, blue in another light and gray in yet another light. Interesting yarn.Harley by Jenny WilliamsLady Jane by Susan Mills. Â I set my sights on this sweeter probably 10 years ago. Â I am going to make it this year! Â It is perfect for every day use. Â Yarn choice still under consideration.Lady Jane by Susan MillsMignon byÂ Justin Lorkowska - Sweater for my grand nephew's August birthday.I found this pattern for him before he was born and just loved it. Â Originally on my 2018 list, I decided to wait to make a bigger size - 2T - so he has time to wear it longer for winter 2019-2020. Â This is a top down designed pullover with Honeycomb panels. Â The yarn I have is Cascade Yarns, 220 Superwash Sport in a seafoam blue.Mignon by Justin LorkowskaCreate 3 cowls - one for me, my daughter and my daughter-in-law - I have made many shawls but don't wear them as much as I thought I would. Â No shawls this year - just cowls. Â No patterns or yarns picked yet - but I have plenty of both and just need time to make decisions and put both together into kits ready to knit.Gnomes - these are so darn cute. Â I have no choice but to make several of them. Â Nothing but the pattern picked so far.TapestryI started a basic 'learn-to-do tapestry' sampler from a book in 2018. Â I enjoyed it, but got swept away in children's projects ... and so the incomplete sampler sits idle. Â I'd like to finish it and do an actual tapestry picture this year. So those are my plans for 2019! Â I think the scope of the projects is probably way to large but oh well. Â  Â I have stopped looking at all pattern websites and yarn companies. Â The more I look, the more I think I would like to do. Â It never ends.Do you make craft plans?

title: HELP - A Study in Frustration
text: !!HELP!!I have reached the tipping point in frustrationÂ on commenting in a number of the blogs I follow.It has become so frustratingÂ that I often visit a blog and pass on without stopping to chat!Â Â And that just kills me!!So here is the problem from my end:If the comments setting on your blog is set to "Embedded" - (meaning that when I select the comment button, I don't get a "pop up window") ... your blog with embedded comments does not recognize me as signed into Google and it does not let me comment without a going through many many steps. Â The first step offers me 3 options to sign in to comment with minor frustration:Google Account - this option shows me signed as signed into Google on only one blog and her blog uses the Pop Up window designation - all other blogs do not give me the ability to sign in - even if I am already signed in to Blogger and Google! Â In fact, I also get a prompt to log into Google before my comment is posted, because it is a better way to manage comments. Â And if I choose the Google Account option - post my comment - and hit Post - it acts like it is posting it, but it never shows on the blog. Â Sooo Frustrating.Name/URL - which I now use most of the time: Â Elaine (Retired Knitter) and then I key in my web address. Â This is OK - but not preferred.Anonymous - which I don't use - I don't want to be anonymous and some blogs don't accept thatÂ The second step - Prove That I Am Not a Robot - is where things get very frustrating:I get dumped into reCaptcha that shows me pictures after pictures after pictures of Crosswalks, Buses, Cars, Fire hydrants - over and over again. Â I took notes - the average number of screens I am offered is 4 - that means that sometimes I get 6 or 7 screens before I am accepted. Â And those screens are small and grainy and just hard to see. Â That is NOT OK!PLEASE TELL ME THAT THIS PROBLEM IS NOT JUST MINE!Yes, I know some of this is a Blogger Platform problem! Â How many readers leaving comments on my blog have had this same problem? Â Does anyone have a suggestion or a fix for this problem that I can do from my end?Â Here is what I am doing on my blog:My blog uses "Pop Up Window" commenting. Â Please, please, please, consider changing your blog to "Pop Up Window" commenting. Â For some reason it is less problematic for the commenter. Â "Embedded Comments" have more problems.I have removed the reCaptcha and the Robot Check from my blog. Â Yes, this is a risk. Â I am going to give this a try for awhile to see if it makes things easier for visitors who want to comment. Â If you are reading this post (follower or not),Â please, please, please,Â leave me a comment andÂ then let me know what happened.Â I may need to put Moderation back on my blogs to protect it from Spam, but for now I will just "fly without a parachute" and see what happens.Finally, if I can't find a work around on this problem, I will stop trying to comment on blogs that have Embedded comments. Â Sorry, folks! Â This is is supposed to be fun and it definitely isn't. Â I will still swing by and read what you are up to - but no commenting.

title: Rocky Point Disappearing
text: Rocky Point, Long Island, New YorkAn Interesting and Beautiful PlaceThis is one of many cross stitch pieces given to my mom by her long time friendfrom Rocky Point. They were very good friends.In my recent visit to see my mom's life long friend in October (story here), I learned about Rocky Point, Long Island, New York, her chosen home. It has a dynamic and surprising history.A *Nor'Easter storm was coming through on theday of our visit. Â The winds were blowingand it was very wet. Â This street where my mom'sfriend lives was beautiful just the same.At 93 years of age mom's friend has many wonderful memories of Rocky Point. Â During our visit she shared what Rocky Point was in her youth and what it is today.Her home - updated and expanded over the years fromthe original cottage of the 1930s.On the surface this community has a wooded 'settled' feeling with long established year round homes nestled within its boundaries. Â Initially filled with summer cottages in the 1930s, now it has a mix of updated year-round structures and a few of the original summer cottages. This path leads down to the Long Island Sound. Â At the path's head, the sign said"No Tresspassing" but my sister and I decided it didn't apply to us. ğŸ˜†.If we hadn't taken the path, we would have missed the amazing views of the soundduring angry weather.But the 'settled' feeling is a false one. Â Time and nature is making dramatic changes to this land. We were almost at the water's edge at this point.The picture doesn't do the angry waves justice! Â Theypoured over that bulkhead. Â The bulkhead is important.It holds down the erosion of the coast for the house located above the cliff. Right beside theÂ bulkhead the erosion is huge.Walking back up the hill - my sister ahead of me.The wind was strong.During our visit we noticed a picture mounted on the wall. Â It was a kind of map of the Rocky Point. Â Shown in dark blue background with light print, it had the look of a surveyor's document. Â Individual plots of land, roads and the shoreline of the Long Island Sound showed the scope of the area in the 1930s. Â Our host explained that this picture showed Rocky Point as it was when her great aunt purchased the cottage (now a winterized and expanded home) we were standing in. Â She pointed out exactly where we were figuratively in this map of the area.Now for the big disconnect.Standing at the front door of her home I could see a row of houses across the street that runs parallel to the rugged cliff coast line beyond. Â Those houses back yards' end at the cliff's edge that drops off sharply into the Long Island sound.But standing looking at the long ago map of Rocky Point, I see that my current location is many parallel streets away from that cliff. All the land shown was divided into many many individual plots where houses resided. Â That land, those roads, and those cottages are all gone!In fact, several houses just across the street were already considered 'Condemned' by the State. Â And one house was gone .... off the cliff. Â All that remained was the front yard and a road side mail box.In the fore front - the road my mom'sfriend lives on. Â Behind that is asolitary mailbox. Â Behind themailbox is a fence located in what usedto be the front yard of a house.The house is gone.Yes, my mom's friend lives in a house that used to be be far from the coast ... and now is exactly one street and one row of houses away from being cliff side.The supports of a houseÂ that fell off the cliff into the Long Island Sound.It was Â Geology 101 for me. Â Geology 101 talked about land changes in terms of hundreds of years - even thousands of years. Â But changes demonstrated so dramatically and stunningly within the span of one life time ... Â that chapter was not covered in my class. Â  When my mom's friend inherited the Rocky Point property in the 1960s she had the foresight to check with a geologist. Â His assessment in the 1960s was that her property would last until the end of her life - but maybe not until the end of her children's lives.The story of a fast disappearing coast line - is hard to ignore when recognized over a very short period time. Â Yes, this coastline has probably been receding for hundreds of years. Â But would it have been so easily measured if man had not built right up to the shoreline back in the 1930s? Â And would there actually be less erosion if accelerated global warming was not whipping up violent storms to pound on this coast? Â And could man do something - like sand dunes seen in beach communities to slow the march of this destruction?The next day was BEAUTIFUL. Â Fall colors still held onto the trees despite the winds that whipped at it.The pictures of this beautiful area do not do justice to the beauty and drama that is Rocky Point, Long Island. I am glad I got to see the splendor of this place - and the drama of it as well. Â During our visit the area was experiencing a *Nor'easter. Â This strong storm was churning the Sound and chipping away at the shoreline as it has done hundreds of times. Â Even once the shoreline claims our host's home, there will still be many properties behind her that will still stand. Â But as time passes each house will take its turn at being 'beach front' property ... until they aren't any more.The sky and the sea was beautiful. Just beyond the white fence, the cliff drops off.I am standing in a back yard of a condemned house -condemned because it will take its turn to fall intothe Sound.The quiet of the next day! Future years may not be quiet for this little house.But today, all is well.One last look at a yard - and property behindthe fence that is disappearing.It is just nature at work- relentlessly!*Â Nor'easters are usually accompanied by very heavy rain or snow, and can cause severe coastal flooding, coastal erosion, hurricane-force winds, or blizzard conditions.Â Nor'easters are usually most intense during winter in New England and Atlantic Canada (definition from Wikipedia.)

title: The Quiet Holiday - A Gentle Reminder
text: As we approach the Christmas season, it is time for a gentle reminder. Â Amidst the flood of holiday cheer and good will, there are those who may desire to skip the merrymaking. Â The reasons are many. Â A first holiday without a loved one or friend, serious health or money problems, and some, like myself, have memories around this time of year that are like scars over a wound.Of course you can't miss the commercial signs of Christmas. Â  The festive decorations in red and gold and green that cover shopping malls, homes, even cars ... seasonal music pouring into our ears, trees gayly decorated and beautifully wrapped gifts. Â TV shows with charming holiday stories that all have a happy ending. Â The societal prompts are everywhere - "Be Happy!"And yet ... Be Happy ... Â Well, it has not been my response for many years to this holiday. Â I make an effort to keep those sad reflective feelings at arms length around others in December. Â But I feel the need to remind all on behalf of the "Less Than Happy Club" of which I am a member, that Christmas is not always a joy filled.My memories ...shared with you as a one example of the struggle some havethis time of year.Â Old memories ... as an elementary teacher pulled suddenly from my students, Â .... standing in the school secretary's office decorated in reds and greens and golds, hearing mom's voice say over the phone the words "dad just died," Â tears, Â confused faces of my second graders as I left them with a substitute in the middle of their holiday party ... waiting outside for my husband to pick me up, disbelief, seeing another staff member, arms filled with holiday cheer for a staff party, smiling and happy, and seeing the smile fade as I said the words ... Â and within days standing at mom's side in a funeral home that was decked out with the reds and the golds and the greens of the season, helping to pick out a casket while Christmas music filtered softly through the speakers, hearing her whisper, "I hope he knew that I loved him."The date was December 23, 1970. Â I was 23. Â I remember it like it was yesterday.Years pass. Â The holiday subtly changed. Â Bad things do happen when the world seems happy. Â New to me at age 23. Â Children were born, memories were put aside with purpose and with determination. Â Some joy seeped back in.Fresher memories ... the same music, the same reds, the same golds, the same greens of the season, the same joy in the air ... Â except it was December and my 85 year old mom moved in assisted living. Â Christmas was hard. Â And the next year was harder, always harder. Â I began to dread the signs of the approaching happy season. Â My mantra Â ... I will get passed this - then 'normal' can return. Until Christmas 2014 came. Â The same of everything was back. Â Again. Â Music, greens, golds and reds, decorated trees, gifts. Â All the same - except three days before Christmas a new image was added ... a nurse sitting me down ... the words "your mother is dying." Â Regrets expressed, only a few days left, comfort drugs for her, can I do anything for you or your family. Truly, what little joy of the season in me was sucked out. December 28, 2014 she died. Â I was 67. Â I know that was 4 years ago,but it is really only yesterday in my mind.Scars upon scars. The 'happy' season is different for me now.I accept the memories now. Â They are a part of who I am. Â Not something to be swept aside. Â It is an anniversary of a sort that two important people passed from this life during the happiest time of the year. Â And one life, mine, changed because of it.My experience isn't unique. Â Nursing homes report a high incidence of death at Christmas. Â And the troublesome problems of life continue - missing a loved one, financial problems, health problems, emotional upheaval - despite the constant unending message of December to "Be Happy."So remember as you move through this month some folks are struggling. Â They may still smile and laugh and appear to be engaged in the wonder that is the Christmas season. Â But they may be wearing a mask. Â I know that I do.Be kind. Â Be understanding. Â Be tolerant of their need for space from the season. Â Be happy yourself. Â But remember, sometimes 'happy' is not the goal for some -Â sometimes just a quiet peaceful holiday is all that can be achieved.And that is ok.

title: Observations of Living in a 55+ Community
text: Do you ever look back at a major life decision and wonder if you would have made the same decision if you had known then what you know now?After 2 years of living in a 55+ community, I have made some interesting observations about this style of living and our decision to move here.When this community was being built in 2007, it was a very popular option for interested seniors. Â I understand from some original owners that there was a waiting list for units. Â New owners initially fell between ages 55-65 ... younger seniors. Â All moved in within a year or two of each other as the development was built. Â All had similar motivations and were inspired to make this new style of living successful for themselves. Â Newsletters, committees, social activities, and active board of directors (some report an over active board that ruled with an iron fist) were the norm. Â Naturally there was an excitement in wanting to make your "new home" perfect.That is what I briefly know about this communities early years!I have impressions of how this community has changed over time and what it is now. We moved into this condo when it was about 14 years old. Â When we were searching for a condo we looked for specific things: an evaluator, less living space to manage, lower living costs, a reasonable condo fee, pet friendly, geographically close to our kids, and a property that was cared for and financially viable. Â We weren't looking for some of the more typical considerations - amenities like organized social activities, business center services, or exercise equipment. Â In fact, we were initially not even looking for a senior community and we were looking for places without those typical amenities. Â The fact there is no newsletter or committees or social calendar is just fine with us. we did not want to pay for things we would not use - those amenities comes with a high dollar price tag in the form of elevated condo fees. Â Nothing is free.Some of you were readers of my blog as I struggled with the decision to move and to find the right place. Â You might remember just how emotionally draining and exhausting the whole process was. Â I have some observations on the pluses and minuses of the decision I made two years ago. Â Plus: Ease of interior maintenance - since I am the one doing all the maintaining - this is important. Â Minus: Vanilla is not my favorite flavor - I like variety. Â I miss the mix of residents that we used to have - families with young children, singles, Halloween Trick or Treaters.Plus: Â Definitly cheaper - a big plus. Â We have an adequate retirement, but time and inflation can eat into that nest egg. Â Expenses are stable here with no large jumps in the condo fee. Â No external issues to manage like when the roof leaks or the snow falls. Â Minus: Â Less control over making sure the exterior is repaired and maintained. Â Property ages. Â Halls need painting, hall carpet needs replacing ... now at 16 years old, this property needs on going maintenance.Â Plus: Â Quieter - neighbors are more considerate of how they live their lives and how it might impact others than in more vibrant younger communities.Â Minus: Â Moving after 55 - at least for me - means leaving behind a place called home of 30 years. Â That same feeling will be unlikely here.Â Plus: Â More time for me and my personal pursuits. Â Minus: Â Some folks who live here are aged past the point of being independent safely. Â That is an issue everywhere, but when you live in a senior community, it is more evident.Plus: Â You can build new friendships among your peers when you are surrounded by your peers! Â I have been very lucky to make several friends in this community. Â Nothing is perfect - every style of living after a certain age carries some concerns. Â We certainly could not have anticipated some of my minuses and pluses when making this decision two years ago. Â But despite the minuses - I am still content with our choice.It is nice to know that! Glad that looking back didn't result in regrets!

title: Making Plans
text: Making PlansThat's where November always leads me.Now, make no mistake. Â These are not resolutions! Â I have taken the stand to 'resolve' nothing!! Â Especially at the beginning of a new year.Resolutions typically involve something personal like losing weight, or exercising more, or sticking to a budget. Â They seem to focus on improving something about yourself. Â I have personal goals like this but I have moved away from hanging the start date for these goals to the first of the year. Â It never works for me.But November ... that's different! I feel the pull to make plans for the next year - sort of like a to-do list for the coming year. Â I guess it is a lot like what gardeners do in February, as they scour the seed catalogs ear marking pages, making lists and placing orders for their spring-summer gardens. Its a plan, not a resolution.Over the last few weeks I have been thinking and planning and organizing to make two significant projects (from different sides of my life) happen in 2019.Project from the fun side of my life:A Knitting PlanKnitting Projects in 2019:Â  I am building a list, and creating the yarn and pattern kits in preparation for next year's knitting. Doing this will mean I won't be swallowed up by only kids projects (as much fun as they are) - finally getting to a sweater for myself two years in the waiting. Â Slim down the patterns: Â How many patterns does one person need! Â To find any inspiration in that pile of paper is impossible. Time to recycle most of it.My yarn: Â It owns me ... I don't own it. Â Recently I tried to find some yarn in that avalanche of skeins and it was so frustrating. Â Far from fun. Â I have to find a way to own that yarn again - and not the other way around.Â Project from the business side of my life:A Hold-It-All-Together PlanAs with most couples, my husband and I shared the responsibilities of our married life for almost 50 years. Â As my husband's disability has grown, the sharing has shrunk. Â Slowly his to-dos got added to my to-dos ... Â and along the way new to-dos out of necessity also got added to my list. At the same time, however, my aging brain is saying -"Lady, you are getting older -Â and so is your brain -Â AND you have already filled me up -Â AND there is no room to add more stuff -ANDI am retired, you know!!"Â So what to do, what to do.Enter my invention -My Book of Many Things!Ok, this is not exactly my invention. Â It is a carved out piece of The Bullet Journal method. Â Here is a second link on Bullet Journaling. Â What I think I need to do is extract just the pieces of The Bullet Journal system I need to help track all the details that I don't want to store in my brain. Â These details are not to-dos. Â They are more the reference materials of my life.Lost? Â Let me explain further.See, my life isn't as crazy daily or even weekly as it used to be - so the calendar portion of the bullet journal system is not very useful to me. Â That calendar feature was built on the idea of Â 'to-dos' lists that could be juggled and adjusted daily within your bullet journal. Â That calendar system is great, by the way, and I used it when we moved. Â It saved my butt as I independently juggled downsizing, purchasing property, moving, and selling property - all in a 6 month period! Â I kiss the ground the inventor walks on because kept me from totally de-compensating during a stressful life event. Â But now life is more peaceful and my to-dos don't consume me like they used to. Â I keep a wall calendar for appointments, and daily 3x5 cards with to-dos. Â That simple process works for me now. But there is a sea of information that needs a place to reside outside my brain. Â It is sort of the reference material of my life - the big picture stuff - the future road maps - beyond just cleaning the toilet today or dusting the bricka-bracka tomorrow! Â Archiving it in writing into a single place is the plan I am working on. That single place is my Book of Many Things 'cause that is what it will hold.So what kind of information am I talking about. Â Here is my initial collection:Knitting List for 2019List of packing items when traveling or off for the weekend. Â I hate building that list every time I pack a suitcase.Budget Plans and schedulesBlog post ideasLog ins and passwordsKnitting Group RotationMovies/Books Titles - what I have read or what I plan to readFuture purchases or wish listsBirthdays/AnniversariesMenu plans for big celebrationsDoctors and their demographicsRight now this stuff is scattered in a number of places. Â There isn't a real logic to its location. Â And sometimes they are housed in locations that made sense when I did it, but they no longer make sense - and I can't find it.I am still sorting out if I want a bound book or if I want a 3 ring binder. Â A bound book has more appeal to me. Â My life has a lot of 3 ring binders in it and I don't think the ability to insert or replace pages is a big enough draw to pull me away from the idea of a bound book. Â I like the permanency of a bound book. Â And the Bullet Journal System is built on a bound book.Obviously the Knitting and the Book of Many Things projects need more thought and planning.I am in the planning part of this process now ...Â 'cause it is November,Â and it is what I apparently do in November!!

title: Not a Minimalist
text: I am greatly inspired by the movement called Minimalism. Â I have read books and followed blogs by folks who espouse minimalism ... those who describe what it looks like and what it doesn't look like ... those who have used broad brush stokes to explain it - like "Less is More" and those who nail down the concept to the point of how to organize your sock drawer. Seriously, I love that minimalism defies definition.Plug the word minimalism into any online search engine and a plethora of links and titles pop up. Â So I won't bother to enumerate titles I have read and enjoyed. Â If you link the word "frugal" to minimalism in your mind, I will say most definitely, it is not the same thing at all.For me minimalism is simply reaching of "enough." Â Enough for your needs - be they physical or emotional or mental. Â Moving beyond "enough" or more than your needs is not a minimalist.So why do I even mention this at all.When I discovered the minimalist movement maybe 10 years ago, I strived for that. Â Or I should say I strived for magazine equivalent of minimalism. Â  The magazine equivalent looks something like:All surfaces clear of brick-a-bracka.Drawers and closets with space to spare.More visible floor space.Less stuff on the walls.No duplication of items.No items stored for some distant point in time when I 'might' need them.Initially it was an astounding goal to strive for in a household that was more than one person and was filled with the possessions of several family members - possessions built over their life times. Â But no matter. Â I strove for that. Â And as the clutter began to clear - I could feel that sense of well being that has been described over and over again by others.Then when the dust cleared after mom's death, and it was just my husband and I, I really stepped up the push to removed in some way all the stuff that was weighing me down. Â Due to need, I even extended that to how much living space did we (a retired couple) really need to be happy and safe - ending in our move to condo living.Broadly stated, over 10 years we probably reduced our environment baggage by 75%. Â But still ... I didn't fit that 'magazine image' of a minimalist. And then I realized that maybe I was a minimalist after all. Â I had reach my goal of "enough." Then I walked into my yarn room. Â Believe me when I say, I am far beyond 'enough' when it comes to my crafts. Â And then I checked my pantry. Â I am a food hoarder. Â The pantry is always bulging and I can't seem to get that under control. I am not a minimalist. Â I am a person who continues to strive for 'enough' in all things and although that state of being doesn't have a label like "Minimalist" ... I am ok with that. Or maybe I should just make up my own term.I am an "Enough-ist."Â Hmm ... It doesn't roll of the tongue does it!? I am open to suggestions!!

title: Lessons in Friendship and a Trip
text: In the last years of my mom's life I learned many end-of-life lessons. Â As her body and mind failed her, she showed how hard aging can be, how the little steps in "letting go" of independence can drain your enjoyment of life, and how her love of family continued despite all the loss.The lesson of friendship, however, I learned from someone else. A true friendship doesn't fade away because our lives change, or we move away or we get old, or our brain dies slowly. Â Recently I learned that even if we die - that link of lasting friendship and affection is not lost ... unless we intentionally let it go. Â Mom's friend of 65 years had no intention of letting go of anything. Â I learned something about friendship from her one weekend in October.When my mom's friend called me and invited my sister and I to visit her (almost 4 years after mom's death), I was blown away by the invitation. Â She lived far away and had limited mobility and mom's dementia removed mom mentally from her friends. Â But mom's friend managed to keep connected with me over the course of mom's last months. Â Since mom's death, that friendship connection remained strong within her friend - wanting to know about our growing family ... and mom's great grand babies! We were thrilled to get the invitation.Our visit would take us into Long Island, NY by train. Â I love train travel. Â My sister and I looked upon it as an adventure. Â Thankfully my sister is a seasoned traveler so she took control of working out the details of travel.The train turned out to be great fun. Â Who knew they served food and drinks in a dining car! Â We were several train cars away from the dining car, so we walked (read: staggered - train movements, you know) through another car I have never heard of - the Quiet Car! Â Apparently in the Quiet Car - you must be quiet. Â Ha! Â A Quiet Car seemed like an odd thing to find in a bouncy noisy rocking mode of travel. Â Each car has a toilet - thankfully. Â The seats in the train provide a pull down tray and reclining options just like riding on a plane. Â But the similarities between train and air travel stopped there. Â Air travel requires so many security checks before you can even board the plane. Â Train travel? Â Not one security check. Â Sort of like riding a bus - you have your ticket and you just get on - and don't tarry, 'cause that train is rolling out of the station with or without you. The highlight of our trip was seeing Mom's friend again. Â She had retired many years ago to a beautiful area of Long Island called Rocky Point. Â At 93 years of age, she is still as sharp as ever. Â Our conversations with her were interesting and animated. Â She had her share of health issues that limited her mobility, but make no mistake ... she had her mind!My sister and I prepared photo album of our grand babies as a gift for her. Â We also included several pictures of mom during her last years just before the dementia totally took her from us. Â She loved the book and we heard from her daughter that she shared it with others. Riding home on the train after our visit left lots of time for thought and reflection. Â  I couldn't help but marvel at how rich my mom's friendship life was with this woman. Â Mom's friend was always a fire ball of a personality. Â My earliest memories of her (I was probably age 7), are of a woman who was strong of body and mind, energitic and very generous of herself. Â My mom was always a calm accepting kind of a personality who understood more than she ever said. Â Together they complimented each other so well. Â But I was also sad because mom was not here now to enjoy the friendship they had cultivated over a lifetime.We plan to do our share of staying connected with this wonderful woman ... especially now that we know that she has not let go of her friendship with our mom. Â Not even death can take away what they had. Â The album we gave her had lots of open spaces. Â We will keep her current with pictures and notes - and we will take her up on her invitation to return for another visit - probably in the spring. Some lessons in lifeÂ ... well ...Â they brought tears to my eyes more than once that weekend.Next ... a little pictorial of Rocky Point Long Island - the beauty and the reality of living there.
