title: A Rant:  Time to build that wall!
text: Fair WarningÂ to readers.If you are a Trump supporter, please stop reading now. Â This is a rant. Â It is my personal opinion. Â It won't be repeated in the future on this blog,Â but it needs to be said.I am putting up my own "wall,"Â on the crazy and depressing political scene,Â on this day,Â with this blog post.I have lived in a state of disbelief that Trump was elected President. Â  My gut said this man was wrong for this job. Â But in the beginning - without a track record to measure against - it seemed unfair to judge him. Over the first year, I have watched all the repeated 'political fire storms' of this administration on the news and in social media daily. Â Every single day! Â It never ends. Â This President intentionally creates most of his own problems and seems to thrive on it. Â He has made terrible picks for many of his most important positions. Â He says things that have to be 'translated' by his staff, because the general population finds his words at times shocking. Â This past week I watched "Trump: An American Dream" on Netflix. Â The series followed him in his business and personal life up to the point he entered politics for the Presidency. Â It highlighted the fact that his ideas, his words, his behavior, Â has not changed a smidge since he learned to walk and talk. Â Granted - you can argue that any sources of information can be slanted. Â But I have heard enoughÂ words said from his own mouth on cameraÂ Â over and over and over again to know that my gut was right all along. Â This is the wrong man for the job of leader of the free world! (which, by the way, we are not any more.)This month, in a string of upsetting stories (as if the threat of a nuclear war with North Korea and making friendly nations adversaries while admiring our historical adversaries ... if that wasn't enough), I saw a video clip where Trump was admiring the North Korean dictator's followers - all those people who sit up and take notice when their dictator speaks. Â Setting aside the fact this dictator will kill you if you don't 'sit up and take notice,' our President (in his own words - on tape so that there can be no misunderstanding) wants "his people" to do the same for him. Â The President's interpreters wanted us to think he was "joking." Â Joking - no one with two brain cells would believe that after the last year. Â Then the stories of immigrant children being separated at the border from their parents. Â And from the UN yesterday - we have withdrawn our representation on the UN Human Right's Counsel. And that, folks, was just this last month! I am just done. I can't continue to watch our country sink to a new low - every single week - for another 3 years. Â I have all the information I need to confirm that my gut was absolutely correct in 2016.So I am building my own wall - a virtual wall to separate me from the grim drama in our government and the man who creates it. Â I am banishing all Trump information as much as possible - from my life. Â I have seen enough to know that I will vote against him and against anyone who supports him. Â I don't need to hear more. Â  I deleted all Facebook postings (including a few 'friends') from my newsfeed ... people who routinely push Trump stories. Â I will not forward any more Trump posts on Facebook. Â I just add to the stress of others by doing so. Â I no longer watch CNN. I agree with their point of view, but it is Trump, Trump, Trump - 24/7! Â Just can't have a steady diet of it anymore.And I will take the only action available to me - I will vote!It must look to some like I am sticking my head in the sand. Â They would argue that all citizens remain continually informed and ready to fight against America's wanna-be dictator. Â They believe keeping the electorate in a constant of agitation and frustration is the way toward change. Â Maybe ... I hope so.But for me personally, and for my own health and peace of mind, I must look at this situation through a different lens. Â I will vote. Â I will encourage everyone to VOTE. Â My elected representatives already reflect my point of view. Â  They are doing what needs to be done: RESIST. Â In fact, our Governor, Larry Hogan, (a Republican Governor in Democratic Maryland) has pulled our National Guard Troops and a helicopter from the Texas border until the current policy of separating immegrant children from parents is changed. Thank you Governor Hogan. Â It isn't a large gesture because our commitment wasn't that big. Â But it is a stand and a statement! Â Governor Hogan has my vote. Â I look for other states to take the same stand.Voting - the only tool I have. Â I leave all the rest to younger more energetic citizens. VOTE is my mantra!And as for my wall ... Â for the record - I am not asking for anyone else to 'pay' for it or to join me in building one. Â What I am asking of everyone is toVOTEÂ everyone!!Â VOTE!Stepping down off my soap box now. Â I won't be tarnishing my blog with his name ever again.VOTEAn apology and a disclaimer:My apologies to any readers who are ardent Trump supporters. Â It is not my aim to make your position somehow wrong.Â Â But, this is my blog, and my peace of mind has been negatively affected by this elected officialÂ and I have a right to express my opinion on it - on bended knee if I choosebecause the Constitution allows it ...Â at least at this point it does.

title: Commenting Problems.
text: Since returning to blogging I have received a few emails saying they couldn't find a way to comment on the blog. Â Obviously this is not a problem for everyone. Â But I wasn't sure exactly what was happening. Â I checked all my settings and everything seemed fine. Â I send an email message about this problem to Blogger Support Forums. Â Here is their response.*****Your readers need to be identified, using their Blogger / Google accounts.  Unfortunately, some readers security settings block their identity, inadvertently, from the commenting script.http://blogging.nitecruzr.net/2015/05/when-you-comment-you-need-to-be.htmlAny filters are subject to update, by the creator. Â If the problem started a few days ago, your readers may have to look on their computers, and find out what product or accessory was updated, a few days ago.http://blogging.nitecruzr.net/2014/01/almost-nobody-controls-their-own.htmlFirst, as individually possible, each reader should clear cache, cookies, and sessions (yes, all 3) - then restart the browser, and check again.http://blogging.nitecruzr.net/2010/11/clearing-cache-cookies-and.htmlThe Blogger / Google login status, and the ability to post comments, is sensitive to both cookie and script filters. Â Your readers may need to enable (stop filtering) "third party cookies", in their browser and on their computer. And, have them check their script filters, too.http://blogging.nitecruzr.net/2016/04/blogger-magic-enabling-cookies-in-your.htmlhttp://blogging.nitecruzr.net/2016/04/blogger-magic-enabling-scripts-in-your.htmlThird party cookies filtering, in a browser setting, is the most common solution, overall - but your readers may have to search for other filter(s) that affect their use of Blogger / Google.http://blogging.nitecruzr.net/2010/11/blogger-layered-security-and-you.htmlIf any security product has a "block" list, ensure that "blogspot.com" (and any variants, as suggested above) is not in the "block" list.[FAQ] Why Can't I Access My Blog / Comment / Follow Blogs?Trying a different browser or computer is a good diagnostic technique - though not always a permanent solution.http://blogging.nitecruzr.net/2013/09/diagnose-problems-using-differential.html*****Yikes!!Â I had to read this message a few times because I didn't understand it all.  I have made one change.  For a few years I had "Comments Moderation" checked in my settings.  I did this because I started getting targeted with unrelated comments that sounded like a spamming computer created them.  As comments came in, I could review and approve them and post them to the blog ... or delete them after I labeled them as Spam.  One suggestion above was to remove Comments Moderation.   I have done that ... for now.  But I did add "Word Verification" - which will involve you taking an additional step before your comment is posted to my blog.  This step usually filters out automated spamming as well.I would appreciate a few of you checking out your ability to comment on this specific post.  Let me know if you can post AND if the Word Verification step shows up. I have temporarily added my email address to the right side of my blog.  Let me know what you experienced.  Thanks all

title: The Eaglet!
text: Look at that face!!Â Isn't it the most beautiful face ever!!I am talking about Eskarina, of course, my beautiful grand daughter, but the post is actually the story of this baby eaglet! Â This stuffed toy baby eaglet! Â It has a story.You see ... about 37 years ago I was walking down the isle of a grocery story. Â  Yes, a grocery store. Â (Don't you love it when a story takes an unusual turn.) Â I had both my children with me. Â My son was about 7 and my daughter was about 4. Â Grocery stores back then had a child's section of toys that was designed to snag a youngster's attention and increase sales on non-food items. Â Really, it was designed to create an argument over buying this, that or another thing. Â  On this day 37 years ago, it fulfilled its mission.I was about half way down the isle when my son called to me that "this baby eagle needs a home." Â  I remember turning around still staring at my shopping list and eager to finish up. Â I had no intention of being sucked into purchasing a bit of fabric stuffed with artificial polyester - because 'it needed a home.' He did not throw a tantrum - that would have been the quickest way to defeat - he knew that! Â I remember him pleading towards my sympathies. There was no other eagle in the display. Â This 'baby' needed a friend. Â We couldn't just leave him there. Â Who would take care of him. Â Â And so on and so on and so on. Â Â He was so sincere and I could tell he was near tears over this obvious abandonment of a baby eaglet! Â (Remember folks, this is a stuffed animal. Â Just to hammer the point home - it is still a baby stuffed animal 37 years later!!) Â But, no matter. Â My son had instantly bonded emotionally with the plight of this poor baby eagle.Now it should be stated clearly ... I am not heartless. Â I bought that baby eaglet (stuffed animal) ... my son took good care of him AND, after my son had outgrown his stuffed animals, that baby eaglet survived my purge of stuff - actually several purges of stuff - right up to the move to the condo.This past weekend we took our adult children and our grand daughter out to eat - celebratory for an anniversary and a birthday. Â I brought the eaglet to the dinner for Eskarina!And when I pulled it out of the bag, my son got a small smile on his face.Priceless!Â Â Well worth the cost paid 37 years ago!I do it again in a heart beat!!!

title: Eating out of a cooler - and a lesson for everyone.
text: So here is my beautiful newish refrigerator - dead!That is why it is propped open.And here is my current refrigeration system. Â Actually my current refrigeration system has shrunk considerably since June 1, when my 19 month old state-of-the-art refrigerator died full of food in all its compartments. Â On June 2 we started with these two coolers, 4 styrofoam cold chests and two cooler grocery bags. Â And since June 2 (14 days ago) we have purchased ice every single day - for a total of 45 bags of ice (10 pound bags or 450 pounds of ice ... so far!!!) Â Buying ice.Â Every day.Changing out the coolers.Â Every.Single.Day.What a chore!I am so over it!But somewhere around day 10 - after we threw away or ate most of the perishable items, I began to think on this experience as 'camping out' in my condo. Â The upside - I have air conditioning, and there is no sleeping on the ground. Â I don't get rained on. Â No bugs. Â I have cable TV. Â Not too bad for camping. Â And we eat some of our meals as take-out from restaurants. Â Normally eating out is a plus. Â But even restaurant take-out food is getting old. Â Just in case you think we aren't pursuing a fix for this equipment - let me assure - you we are. Â The latest update on the repair - we don't anticipate any forward progress until hopefully next week. Â  It is only a hope now because the last 2 visits from the repairman resulted in disappointment. Â There is an electronic computer board that controls everything (a very expensive piece that is covered completely by our appliance coverage) has come in twice - but was the wrong board. Â What was ordered was right. Â What was received was not.The story gets more complicated because this unit is an LG - and was highly rated by consumers, BUT getting parts is way more difficult than a GE or a Frigidaire unit. Â LG has 3 suppliers in all of the US - one is in New Jersey. Â If the part you need is out of stock, you might have to wait for it to arrive from .... wait for it ... Korea!! Â KOREA!! Â I should have ask Trump to bring one back with him.And the repairman suspects that the reason we keep getting the wrong number - an 07 board - is because LG refrigerators are built in Korea (except when they aren't) and the 07 is a substitute for the 01 which is what we need. Â Ours was built in Mexico and just won't accept the substitute board of 07. If it isn't an 01 - it won't make our fridge run. Â Everyone still with me?Actually the only thing that is important for you (and for us if we are forced to buy another unit), is that when buying appliances, buy brands like GE or Frigidaire. Â As the repairman remarked - really, everything being produced now is trash - even if the consumer ratings are very high (like ours was), and it is better to get a unit where replacement parts are easy to get.Yesterday we went food shopping. Â It was a challenge an adventure. Â Buy only enough fresh veggies for 2 or 3 days. Â Buy only items that are packaged and don't need refrigeration. Â Buy only the smallest Â containers so that once it is opened, it is used up and doesn't need to go on ice.For dinner tonight??Hamburger Helper! Â Yes, I am reduced to Hamburger Helper. Â (My apologies to anyone who buys and enjoys this. Â We used to have this when I didn't know how to cook. Â It was pretty wooden then. Â Doubt things have improved.) Â This one is called Salisbury Steak. Â We will have a tossed salad and some crusty bread with butter.I am planning on topping dinner off with a stiff Vodka Tonic! Â Over ice!!Maybe two!

title: 49 years!
text: Today is the 49th Wedding Anniversary for my husband and me.Sometimes I just can't believe what a big number that is. Â Of course, we will be approaching 50 years married next year. Â Yikes. title: The Zookeeper's Blanket by Justine Walley
text: I am a knitter! Â Not a weaver or a crocheter or a spinner ...Â although I sometimes dabble in those other crafts.Sometimes non-knitting projects grab me ... and won't let me go until I have done them. Crochet is one of those non-knitting project offenders. Â The first project was called The Island Playset and here is the link to that project. Â I owned the pattern for a year before I had a special little boy (a grand nephew born in 2017) that I could make it for. Â When I started it I had to relearn crochet. Â I had to put ice on my left thumb to stop the pain. Â I had to have this project so I pushed on.This year a second project caught my eye called The Zookeeper's Blanket. Â My eyes said "Ohhh. Â You must do this." Â My thumb said "Hell, no. Â I am warning you."This is the Zookeeper's Blanket as created by the designer.I have already identified 3 animals that I will not makeÂ because I think I can find better ideas.But the blanket, even as shown, is darling."Caught my eye" is really downplaying its impact on me. Â I purchased it right away. Â No thought. Â Must have! Â Must make. Â Must set my knitting aside (did I just say that??). Â And a worthy recipient, my darling grand daughter, was already on hand. Â Is this Kismet or WHAT!Now here is what I objectively think about crochet ...Love the lookNot good at it.Hurts my left thumb.Struggle with the instructions.Not relaxing.Hurts my left thumb. Â Able to make designs/shapes not easily made in knittingGreat for toys and blanketsNot so good for wearables.Hurts my left thumb.But I wanted this Zookeeper's Blanket - Â I pulled out my hooks and my crochet cheat sheet and plunged in. Â Low and behold - I found I was enjoying the process. Â Actually excited about the blocks that were developing from my hands ... now I am looking for yarns to use that would add color and texture ... and ... pushing myself to develop some animals that weren't part of the original pattern just because I think I can.My lobster block.Feels like the Crochet Fairy dropped in and sprinkled me with her fairy dust!My bear block.Anyway, I hope you enjoy the pictures of my progress and where I am going with this blanket in the future.My octopus block.The down side of this project is there are lots of colors and shapes. Â Lots and lots of ends to weave in. Â Lots of sewing. Â A very fiddly pattern. Â I usually hate all that, but because of the fairy dust - I am not having a problem. Â As others who completed this pattern noted: Â The pattern has a lot of ends to weave in - but it is worth it. Â I agree.My cat block.The blocks are so darn cute, when I finish one I can't wait to start another one.Sample of another's interpretation of the project using all sheep and one dog.So darn cute.And what I love most of all is seeing the originality of others who have done this pattern. Â Some used one theme - many sheep and one dog. Â Very cute.The sample the crocheter made up some of her own animalsnot used in the original.Some alternated animal blocks with plain blocks. Â That is my choice because I don't care for some of the animals in the original pattern. Â So unless I can find some replacements (which I have), the blanket would be too small. Â And alternating with plain blocks allows for less ends to weave in - and a focus on the cutest animals.My grand daughter's room is done in green. Â My plain blocks are green.This picture gives a sense of how I will put my blocks together.Some crocheters suggest putting a backing on this blanket since one side is cute and the other side is - well, not cute. Â I am actually considering that!! Â Crazy but I always hated extra steps that didn't involve knitting - like linings and extra sewing. Â That darn crochet fairy dust is powerful stuff.An original design, a butterfly, created by a crocheter.Hoping to copy this one.Â And my thumb?? Â I think the fairy dust has healed it.I wonder if there is fairy dust for cleaning your house. Â Or fairy dust for cooking dinner night after night after night!! Â Or can I send that fairy off to my exercise classes for me - and bring back the benefits while I sit making this blanket??If you think you have the answers to these question (and they involve common sense) don't bother saying them out loud. Â Fairy dust has blocked any reality checks!My deadline: - Christmas.

title: Rehabilitated Plant Killer?
text: My thumb is brown.Seriously! My history with plants is just awful.I have left many dead plants in my wakeOnce (long, long ago) I had an 8' x 8' foot space in a rented community garden. Â My plot was a plant grave yard. Â The plots around me flourished. Â I took that as a sign - 'you are a plant killer.'Our next townhome was surrounded by trees. Â No sun ever. Â When we landscaped our postage stamp size lot - I told the landscaper ... select plants that will live in spite of me. Â He did. Â We had to pay someone yearly to fight them into submission. Â Those plants were not my success being chosen and planted by plant pros. Â Plants on my deck never survived. Â Not enough sun? Â Not the right plants? Â Too much water? Â Not enough water? Â The secrets of plants totally escapes me.Now I am in a condo. Â No rented garden space and deck so small that more than 2 people on it is a crowd scene. Â BUT I have 12 hours of full sun on that deck. Â I started thinking ... maybe, just maybe.Despite my poor plant parenting ... I totally love nurseries. Â All those flowering plants bursting with health and promise. Â So off I went. Â This time I was careful to read all the plant tags to get something hardy and that likes full sun Â While I was there I noticed something called "patio tomatoes." Â A vegetable. Â hmmm ...Not too big at this point. Â 'Patio' ... designed for small spaces maybe? Â So along with some flowering plants - a patio tomato plant came home with me as well. Â As we left the nursery, I felt like I needed to apologize in advance to these plants that they wound up with 'plant killer' me. Â I promised to do my best - without mentioning that my 'best' killed other plants.Soon I noticed this.Flowers ... maybe (one) tomato was in my future. Â Success! Â The tomato plant is not dying!! But then I noticed peeking below the flowers Â a green tomato! Â Ok, maybe I will get two tomatoes. Â Happy Dance!Before I knew it, I had multiple green tomatoes and they had all gotten bigger!!! Â Last count was 18 actual green tomatoes! Â Holy Cow. Â This is unheard of ... (small panic). Â Its still early in the growing season. Tomatoes EVERYWHERE!!Ok, the secret to growing plants - at least for me - is to apologize in advance! Â They seem to love a penitent owner. Â Well ... that and a sign in my kitchen to remind me of my responsibilities ...Here are some other beauties on my deck - still living I will point out.If all goes well this year ... I think I will plant some herbs in pots next year. Â I love fresh herbs like parsley, cilantro and basil. What other kinds of edible plants work well on decks?

title: The Pull of the Moon
text: Recently I have been cleaning out my Kindle of books I probably will never read. Â Scanning the book summary of each book - and deleting a bunch of them. Â Many were free and sounded interesting at the time I selected them. Â But now they seem trite and repetitive. Â Whatever was I thinking ... was the thought that passed my brain over and over.And then I came to this title:The Pull of the MoonÂ by Elizabeth BergThe publisher's summary read like this:***Uncomfortable with the fit of her life, now that she's in the middle of it, Nan gets into her car and just goes--driving across the country on back roads, following the moon; and stopping to talk to people.Â Â Through conversations with women, men, with her husband through letters, and with herself through her diary, Nan confronts topics long overdue for her attention.Â Â She writes to her husband and says things she's never admitted before; and she discovers how the fabric of her life can be reshaped into a more authentic creation.***This book has been waiting on my Kindle since 2015. Â I read the summary and a little pull made me select it again - this time to read now.As I read, I found myself relating strongly with Nan, the 50 year old woman who it seemed was having a mid-life crisis of some sort. Â But early on I realized this was not a crisis at all. Â It was a breaking out, a leap for freedom, a search of the self, ... a self she had ignored for so long. Â Then a quoteÂ leaped off the page and pointed a finger straight at me.***"Most women are full to the brim. Â I think we are most of us ready to explode, especially when our children are small and we are so weary with the demands for love and attention and the kind of service that makes you feel you should be wearing a uniform with "Mommy"Â embroidered over the left breast, over the heart. ... It wasn't that I was really unhappy. Â It was the constancy of my load and the awesome importance of it; and it was my isolation. ... I see now, there were internal earthquakes wanting to happen all the time."***But, YES! Â That was me. Â Most of my adult life. Â It was me. Â Except the word I would substitute for the embroidered "Mommy" label would be "Caregiver." Â Caregiver was not a life role I ever aspired to. Â True ... I chose to be a parent - and wouldn't change that role ever!! Â The reward for being a parent caregiver is the wonderful adult children I have today. Â But the "caregiver" role continued to follow me. Â First it was my husband's grandmother. Â My husband was her only living relative. Â Of course we would care for her. Â Then it was my mother-in-law. Â My husband had no other blood family but his mom, so yes I would care for her. Â Then my own mother started to fail and she needed an advocate ... a caregiver! Â A no brainer - my mom needed assistance and I could not turn away. Â I never thought twice about that choice. Â In fact, I never thought twice about any of those decisions.Now I am 71, and I feel a 'short-timer' in my life. Â Oh, I plan to live as many years as God intends, but to be frank and realistic, Â I certainly have more years behind me - than ahead of me! In fact, my body tells me this is true.My caregiving role, however, continues to haunt me even now. Â My husband is now legally blind. Â Going blind late in life makes becoming a 'skilled' visuallyÂ impaired person, pretty darn hard. Â He needs more of me now than ever.The Pull of the Moon hit a major nerve for me. Â I have actually thought about just getting in the car and driving away. Â It has crossed my mind a lot more than I care to admit. Â When the summary said Nan did just that ... drove away ... I thought - see, this isn't such an abnormalÂ crazy thing to do. Â Like Nan, I would not describe myself as unhappy. Â But I do often feel that I am "full to the brim." Â "Explode" also comes to mind atÂ times. Â In fact, I started this blog back in 2007 as a way to keep from exploding. Â The words "constancy of my load" and "importance of it" and "isolation," Â ... well, folks, this book is me.Do you ever feel the way Nan does? Â Would you ever jump in the car and just drive off? Â I won't, of course. Â The hardship my absence for my husband and the worry it would cause my family would be too great a guilt for me to live with. Â  But I doÂ fantasize about doing that.Â And that is all I would do - fantasize, because just jumping in the car at 71 and driving off is totally unrealistic. Â Think of it - I would need to pack all my pills and eye meds, and ace bandages and cold wraps for my knee ... and my pillow. ğŸ˜€ I would have to rent a trailer to pack all my knittingÂ paraphernalia, of course!!! ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ Â My computer, iPhone, Kindle and iPad need to come as well - with all the chargers. ğŸ˜ğŸ˜ğŸ˜ğŸ˜ğŸ˜.Â I can't eat a lot ofÂ restaurant food any more - heartburn, you know. Â So I would have to pack a cooler! Â Â ğŸ˜œğŸ˜œğŸ˜œğŸ˜œğŸ˜œğŸ˜œğŸ˜œ Ha! Â Barriers everywhere!Why didn't Nan have to do all that stuff? Â Simple: she is only 50!!!!*sigh*Guess I missed my window of opportunity for this adventure. Â So I am left with living vicariously through Nan. Â My advice to Nan? Â YOU GO GIRL!!!I recommend this book. Â Good writing, interesting story line, thoughtful observations and a really good Â woman-to-woman book about our journey as females.

title: On Being A Grandma
text: It is still early days in this 'grandma' thing. Â My dear little granddaughter is just 3 1/2 months old. Â She is growing and changing really fast. Â Too fast it seems. Â While I want to slow down this precious time, I am so very grateful she is developing normally.I cannot help but deeply love this child. Â She can now focus on faces and her deep blue eyes remind me of another set of blue eyes that stared back at me more than 40 years ago. Â She has her dad's eyes, nose and forehead. Â Seeing her brings back many memories of him as an infant - memories that I thought could only be triggered by our Â still pictures. Â Now I have this live little person who looks at me through the eyes of her father with an unknowing stare. Â Time, experiences and love will put recognition in her eyes. Â But that side-eye look she has in that chair with its own eyes is priceless.For now it is enough to know and see how beautifully connected she is to her parents ... how she fits so comfortably onto their chests, how her eyes follow them when she is separated, how her head turns towards their voices.Recently she discovered her hands. Â She has these tiny little digits and miniature nails. Â It is amazing to watch the awareness of herself grow within her. Â And with that discovery ... her thumb ... that finds it way into her mouth when she is trying to comfort herself. Â These small discoveries are so endearing to observe.There is one small sadness that crosses my mind at times. Â This dear baby girl has only one grandma - one grandma on earth, that is. Â Her other grandma in heaven. Â How much I would have loved to enjoy this child with her other grandma. Â When I saw the sleeper below, I knew I had to get it."Handpicked for earth by my grandma in heaven."And, of course, my hands have been busy. Â Even before she was born, my son found this babyViking hat picture and forwarded it to me. Â I researched and purchased the pattern, which included a dad sized version. Â Her eyes say she is not sure about this hat or the person taking the picture, but she is in dad's arms so it must be ok.Her connection between her and her mom is so strong that I can't help wondering if she knows that her mom is a separate being. Â Guess that is something that will be learned at some point. Â No sense rushing such a precious time of life.This child can't begin to know what wonderful parents she has.For now my role as grandma seems to be as an observer of this new little nugget of a person. Â How did I miss all these small little observations of my own children. Â Oh ... that's right! Â I was busy making sure they were fed, and dressed, and clean, and safe. Â I was sleep deprived and focused on their growth. Â And I was growing as a parent with all the unknowns and second guessing. Â Now as a grandmother I have the luxury of time and memory. Â I have the joy of watching and holding and loving - until she is old enough to understand.And what a JOYÂ it is!

title: Ok, Ok ...
text: ğŸ˜‹I know. Â I've been missing in action AGAIN!I did hear from a few readers that I was missed! Â Ha. Â One, and I won't name names - even asked me face to face, "So where are you?" ... to which I resisted the obvious "Right in front of you."I just go into dips on this blogging thing it appears ... especially when my life seems to be sailing along evenly - without drama and disaster.Of course, this winter was very eventful. Â One of the biggest events of my life. Â I officially became of a grandmother of a being with 2 legs! Â While this statement sounds a bit odd, those who know me personally know that I have been a grandmother to 4 legged mutts for many many years. Â They know me by the title of 'gran-ma.' My grand daughter, Eskarina Faye, was born February 25 - 7 lbs, 7 ounces. Â It has been such a joy to see her grow and develop so quickly. Eskarina while still in the hospital. Â Pretty wide awake here.But don't be fooled. Â There was a lot of sleeping too.My husband and I with Esk at our condo soon after discharge.You can be sure I will be sharing more pictures of this little dumpling as she grows. I do get some questions about her name. Â It is unusual. Â A little explanation.My son and daughter-in-law are big fans of the English author, Terry Pratchett. Â I think I mentioned this author in connection with a chest of drawers my son painted for his soon to be born daughter. Â You can find that post here. Â Terry Pratchett is the author of over 40 comic fantasy books that occur in Â a universe called Discworld. Â Discworld is a flat world carried by four elephants riding on the back of a giant turtle. Â Here is a link that explains things better than I could. Â It is a charming set of books and I have read a few of them.Eskarina's name comes from a novel in that series called Equal Rites. Â The back cover gives a summary. Every world has its rules - even a flat one carried by four elephants riding on a giant turtle. Â That's why a dying wizard is searching for an eighth son of an eighth son to bestow his wizardly powers upon before meeting Death in six minutes. Â Unfortunately it is quickly discovered - though not quite quickly enough - that the newborn babe the wizard anoints just before bidding the Discword adieu is, in reality, a girl! What's done cannot be undone - despite old Granny Weatherwax's attempts to bring the child into the witchy fold - little Esk is now a wizard, through and through.It is an interesting novel in today's world where equal rights for women continues to be an issue. Â  I think the book's play on words is fun - rites vs rights - and the fact that Eskarina is a wizard in a world where only men can be wizards is a timely topic.So here is my little Esk about a week ago.Pretty much everyone agrees she has her mother's mouth and her dad's nose and eyes. But we all know how this goes. Â She will change many times as she develops.She is a cute little nugget and I am one lucky 'gran-ma.'That's all 'till next time.

title: Coming Clean: A Memoir by Kimberly Rae Miller
text: Photo Credit: AmazonAmazon Product Description:Kimberly Rae Miller is an immaculately put together woman with a great career, a loving boyfriend and a beautifully tidy apartment in Brooklyn. Â You would never guess that behind the closed doors of her family's idyllic Long Island house hid teetering stacks of aging newspaper, broken computers and boxes upon boxes of unused junk festering in every room - the product of her father's painful and unending struggle with hoarding.In this dazzling memoir, Miller brings to life her experience growing up in a rat-infested home, hiding her father's shameful secret from friends for years, and the emotional burden that ultimately led to her suicide attempt. Â In beautiful prose, Miller sheds light on her complicated yet loving relationship with her parents, which has thrived in spite of the odds.I downloaded this audiobook out of curiosity, free with Kindle Unlimited. Â It focuses on a mental condition that has been highlighted in the TV series The Hoarders. Â The TV series - as with most shows that seek to obtain and maintain a viewing audience - showcases the most extreme cases of hoarding - always escalating the cases with each season. Â I watched the show until it began to slip into animal hoarding and the sad state of the hoarder and the terrible outcomes for the animals they kept. Â I couldn't watch any longer. Â It greatly tore at my heart. Â But when I found this book, I was drawn to it as it seemed to focus on the struggle and the love that this family had for each other - while dealing with this affliction.I didn't expect such a sensitive and touching story. Â The author reads this story in the audiobook. Â Since it was her own story, I felt comfortable with her reading style. I felt compassion for her as she struggled to pull away from her upbringing while not abandoning her parents. Her supportive love for them was apparent. Â The parents love for their daughter was equally demonstrated but it did not overcome the strong hold of hoarding behavior. Â There is no simple resolution at the end of the story despite all their efforts, but acceptance, love and continued family loyalty provided a realistic ending to this memoir - something that was missing from all The Hoarders TV shows I watched.I recommend this book to anyone who wants a better understanding of this mental problem.

title: Evenings
text: Evenings ... I love evenings.Let me count the ways!Nobody wants anything from me. Husband goes to bed around 7:00 pm. Â My grand dogs are early to bed types. Â Even my adult kids hit the sack earlyÂ - mostly because they have to go to work the next day.Â Â Nobody calls - my friends all seem to be early-to-bed types.Â I control the TV remote.I get to choose the TV shows.I can choose Netflix.I can choose Amazon Video.I can choose Verizon on Demand.I can turn it on!I can turn it off!I don't have to talk to anyone.Talking is over-rated.Silence is golden.My own company is the best company.Night time is quiet time.The world is pretty quiet at night.Animals are quiet.People are quiet.Traffic is less.I can sit and do nothing and not feel guilty.I can knit.I can read.I can listen to an audiobook.But I can do nothing.Â I can sit on the balcony andwatch all the folks coming home from workgrateful that I am not one of them.I think everyone needs a quiet peaceful time during the 24 hour cycle that measures our life ... time without regard to the needs of others. Â  It is hard to carve out that time when you are younger with demands of job and family. Â I was never successful before retirement. Â Having it now is a simple pleasure I look forward to every single day.Do you have a favored time of daythat is just yours without demands?

title: Big Deep Breath
text: Its been a busy day.Last night was the last 'hurrah' for Christmas in our house. Â We host an after holiday Christmas party for a group of friends we see monthly during the year for gaming. Â Whatever the first weekend in January is after the New Year ... that is the date of this party. Â I'd love to dismantle Christmas before the New Year - but I hold off until this event is past.As I put away Christmas for another year, I like to think of the weeks following as a 'purge' time. Â The fact I purged greatly 17 months ago to move into this condo doesn't change the fact that stuff still travels in the front door all the time, and if, on balance, stuff doesn't travel out the front door - the clutter builds. Â And it is building and building.So here is the path I'll travel from one task to another:My hands are all over Christmas decos and because there are still things that never get displayed - they need to be thinned. Â Then we move onto the single storage closet I have where Christmas is stored. Â Christmas stuff is stored to the back, and I need to pull a lot of stuff out. Â Once it is out of the closet - I decide if it goes back in. Â That darn closet is next to impossible to step into now.Â In 6 or 7 weeks a grandchild will grace our lives. Â Room to be made - literally. Â I have a guest room/yarn room with a closet. Â  That space is packed. Â Some stuff hasn't been touched in 17 months. Â My grand daughter will fit comfortably in my condo when I am done. Â For months I have hated opening my two bathroom linen closets. Â Again, again, again - if it hasn't been used in 17 months it needs to go out the door.Lastly the kitchen! My pantry is packed to the max. Â Reorganize and consolidate. Â Because it is such a mess - I find myself buying stuff I already have. Â grrr .... Â And those kitchen shelves, Â generous space for sure ... and because nature abhors a vacuum I filled that space. Â Not always a good thing.See how one thing just leads to another? Â I hope I can welcome the spring with a clean slate. Â (I can hear the snickers now - 'first day of spring - in which year.') Â To my nay sayers ... goals are good. So let's say I pick Spring 2018 to finish - yes, this year.All these tasks are the perfect winter activity when you are not distracted by all the things that grab your attention outdoors.When all this gets done - then I can take a breath. Â A big deep breath, once again - until the future incoming stuff begins to chip away at my contentment and I am forced to walk this way again.

title: The Heel Slide
text: A major development!!A major positive development!!The best kind of development.I guess the title of this post Â gives it away. Â No? Â Well for those still in the dark, let me share a little bit of the back story on the Heel Slide. Anyone who has had work done on their knee probably has come up against the heel slide exercise. Â Heel slides help you regain your range of motion in the knee after an injury or surgery. Â Basically, you lay on your back like the lady in the picture with one leg extended straight, and the other leg is brought to your butt as close as you can. Â My therapist, Sarah, instructed me to use a strap around my ankle to help pull the heel as much as possible to the butt with the help of your hands.Looks simple, right? Â It can be, but it can also be difficult - (translation: hurts like hell.). Â This woman obviously didn't have surgery - her face is peaceful. Â She is not swearing.So, since mid-May I couldn't do this with my left knee. Â I could pull my right knee up to my butt, but the left knee - got about as far as the picture lady is before tears formed in my eyes.Anyway all summer and fall this self-torture activity was part of my routine. Â As I healed my therapist took measurements of the angle my leg made - and the sharper the angle, the more improvement until I was "within normal range for my age." Â (There's that "for my age" crap again!).When I knew I was nearing discharge I had a serious talk with my lovey therapist, Sarah - who by the way has a doctorate in this stuff - and is not a wilting lilly about inflicting pain if it helps healing. Â (I hated that part.)The conversation went something like this:Me: Â  Â  Â  Â "Sarah, watch this." Â (I bent my right knee to my butt, I could touch my right heel with myÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  right fingers.)Sarah:Â  Â  "Yes, Elaine, that is excellent, more than is expected."Me:Â  Â  Â  Â  "Now watch this." Â (I bent my left knee to my butt. Â There was still a great divide betweenÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  heel and fingers.)Sarah:Â  Â "Right - but your flexion in that left knee is within normal range.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â (... for a person of your age - which she didn't say, but I was thinking.)Me: Â  Â  Â  "So, Sarah, last night I was watching a Christmas Special with the Radio City Rockettes."Sarah:Â  Â  (small eye roll with grin). Â "I can hardly wait to hear where this is going. Â And ..."Me:Â Â  Â  Â  "Well, I noticed during one of their routines, they could all touch their heels to their butts."Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â (It is not important that I explain to you how I know, but trust me on this. Â They could.)Sarah: Â Â "Yes, I imagine they could."Me:Â  Â  Â  Â  "So ...?"Sarah: Â  Â "But you are within normal range for your ...." Â (oh, you know the rest.)Thinking back on the conversation I guess I could look at the glass as half full - and say my right leg is 'Radio City Rockette worthy.' Â I am pretty sure one leg is not good enough to make the Rockette line up.I was discharge from PT the beginning of December - with one leg more normal than the other (see I can be positive.) Â  That status was fine with the doctor and fine with the therapist and fine with Medicare and Blue Cross who paid for all those months of PT.Now to the reason I am sharing all this with you! (I know you were wondering.)On New Year's Eve I was doing my exercises while watching TV. Â (I am just a party animal, you know.). The last exercise on my list is the Heel Slide. Â I start with the right leg (one that can reach my butt). Â Want to be sure that my right leg doesn't get any ideas about what is "normal for my age."Then I did my left leg, reaching with my left fingers to find my heel (which I haven't been able to accomplish all year) ... and the two met - fingers and heels. Â AND with NO swearing! Â None at all. Â Shock! Â Took a small moment to make sure I was exercising the surgery knee - I most definitely was! I jumped up. Â (I use the term 'jump' loosely - but I did get up.) Â I had to tell someone. Â My husband was already in bed - and asleep! Â And then I realized, the person I had to tell was Sarah. Â My husband would have said, "Oh, that's nice." Â But Sarah ... she would have understood. Â I shot an email off to her. And, as I expected, Sarah was appropriately excited!!Now I should mention, that the left knee is not really 'Radio City Rockette ready' - the heel isn't touching my butt yet! Â But it is only a matter of time.New Goal for 2018 -Â BECOME THE FIRST 70 YEAR OLD RADIO CITY ROCKETTE!Or ... maybe I will just accept the fact I could be a Rockette if I wanted to. Can your heels touch your butt? Â Could you be a Rockette?

title: I looked in the mirror!
text: It is amazing how easy it is to deceive yourself ... especially if you don't look into a mirror!Â Â Really look,Â not just glance while brushing your teeth or combing your hair.In an effort to keep my exercise program interesting and well balanced I finally opened a DVD set purchased maybe 2 years ago. Â Yes, yes ... 2 years! Â Sealed up in plastic just like new, it was.I do this little mind game thing ... get stuff and own it ... and somehow believe that ownership alone is is enough to absorb the knowledge or benefit of the item without actually reading or viewing or doing the whatever ... in this case doing the exercises. Anyway, the DVD is Stronger Seniors. Workout Program with Anne Pringle Burnell.The cover stated - "Safe & Easy to Follow. Â Increase Stamina. Â Strength training for upper and lower body. Â Improve Balance." Â See what I mean ... no where does it say you have to actually DO this stuff.Anyway, I need everything this DVD proclaims, so to avoid boredom with my regular routine, I decided to try this out. Â I broke the plastic on the DVDs.The very first thing I noticed was that the 5 or 6 folks behind the instructor were old. Â The second thing I thought was ... I bet this DVD set will be too easy for me. Â After all, look at the participants. Â They will need a slow and gentle exercise routine, and I can certainly do more.I launched into the first disk (Stretch). Â At first it was slow, but it picked up steam. Â And I kept up. Â Each disk was 60 minutes. Â The instructions suggested alternating these disks on separate nights. Â Well, of course, if you are older you need to alternate nights. Â Me, not so much.On the first disk I noticed I was actually getting a work out. Â I pealed off my sweater. Â I was getting warm. Â I completed the 60 minutes pretty well - and it did target my upper body which needs more of everything. I checked out the second disk (Strength and Balance). Â I needed both. Â I started the second work out. Â It was also a pretty good work out - using weights. Â I was using 3 pounds weights. Â I noticed some of the participants were using 4 pounds weights. Â (Heck - I don't have 4 pound weights. Â I need to buy those. Â In fact I will buy 5 pound weights. No one was using 5 pounds!!) Â But as the program proceeded, I noticed some of the movements were uncomfortable in my right shoulder. Â I backed down the routine to no weights on the right side. Â Of course, the DVD participants who were following the instructor (using 4 pound weights, no less) continued on with no apparent effort. Â *sigh*Hmmm ... I am younger than those folks ... I should be able to do this with no effort!Finally I moved on to the Balance section. Â I was starting to get tired. Â I was very sure the DVD folks Â must be tired too. Â Of course, they had their game face on, so I put my game face on (even though there was no one to see it but the cat.)And then it got serious.I am pretty good at balancing with two legs. Â (In September I wasn't good at balancing period. Â I used a walker and then a cane. Â Two legs now is a step up.) Â I am less confident with one leg. Â But I charged on with everyone else knowing I could do this. Â At some point I looked at the DVD participants ... you know ... the 'older' folks in the background. Â No one, and I mean absolutely NO ONE, was struggling with the balance portion of the program. Â They performed the exercises with steady feet and ankles, no support required of chair near by, and no swearing! Â Meanwhile, back in my living room, my feet and ankles gamely tried to keep me upright. Â They were wobbly, constantly adjusting to keep me from falling. Â My hands, that were firmly instructed to not touch the chair, did so anyway. Â And swearing! Â Lots and lots of swearing. Â The cat left the room!I completed the second DVD. Â It wasn't pretty. Â And when I passed the bathroom mirror later in the evening, I noticed that the living room participant was ... well ... not in her 50s or 60s. Â  Somehow my eyes blinded my brain to the fact I am older. Â Darn! Â How had I missed that!So - ok! Â I will used these disks 'cause I apparently need them. Â I will admire those DVD participants who are able to do ALL the exercises with strength and skill (and no swearing.) Â And I will believe what the mirror is telling me - that I am a senior who needs to get stronger like the folks in the DVD.I believe there is a biblical lesson about 'pride and falling' buried in this post! ğŸ˜€And, by the way, this DVD set is very good. Â I don't know why I waited 2 years to break the seal and open it. Oh,Â that's right!That mind game about owning and not doingÂ may have had something to do with that!

title: 2018 Craft Plans
text: While I make a point of avoiding New Year's Resolutions, I do feel that creating a list of to-dos is helpful in planning yearly crafting activities. Â There are so many things I would like to do and try. Â If I don't make a list ... it doesn't get done. Actually that is simple truth for me - no list, no focus. Â List making is something I do without thought - just like breathing. Â Do I accomplish everything I write down? Â No. Â But it shows what is important in the end. Â Unimportant things just slip from day to day - and sometime disappear.Over December I gave quite a bit of time to thinking about 2018 crafting: knitting, crochet, spindle spinning and, maybe this year, a needlepoint project. Â Those items fleshed out they look like this:KnittingRed hoodie for my grand daughter - almost complete now - for next ChristmasA cable sweater for my grand nephew - for next ChristmasA knitted toy for my grand daughter - for next ChristmasA summer something for my grand daughter.Baby blanket for my grand daughter - because a knitter who does not create a baby blanket for her own grand daughter is in conflict with the knitting gods.A sweater for myself - using some wonderful yarn I purchased for Christmas 2016 - this to-do will not slip off my list.Another shawl - with beads - for my daughter-in-law.Another shawl - with beads - for my daughter.CrochetÂ Amigurumi toys - at least give it a try. Â I have this book on order. Â Cute!SpinningSpindle spinning still calls to me. Â I have several spindles and many wonderful options regarding fiber. Â Creating the yarn will be the full goal - not what I plan to do with it.NeedlepointDuring the 1980s I did a number of needlepoint project and enjoyed it greatly. Â Now as my son and daughter-in-law prepare to welcome a daughter into their world by creating the nursery, I feel very inclined to create a needlepoint picture for her room. I am actively looking for a needlepoint canvas of a dragon or wizard to match the theme of the room. Â Selecting the canvas and the yarns and working on the actual project will take some time - probably ending in a finished project some in 2019. Â So this list of things is stored here on my blog - so next year at this time I can see just how many are achieved.I don't make resolutions. Â I do, however, enjoy visiting the blogs where people publish their resolutions. Â To me resolutions are not so much goal setting and achieving ... resolutions reflect our desire to be someone different than we are now - or improve qualities that we already have but have not 'fed' recently. In recent years I followed the blog trend of picking a single word and seeing how closely I could live my life to demonstrate of that word.In 2016 I picked the word - Move! Â I wanted to be more physically active. Â I don't know about physical activity - be we did move - in 2016 - and it did require a great deal of physical activity on my part. Â I guess that counts even if not planned that way.In 2017 I picked the word - Consistency. Â I wanted good habits performed more consistently. Â In truth, I promptly forgot that word as I got into 2017. Â I couldn't even guess what it was until I looked it up for this post. Â Certainly exercise was a good habit I wanted this past year. Â  Looking back I did consistently exercise - joining The Y last January and being dedicated to my PT exercises since June. Â So what to do about 2018!I won't be doing 'Resolutions' nor picking a 'Word' to thread through my year. Â If I learned anything from my life in 2017 - it is that regardless of any goals or intentions I have - the future will happen regardless of my plans for it, and I will be responding.But the question that keeps rising to the surface is: who will I be in 2018?Health:Â The events of 2017 set me back. Â This body is good for only a fixed period of time, and I want to be sure it is functional for ALL that time. Â So I am continuing what I started in 2017 - to maintain and improve this body through regular activity.Â Distractions: As in previous years - I need to start decluttering again. Â  Objects for me are distractions and the condo has started to feel full. Â All the downsizing I did allowed me to move from 2200 square feet space into 1375 feet space in 2016. Â Someday I may need to shrink even more - maybe into a single room. Â What I do now will minimize what my children may be forced to do on my behalf in the future. Â  Objects are half the battle. Â Time is the other half. Â The clutter of an overly busy calendar can be stressful.Â Grandchild:Â  This will be a new adventure! Â One that I can hardly wait to begin. Â Keep healthy for a grandchild.Make space and time for a grandchild.Those are the words that will guide me in 2018!Who will you be in 2018?

title: New Year's Eve Reflection - 2017
text: I like to look back at the previous year - to check out all the shiny parts and the warts - and then file those memories away and start the next year new.Before I began this post - I checked back on my reflection of 2016 and I summed up the year by answering 20 questions. Â It was fun. Â This year feels different so I am going to use a few emojis.ğŸ˜±. In January we got a new President. Â *sigh* Â I try to avoid political topics in my blog. Â But a face 'screaming in fear' seemed to be the only emoji that seemed to sum up my reaction to Trump as our President. Â And as of December 31, 2017 - this man has done nothing in his first year in office to change my mind. Â Screaming fear of what he will do to our country and our future haunts me. Â I thank God in my prayers that our founding fathers had the good sense to create 3 branches of government - to act as checks and balances for 'mistakes' - for he truly is a mistake, one that we must survive Â ... hopefully.ğŸ˜Œ. In April I turned 70! Â I thought a 'relieved' face seemed the best choice for that birthday. Â Although I still have problems with the size of that number ... I am pleased to have reach it and I hope for many more years in this life. Â You only get to go around once - so I am relieved to have reached 70 and I want to complete the circle and not get cut short.ğŸ˜. In May I awoke one morning to a sore swollen knee. Â I had problems with this knee in 2013 - and it resolved with PT - but not this time. Â Eight weeks of PT and I still walked with a cane. Â I think 'sad' face fits this extended event that ate up my summer.ğŸ˜¿. In June our dear dear Max died. Â Max was one of two cats, brothers actually. Â For 9 years of his life we treated him for degenerative kidney disease with fluids to flush his kidneys. Â At age 11 he lost his battle with that disease, but he was a bit of a success story - as most cats don't last that long. Â It never is easy to say goodbye. Â We miss him still. Â However his brother, Wally, seems to have come out of his shell and is an entirely different cat ... friendly, outgoing, enjoying life completely. Â Go figure. Â Guess they weren't as close as we thought.ğŸ’. In July my son and his wife announced they were expecting a child. Â HOLY COW! Â I am going to be a grandmother! Â Me! Â I had given up that hope a while back. Â A heart wrapped in a bow seemed to sum up this wondrous news. Â And it is still a bit unbelievable to me, despite the fact my daughter-in-law is clearly growing another person inside her body. Â February can't come fast enough for us.ğŸ˜¡. Â In September, after 8 weeks of PT - with minimal improvement - an MRI revealed that the left knee had a miniscus tear and could only be fixed with surgery. Â In some ways it felt like I had wasted my summer and that was frustrating. Â But now I had a real diagnosis, so taking a positive action to fix the problem - well - it changed my angry face into ğŸ˜ - neutral face! Â Get the darn thing fixed!ğŸ˜. In October and November I was back in PT and improving. Â But the beauty of recovery was that I now had time to knit and knit and knit - to my heart's content. Â And I finished a large number of projects. Â During that time I realized that despite my sampling of other related crafts (weaving and spinning) over the years, knitting continues to be my true love. Â ğŸ’—ğŸ’–ğŸ’ŸğŸ’–. Without knitting I would be lost. Â My knee might not be fully functional, but my hands are fine - I can knit!ğŸ’ª. In December I was discharged from PT. Â I am better, but not perfect. Â I am working towards perfect - and both the doctor and the therapist said it might take a year. Â In the meantime, I am doing my exercises, Â going to the gym and joining an exercise class in January. Â When this knee finally starts feeling like the other knee, all the other parts of my body will be up to speed as well.That was my 2017! Â Highs and lows. Â Normal really. Â I will say that after this year - I understand better what physical set backs do to a senior citizen. Â This knee repair was minor, but it set me back more than I care to admit, and the struggle to regain what was lost just takes more time at this age.I have often started and stopped exercise programs over the years. Â This time the seeds that I have planted in 2017 to improve my health I will continue to cultivate in 2018. Â Now I don't feel I have a choice - not if I want to continue to live a normal life!Goodbye 2017!I learned a few lessons from you this year.Who knows what 2018 will teach me.ğŸ’

title: Made it!
text: Anyone who has read my blog for awhile knows that this holiday has become a hurdle I struggle to get passed. Â  By the time I get to the 27th or the 28th, I am thrilled to be passed another Christmas.I love the fact we are over 360 days away from the next Christmas. Â I am happy to see the holiday decor begin to disappear from the stores and homes. Â The holiday music that has been playing 24/7 on my favorite radio station (since before Thanksgiving, for gosh sakes), finally will revert to normal "70,s 80's, 90's and hits of today." Â  I know, I know ... I hear whispers of "grinch." Well, let me assure you. Â I am not a grinch. Â I value the holiday for what it should be - a celebration of the birth of Christ. Â I love making someone smile with a specially chosen or hand made gift. Â I find peace in an evening walk around my neighborhood to see the holiday lights. Â But sadness does follow me. It hasn't always been that way. Â If life delivers enough hard hits during the holidays ... it can change how you respond to them. Â My dad died 3 days before Christmas in 1970. Â My mom died 3 days after Christmas in 2014. Â And in the last 10 years, my mom spent many holidays stuck in Assisted Living or a nursing home - because she was too disabled to get home. Â I know neither parent would want those experiences to ruin my holidays. Â The holidays aren't 'ruined,' but they are changed, and maybe permanently so.Looking up - this year's Christmas was easier than last year's Christmas Â It was our second year in the condo. Â I have stopped grieving the move from our townhouse of 30 years. Â I still wish life hadn't made this move necessary. Stairs and a recently blind husband are just a bad combination. Â So I am passed that loss and really appreciate the convenience of the condo. Â I 'visit' my parents right after Christmas every year. Â The trips are filled with less sorrow now and more just a flood of memories of my life with each of them. Â I think it is good to allow those memories to surface (the good and the bad) - and to remember where I came from. Â It gives me some comfort to know they are both beyond suffering now. Â And we - as a family - are celebrating a soon to be born child. Â Maybe this grand child will help heal some of those hard hits that make this season so hard for me. Â Maybe life is finallyÂ giving me a mark in the positive column with a new little life to cherish.Regardless ... Â This year ... I made it! Â Passed another one!

title: A Fearsome Guardian
text: A guardian at the door to my grand daughter's bedroom is this magnificent dragon. Â He sits upon "The Luggage," another guardian! (see previous post for an explanation of The Luggage.)The Dragon was purchased by my son at a toy store near where he works. Â The store was going out of business and he got it for a reduced price, but I suspect he would have paid full price.In person, it is a pretty amazing figure. Â Magnificent in his details.Just check out the wings - an impressive wing span I am sure.Fearsome teeth! Â All the better to eat monsters!Massive feet - needs a pedicure, I think. Â But those nails will rip any monster apart in a Nono-second!!Â Â Scales are soft to the touch. Â But don't be fooled. This guardian means business!Some of you might wonder why would we want to give a little girl a jumbo dragon ... even if he is a fine specimen and will serve as an excellent guard. Â Well, the short answer is ... dragons are for girls. Â Just look at The Game of Thrones TV series (also a series of books.) Â That story includes 3 very serious fire breathing dragons and they belonged to a character called The Mother of Dragons - a girl! Ha!Truthfully, Dragons hold a rather large place of honor in my family. Â My husband and a group of his friends play a monthly game similar to the original game of Dungeons and Dragons. Â If you aren't familiar with that style of gaming, it is a story based game populated by imaginary characters that are created by those playing the game. Â There is no board - but there are dice of various shapes and each person has a character sheet that describes his or her character's skills and attributes. Â A 'dungeon master' or game leader - typically my husband - creates the fantasy world with a story line, goals and achievements. Â Participants improve their characters' skills and attributes by gaining experience during the game - if they don't die, that is! Â  It is a game of the mind and the imagination.The original game of Dungeons and Dragons was created back in the 70s. Â Our family and friends have met to play this game or similar versions of this game for all these years. Â Our son and daughter-in-law are part of this group - and my son has played with this group since he was probably 7 years old. So a dragon is a perfectly normal thing to give to a girl whose father and grandfather have devoted so much time to. Â Maybe when she is 7 years old, she may desire to pull up two chairs - one for herself and one for her dragon, and join in the game. Â And if not, what better guardian could a little girl have than her own personal dragon to scare away the monsters!And besides, Â it doesn't hurt that this dragon is darn cute!

title: An Unpleasant Truth, an Update, a Rant and Lessons Learned
text: I knew about this unpleasant truth before my knee surgery. Â I watched it play out in my mom's last years of life.The Unpleasant Truth:Simply stated,Â after a certain age, any major health event (like a surgery) can result in a negative impactÂ on your previous function and energy levels.Â With my mom I called it ... "a new normal." Â Recovered ... but at a lower level than before. Â While I watched this gentle downward slope occur in my mom after every illness, I simply would not believe it could happen to me. Â I was younger and stronger (then), and as we all know - younger folks usually have a fixed (and sometimes unrealistic) opinion about their aging years. Â So it was with me. Â I would not give in, not give up, not stop trying ... I would not! Â And I haven't, but ... now I actually am older. Â My attitude is still stubbornly the same, but my body as other ideas.With this knee surgery, I may have experienced a little bit of that "new normal" and I am not happy about it.The Update:Two weeks ago I was discharged from Ortho care - I was recovered, and my flexibility and strength were "within normal range for my age." Â Translation? Â You aren't in your 30s anymore. Â Ha! I was fine with being discharged, but I countered the 'normal for my age' comment with ... I am not normal for where I was 6 months ago. Â They said complete recovery will come with time. Â But, I countered, will my left knee be as flexible as my right knee 'with time?' Â  "Hmm," they responded, "maybe." Â That was not the answer I wanted.This week I was discharged from PT. Â My progress has plateaued, I was doing well, and I will only "improve with time and regular adherence to an exercise program." Ok, I am fine with that. Will I improve enough so that both knees are the same? Â "Maybe."Professional opinion? Â It may be another 5 or 6 months before the symptoms resolve. Â (Do I hear a 'maybe?')The Rant:Crap! Â 'Maybe' is such a weaselly word. Â Not 'yes', not 'no', just somewhere in the middle? Â or maybe yes? or maybe no? Â Crap, crap. Â I am just not a 'maybe' person.I want my left knee to be as good and my right knee. And I have done way more Â over 6 months than just 'wish' that was so. Â I was adamant from day one when I knew something wasn't right. I would get this condition fixed ... I wouldn't let it set me back. Â Over 6 months I did the doctor thing ... the X-ray, meds thing ... the PT thing ... the MRI thing ... the surgery thing ... the PT thing, AGAIN.The Orthopod said my knees "are great." Â "Fix this small problem and you will be good to go." BUT I am notÂ 'good to go' yet!! Â My knee still swells, gets stiff, hurts at times. Â My left leg is not as strong as my right yet. Â My general stamina is much reduced because I couldn't do aerobic exercise. Â  I can't sit too long, I can't stand too long, I can't walk too long! Â I can't get down on the floor easily.This better not be my "new normal." Â I will know better in May - 6 months from now.Lessons learned:Avoid all optional surgeries if at all possible at any age, but certainly after 70. Â Sometimes the 'fix' is not a 100% fix no matter what the medical professionals say. Â I still would choose this surgery because now I don't walk with a cane anymore. Â (That's one in the positive column.)Stay active - exercise, exercise, exercise, 'cause it doesn't take that much down time to set you way way back. Â Be at least strong going into any medical procedure. Â It can't hurt.The term 'new normal' is a misnomer. Â It sounds somehow like an ok status. Â It isn't! Â The unpleasant truth: Â 'new normal' is really 'a step backwards.' Â Ok, done!Time to close up the computer! I have exercises to do! Â :-)Talk again soon!

title: Girls vs Boys
text: The most important job I have ever done was raising two children into fine responsible adults. Â I've done other jobs - some paid and some not - one of which includes 8 care giving years for my mom at the end of her life. Â But raising children well tops the jobs list because it impacts our future as a community, a nation and a world. The raising of a grandchild carries that same level of importance, and when the grandchild is a girl - in today's world - there is one other point to consider. Â Women are on the rise in our culture - the struggles are real - equality is not yet a reality, and it will take strong smart women in the future to move a culture in the right direction.When I was a second grade teacher, I really enjoyed watching the boys in my class. Â So open, inquisitive, natural, daring, and often challenging in their approach to their environment - even if they knew they were going to get into trouble! I loved it. Â On a rainy fall morning, as I watched the arriving children walking across the playground on their way to school, I spotted Terrence, one of my students. Â He was decked out in a bright yellow slicker that covered him from under his chin to well below his knees. Â Room for a growing boy - and it covered him completely. Â He had matching rain boots on and a matching broad brimmed yellow rain hat that tied under his chin. Â You could tell his mother made sure that this child of hers was going to arrive at school ... dry! Â But she underestimated the powers of a 6 year old boy. Â The playground had some low spots. Â Big puddles. Â He was drawn to those puddles like a magnet is drawn to the north pole. Â I'll give him credit. Â He stopped at the edge of a big puddle and looked at the water. Â His mind radiated the message ... I am going to be in big trouble for this! Â And then, with a big smile and much joy, jumped into that puddle stamping around until he was totally soaked. I remember smiling broadly with him. Â I remember the other students giving him a wide berth in the playground, and I remember the astounded look on his mother's face when she had to bring dry clothes to school later that morning. Â But in that moment he didn't care - puddles were meant to be stomped in. Â He was going to stomp, and stomp, and stomp. Â And he was willing to pay the price. Every girl in my class arrived totally dry. Â :-)That is the strongest memory of my 4 years of teaching second grade. As a new teacher I wondered ... how much of this difference between boys and girls is due to nurture rather than nature. Â Now I strongly believe nurture is the stronger influence in how individuals approach all things in their environment. Â And now I am going to have a grand daughter. Â The stakes seem so much higher for her today than that day I watched Terrence make an educated decision and taking a free action. Â  Nurture. Â That is what it is all about.We are totally thrilled as a family for this cherished little girl. Â My first words to my son on learning the sex of his child was what I wanted for her. Â I want his daughter to be raised as a self confident, strong, intelligent, and fearless individual. Â We need more women in the world who aren't limited by their gender. Â I believe the time is ripe for raising these kind of female children ... especially in light of the current movement of women on the public stage!! Â And he agrees! Â My son is a black belt in martial arts, he is creative, self taught, self confident, not worried about wearing pink (another story for another time, ha!) and he picked a spouse who espouses exactly the kind of woman we should have more of in our world. Â He plans on raising his daughter in the style that will make her all of the Â things I want her to be! Â My son and his wife are perfect for raising a girl.I am so proud of the son I raised. Â My daughter as well ... she is no slouch either. Â She agrees with us completely, but sees things through a slightly different lens ... "yes, mom, she can grow up to be ALL those things, while wearing pearls and lipstick." Â I guess as a family we have all the bases covered!!:-)I think of Terrance now and then. Â He would be about 54 years old today. Â He is forever frozen in my mind as that wonderfully free and inquisitive child - all in yellow. Â He, of course, will never know the influence he has had over my hopes for my grand daughter today. Â Dear grand daughter, find the same the same joy, freedom and adventure in life as Terrance ... starting with the puddles!

title: My Shower Gifts
text: Officially my husband and I contributed to the purchase of a very nice stroller. Â You know, of course, I couldn't leave it at that. Â I am a knitter. Â It would have been the greatest of sins against the knitting gods if I hadn't knitted something for this dear child. Â And, I am sure you will not be surprise to discover that I did more than one item! Â After all, I was laid up with a bum knee. Â But my hands weren't broken. Â So here is what I brought.These two helmets were crochet.This first item - a baby Viking Helmut - my son's discovery. Â  He found the baby Helmut picture somewhere and forwarded it to me. Â No explanation, no requests - just the picture. Â So within about 15 minutes I found the pattern on line - (fast fingers) - and it was purchased. Â And oh so lucky, the pattern included other sizes - right up to adult. Â So the new dad got a matching helmut as well. Â And - of course - I couldn't leave it at that. Â I found a book titled: Â "How to raise Viking children and other tales of woe." Â How cute is that!The next project was a cotton baby blanket. Â The cotton was purchased about 4 years ago (I was still hopeful at the time I would have a grandchild - purchasing yarn in advance - well in advance as it turned out. ) Â I had so much of this cotton I made a matching bunny.The bunny's butt! Â :-)This next project is a newborn matching sweater and bonnet. Â Now in the atmosphere is full disclosure I must share the fact that for years I always said I would NEVER knit anything in newborn size. Â Never, never, never. Â Babies grow so fast ... I expounded to anyone who stood still to listen. Â It was a waste. Â Crazy! Â Insane really. Â Certainly not sensible!Then there was going to be a newborn in my world. Â And what size is the first garment I make for her - newborn! Lesson to be learned from this story ... never pay any attention to anything I say! Â :-)This final gift is long overdue. Â It is a shawl for the new mom. Â I have had this idea for some time that new mothers-to-be should have a personal gift just for them. Â After all, anyone who has been pregnant knows that pregnancy isn't always easy. Â Nausea, expanding waist line, frequent trips to the bathroom at night, someone punching at you from the inside, odd cravings, crazy hormones ... really, this list is the tip of a slippery iceberg! Â It can be the most wonderful time of your life - or the worst - and even a mix of both. Â A gift for the person who is sharing their body with another human being is the least I could do.My daughter-in-law is of Italian descent, with dark hair, dark eyes and a lovely olive complexion. Â This red color is perfect for her.Since the shower my knitting list of projects has grown very large. Â No more newborn - for sure. Â Working on an 18 month red hoodie for my grand daughter now. Â And there are two knitted dragons I want to make (more on the dragon theme in another post.). Â Several shawls are in my line up for my daughter, daughter-in-law and myself AND a matching poncho outfit for mother and daughter - the pattern is so darn cute. Â  My sister's daughter had her first baby this past August - and yes, I did some knitting for my grand nephew, Will (pictures to follow.). And there is a very handsome cabled sweater in my radar for him in Christmas 2018. So I will be busy. Â Very very busy! So much to look forward to!!

title: A Baby Shower
text: Although I have avoided repeating it over and over and over ..... and over again on my blog, it probably needs to be said now as I begin this blog post. Â I am going to be a grandmother in February.Â Ok, more emphasis - I AM GOING TO BE A GRANDMOTHER!!Oh, heck, one more time with feelingÂ Â I AM GOING TO BE A GRANDMOTHER!!!Hopefully you get the picture ... a mother (me) who has looked forward to being a grandmother for probably 20 years and just when she accepted the obvious - no grandchildren for her (me) - a grand child was conceived. Â It is like winning the billion dollar lottery - hard to wrap my brain around it.This little life is most precious to me. Â Sort of a perfect jewel in the crown of my life. Â Earlier this month we held a baby shower for my daughter-in-law. Â It has been probably 40 years since I attended a baby shower. Â They haven't changed much. Â Food, laughter and gifts. Â At the new mom's request, we skipped the games. Â But we did have a few fun activities.Time Capsule StationI was in charge of the Time Capsule activity. Â Guests were invited to write a note to the new baby. Â Notes can include best wishes for a full life, predictions of how the baby's life will evolve, stories about the baby's family members, advice, etc. Â The notes are put in a 'time capsule' to be opened and read by the child on her 18th birthday. Â We are taking this activity one step further. Â Instead of limiting notes to just those who attended the shower, the 'time capsule' can be added to over the years with notes by friends and family.The sign explaining the 'time capsule' project.Periodically throughout the event I noticed people sitting at the table, writing their notes and using the sealing wax I included to seal the envelope.The mirrored box for putting the notes in - which will be Â replaced by a sealed box with a slot on topÂ that her dad, my son, will make.I enjoyed the search which resulted in this beautiful mirrored box. Â It will be replaced by something that can be sealed. Â But this lovely box can be used by my beautiful little grand daughter to hold any special items she desires.The first two letters - one from my daughter and one from me.I am also very grateful for an opportunity to share through letters my love and bits of my life with my grand daughter as she grows. Â I hope I live long enough to see her grow into a young woman, but life makes no guarantees. Â So having a voice through writing to share with her as a young adult is very important to me.As with most parties there was food. Â Lots and lots of food. Â Too much really. Â We had about 20 guests and could have fed 50! Â No one left hungry.Another activity was decorating Onesies. Â Guests used their own originality to put messages on these tiny garments. Â Then they were hung on a clothes line for all to see. Â Great fun!Guess who did this one!! Â :-)It was a wonderful time for all. Next up ... the gifts grandma (me) brought to the shower. Â Yes, they were handmade.

title: My Happy Place
text: This is a beaded shawl I finished for my daughter as a gift for this Christmas. Â I don't think she follows my blog so this picture should be safe here. Â The pattern is called Cathedral Windows.And she lives directly across the street from the National Cathedralwith beautiful cathedral windows. Â Â I began knitting officially in 1998. Â I say 'officially' because I sort of knew how to knit back in the 70's, but the hobby never took root then. Â I was self taught. Â I was terrible at it. Â I wanted immediate gradification. Â I had no patience for long projects, problem solving fit issues, learning to correct mistakes, or accepting the fact an item might 'perfect' even if I was the only who could see the error. Â In 1998, however, I left a life sucking management job and had learned that imperfection was ok. Â I decided to 'recover' from that profession by learning to knit at a yarn store. The time was right. Â Knitting became a life-enhancing hobby that I would be lost without.Over the years I tried to expand my crafting horizon beyond knitting to other related activities.Â Some Merino and Silk fiber that is waiting for me tospin it.I learned to spin. Â There was, of course, the initial excitement and purchasing of equipment. Â  First I spun yarn on a spindle and then quickly bought a full size spinning wheel.
