Â Although 30 minutes doesn't sound all that far, when you are as close as 10 minutes to your family support system, adding another 30 minutes to that commute is not appealing. Â Oh well, we will be patient and hope that the summer will produce another condo possibility. Â The rest of the week is uneventful.What keeps me awake at night ...I worry (mostly between 2:00 and 4:00 am) that moving my visually impaired husband out of this townhouse (a home he knows intimately) is a mistake. Â We both agree we should have a residence that would allow us to live on one level. Â At a minimum, we should live in a place where we could reach our front door easily with a walker or wheel chair. Â Sadly, this town home is not that place. Â But right now, in this minute, we are able to live here comfortably. Â Is it an over reaction to move before the need is there or is it the adult thing to do before we are forced by circumstances? Â It is easy to talk yourself into staying in a home you love and can manage now. Â It is the comfortable and simple choice. Â But just when you have yourself convinced that it isÂ ok to stay ... your husband misses the last step on a flight of steps and falls on his hip. Â And that is exactly what he did on Sunday. Â He is ok, butÂ ... guess it is not ok to stay here. That is it for this week in my little corner of the world.

title: Put the Skids on Time
text: What the heck!It is June 4 already!Â Â JUNE!Â Â JUNE!!!Does anyone else feel like it shouldn't be June already - it should be more like March, maybe April, but definitely not June. Â Although it is still technically spring, it will soon be summer in my little area of the world. Â SUMMER! Unbelievable. I feel like if I blink, I will miss summer entirely, skip fall and be facing winter ... again!I willingly admit that as I age I have a love hate relationship with time. Â I love that I have more free time day-to-day than at any other point in my life. Â I love that I can do nothing for a day - pushing planned to-dos into the future, because there is more time in my future than ever before (hopefully.) Â I love that through the passage of time I have learned to be more respectful of the time gift I have been given ... Â 'retired time' when I can do mostly whatever I want. Â I love all that. Â You don't get to 69 without knowing that some folks never get that gift.But there is a hate side to this equation. Â I hate that my future time can be counted in mostly years and not in many decades. Â I hate that at 69 I don't have 69 more years ahead of me. Â In fact, in just one small decade I will be 79 - a time when the chances of living another decade are considerably smaller. Â I hate that because of time my mortal body is starting to have problems - that my 'retired time' will be shared with an aging body that has a built in obsolescence.I need to put the skids on time - slow it down.Â Â But how is the question.Think, think, think ...I've noticed that when you aren't paying attention to time, it speeds up and slips away. Â If you are paying attention and are more mindful of the moment - time seems to slow down. Â I may have read that somewhere. Â In truth, Â that is just a 'mind game' as time never slows down or speeds up - just keeps ticking away - totally irregardless of what individuals do. Â It is only our perception of time that may change with attention to it.Maybe time is like a fortune of gold coins. Â The quantity of time or gold coins is a fixed number - unknown and different for everyone. Â Each minute spent is a gold nugget that cannot be replaced. Â How each golden minute is spent is in our control - not much else is within our control. Â But can that approach put the skids on time?Maybe trying to slow down time is the wrong approach. Â Maybe the best way to handle time is to see it through the eyes of a dog. My dear grand dog, Grimace who passed away this spring ... who never pondered time,who lived in the moment, who spent his golden nuggets of timemaking others happy.That face says, "This is the moment that counts, Grandma. Â Not yesterday, not tomorrow. Â Just today. Â Now can I have that treat you are holding?"I am still learning Grimace. Â I am not as smart as you.

title: Right sizing
text: I recently read the term "right sizing" in a blog post on Miss Minimalist.Miss Minimalist hosts a weekly post featuring readers who are pursuing a minimalist life style. Â  Those posts very interesting as they allow you to peak into the lives of folks making big changes. Â  Â This Monday she hosted "Heather in Texas" who used the term "right sizing."Yes! That is what I am doing. Â Getting things to a size that fits me! Â What a great term. Â It does not dictate a one-size-fits all style of living.And in truth, I think it is what we all do in our lives. Â Size it to fit our desires.It got me thinking. Â Why did it take so long to seek out my own personal right size? Â Some of the writers on Miss Minimalist are in their 20s. Â Amazing that they should be so independent of thought at such an early age to know what size life is right for them.Not so with me. Â I was very impressionable as a young adult. Â Looking back my desires and goals were often formed from those around me. Â I believe the biggest influence in my early 20s came from my future mother-in-law.They say first impressions are the most lasting. Â Certainly it was so with her. Â Her small two bedroom apartment looked like a gift shop. Decorative objects filled every flat surface and wall. Â Weekends were spent keeping artful displays dusted, polished and organized. Yearly, she would hand wash all the walls and ceilings, and every year she would get down on her knees and scrape off all the weekly layers of "Wash and Glow" (one step wash and wax solution) from all the floors with a paint scraper. Â She would then apply a new layer of "Wash and Glow" to her floors and the cycle would begin again. Â  Â During this time she would rearrange all her furniture and decorations. Â Her drawers and closets were perfection. Â Nothing gave her greater joy than having someone comment on what a lovely home she had. Â In hindsight, sadly, it is evident that her home reflected her worth in her eyes. In those first years, I admired all that. Â Coming from a lower middle class family that did not have any disposable income, her apartment and style of living made a big impression on me. Â My dysfunctional family was the opposite of everything she was. Â I didn't see the negative life experiences and disappointments that lead her to such a controlled way of living. Â I wanted to "right size" my life to reflect what I saw in her. Â And in many ways I did.I came to understand, however, that her obsessive focus was on objects - not people. Â Objects didn't disappoint - and people did. Â As she aged her social contacts became limited. Â Her "friends" were her hairdresser, the grocery store checker, the taxi cab driver. Â Now I know that those folks could easily be discarded if they disappointed. Â  She had right sized her life to one narrow little path to minimize disappointment.Those early influences lingered on in me for years and years. Â Eventually I learned to love and accept this woman for who she was while growing to understand that her "right size" was not right for me. Â She was a wonderful grandmother to my children. Â She died almost 20 years ago and I miss her to this day. Â But her life style influence has almost totally faded from my radar. Â It took about 40 years, but my own style is evolving in an entirely different direction.Right sizing my life kicked into high gear when mom died. Â I am reaching what is good for me. Â The size of our house may continue to be too big, but the contents are reaching a level that is manageable and comfortable.

title: My Life List - Memorial Day Weekend 2016
text: My Life ListI am joining the blogÂ Smidgens, Snippets and Bits in sharing "My Life List."My Life List Currently:Â I am thankful ...... on this Memorial Day for the citizens who gave their lives in service to our country. Â My earnest wish is that we can live in a world where there is no need to memorialize deceased military citizens because the world will be at peace. Â Human beings being what they are, I am sure not even my great grandchildren will live long enough to see that day.Looking out my front window ...... I see well maintained green spaces and terraces. Â I live on a small hill that separates us from the street. Â It was the distance from the street that attracted me to this location. Â Townhouse developments are typically uninteresting, cookie-cutter communities that resemble each other. Â Frequently they have tiny front yards that hug a parking lot. Â The developer of this community created an appealing space at the entrance where some of the town homes are up off the street allowing some sense of privacy and style. Â The original landscape has matured. Â After so long a time I hardly even notice its inviting beauty until someone else comments how lovely the setting is. Â I'll miss this view when we leave.As I ponder ....... the Memorial Day holiday and this political season I can't help but wonder how our country got to such a dysfunctional place. I try to avoid taking public positions on political and religious views. Â No one's deepest beliefs are changed by raging discussions of these topics. Â But I am so uneasy at the national trends right now, I feel the need to express a worrisome opinion somewhere. Â My blog ... my space .... my opinion.I am a registered Independent. Â I have supported both Democratic and Republican candidates over my voting history. Â One party never has all the answers. Â But we are so divided as citizens now, and I believe that this division is reflected in the leadership we elected ... polarizing us even more. Â Setting aside policy differences, when we cannot even replace a Supreme Court Justice using the rules our nation lives by - our Constitution - we are in a very sad state.I believe current candidates are the most diverse (and one is just plain frightening) choices for President in our history. Â Sadly no candidate shows the leadership potential to pull us away from our derisive path. Â I admit to being a big supporter of President Obama ... not because I agree with all his policies, but because he is an educated, even-tempered, thoughtful man who has served with grace under incredible pressure. Â If a person of his quality could not bring us to more national unity and understanding, the current batch of candidates most certainly will make things worse.When the nations of the world look at our struggles to pick a leader ... a leader who historically is the leader of the free world ... I am sure they cringe. Â What has happened to America? Â Are we going through a "terrible twos" period in our history, or a mid-life crisis, or are we in decline as the voice of reason in a crazy dangerous world?I hope we are in a momentary "blip" in our history. Â That calmer more reasonable minds will prevail and we return to a better sensibility of who are ... and behave accordingly! Â (I am such a polly-anna!)Â What I am learning ...... I am learning to keep my mouth shut about this political stuff on Facebook. What I am reading ...Â This Bitter TreasureÂ by S. W. Hubbard. Â  This is the 3rd book in the Palmyrton Estate Sale Mystery Series. Â The lead character, Audrey Neaton, is the owner of an Estate Sale company. Â The mysteries revolve around that various estate sales she coordinates. Â There is always a mystery and there is a bit of romance but the theme that attracts me is the estate sale business. Â Great fun!What I am creating ....Besides an ulcer :-) ... Â I am still working two shawls.Discovery time ....I bought two new items this week. Â During a period when I am not buying much of anything, I was kind of surprised by these purchases.The More of Less: Finding the Life You Want Under Everything You Own by Joshua Becker. Â I obviously have a weakness for reading non-fiction books on this topic. Rated on Amazon as 4.8 stars out of 5, I couldn't seem to pass this up. Â I usually buy Kindle editions because they are cheaper and don't take up space, but for this title, the Kindle was more expensive. Â I probably will pass the book on when I am done. Â My designated shelf for books is full and I am not going to allow it to spill over.The Handbag of Holding - Â Ok, this was a fun impulse purchase. Â I will admit to a bit of a tote bag obsession. Â I always have a knitting project or two, plus my Kindle and my iPad with me. Â I am always on the search for interesting and functional totes. Â This bag is the latest in that search. Â The origins of this bag and name are found specifically in the fantasy game Dungeons and Dragons (D and D). Â A "bag of holding" is described as a "wondrous item" used by gamers to hold a great number of items that wouldÂ normally be to big or to heavy for the bag or a person to carry. Â It is "a bag that has an interior space considerably larger than its outside dimensions and can hold up to 500 pounds. Â The bag weighs about 15 pounds regardless of its contents." Â See? Â Wonderous! Â Anyway, I came across The Handbag of Holding on Amazon. Â It is a tote designed to hold a lot in an organized fashion and its zipper pulls are 20 sided dice (another game reference.) Â It has a handsome tailored look, and I love the game reference. Â I used to play D and D with a group - and my husband and son still play monthly with same group of individuals for over 35 years. Â Feel free to check out the Amazon links.What I am watching ...I finished watching House of Cards and am now struggling to find another highly rated series to follow. Â I have sort of run out of titles. Â Any suggestions? I started a TV series call Grace and Frankie. Â The actors are Jane Fonda, Lily Tomlin, Sam Waterston and Martin Sheen - all actors I enjoy. Â Briefly, it is a comedy about two women finding out that their husbands are not just work partners, but have also been romantically involved for the last 20 years. Â The wives have a strained relationship already and coping with this news doesn't make things better. Â I have seen the first two episodes and I am not entirely sold on it, but it has multiple seasons and is highly rated so I will give it a few more episodes before I decide. Â Sometimes these things grow on you.What's on my camera phone ...The beautiful lady is my daughter, Kristin with her dog, Milo. Â This picture is one of the professionalshots taken for sales promotions where my daughter works.She is the Director of Sales at a Retirement Continuing Care Community in DCand Milo is considered "part of the sales team." Â Folks love seeingthat pets are part of the life in a senior community so it is not an idle title for Milo. He is not on the payroll, but he pulls is weight. :-)A quote I want to share ...Some things in life cannot be fixed. Â They can only be carried. Â Megan DevineIn my experience most things can't be fixed. Â They must be carried. Â And the load of carried items just keeps getting heavier as the years pass. Â I think that is why people get shorter as they get older - the weight of life gets heavy. Â :-) Â Well, that is my story, and I am sticking to it.A peek into my week ...It is the end of one month and the start of another. Â I feel the pull to start initiate and/or re-commit to things at the beginning of a month. Â I plan to focus on these 3 things:With the downsizing efforts reduced, I have time to finally get my photo albums and loose pictures organized. Â I am also hoping to do some journaling in the finished albums - adding thoughts and remembrances in and around the mounted pictures. Nothing fancy - noÂ scrap booking or artistic endeavors - just a way to make the parade of photos more interesting and maybe more meaningful to someone else should they show an interest. Â  Â Increase my step totals beyond the 7,000 average I do now. Â Goal remains 10,000 steps a day.Be more consistent in my stretching routine.A peaceful Memorial Day to you!Remember what all those soldiers died for.Make your citizenship count in a positive way.

title: Authenticity Shawl
text: The second shawl I am working on is called Authenticity. Â The first picture shows the finished project as shown on the pattern. Â This is another pattern that can be made bigger by repeating the 16 line pattern any number of times or by adding to the garter trim. Â I plan on making this one a bit bigger as well. Â The yarn I am using is Berroco Lustra is which is 50% wool and 50% tencel. Â As a result it has a shiny appearance. Â The picture below is closer to the true color of the yarn than the succeeding pictures. Â But even so, the gray threads in the picture below seem to be 50% of the color - when they are not. Â It has a more deep purple pink look to it. Â Maybe when the shawl is done, I can take a picture of it out doors in natural light.The picture below is provided just for comparison - they don't look at all the same when they are exactly the same ball of yarn. Â Lighting is so important when trying to capture color. Â I hardly ever get it right.Here is my progress knitting Authenticity. Â As you can see, it will require very strong blocking to bring out the pattern. Â Also, this pattern is not the most difficult lace pattern I have ever done, but it does need your attention while knitting. Â I am always counting the different sections to make sure I have the right number of stitches before beginning the next row. Â I try to be so careful, but mistakes happen more frequently than I would like. Â So far I have caught them at an early stage. Â I will be very glad to get to the lower garter boarder where I can relax and to worry about counting sections.

title: Hitchhiker Shawlette
text: As mentioned in a previous post ... I am working on two shawls. Â This first shawl is an asymmetrical Â shawlette. Â The yarn used was a Socks that Rock medium weight. Â The dyer has a tendency to create yarns with bold large shifts in color. Â The dying technique can cause pooling of colors (large areas where a single color can collect together resulting in uneven or badly placed blotches.) Â Finding the right pattern for these Socks that Rock yarns is important if you want to avoid unintentional pooling. Â Also interesting to note is that when the yarn is in the skein it looks different from when wound into a ball. Â The two yarns above looked exactly the same before I put one into a ball. Â They look so different to my eye.The pattern I used is called Hithhiker. Â The designer's picture is a smaller version. Â This shawlette can be made bigger just by continuing to knit until you decide to stop. Â My version is generally bigger. Â This pattern has the advantage that you can work on it without paying much attention. Â You knit every row (known by knitters as garter stitch) and the instructions for the points are very simple. Â  Â Generally I like to have a project that requires little or no attention while I knit so I can watch TV or carry on a conversation with friends and not worry about making mistakes that require major ripping out to fix.Once completed this seldom needs blocking. Â The garter stitch lies beautifully flat and needs no massaging through blocking to look "finished." Â Most knitted garments need gentle blocking and some shawls required excessive blocking to bring out the pattern and provide a finished look. Â Not so with this pattern.I think this is my 4th Hitchhiker. Next up - a traditional shawl.

title: Rags
text: Here is my newest baby, Ragnar Â ... sometimes called RagsWe like our agent! Â It was a good decision to change agents. Â The first gentleman was nice, but I couldn't help feeling he was focused on a different element of the market than we were.Our third meeting with the new agent went well this week. Â The walk-through of our property was simplified by the fact we will not be residing in the house when it is shown. Â So our "punch list" should be short.But during our talk I was caught unexpectedly by an emotion that I have kept under control.He said our house would show very well in the pictures and in person. Â Our care and improvements will make for an easy showing. Â Then he said that the brochure they would create would also look great.Brochure!! Something about having our house shown in a brochure made the emotion of leaving this place suddenly rise to the surface. Â I responded, that I would try not to cry when he created that brochure. Â He glanced at me and paused for a moment. Â He then gracefully shifted his gaze and commented that a move like this after 30 years is hard - so much life has occurred here - and your obvious care of the property shows just how hard it will be. I could feel my eyes tearing up and my throat tighten. Â I couldn't speak.He quickly went on to describe the house he and his wife had lived in and had 6 kids in - 1100 square foot rancher. Â He talked about how it felt to keep that house, but rent it to strangers. Â That his son still cuts the grass for that property. Â That he only rented to those he trusted, but still had attachments. Â And so on and so on.While he talked I had a chance to get control of my emotions. Â I was grateful.We moved on.Oh my God.Â Â This won't be easy.Â Â How will I ever get through the settlement process!

title: Sliding towards less
text: While I am not qualified to speak on the topic of minimalism, Â it does feel like I am slipping towards a "less" style of living. Setting aside the downsizing efforts needed to move, getting less stuff off my radar always makes me feel better. Â I've done this many times, but not so drastically as this time.For the most part, I can't remember the bulk of what I have carried out the door. Â Obviously if I can't remember that mountain of stuff, it was not important. Â It was taking up space in my world and robbing my attention and energy.But the remembered list of discarded things is considerable AND remarkable for many reasons. Â It totally astounds me how much we held onto - long beyond our interest in them. Â Passions from 20 or 30 years ago that we lost interest in and just boxed away. Â Hobbies and past times my husband could no longer enjoy because he could not see. Â Sentimental items that lingered because we could not let go of the emotion attached to them. Â Valuable items we never touched much less saw for years and years.Here is a brain dump of the remembered stuff that is living with new owners.Doll house and all the doll house furniture - this all went back to the original owner, my daughter and pictures of that lovely hobby were featured here. It is the one thing if she simply didn't want it any more, I would take back.Stamp Collection - Â valued at over $80,000 at one time.Huge board game collectionVast library of books - near a thousand at one point when my husband could readMiniatureÂ hand painted soldiers - over 300 miniatures, many were museum qualityThemed chess sets - 10 or 11 in allGerman imported nut crackers - 22 in allFurniture - 2 chests of drawers, 2 benches, a full size freezer, 2 desks, a head board - that was just in the last 3 months - many more pieces in the last year.Kitchen stuff - mugs, good china, Kitchen aide food processor, about 40 cookbooks (a ridiculous number for a person who doesn't want or like to cook)Â Crafts - spinning wheel, yarn, about 25 books, yarnMy work clothes are gone, boxes and boxes of shoes are gone - mostly because my sad old feet can wear only about 3 pairs without pain.That list makes me a little breathless. Â The money we spent. Â Yes, we did get enjoyment at the time but really ... the space and energy it subtracted from our lives over years exceeds the balance of enjoyment we got for a short time. Â Too bad I can't send a message back to my younger self and say "STOP! Â You won't really care about this stuff for most of your life!" Â Well ... I still care about that doll house and my yarn, but everything else, not so much.And still stuff remains .... photo albums and pictures I will keep because they spark precious memories. Â I still have a lot of clothes. Â Guess I will need to check out condition and size. Â Our pantry is shrinking ... the thought crossed my mind more than once over the years that I may be a food hoarder. Â At least all the expired foods are gone :-) and I check the pantry before I shop. Â Ha! Â There is a roughed in closet with storage items (Christmas, lamps, picture frames, ladder, shovels, etc) that has yet to be explored. Â I bet I have weed killer from 1999. Â And my yarn room. Â *sigh* I have given away some yarn to various folks and about half my pattern books. Â I could still knit until I was 97 without buying even one skein of yarn and never run out. Â Here there is no doubt ... Â I am a card carrying hoarder of yarn. Â I think I will happily hold on to that title until I take my last breath.Interestingly enough, ongoing stuff reduction seems to have unintentionally spilled over into other areas of my life. For example:I have long since given up a wide array of cosmetics, perfumes and lotions. Â My approach to personal appearance is simple - this is me, the way God made me and life changed me. Â My gray hair and wrinkles have been well earned. I wouldn't think of hiding them. Â I am happy with myself the way I am. Â All I really need is a blow drier and hair brush, moisturizer, lip gloss, a splash of blush, enough sleep to keep the circles from my eyes and a smile! Â I hope all that counts as graceful aging instead of laziness. Â Ha.I have never been a big jewelry person but I did have a few pieces that were special. Â I gave away some to family, kept a few, but only wear my wedding ring now. Â I don't even wear earings in my pierced ear lobes. Â My, how times have changed.My personal schedule is much reduced. Â I used to enjoy many social obligations and organized groups that used my talents. Â I don't get the energy or enjoyment I used to from that busy schedule. Â Now I limit myself to fewer external ongoing commitments and look forward them more because they are not squeezed into an over committed calendar. Â I am happy with my own company, my family and close friends. Â I don't seek out more just because I have time for more. Sliding towards less ... Â a good thing.

title: My Life List
text: I follow the blog Smidgens, Snippets and Bits. I found Paula when she was a caregiver for her husband who has since passed away. Â I was caring for my mom at the same time and my mom passed away several months after her husband. Â She and I had a lot in common.She has a fun blog, and you should check her out. Â One post she offers with regularity is a "My Life List." Â  Â As I read through her recent list, I realized that my own responses to her prompts jump out of my mind too. Â Although she started this practice as a link to A Simple Woman's Daybook blog, she decided to break away from that format. Â Her own format is relaxed - no strict rules about entries or prompts, no linking to other blogs, just a way to share short bursts of your own life as it suits you. Â I loved the idea of it and have decided to "steal" (translation - join) her idea. Â Knowing Paula, it will make her smile.My Life List Currently:Â I am thankful ...... for the continued thread of connectivity and friendship I have with blog friends who have traveled with me since this blog was created in 2009. Â So much has changed, so many hurdles leaped. Â And yet, here we still are together.Looking out my window ...... I see green. Â I am so fortunate to have a green back drop to my townhouse. Â Yes, I have neighbors attached to me on either side, but when I look out my back windows it is like looking into a small forest of green. Â Deer frequently visit that hill of green and you don't need binoculars to see them ... I am that close. Â Sometimes they sit on that hill (they think they are hidden) and I can watch them. Â Mom used to love that. Â I will miss this view when I move.As I ponder ....... the next 15 years. Â Yes, in only 15 years I will be 84. Â Seems almost impossible, that so much time of my life is behind me and that I will be an old woman by anyone's definition in 15 short years. Â I am not sure I would think about this next stage of life it I hadn't watched an elderly person walk through it while living in my home. Â That realization is less a theory and more a reality once you have had the experience. Â It is much like the young person at 25 who knows if they live long enough they will be a very very old person at 50, (ha), but really doesn't believe it so it is more theoretical - and yet as you get closer to 50 you start to believe it as reality (except 50 doesn't feel "very very old.")What I am learning ....... patience! Â Patience, patience and more patience. Â I thought I had learned all there was about patience in taking care of my mom, but I find the well of patience I still need to learn continues to grow in taking care of my husband with his increasing visual impairment. Â Being his eyes is a daily - sometimes hourly - task. Â I push back frequently in many small ways to encourage independence, but it is like pushing a boulder up hill. Â And he is a person with little patience - has been all his life, so the frustration he feels is so great with this limitation - and the sorrow I feel knowing this sometimes brings tears to my eyes. Â In writing this, I realize that maybe what I need to be doing is teaching him patience. Â Hmmm ....What I am reading ...I am almost always "reading" two books.I am listening to The Sound of Glass by Karen White.I am reading on my Kindle Treasure of Darkness by S. W. HubbardWhat I am creating ....I am working on two shawls. Â Pictures to follow in another post. Â All my other fiber projects are packed away so that the house looks tidy and uncluttered for a potential sale.What I am watching ...Season four of House of Cards - Oh, my God, these people are so despicable. Â And I wonder at myself that I can't stop watching that show. Â Ha!What's on my camera phone ...I have been helping my husband to set up a new iMac computer. Â  In doing that I took two pictures of our personal wall paper from the old iMac. Â The first picture is my wall paper of a flower filled with color and shades of pink. Â The second picture is my husbands wall paper. Â Color has no meaning for him. Â He needs contrast and bold lines - and with these changes he can see only parts. Â We can't look through his eyes, but these images sort of demonstrates the scope of what he dealing with. Â These pictures make me sad.A quote I want to share ...One day she finally grasped that unexpected things were always going to happen in her life. Â And with that she realized the only control she had was how she chose to handle them. Â So she made a decision to survive using courage, humor and grace. Â She was the Queen of her own life and the choice was hers! Â  Luputha HerminI have a ways to go before I am using courage, humor and grace.A peek into my week ...This week we meet with our new real-estate agent for a final walk through of our property, to get a final punch list of changes needed so we are ready to sell this property if something shows up on the market for us to buy. Â We will also sign the contract with him. Â And my regular schedule of dogs visits starts up again mostly because the puppy needs a break mid-day to peep and have his lunch. Word of the year update ... Move!Well, my word for the year is "move" and I guess it still fits. Â I planned it to mean keep my body moving. Â Turns out it is more like "move" all your worldly possessions somewhere else! Â Yikes. Â How did that happen. Â My "move" exercise efforts are still struggling. Â By the time I get done with my "move" all your worldly possessions efforts, I am bushed. Â I guess moving is moving regardless of how it happens. Â But now that my downsizing efforts have slowed, my exercise efforts need to pick up.Well, there you have it! Â I think it is a fun exercise and it hits the high (and low) points of my life today. Â Enjoy.

title: The Finish Line
text: I have finally gotten our worldly goods down to the basics for living in our townhouses. Â Trips to the dump and to Good Will have slowed. Â Yesterday several pieces of furniture where picked up and hauled away. Â Oh, there are still some small pockets of stuff I haven't finished getting through. But we are close. Â If were were to move now, of course, I am sure other things would not come with us because space in a two bedroom condo will be more limited.But ... where to go. Â That question still haunts us.Our search continues to limit us to elevator buildings or first floor units. Â We are further limited by location and condition. Â  Not all locations are acceptable for a variety of reasons. Â But the issue of condition (how well maintained, how clean, appliance issues, etc. etc. etc.) still remains a large stumbling block for me. We are looking for a 'move-in-ready' property. Â My definition of move-in-ready, means that I can move in and not be faced with major condition expenses in the first year. Â Our house will be move-in-ready by my definition. Â In fact, it would be several years before someone would need to take action on anything ... unless they simply want to change the paint color, upgrade my new kitchen counters or purchase other appliances in a different color. Â I personally find those kinds of changes wasteful if the item functions well and is clean. Â But I understand about differences in taste. Â Some "move in ready" places, however, Â the appliances are so old and so dirty (and some have external damage) ... they would need to be replacedÂ beforeÂ I moved in.I don't want people to think I am a persnickety housekeeper. Â My appliances are not always clean, for years I lived with clutter, some of my carpet is original, and many dust bunnys use this place as a postal address. Â But if I sell this townhouse, those short comings will not be someone else's problem. Â I'll take care of them before I show this house to perspective buyers.In the two and a half months of condo searching ... and visiting a few properties that came close to what we were looking for, only two condos hit the market that were perfect and they were right in my neighborhood. Â Two units out of hundreds. Â They got snapped up quickly.So my husband and I have started to qualify every moving conversation with the possibility that we will stay here. Â It would mean some major expenses to retro-fit this townhouse to be user friendly for seniors. Â Two stair lifts would be a very expensive addition to a house that is too big for us now. Â  When you live in a 3 level town house and each level has things you use in daily living - it adds up to two stair lifts. Â But it is an option down the road.Fall is the 'finish line' for us on moving. Â We can continue to live with uncertainty for that long. Â We can continue to expend the energy that is required on multiple levels to make a move happen until we reach the finish line. Â  At the finish line, we will be in another abode ... or not! Â Either way, we are ok with it (cause I am not doing this again next year.)We are lucky that either choice is a good one.

title: One step back ...
text: This week we decided to change real-estate agents! Â Not that we had signed agreement yet with anyone, but we had been working off and on with one man from last fall Â ... Â more off than on!!We met with another agent from a different real-estate company who was recommended by my son. Â During our first meeting I felt more at ease about our decision to sell and move than I had during the last 10 months. Â I can't tell you what made the actual difference between the two agents, except to say that this new agent is focused on the general real-estate market - which we are stepping into with trepidation - and the other guy was focus on the 55+ senior market which we had decided against.Maybe all the stars just aligned in the sky at the right time. Whatever the reason, we changed agents this week.I will tell you this ... doing this whole process without an agent would make my head explode! Â I can't believe all the little twists and turns you go through to make a move like this. It is always making trade offs, deal making, massaging the numbers, exploring different options ... it is exhausting and stress filled stuff. Â Why can't selling and buying real-estate be like buy a bathing suit. Â You go into the store, look at all the bathing suites on the rack, pick a size and color, try one on, you pick a bigger size (nuts), try on another one, you look for something that covers more of you, (decide you really must lose weight sometime soon - or stop using mirrors), you take it to the check out and pay for it. Â Then you can walk out of the store and put it on right away (ok, you find a private place to put it on right away so you don't get arrested.) Â Woo hoo! Â Done!Ok, buying a bathing suit is almost as hard as buying real-estate.*Sigh* Â This is bringing the crazy out in me!Best to have the right agent so I won't go crazy.Or should I say ... Â go more crazy than I already am! Â :-)

title: Life goes on ...
text: Our family are devoted pet owners. Â And "devoted" may be interpreted as obsessed.We are truly obsessed with loving and sharing our lives with our furry family members.Recently one family member, my Pug grand dog, Grimace, passed away. Â We are still in mourning for that dear soul.Â If we could somehow get him back whole and happy,we would do it.But life goes on ... each moment moves us in a different direction.Â And there are so many sweet little fur faces out there.Here is my son's next sweet little guy.Meet my new grand dog baby!He is an English Bull Dog who is about 8 weeks old. Â Right now his name is Sampson - the name the breeder gave him, but by Friday, the day my son picks him up, the name will be something else. This little guy has wrinkles to spare and he has that wrinkly frowny face so typical of English Bull Dogs down pat already. Â No need to wait until he is 5 or 6 years old to see it evolve! Â We do love our smoosh face dogs. Â Ha!My heart still breaks for my dear Grimace, but there is room for this little guy to find a place there and start setting down roots. So meet my next heart break - 8 to 10 years out into the future.They just don't live long enough!How can you not love that face!

title: The day after ...
text: When a pet gives you his heart ... it is hard to not return the affection.This is Grimace. Â He is my son's dog and Grimace loves his "papa" very very much.He came into our lives as a rescue at the age of 3. Â He made such a difference in our lives.Such unqualified love and devotion he shared with all his family.At some point he discovered he had a grandma. Â That discovery led to 11 years of a loving relationship that grew and grew and grew.There was nothing I wouldn't do for my soul mate.Towards the end of his life we became so close.Yesterday, at the age of 14 1/2 my dear Grimmy's life came to an end.Â I was at his side.He struggled and struggled until the very end.I kissed his dear face, rubbed his floppy ears and gave him a last hug.It was my last loving gift to him - letting go!Today is the day after.I am lost without him.

title: Progress ... to a brick wall?
text: The moving saga continues. Â It progresses to a point that may hit a brick wall.The last few days I took a break from all this effort. Â I was too tired to continue. I really need to pace myself now. Â My energy levels are not inexhaustible. Â Such a sad observation of an older body. Â But it confirms the need to make some life adjustments during this year. The real problem so far has been the lack of properties that fit our needs. Â Oh yes, there are bunches out there, more and more every day. Â And that is encouraging. Â But I know we cannot move into a 2 bedroom, 2 bathroom condo that has only 800 to 950 square feet. Â I have seen a few. Â We need about 1,000 square feet. Â And many condos use that limited space very poorly. Â They are filled with walls and hallways - instead of maximizing the limited space with an open style floor plan. Â It is amazing how many advertise an "open floor" plan and when you see it, the walls seem to close you in.Then there is the problem of condition. Â Neither my husband or I are handy. Â We won't move from a townhouse that really is "move in ready" and start over in a condo that was listed as "move in ready" and isn't. Â One property needed all new appliances and painting throughout. Â All the closet doors would need to be replaced. Â And, of course, the biggest hinderance, no access by wheel chair or walker should we need it in the future. Â I could not face repeating all the work we did here - to make another place right for us. Â If it was a hobby or a talent of mine, maybe, but it isn't. Â And that kind of updating requires money when you hire someone to do it for you.No matter ... something may show up. Â It is only April. Â We have searched for only a month. Â We are early in this process. Â But it sure is tiring and challenging.The downsizing and cleaning continues. Â Collection of packing materials continues. Â A few boxes have been packed. Â The house continues to feel less and less filled - even if only to our eyes. Â It has been a freeing process. Â One I wish I had done earlier.But the condo market in our area just isn't cooperating yet.Although my husband cannot help with any of these efforts ... we have settled together on a plan of action.Our plan looks something like this ...Continue the clean out and downsize efforts until we reach the point that the remaining stuff is what we use all the time and love. Â Continue to look at condos with the eye to move in 2016.When we find a property we are interested in, then put our townhouse on the market to sell. Â This approach is chancy because it assumes that the condo seller will wait while we sell our townhouse. Â It is possible. Â We both agree, however, we don't want to be pushed into buying something else quick (maybe making a bad decision) because we have a buyer for our place waiting in the wings.Â Come October, if we have not moved, we may wind up settling in place making adjustments to this property to make it almost do-able. Â Those adjustments include things like stair lifts and hiring cleaning help. Â Certainly this is a fall back position - and not ideal on many levels. Â But re-settling in a condo that doesn't fit our needs either is not ideal. Â On the upside the townhouse and our contents would be in total move-ready condition should something change unexpectedly.Right now, I think that is the best we can do.

title: Breakfast
text: Moving away from the moving theme for a bit, lets talk food.Breakfast!Yes, that is my breakfast. Â I love breakfast. Â And not just any breakfast. Â I need something that will hold me until lunch time. Â I have repeated this breakfast menu almost every single morning for more than a year.One egg and one egg white, sprinkled a little cheese,Â 2 pieces of low fat sandwich ham fried in butter :-)fresh veggies cut up with a tablespoon of humus,a wassa cracker, a tablespoon of humusand if available ... massaged kale. Â Oh, and my second cup of coffee. Â The first cup of coffee must be ingested about an hour before starting to cook so that I am safe working over hot surfaces. Â Ha.Every.Single.Morning. Â Over and over again.When I go to bed at night I think about breakfast, I love it that much. Â I think, maybe I will eat something different in the morning. Â Maybe oatmeal with dry fruit and nuts. Â Maybe some pancakes. Â Maybe waffles. Â Maybe a bagel with cream cheese. Â Choices, choices.But in the morning, my body seems to crave everything in that picture and I begin the ritual breakfast meal prep. Â And when everything is ready, I sit at the table with my Kindle and read while I eat. Â It is amazing I don't get tired of it.There is only one exception to this breakfast.Left over Chinese carry out!That is AMAZING at breakfast.So what does your breakfast look like? Â And please, someone say they love Chinese carry out for breakfast. Â :-)

title: Good Morning World ...
text: ... at 5:30 am, sometimes 4:00 am, and even 3:00 am.Sleep does not seem to be my friend all that much of recent months.I know the problem probably lies in change. Â Moving may be the culprit. Â We are probably only 10% into this whole process ... and I am tired - like all the time tired.Packing up everything you own and moving it somewhere else unsettling at any age, but more so when you get older. Â Add to that all the details required to selling and buying property, changing all your services and getting resettled somewhere else is enough to rob anyone of sleep. My brain seems to have trouble shutting off and taking a break to sleep. Of course sleep and I haven't been all that fast friends since I entered my 60s. Â And I regularly use non prescription sleep aids to get my eyes to close at bedtime. Â The problem is keeping them closed. Â Hence the 'joyful' welcome of the morning. Â Truly, if I open my eyes and the clock says 5:30 am ... I count that as a full night sleep even if I closed my eyes at midnight. Â If the clock says 2:00 am, I have a serious talk with my wide awake brain as I lay there in bed willing sleep to come. Â Usually by 4:00 am I win the war and sleep comes.And yet, around 2:00 in the afternoon, I can't seem to keep my eyes open. Â If I sit, the body takes that as a signal to relax and the eyes quickly follow. Â Seldom do I actually sleep then either. Â I rest.My mom used to call this position 'just resting her eyes.' Â I get it now mom, I get it! Â Too bad she is not here in person to see that I get it.And maybe this all has nothing to do with the stress of moving. Â Maybe this has more to do with facing my 70s.Maybe that aging brain I talked about a few posts back is just the tip of the iceberg of everything slowing down.Well ... so much for wool gathering! Â No time to dither.Â Â Need to keep moving and packing and pitching!Â Â The clock is ticking.Â Â Too much to do to sit and watch it tick.

title: The Oven Conveys with the House.
text: Today I cleaned the oven.Ok, ok, I have a self-cleaning oven, and it cleaned it self ... but when you clean your oven only every 4 or 5 years, it is a big frick'en deal. Â So I take credit for hitting the self clean button and thinking, "Oh good, it still works."It was a lovely day today, so I had all the windows open. Â Why is that important? Â You will understand shortly.I am getting ready to sell this house and the oven conveys with the sale of the house, so it was time to clean the oven. Â I mean, after all, when I start looking at other properties to buy I will certainly open the oven to see if it is clean! Â :-) Â  You would do that right?? So my oven needed to be clean in case someone like me looks!But I am so much better at this than I used to be.Several years ago - well, maybe more than several years - like maybe 25 years ago, I remember deciding to clean my dirty oven. Â It was a self-cleaning model then too. Â  The oven was very dirty. Â Not just stained with cooked on stuff on the sides, but bunches of clumps of crusty whatever clustered on the bottom of the oven. Â Yes, that bad. Time to do the deed. Â I locked the oven door and hit the self clean button. Â I smugly enjoyed the ease of this 20th century feature while my oven started its clean cycle. Â I remember thinking that I was a modern 20th century wife and mother. Â I didn't need to do this distasteful task myself. Â With the flick of a finger, I was cleaning my oven.Oh, did I mention it was January? Â Did I mention is was about 35 degrees outside? Â Well, it was. That's important to know.Anyway, now the oven was cleaning. Then the oven began to smoke. Â Smoke started to creep out of the stove vents. Â Not a lot but enough to be alarming. Â The smoke detector sensed the smoke and it began to chirp ... ok, scream. Â Yikes! Â I tried to turn the oven off. Â The oven ignored my efforts. Â  It was locked in its clean cycle, the heat was at hellish levels, and it was doing what I was asked it to do. Â No stopping it now. Â Crap!I tried to turn the smoke detector off and realized I didn't know how to turn it off. Â Great! Â My eyes began to burn a bit, and although the smoke level was minimal ... (how do you judge "minimal" smoke in your house?) ... the smell was getting intense. Â I started to cough. Â I decided to turn off the house heat and open all the windows. Â I had young children in the house, after all. Â We needed to breath!!Oh, and did I mention it was January and it was 35 degrees outside? Â Well, it was.So then the house began to get cold (but the air quality got better ... I am a "glass is half full kind of person.") Â But we were getting really cold. Â So we all put on our coats and sat at the kitchen table huddled together waiting for the oven to do its thing. Â For 3 hours!!Oh, and I also stepped down off my 20th Century modern woman pedestal long enough to figured out how to stop the blaring smoke alarm.It was not my finest hour.So this week (mid April) when I pushed the self cleaning button of my oven, the day was beautiful, Â the temp was about 65 degrees, my windows were open AND I cleaned out the crust at the bottom of my oven in advance (Very.Very.Important) We still had some odor. Â My husband complained about the smell in the house and I cautioned him that things could be worse ... it could be 30 degrees outside, the smoke alarm could be screaming and he would need to wear his coat. He had NO IDEA what I was talking about. Â See 25 years ago he was at work when I last covered myself in glory with my skillful oven cleaning efforts. Â I am so much improved now! :-)Don't go looking for the 'before' picture. Â There isn't one.I have no intention of leaving proof behind of my house keeping Â short comings.:-)Anyway, the oven is now sparkling clean. Â Now we can move.

title: Where to go ...
text: The big question is ...Â Where!!Where are we to go?I have given this some thought. Â If you know me personally, you know I love lists. Â Here is my list of criteria for our search - in pretty much the order of importance:Stay in Howard County where there is an excellent hospital, ideally stay in the city of Columbia where we have lived for 43 years, and if all the stars align correctly, remain in our current neighborhood where we have lived for 31 years. Â Guess you could say we have history here. :-) Â Thankfully we have two lovely condo developments close to us that fall comfortably within bullet #1.Buy down - meaning, buy at about 80% or less of the current value of our town house. Â Although that narrows our choices, Â there are options in that range.Two bedrooms and two bathrooms. Â At a minimum a full and a half bath - 2 toilets! Â At our age, waiting to use the toilet is not realistic - at least not without a change of pants (ha!). Â Just say'en.No interior steps. Â It is amazing how many units have steps within the condo. Â We might have to take 5 or 6 steps to get to our front door, but lack of steps inside the condo is non-negotiable. Â After living with 49 steps in total, I think we can do 6 to the front door.Square footage should be between 1000-1200 square feet. Â If I was single, I could go smaller, but two people need more space - especially two people who have been married for 47 years. Â If you have been married that long you know exactly what I am talking about! Â Walking distance to a grocery store. Â Most couples share driving duties. Â There is a main driver and a back up driver. Â Well, our main driver, my husband, stopped driving 10 years ago - and our back up driver, me, Â is getting older by the minute. Â Just to be safe, close access to basic necessities is important.No top floor condos for me - even if there is an elevator. Â I'd like to think I could jump from a burning building and have a chance of surviving. Â :-) Meant as a joke, but at the same time I am very serious. Â So a second or third floor condo is preferred. Â An elevator building is required for a third floor condo.I am on the fence in getting a first floor condo - but I am trying to keep an open mind. Â I live in a city, a safe city mostly, but crime happens even in safe places.I am not interested in a Â 55+ plus community. Â I enjoy living around a variety of people of different ages and backgrounds. Â Besides, those 55+ communities are more expensive than we can afford.And finally, no condo fixer-uppers! Â My husband and I are degrading into fixer-uppers. Â We don't have to live in one!So that is my top 10. Â  Will I get all 10? Â Chances are against it.I have spent considerable Â time checking out online properties. Â The real-estate Â listings today are wonderful because they provide pictures and details without ever leaving your living room. Â That search has resulted in exactly one property that meets all 10 criteria. Â Only one out of hundreds. Â Amazing. Â I must be too picky. Â Of course every day is a new day in the real-estate world. Â Who knows that will be listed tomorrow.Next week we will see the one condo that fits our needs ... if it is still available! Oh ... and today is my birthday!! Â Happy Birthday to me. Â Guess I will find out who actually reads to the end of my wordy contributionsÂ to the blog-sphere!Â Â Ha!

title: The Big Pitch to Small Living
text: I am not talking baseball.I am talking clutter, downsizing, shrinking. Â I am talking giving away stuff to friends and family, trips to the dump and donations to charity organizations.Over 7 years of blogging, I've written 28 posts about clutter. Â Clearly this topic is important for me. Â And it is breath taking (and embarrassing) to think of all the items that have passed through my hands over the years. Â You can't inherit 3 households (small households for sure), and not have a mega highway of stuff running through you life. Â Let's not forget my husband and I also contributed generously to that collection of stuff.Some people downsize to the point that living in a smaller space comfortably is possible. Â That is our goal. Â But smaller can translate into tiny for some. Â That is not our goal. Â I have been, however, very curious about the tiny house movement. Â The true tiny house runs about 120-220 square feet of space. Â It is fascinating to see those small spaces and how inventive folks need to be to live in them. Â I wouldn't live in one myself but it is fun to explore that option through the lives of others. Â Of course, when you live in 2200 square feet of space like I have done for 31 years, stuff grows to fit the void. Â Getting to smaller living is hard when you live in a bigger than average structure.That is about to change for me.Less stuff and less square footage.Our goal is to shrink from 2200 square feet to pretty much half or 1100 square feet. Â Not exactly a "tiny" house, but it will qualify in my mind as smaller living.And to get to that goal, the "big pitch" is underway. Â This time it is not just stuff at risk... furniture is also getting the boot.I always find this effort to be so rewarding. Â As I pare down my belongings, I feel lighter, more in control, and in a strange way - very appreciative of the stuff that makes the cut. Â It is like seeing 'the keepers' with more clarity remembering why I loved that item to begin with. Â Truly, too much stuff seems to distract me from what I really care for.I have made pretty good inroads in cleaning out stuff, but much remains to be done. Â I am so grateful that I did so many decluttering sessions in the years before this one. Â I can't imagine how hard this would be if I had a house that was literally stuffed to the rafters.A month ago I gave away a full size spinning wheel that I purchased 7 years ago - during a time when I was coping with stress by buying stuff. Â When I think of spinning I am drawn to spinning on a spindle. Â Spinning yarn is in my future - just not on a wheel. Â My spinning wheel was a gift to my cousin - and she and Agatha (yes, the wheel's name is Agatha), are spinning away joyfully together. Â Never have I had so much fun sharing of my belongings as that gift to my cousin.Yesterday I gave away a collectable bear dressed in a Marine Corp dress uniform. Â It was a pricey bear I purchased when my son entered the Marine Corp. Â It when to a family with a new born boy - the father was a Marine. Â The perfect home for my Marine Corp bear! (Wish I kept a picture of him for this post.)Today I gave away my Kitchen Aide Food Processor. Â God knows that I was thinking when I bought that. Â I cook only to eat - certainly not out of enjoyment - and that kitchen gadget was pricey. Â It is not going with us.Tomorrow we are having a "give away" for friends. Â My husband and I collected Chess Sets for many years. Â Our kitchen table is stacked with them. Â We kept a special few - maybe 3. Â I really love those 3. Â But the others, all beautiful and unique, will find new homes soon I hope.I am not sorrowful or pensive about any of these departing items. Â In fact I can't even remember most Â the stuff that I carried out of this house in the years preceding today. Â Its been freeing and fun. I am excited about this move to less and smaller. Â Yes, it is being forced on me by circumstance, and the steps needed to get their are tiring and scary, but the end result will be positive!

title: Here
text: Sadness creeps in when I think about leaving this townhouse. Â I miss this place already and I haven't even left it yet. Growing up I never lived in a home we owned. Â I was raised in rental properties and we move a few times before I got married. Â As a married woman we moved a few times before settling here. Â  There was no place that had roots for me ... until here.I've lived 31 of my 69 years in this spot. Â My roots here are deep. Â It has been sort of my silent partner through some of the toughest and happiest years of my life. Â It has been a good place to live.I raised a family here.I supported two elderly relatives through their last years here.I offered shelter to my adult children more than once here.I watched my mother sit on the front porch for hours here.I mourned the passing of my mom here.I watched my mother-in-law suffer and die here.I watched my husband lose his vision here.I mourned the loss of 7 cats here.I watched my son leave for the military here.I worried every year he was in service here.I watched my daughter struggle with the downs of job loss here.I watched my son leave this house on his wedding day to start a new life here.I welcomed friends and family through many many holidays here.I welcomed a new daughter-in-law into our family here.I snuggled and loved (beyond all reason) grand dogs here.I struggled with my own demons in a demanding job here.Here ...the place I am preparing to sell because it no longersupports my life in a safe and comfortable way.I try to remember how lucky I have been to experience home ownership. Â Much of the world doesn't have more than a hovel to call home. Â I remind myself that when I am long gone from this earth this townhouse will still be here, sheltering another family I hope. Â I instruct my silly self to focus on the fact this townhouse is an inanimate object, a structure - not a living being and my attachment is maybe a little bazaar. Â  All those life experiences live vibrantly in my mind only.I know all that.But I can't help the feeling that a major portion of my life experiences are embedded here - in the Â walls, the air, the foundation. Â And I can't box any of that up and take it with me.I hope I don't cry during settlement when I sign this place away to someone else and walk away ... this place I called home for 31 years. This place with my roots.How will they know how special 'here' is!

title: Early Stages
text: So what does this picture of boxes suggest to you?If you thought of 'moving,' you would be right!We are facing a move and we are in the very early stages of that enormous task.Long time readers know that I live in a 3 level town house with 2 full flights of stairs. Â Those who followed the blog during the years my mother lived here know that I also have 20 common area steps to climb to reach my front door. Â 49 steps in all! Â Some may also know that after 30 years of wonderful service to my family, this town house has gotten just too big. Â Too big to heat and cool, too big to clean (3 1/2 bathrooms for 2 people is too many toilets to clean and does anyone really need 11 closets,) and too much in taxes and upkeep for retired folks on a limited income.I frequently hear things like - what a lovely setting, how well maintained, the neighborhood is great, and .... huh, just how many steps do you have?? Last year we began talking about moving. Â But my husband and I were of two minds - so the topic was dropped. Â This year, with me facing 69 and him facing 70, (yikes) the topic of downsizing brought us to the 'move' question again. Â  The realization that on this day we are as young as we are ever going to be was a big motivator to get serious.So the downsizing parade has begun. Â Lists of furniture and objects that will not travel with us are underway, conversations with the realtor and our bank are in full swing, and packing has begun. Â All very early stages, but started in earnest.And let me say this now ... it is exhausting and at times overwhelming. We should have done this years ago, but years ago I was exhausted and overwhelmed with caregiving. Â The timing was never right for a move. So I plan to take you with me during this 'adventure' (nightmare.) Hold onto your hats!In closing - a personal observation about aging as it relates to change and big decisions (and this move is a big decision.)I learned through practical experience how the aging brain handles change. Â Not well! Â It looks very much like ... nothing. Â No movement, no change to upset the status quo. Â There is comfort and security in the known. Â Lack of action makes a weird sense as time marks your body and mind. Â Looking to conquer even small challenges is not on your radar.In early senior years the brain may continue to function well, but it is easy to slip into faulty thinking about the future. Â  "I don't need to change anything. Â Yes, this  isn't ideal but I can handle it now, and yes, I should be able to handle it for years to come." Â And in a small percentage of the population that may be true. Â But can you be sure you are in the small percentage. Â Hard to know.I have seen the initial stages of faulty thinking in myself this year. Â Last year I was 100% in favor of selling the townhouse and moving. Â I saw the writing on the wall of our lives. Â It was all plain as it could be. Â  We need to move. Â I was 68 last year.This year I am 69 and the tiny web of resistance to change crept in. Â Again I started to push for a move. Â My husband started to see the logic of it, but I began to second guess myself. Â There were days when I wondered is this the right thing to do. Â After all, we are handling it now, how terrible would it be if we didn't change anything, yes, I know all these steps are not ideal for my disabled husband, but he has fallenÂ onlyÂ once on them. Â We are doing just fine now.See what I mean?Next year I am 70Â and who knows what I will be able to talk myself into not doing.The early stages ... the clock is ticking!More to come.

title: Why blog ...
text: Oh my! Â My last post was in January - expounding on the reaching the mid-winter point! Â Here we are in April and not a word written in-between. Yes, I still live! Â And shocking (to my mind), I have received a few inquiries ... where are you, are you returning to blog land?One of my blog friends, Paula, posted an interesting piece on March 5th called Where did they go?Â  She lamented about folks who stopped posting to their blog for 8 or 10 months, some as long as a year ... some never to return. Â She missed the sharing of life experiences and wondered why they stopped. Â That post sparked my thinking on those of us to disappear from blogging - for a time or forever.I guess it all comes down to why a person blogs in the first place. Â I think we blog writers fall into 2 camps of people:those who write for themselves (they don't need an audience, they just need to get ideas out somewhere and the blog is a good place to plant them.)those who write for others (they write to educate, to sell, to explore ideas others, to generate conversation, to share a talent or hobby.)Some bloggers might say they slop over into both categories, but I fall entirely in the first category. Â I write for me. Â The need to write comes and goes as life changes. Â I believe the first category is where most "drop outs" can be found because the "need" to blog wanes. Â Life changes.For myself, it all started as a way to cope with my intense caregiving experience. Â Eight years is a long time to step out of your normal life and give that energy to someone else. Â My blog was a coping tool. Â It was at times a life saver.After mom died, that coping mechanism seems less needed. Â Moving on and sorting out how my life was now as well as adjusting to my own aging issues seemed uninteresting to write about. Â Hence the periodic absences.Well, I am back again. Â For how long I do not know.But I will tell you ... it hasn't been boring here in my corner of blog land.More on that to follow!

title: Half Way
text: We are nearing the end of January - and in my mind - we are reaching the half way point in winter 2016.And what a winter it has been. I live in the Maryland - and this past weekend we had the worst winter snow storm in the history of the state - in my county we had 32 inches of snow over 2 1/2 days. Â Crazy crazy weather, because just one month ago in December it was so warm I briefly thought of turning on the air-conditioning. We had days of warnings and predictions. Â The reaction was also predictable. Â HUGE runs on the food stores were reported. Â Empty shelves, store staff struggling to keep up with the restocking and one story told of a person selling a loaf of bread on Facebook for $10. Â  Good grief. Â You really only need enough food for your typical week - sometimes less. Â But panic in this area hits even when one or two inches of snow are predicted. Â When 2 feet are predicted, the mob reaction is breathtaking. Â And then the storm arrives and you are trapped in your house. Â We had strong winds, thunder, and very very cold temperatures to accompany all the feet of snow that got dumped on us. Â I always think I am going to get soooo much done while nature does it's worst. Â I will cook up a huge feast, I will knit tons of things, I will read several books and I will cuddle up on the couch with a dog. Â I did cuddle with a dog wrapped in a blanket, but mostly I watched the storm rage outside - except for when I was out in it shoveling. Â My grand dog has short legs. Â Three feet of snow would be impossible for him. Â So many many trips with the shovel were made so that I could manage the snow accumulation in smaller bites. Â I also made sure the birds were fed on my back deck. Â Food is what keeps them warm during these severe conditions. Â And I watched a lot of TV. Â The storm coverage was constant. Â Images of stupid people who just had to get out in the storm - stuck in their totally ill equipped vehicle were common. Â Really, those folks should be fined for obstructing roadways. Â If they had to be somewhere due to the nature of their jobs, Â they should arrive before the storm and plan to stay over. I survived the "snow-ma-geddin" of 2016! Â And we didn't lose power - thankfully. Â Today it was bright and sunny. Â I am still shoveling, of course. Â It will be another day before things are mostly normal. We are half way through winter and I am keeping my fingers crossed that Mother Nature has expended all her energy on this storm. Â Please, let the rest of winter pass peacefully. Â My back isn't as young as it used to be.Any big weather in your area?

title: God's Plan for Aging
text: With the popularity of Facebook now-a-days, I rarely get fun stuff circulated in my email as I used to. Â That actually is a good thing. But today a friend forwarded this piece of 'wisdom' to me - it is worthy of sharing. Â I would love to give credit to the one who wrote it originally, but that information seldom follows with the text. Since my theme this year is 'Move', it seemed somewhat appropriate - except I plan to 'move' far more than this piece implies!Enjoy!God's Plan For Aging.Most seniors never get enough exercise. Â In His wisdom God decreed that seniors become forgetful so the would have to search for their glasses, keys and other things thus doing more walking. Â And God looked down and saw that it was good.Then God considered the function of bladders and decided seniors would have additional calls of nature requiring more trips to the bathroom, thus providing more exercise. Â God looked down and saw that it was good.So if you find as you age, you are getting up and down more, remember it's God's will. Â It is all in your best interest even though you mutter under your breath.Nine Important Facts to remember as we Grow OlderÂ (my personal favorite is #6)Death is the number 1 killer in the world.Life is sexually transmitted.Good health is merely the slowest possible rate at which one can die.Men have 2 motivations: hunger and hanky panky, and they can't tell them apart. Â If you see a gleam in his eyes, make him a sandwich.Give a person a fish and you feed them for a day. Â Teach a person to use the Internet and they won't bother you for weeks, months, maybe years.Health nuts are going to feel stupid someday, lying in the hospital, dying of nothing.All of us could take a lesson from the weather. Â It pays no attention to criticism.In the 60's people took acid to make the world weird. Â Now the world is weird, and people take Prozac to make it normal.Life is like a jar of jalapeÃ±o peppers. Â What you do today may be a burning issue tomorrow.Don't ignore this message. Â This is your only warning.Happy Thursday to you all!!

title: A Word!
text: A common practice in blog-landÂ (and other places I discovered) is to pick a single word to describe the intent or focus for the coming year. I have enjoyed reading some of these posts and recognized some repeating themes - especially if you have watched from the side lines for years like I have done. Â Some popular ideas are Peace, Simplicity, Nourish, Downsize, Joy, Family, Organize, Love, and Happiness.Did I ever pick a "word" for myself? Â Never. Â I always thought it was a good idea, but I never seemed to have the energy to sum up my life for a year into a simple single thought - and keep that as my focus.But as I look back over the last decade - one word does seem to pop into my mind without any effort now. Â It is more of an after thought, but very true. Survive.Funny, in all the years I watched others select a word for their coming year, never once did I read 'survive' as a word for the future. Â I guess 'survive' mostly becomes evident after you do it. Â And I did do it. Â I survived a long caregiving experience despite some pretty significant set backs that had nothing to do with mom. Â Sometimes you just don't know what you are capable of doing (and surviving) until you get through it.But what about 2016!You know ... I am thinking this is the year I just might pick a word. Â When I started thinking about it around the New Year I bounced around all the typical words I had heard before. Â Who doesn't want 'peace' in their lives? Â And God knows, I have strived for 'simplicity' and 'downsize' for two years! Â I am big on 'family.' Â Family and eldercare ... well, that is like putting your money where your mouth is. Â On and on, my brain rolled those words around and around. Â Nothing seemed to fit this coming year.Then it came to me. Â I have a word. Â It fits perfectly with my current focus. I am 68 and I feel the weight of my accumulating years as well as the impact of past emotional stress. Â I know that action always makes me feel better - even though I struggle with consistency in exercise. Â My word should be an action word. Â 'Action' seems to slip out of the vocabulary of many older adults. Â And from what I have seen, 'sedentary' is a killer.My 2016 word is:MOVEAll righty! Â Got the word. Â Now let's see just where it goes! Â Or rather, just where I go!Do you have a word for 2016?I'd love to hear it if you do.

title: Get Reading - A 2016 Challenge
text: I have been a member of Good Reads for many years, but never an active participant. Â I would visit the web site, look around, occasionally get some ideas about books, once in awhile I would update my reading list. Â  Really ... not much of a 'member' ... more of a window shopper!This year I decided to get more engaged - more engaged with everything - and I decided to join the 2016 Book Reading Challenge. Â To join this challenge you pick a goal of how many books you will read in 2016. Â The books are logged on the Good Reads web site and you can track your progress. Â I added a tracking device to my blog on the right. Â I picked 26 books - or a little over 2 books a month - which I felt was reasonable goal. I sincerely had no clue how many books was a reasonable number for me. Â I frequently read or listen to books. Â Listen more than read. Â A few years ago I got a Kindle Paper White - and my actual reading dramatically increased, but still listening outranks reading. Â I can listen to books while doing many other things. Â But I never tracked how many books were completed.This year will be different. Â And shockingly - today, January 9 - I have already finished 3 books. Â I have two others in the works. Â I suspect my guess-timate of how many books was reasonable is way way off.But I won't be changing my first estimate. Â I will stick with 26 books for 2016 and see just how far off I am. Â If I had to guess what my final total will be ... (you know, just between you and me - and not Good Reads), I will probably complete about 100 books this year.It will be fun to look back and see what the total actually turns out to be.Are you on Good Reads?Â Â Are you doing a reading challenge this year?Â Â If so, what is your goal for 2016?

title: New Floors and curtains!!
text: Love it! Â The wood floors are in, the kitchen and bathroom even have tile floors, curtains on the windows, and cutest of all (you have to look closely,) in the Master Bedroom on the second floor (right), there is a Pug on the floor near the foot of the bed. Looks like more the the miniature accessories have been added as well. Â I will have to take some close up pictures to show off the details. Â Wonderful. Â Great job, dear daughter!!

title: Doll House in Development
text: A farm style house with a turn of the century interior.(Turn of the last century!)When my daughter was 12 she wanted a doll house.The front porch. Â There are steps that lead off the porch to be added.Not a toy version, but an actual adult-style doll house.Â Â I say "adult-style," because these kinds of doll houses are really aimed at adultsÂ due to expense and the delicate nature of the accessories.Â I love looking in the window as if it was a real home - seeing the furniture and the lights.We purchased a fully assembled doll house - not finished or decorated.Â Â This house was unfinished brown wood inside and out the day we carried it out of the toy store.Â Â You can buy these structures as kits - all in pieces with assembly instructions.Â Â I knew our assembly skills were lacking - just not our thing. Â Better to pay extra to purchase an assembled house than to have pieces laying about for years.Â Adding lights really contributes to the charm of the house.Â  Many gift giving occasions focused on doll house furniture and accessories.Â Â My mother-in-law and I joyfully shared my daughter's enthusiasmÂ by purchasing items at other times as well. Â The living room.I wired the house for electric. Â We painted the rooms and added some wall paper. Â It was basic even then. Â But creating a doll house is a long term commitment - a hobby. Â We knew it would take time.The daughter's roomBut as with many childhood activities, my daughter's interest in the doll house faded as she grew through her teen years. Â I kept the house, but dismantled it. Â I packed away all the little pieces for a future time. Â I loved it enough to become the caretaker. Bathroom - with old style toilette in the foreground.About 10 years ago while my daughter was spending time at our house, she started to take an interest in the doll house. Â She finished off the exterior by adding siding. Â She repainted the roof tiles. Â She added a few little interior pieces. Â But her life got busy again and the doll house sat idle again.The foyer.I continued to keep it. Â Maybe I would do something with it once I retired. Â But my retirement years were filled with care giving. Â No time or energy left for a doll house. Â It remained in storage.The kitchen.There was never any though of getting rid of it. Â The house was just in hibernation.This old time stove was a fairly expensive piece when we bought it in the late 1980s.But we all fell in love with it. Â The various drawers open. Â We even have copper pans for it.Last year during a major town house clean out, Â I asked my daughter if she wanted her doll house.Â Â I would still keep it if she didn't want it.Â Â She did want it and her brother moved it to her condo in his vehicleÂ because it is too big for a standard size car.The den. Â The desk is a roll top desk. Â The top actually closes.Since taking on full ownership, she has made many improvements.Â Â She has rewired the electric, repainted, wall papered,Â and replaced a few small pieces of furniture that did not survive 25 years in storage.Attic boy's room.The blanket on the bed was made by my mother-in-law who died in 1997.The crocheting and yarn are not totally to scale for the furniture,but the item is priceless because it was made with love.It is a work in progress.Â Â The pictures are missing many of the smaller items like dishes, the resident family,Â some pets, and household decorations - final refinements that can be added towards the end.Many of those items we already have.Â She has ordered new flooring and curtains.Â At some point rugs need to be ordered.Â And I wish my phone did a better job of handling the lighting.Â The sewing and spinning room.This room needs some skeins of yarn!! Â I am glad the doll house is now with its rightful owner - being improved and valued - andÂ for now it is adding a lovely interior decoration to her condo. Â And someday this lovely house may be handed down to another family member to love and enjoy.A charming little spinning wheel.Note: Â Updated pictures will be shared once the other major improvements are completed.Finally a light picture that is reasonable.Master BedroomCeiling Light

title: Start the New Year Right!!
text: I am starting the New Year right.Â Meet my adorable grand dogs who fill so many of my retired hours.Grimace - my senior guy.Grimace inherited the role of "King" and elder statesman ofour canines after Meathead died. Â Grimace never wanted to be King, butwe all have to do things we don't want to do sometimes.Dear, dear Grimace is my heart and soul. Â All dogs have their unique inherited qualities. Â Pugs are known most for being companion animals. Â They are happy, cheerful, devoted, and, well ... stalkers. Â I use the word "stalkers" in the most loving way.
