Â Our bills have gone down. Â But even with those changes, we still seem to have too much food in the house. Â I am working to correct that.Sadly that grocery example has played out in other purchases as well. Â  I am hoping this is all in the past.Apparently decluttering has done more than just injuring my lower back. Â  My "want/need" level regarding items has been significantly lowered. Â Â It is like my shopping DNA has been chemically altered. Â Nuts! Â I wish this had happened many years ago. Â Just think of how rich I would be now if I hadn't spent all that money shopping.So how do you shop?Is it for need or want?Is it for amusement?Are you an internet shopperÂ or do you prefer "brick and mortar stores?"Â Personal Disclaimers (or the devil is in the details): Â :-)My hobby stuff is exempt from this whole discussion. Â :-) My old shopping self is still very much alive in my hobbies. Â Baby steps, baby steps Â ...I value the brick and mortar store as a necessary part of our economy - I do support several despite my aversion to shopping in them.Clothing and food for me are best made in a brick and mortar store.

title: Paying the Price
text: The last two months have certainly been strenuous and busy with "house stuff." Â Sorting, packing, lifting, discarding, and generally shedding the stuff of decades sapped a lot of energy. Â Each day I Â worked for a fixed amount of time, then focused on routine stuff like laundry and cooking, and then collapsed for a rest. Â Before bed I enjoyed an hour or so of downtime - knitting, NetFlix, reading. Â I thought it was a pretty balanced approach.But the "personal stuff" that helped to maintain my physical wellbeing was lacking.I promised myself that once the lion's share of house stuff was done I would get back to personal stuff like walking daily, strength/stretching, and watching my diet. Frequent conversations with myself argued that 10 years ago I could have done both - house stuff and personal stuff - at the same time. Â But I have accepted the fact that now splitting my focus results in nothing getting done very well. Â  Probably a subtle age related phenomenon. Â *Sigh*.So the lion's share of the house stuff is done ... but I am now paying the price for ignoring the personal stuff.Sunday morning I woke up with a back spasm. Â No brainer - too much lifting and carrying. Â  It was my back's way of stating the obvious ... "See, you are not in your 30s - not even close - and if you do stupid stuff, I will be sure you pay the price." Â Thank you, Mr. Back. Â I got the message! But carry on is what I chose to do (apparently I got the message but didn't learn the lesson.)Monday - I tried to go for a walk but within 25 feet of my front door I turned around and came back. Â Advil, muscle relaxants and rest were pretty much the activities of that day.Tuesday - Walked down the street very slowly for about 250 feet - had one back spasm that buckled my right knee. Â I returned to the house even slower. Â Repeat Monday activities.Today - Better. Â Walked slowly around the block. Â No spasms but my back is sore and it reminded me to keep my pace slow. Â  I stopped frequently to shake out stiffness in my hips and thighs. Â Hard to know if that was due to lack of regular exercise or if it was a guarding action of surrounding muscles to the lower back injury. Â A little of both I guess. Â During those stops I enjoyed the view - and took some pictures.But I am encourage. Â Progress.It is, however, appalling just how quickly you can lose physical strength and stamina after the age of 60.Tomorrow?? Â More of the same - need to get my daily step totals up to 10,000 a day like I did for so many months before.

title: A breather
text: I think I am ready for a brief breather.It has been interesting discovering, touching, re-purposing, deciding, repacking, moving, discarding, displaying, and/or gifting all our belongings. Â Small untouched pockets of stuff still remain - a small storage closet in the basement, the linen closet, my kitchen cabinets. Â But the lion's share is done for now.A Good Will bag stands at the ready in the kitchen - already full again - but the stuff-movement has reduced to a trickle. The painting is done - and the rooms are mostly back to normal. Â The kitchen renovation is contracted Â probably for August.The yard guy arrived this week. Â Our front and back yard should be brought under control soon.However ...After all is said and done ... and the house looks the best it has looked in many years - we decided to stay - and not sell - at least for this year. Â Part of me is very relieved. Â To sell this house I love ... and to face further upheaval - it is not a pleasant prospect after everything we have done. Â And my husband, while he supported the idea and the need for a move, he seems relieved too. Â But the reason for a change of residence is still a reality. Â Each day I wonder how long we have until a fall by my husband makes our choice to stay a foolish one. Â So the topic is not closed - just deferred.On the joyful side of this discussion ... the main de-clutter goal has been achieved. Â Minor improvements towards downsizing will continue. Â It has finally become manageable.Now the real work remains - maintaining!But first ... a breather!

title: Lesson Learned #5 - Attachments
text: I've spent many precious life hours over the last 10 years moving stuff out of my house. Â In the last year, the highway of departing clutter has become an absolute speedway. Â Here is a lesson I have learned in the process.Lesson Learned #5LastlyAttachments to stuff - does it love you back?I get attached to things.I attach to people and animals as well, but I have a history of loving things ... attaching to them like they have feelings. Â Once you start attaching to things, there is a slippery slope you must manage.Here is my slippery slope.Like most people, Â I save bits and pieces of things that hold memories for me. Â Children's art work, old school papers, a first communion veil, the small worry-stone my son gave me on entering the military, a beautiful greeting card from my daughter with cherished sentiments - just to name a few. Â I am fairly successful at managing stuff in this category. Â For example, I finally discarded my 56 year old girl scout sash with achievement badges last week. Â I wasn't a scout for long, and it wasn't a special time. To this day, "camping" or roughing it for me is staying at a Days Inn. Â :-) Â The sash went out the door las week. Â The stuff I own in this category is down to a reasonable quantity.Managing attachments in other areas of my life result in limited success.I give cars names. Â My last car was a Maxima. Â Her name was Maxie. Â I was in tears when I traded her in. Â Maxie and I were buds for 10 years. Â We got through a lot of bad weather together, but her high-heeled attitude made her designed for speed. Â  She had a passion for it (notice I didn't say I had a passion for speed - just Maxie!) Â At her 10th birthday when she started to burn oil, our trusted mechanic of 35 years could not find the problem. Â A fix would have been hard and very expensive. My new car is a Subaru. It (not she, not he) handles the road great in all weather. Â It is reliable. Â It is transportation. Â It does not have a name. Â I learned my lesson with Maxie. Â And more importantly, I believe the Subaru doesn't care one little bit. Â :-)I have a tough time I throwing away pictures. Â I am sad when I see old family albums abandoned in thrift or antique shops. Â I have many old family albums myself and boxes of pictures, many are duplicates. I also have old family documents - birth and death certificates, military papers, baptismal documents, certificates of achievement, an old driver's license from the 1930s. Not sure what I will do with all of that - right now they are all in one closet. Â But these images are staring at me from the end of the long de-cluttering road. Â They know I have a soft spot for family history. Â They are keeping their collective fingers crossed that they will make the next de-clutter cut in a few weeks. Â We shall see.The attachment to my townhouse is strong. Â Although I yearn for a smaller place - one with less steps, less extra costs, less upkeep, this home holds all my memories of the last 30 years. Â I have lived here longer than anywhere else. Â I raised children here. Â My mother-in-law died of cancer in my living room. Â I remember my son stepping out my front door to enter the military and coming in that same door when he returned. Â My daughter recovered here from one of life's black clouds. Â My husband stood in the kitchen and told me he would one day go blind. Â The house has seen parties for birthdays, anniversaries, weddings. Â My mother lived here for 5 years and I watched her decline here. I cried at my kitchen sink the day I knew she would need to move to assisted living. Â There were joy filled Christmases - and a few sad ones too, like last Christmas when mom died. Â  This house is tattooed with my life. Â I can't imagine letting another family put their marks on it. Â And yet ...How do you avoid attachments to an inanimate building when it feels like more than that? Â I will continue to live in and nurture this house for now - and deal with the fall out that will inevitably come later.The topic of minimalism is cluttered with the principles of letting go and living small. Â  Â But minimalism discussions sometimes miss the point that stuff can make your life "more." Â Yes, less is more, but sometimes things are also more.I think the trick is to pick and choose carefully! Â And if you pick and chooseÂ everything,Â then that is when problems start.Keep only what you love ... and what loves you back.I believe my house loves me back!

title: Lesson Learned #4 - Stress and Stuff
text: I've spent many precious life hours over the last 10 years moving stuff out of my house. Â In the last year, the highway of departing clutter has become an absolute speedway. Â Here is a lesson I have learned in the process.Lesson Learned #4Less stuff equals less stress ... at least for me.For myself, I truly believe less stuff equals less stress.But this may not be true for everyone. Â  I know folks who take comfort in being surrounded by all their many belongings. Â In fact it is said that very creative people are usually surrounded by lots of disorganization, and they seem to function just fine. Â I worked for a woman who hired me specifically because I was an organization greek. Â She wanted me to organize her. Â I discovered that although her office was crazy with clutter, she could easily put her hand on any item I could name. Â Once she realized that her methods worked fine for her ... and my methods worked fine for me ... we got along famously!! Accepting each others differences made us a great team.But an over abundance of stuff can have a very different outcome.At the far end of the "stuff" spectrum is a popular show called The Hoarders. Â It always made me a little sad to see these folks who allowed things to overtake their lives so completely. Â Their stuff did not make them happy. Â They were miserable. Â I stopped watching when the show spilled into examples of animal hoarding layered on top of stuff hoarding. Â Animals who had died in the house and the owners did not know because the stuff was so mountainous. Â Cats who had litters of sick or dead kittens and the owners had no clue. Â Sad was one thing. Â Disturbing was something else. Â  I stopped watching.I have never been near the level of clutter as the TV Hoarders. Â But this week I was face-to-face with my own personally created clutter monster who was hiding in my yarn room. For newer readers, a little bulleted background on me can demonstrate the problem.I am a knitter.I am a rigid heddle weaver.I am a sometimes fiber spinner.Crafters like me usually have stashes of craft related stuff. Â I have a massiveÂ large medium small-ish to medium (???) Â hoardÂ stashÂ collection selection of knitting yarns, weaving yarns, fiber for making yarns, books, knitting needles, binders of individual patterns, kits (knitting and weaving), many looms, many spinning spindles, and a full size spinning wheel. Â (OK, "massive hoard" fits - just don't tell my husband.)My hobby once was housed in a small basement closet. Â Then it was moved to a small room with closet (we call the den.) Â Now it is contained in a moderate size bedroom (we now call "the yarn room") with 2 closets that once belonged to my mom. Â I sort of maybe have my eye on largest room - our master bedroom. Â I wonder if my husband would notice ... oh forget I said anything.I consider my yarn room to be a luxury and a joy.I LOVE LOVE LOVE my hobby. Â I think that sets the stage for you.In preparation for painting the yarn room I had to MOVE . ALL . THE . LOVED . STUFF out of the closets and into the center of the floor so the closets could be painted. It took me a whole day. Â It filled the center of the room and was stack about 4-5 feet high. Â After I finished, I stood back and surveyed the stash. Â It did not fill me with joy. Â I was agitated. Â I was discourage. Â How could I allowed something I cherished to fall into the "too much stuff" category.I have already started the process of thinning the stash. Â There are no ugly items in the room. Â But the stash does fall into two categories: Â like and love. Â The likes are finding their way to new homes where they will be loved. Â And I am happy to make space for my loved items. And what is true for my yarn room has been true for the rest of my house. Â Space is good. Â Less is good. Less stuff is less stress - even if it is yarn.

title: Lesson Learned #3 - Over stuffed?
text: I've spent many precious life hours over the last 10 years moving stuff out of my house. Â In the last year, the highway of departing clutter has become an absolute speedway. Â Here is a lesson I have learned in the process.Lesson Learned #3:Live with less stuff than your house can hold.I have never been a big proponent of Rental Storage Units. This lesson has not been learned from actual experience - just common sense.Yes, these rental storage units serve a short list of purposes. Â Temporary storage of household goods between moves or inventory storage for small businesses are two examples that quickly come to mind. Â I bet you could suggest a few other good uses as well.But too often families use these units for years to store household items they cannot contain in their home. Â Apparently the need for external storage is a growing trend because the sprouting of "You Store It" buildings continues to grow. Â If there wasn't a demand for this kind of storage, the buildings of this type wouldn't be built.It boggles my mind that folks pay money for these units every month for years to store personal stuff - stuff they don't use and probably don't remember they have. Â It is an over-stuffed life for sure.I also scratch my head when I drive by a house with cars that are always parked outside of full garages. Now I am not talking about garages that function extensions of living space - like a place for large exercise equipment or an expansive tool collection with workbenches ... those changes make sense. Â People actually use this space. Â  But folks who leave vehicles ($$$) outside and use their garage as storage for old bikes, boxes of broken and/or discarded toys, old unused refrigerators, old unused kitchen cabinets, party decorations from last New Years, an old kitchen chair with the broken leg, trash, and the like ... Â so that there is no room for their cars - well, the garage is protecting the wrong stuff. We have never had a garage or a storage unit. Â But about 5 years ago we were floating in a sea of our stuff, my mom's stuff, other inherited stuff and there wasn't one space that was open. Â My husband causally suggested that maybe we should rent a storage unit for a while - just to give us some breathing room. Imagine ... paying for breathing room.We did not get that storage unit. Â What I did do was reorganize stuff and buy more things like containers to snuggly store our stuff into our current space, giving us the sense of breathing room. Â Not actual breathing room, you understand! Â Just the appearance of breathing room.Ha!

title: Lesson Learned #2 - Stuff and your heart
text: I've spent many precious life hours over the last 10 years moving stuff out of my house. Â In the last year, the highway of departing clutter has become an absolute speedway. Â Here is a lesson I have learned in the process.Lesson Learned #2Keep the stuff that speak to your heart.My mother was raised in a family where a Hope Chest was part of her preparation for marriage. Â Knowing some of my mom's history, that hope chest probably represents a happy time for her - a time when she was preparing for marriage to my father. Â Little could she guess that happiness with my father would be in short supply. Â Although my dad was a charming, handsome and loving man, he was also sick with alcoholism, and when under its influence, he was none of those things. Â He died in 1970 and I have many bad memories of him, but I also have many wonderful ones. Â The fact that this balance still exists so clearly in my mind ... and I still love him ... is tribute to the wonderful man he was while sober.But mom's cedar hope chest was "born" at a time prior to that marriage. Â In my mind and heart her chest represents the beautiful and smart young woman she was then - with dreams of happiness and familyÂ During my clean out, I unearthed mom's cedar chest in her former bedroom closet. Â It had been buried Â under all her stuff while she lived in my home, and under all my yarn after she moved into Assisted Living. Â I knew this chest needed to be out where I could enjoy it and use it.As you can see, it has wear - and some damage - but plenty of beauty. Â I feel in my heart this chest mirrors how my mom's life turned out. Â Much wear, some damage, total beauty. Because I miss my mom every single day, I want her chest to be part of my everyday life - to help me remember what a wonderfully strong and caring woman she was, how her life started out with hope, and the tarnish of her marriage didn't destroy the underlying strength of who she was.Her chest is now open to the air and loved again but this time by her daughter. In this marathon event of seeking to have less but enjoy what remains more ... questions remain.Do I need a chest? Â No.Is need and function the only qualities to consider when de-cluttering your life? Â No.Will I use and love this piece of furniture all the days of my life? Â Yes.It stays.

title: Lesson Learned #1 - Good Stuff Bad Stuff
text: I've spent many precious life hours over the last 10 years moving stuff out of my house. Â In the last year, the highway of departing clutter has become an absolute speedway. Â Here is a lesson I have learned in the process.Lesson Learned #1Not all stuff is bad stuff!While reading about minimal life styles and the joys of "less is more," you can get swept up by the hype. Â Some self identified simplification gurus put a high premium on getting your possessions down to the bare minimum ... being able to contain all your belongings is your car ... or the joys of brushing your teeth with soap ... or having empty surfaces and shelves throughout your living space.I have a much more middle-of-the-road picture of minimalism..I have had a decent life where disposable income was the norm. Â My husband and I had a broad range of interests and hobbies. Â We enjoyed collecting stuff around those pursuits. Â In some regards, we still do.But over time we packed away many of our passions. Â Sometimes we no longer enjoyed the ownership of an item, but it wasn't junk so we just boxed it up and forgot about it. Â Usually we didn't have space to display everything that 45 years of marriage could produce. Â Or our tastes changed and our interests evolved. Â On we moved to the next endeavor. Â Do you recognize yourself anywhere in that description?One remarkable side benefit of diving deep into your stored belongings is a discovery of a long forgotten treasure that you forgot you owned.This chess set is one such item.My husband collected chess sets. Â We must have 15 of them. Â This was not a cheap hobby. Â Most of the sets we purchased were several hundred dollars. Â But over time we packed them away. This beautiful hand carved and painted Camelot Chess set was created by a wood carver called Whittle Works. Â Holy Cow! Â These figures haven't seen the light of day in probably 15 years.Gosh! Â I still love these!! Â Why the heck aren't they out where I can enjoy them? Well, they are now out. Â I will tell you why they weren't out. Â The set was "out of sight out of mind" in a box buried deeply behind a bunch of bad stuff I didn't care one twit about and now does not live here anymore. Some minimalist minded folks would question keeping this chess set. Â They would ask:Have you touched this item in the last year? Â No. Â Not touched or seen in the last 15 years.Do you enjoy playing chess? Â No. Â I am an embarrassingly bad player.Will you play chess with it in the future? Â No. Â Not my game. Â I prefer Checkers.Do you find beauty or get enjoyment out of this set? Â Yes! Â End of Story.So, there you go. Â The chess set stays. Â The bad stuff goes.

title: Miss Minimalist
text: As a blogger, it should be no surprise that I follow a few other bloggers. Â And lately I have reduced my blog list considerably. Â In fact, I have stopped using my on line blog catcher and just subscribe to blogs using the email option. Keeping the lists of subscribed blogs small has been part of my "smaller is better," "less is more" change of heart over the last few years. Â One blog has been helpful in inspiring me in this direction. Miss MinimalistLiving a beautiful life with less stuffThis blogger and the book she wrote on this subject have been featured in many well known news vehicles such as CNN, BBC, NBC Today, Forbes ... just to name a few. Â Certainly there are a large number of excellent web resources on simplifying and minimalism, but Miss Minimalist seems closest to my own middle-of-the-road mindset on the subject.There is one feature I really enjoy. Â Each Monday she posts a piece contributed by various followers about their journey to reducing stuff and adopting minimalism. Â I love reading about others and the paths they chose for their lives - even if I wouldn't necessarily follow in all their foot steps. Â It is amazing how many ways you can approach the minimalist life style.Today I noticed her post was about moving from one residence to another with a minimalist mindset. Â How timely! Â We have been contemplating the wisdom of making a move to a smaller more senior friendly place the last few months. Â That decision is still a big question mark for us.However, as I am cleaning out my own abode - I kept these thoughts in the back of my mind ...Have I used this item in the last year?Would I keep this item if I were moving next week?Would I pay money to pack, transport, and unpack this item? Â Would this item be worth the time to wrap and box up ... and unbox and use in a new home? Â If the answer was "no" to any of these questions ... why would I bother keeping it now? Â I have my hands on this item right now. Â Does it make sense to keep it and face this decision again at a time when I am actually moving? Â Why table this action to discard an item to a time when the stress of an actual move would weigh me down with all the stuff I kept today? And even if I don't move ever again, is it fair to leave this task to the loved ones I leave behind?I will say that going through this downsizing process has been exhausting. Â I typically spend about 3 or 4 hours a day working through our possessions, touching and deciding the fate of each item, and then I am just too tired to continue. Â I don't make good decisions when I am too tired. Â After about 4 weeks of working through this, I am glad I have the luxury to spread it out over time and do it right. Â I am very glad I am not facing a pending move with the deadline of a mover's truck at the end of the line. Â Now there is a nightmare in the making.If you are going through a similar stage in life - desiring "less is more" - then check out the blog Miss Minimalism. Â Take the time to window shop through her site. Â Pick and choose the topics that interest you. Â See if it doesn't crystalize your thoughts about stuff ... and how you want to live with yours.I am currently reading her book, The Joy of Less. Â I have found that books on simplification and Â minimalism run "hit or miss." Â Sometimes it is just a rehash of what you logically already know or what you have read a bunch of times elsewhere. Â And to be fair, learning to live more minimally only happens if you can consistently take the actions to make it so. Â There is no substitute for changing behavior. Â Just reading about it - isn't enough. Â These are hard lessons I struggle with regularly. Â I will say, however, this book is highly rated on Amazon and so far I would agree with those ratings. Â I will report back when I finish the book.

title: Dust of Ages ... and ages ... and ages ...
text: Dear Blog Friends,Just when I think I'm done with blogging, I get another push to write and bore you to death with all my life "adventures." Â Hopefully you aren't bored to actual death, as that reduces the number of readers significantly. Â And I will admit that "adventures" is a stretch for my life right now. Since visiting with you last I have not been idle. Â In fact, I have been busy to the point of exhaustion as of late. Over the last 8 years, my caregiver focus has been almost totally aimed at my mom. Â After her passing in December, it took awhile to get my "sea legs" back. Â As the list of mom related to-dos dwindled, I had trouble focusing that "caregiver laser-beam" on anything else. Â I was adrift. Â I felt like a gang leader without a gang! (Can you tell I have been watching the violent TV series Sons of Anarchy?Â Â ... which by the way is pretty great! Â Sort of like The God Father, but not.)In the last month a major shift of energies and focus blossomed out of me. Â  Hmm ... Â I guess it was more of an volcanic eruption, than the blossoming.I finally focused my "laser-beam" around my own house and decided Â - Not . Good . Enough .Too much stuff.Too much furniture.Some areas not painted in over 20 years.Some possessions not touched about 10 years.Some possessions overdue a transition to the dump, or Good Will, or to another home.Some repairs and renovations ignored or lived around for way to long.Some items not even mine, for gosh sake. Â It is stifling.It weighs me down.Not . How . I . Want . To . Live!!We did some stuff last summer - hardwood flooring and some painting ... but real issues still remained. Â So I pulled up my big girl panties and put on rubber gloves - and attacked the real issues of my home head on. Â The GoalI want to live lighter ... with less stuff ... with only the things that I love.Â I want space around me and around the things that I love.Like a ball and chain,I don't want to drag along possessions on the assumption that maybe, possibly,Â I might need them at some indefinable point in the future.I want to adopt the life style attitude now of "less is more." Â When it is time to move to a smaller more senior friendly environment,I want to be ready.Â  And when my time on this earth is done,Â I don't want my kids to left with a house full of dusty junk to manage and/or discard.Now I am on a first name basis with the dump guy, a healthy contributor to our local Good Will organization, and many worthy former belongings are now loved by others in their houses. Â  Summed up at least 40% of our stuff-occupants no longer reside in this house. Â We . Have . Breathing . Room!!And the odyssey is not over yet. Â In the near-future ...Some cocky "stuff-occupants" that made the first cut this go-round, won't be living here come the New Year. Â As my husband noted just this morning ... "It is amazing but despite the mountain of stuff we have moved out of the house, we STILL have a lot of stuff." Â  Â Not for long, Kemosabe. Not for long!Our kitchen will get a major face lift this summer.Oh ... and there is less dust as well.

title: My Boys
text: Here is a picture of my boys, the cats that share our house with my husband and I.As you can see, they are brothers. Â In fact, in the dark sometimes it is hard to tell them apart. Â Wally is in the front, and he is pretty much my cat. Â Max is behind and he has bonded with my husband. Â Max is also the cat who has had degenerative kidney disease (since the age of 3) and we have been giving him subq fluids to combat that condition for 6 years - every other day - and will continue to do so for the rest of his life. Â It is what keeps him alive. Â  What is remarkable about this picture is the following:They are both sitting on the couch with me. Â They seldom do that - mostly because our house is usually occupied with 1 to 3 dogs. Â When the guest dogs are in residence, our cat-boys pretty much stick to the upstairs. Â They do make occasional appearances on the first floor, but never so relaxed.They are sitting side-by-side - almost touching. Â When we got this pair, we were looking for a bonded pair. Â Our last set of cats had decided to dislike each other and it was an armed camp for several years. Â Once burned, we did not want to live like that again. Â We wanted the next set of cats to already get along. Â We figured brothers who were already friends would work. Â And it does, usually. Â They play together, they don't fight with each other, but they don't sleep together or groom each other as truly bonded animals sometimes do. Â No matter, sometime they "accidentally" find themselves sitting together ... making it worth the picture!!I love these two gentle souls. Â They are pretty adaptable having lived around dogs all their lives. Â It is nice spending time with them alone - without the competition of the 3 grand dogs who think they own the place!! Â It is because of my desire to honor their rights to our bed and our bedroom, that when the dogs come to visit, I do not sleep in my bed. Â I sleep on the pull out couch or in the guest room in the basement with the canines. Â Â Sometimes I miss my bed, but for these sweet feline faces, I am happy to sleep elsewhere so they can rest comfortably on the second floor when the canine invasion is raging!!Â After all, these boys are mine and this is their home, and the grand dogs are visitors and are borrowed!

title: Insanity is ...
text: "Insanity:Â doing the same thing over and over againÂ and expecting different results."Â Â Albert EinsteinOh, Albert, how true this statement is.I do some of my best thinking on my walks. Â I wonder if Mr. Einstein was a walker.It occurred to me today as I walked that I am moving away from previous insanities. Â That is not to say that my old habits were wrong or defective in some way. Â No, it just means that methods I used previously never seemed to endure or make lasting improvements for me. Â And yet I always fell back on using them when I was "starting over" in my quest to improve my health. Â It was a kind of insanity.For example: In the past, IÂ diligently recorded exercise statistics: Â activities, frequency,Â repetitions, durations, etc. Â It fit my nature to do this, and I assumed it kept me engaged in exercise. Â Funny, but the "engaged" part never seemed to last as long as I wanted.Â Today while walking I reflected that I felt pretty good. Â The distance, time and speed didn't really matter to me. Â What counted was the feedback I was getting from my body that said: Â "enjoying the walk, keep doing this till you are ready to stop, andÂ then repeat again soon." Â Right then I decided to stop record keeping on my calendar (my history of what I had done) and consider the activity as "money in the bank" for the future - improving myÂ freedom of movement for longer into myÂ aging with every step I took. Â The change of focus was the difference between looking behind at the past and seeing ahead into the future.I realized the same was true for my stretching/yoga moves. Â My body had some stiffness from yesterday's practice that I knew would be relieved by more practice. Â In fact, I was eager to get those tiny improvements inÂ flexibility later today ... "banking" those improvements so that my future flexibility would keep me movingÂ and nibble.Â So I am leaving behind an insanity and hopefully finding a lifestyle. Â Only time will tell.The only objective indicator I am using now is the step count on my FitBit. Â The step count proves I am moving enough each day to avoid some of the bad things in life. Â My goal is still 10,000 steps average per day. Â Sometimes I get 10,000 steps through my walks, and sometimes I reach the goal through activities in the house. Â No matter how I get them, it is movement! Â And movement is one of those "magic pills of health" that everyone looks for but many refuse to recognize. Â The FitBit and me are Buds!!Â Hope you approve, Mr. Einstein.

title: Never, Ever Give Up. Arthur's Inspirational Transformation!
text: If you haven't seen this video, you must.Â Â I put this story on my blog because I want this example for meÂ - when I forget that life is what you make itÂ - when I forget that physical limitations can be slowed and sometimes reversed- when I forget to believe in myself ...Never Ever Give UpThanks, Arthur.I need your example.How about you?

title: Reducing Life Static
text: There are many blogs on minimalism and simplification. Â It is a real movement for sure. Â Broadly speaking, the movement to reduce the clutter of life in all its iterations is a desire probably born from our consumer culture where the "cult of big, better, more" is still fully in charge.My own journey to reduce what I call "life static" has been ongoing for years and feels like it is finally picking up steam today. Â It is time for some observations on my current efforts to calm my world down - especially when a big responsibility and focus of life has recently disappeared.It started quietly when I needed to thin out the inherited stuff from the death of a grandmother-in-law and a mother-in-law during the mid 1990s. Â Next came the "newly-adult-children-returning-home chapter," so space was made for them. Â In mid 2000s my mom moved in with her stuff. Â Although I decluttered and decluttered and decluttered over the last 20 years, the stuff continued to increase like rabbits. Â I never got ahead. Â I just stayed even. Â Now the adult children are fully independent, all older adults have passed away, and my decluttering efforts seem to be making a difference.It continues to astound me, however, at the volume of stuff that has passed through my hands in the last 20 years. Â I don't remember one single thing that left this house. Â Not one single thing. That understanding underlines emphatically just how little we really need to be happy. Â Decluttering creates a feeling of lightness, almost like a drug high. It is trite but true - less is more.While decluttering is a big part of my efforts, it is but one small part of my life static picture.Time is precious - more precious to me now than when I was 30. Â It is human nature to think there is plenty of time left to do what you want, but no one has a promise of more time than the current moment. Â I used to think I would return to work in a fun part time job when mom was gone - now she is gone - no job for me. Â No, no, no! Â (see a previous post on The Power of No.) Â I suspect all retired folks worry about money and if it will last. I am no different. But I would rather adopt a frugal life style than fill my free hours with a job to gain a pay check. Â Time is precious. Â Time is the goal ... not money.Travel was always on my radar - especially after retirement. Â But now my husband is not comfortable with his external environment. Â His vision is very very compromised now - what little he has. Â And I find I don't miss travel. Â I love my home and my life. Â I don't need to seek out ways to escape from it like I did when I worked. Â It is an interesting evolution I would never have predicted.I dream of less living space. Â I love my townhouse. Â All 2,000 feet of it has served me well in raising a family, supporting elderly relatives and giving children a safety net while they established themselves in the world. Â But my current dream is less house. Â And less will definitely be more if this dream is ever achieved. Â More on that topic another time.Busyness is way reduced. Â My "to do" lists still get made, but some days they are never looked at. Â Thank goodness there is always tomorrow (hopefully there is tomorrow, but if not, will the "to-dos" really matter all that much to me?) Â And thank goodness for "to do" lists, because once something is on the list I know that it will eventually get done (if there is a tomorrow - but if not - oh well.) Time to think and dream have filled the vacuum left by my mom's death. Â Wow, what a concept - time to think. Â That still blows my mind. My "20 years and 20 goals blog theme" born years ago is now down to a "20 years and 2 goals blog theme": Â (1) keep fit and healthy, and (2) enjoy living every minute. How's that for symplifying! Â Even if my mind starts to fail me like mom's did, I should be able to keep track of 2 goals!!So that is the wrap up for Reducing Life Static.Someday I might even get good enough at this simplifying thingyÂ to get this whole post down to one sentence!!!Â (ok, maybe not.)

title: Inquiring Minds: "Capturing" Blog Posts
text: In returning to blogging and visiting blogs this month I decided to make a change in how I am notified of new blog posts from the blogs I follow.In the past, I used a "blog catcher" ... most recently Bloglovin'. Â Basically I tell Bloglovin' which blogs I follow. Â Bloglovin' captures recent blog posts from my list for me. Â The blog posts are held on their web site until I am ready to read them. Â Once read, the blog posts are automatically removed from my "To Be Read List." Â Bloglovin' sends me one daily email reminding me that I have blog posts ready for review.I am sure most blog catcher sites work in a similar fashion. Â I have used that method for a long time. Now the problem for me is Â ... I seem to get behind on my reading. Â When I open up the blog catcher I can have 100 open blog posts waiting for review. Â It is can be discouraging. Â Sometimes I just mark everything as "read" even though I didn't read it. Â t know the problem rests partly in my tendency to ignore the daily Bloglovin' reminder ... but when I get an individual blog post directly dropped into my gmail inbox, I don't ignore it.So I am moving over to the "send me an email" subscription method for each blog entry posted. Â Most blogs offer you the option to subscribe through email. Â Initially I was worried that my gmail inbox would be flooded ... but that hasn't happened yet. Â Blog posts trickle in daily and are entirely manageable. Â And I find I can read a current blog posting far more promptly than before ... at least so far.SoÂ what methods have you used ...Â and what method are you currently using? Â Is there another option out there I didn't mention?

title: Renew Our Edges
text: I need to spend more time reading Mark Twain's words. Every quote I read rings bells in my brain.An amazing individual.This one seems particularly timely at my point in life.Mark Twain in New Hampshire, 1905The New York Times Photo ArchivesMark Twain"In America, we hurry--which is well; but when the day's work is done, we go on thinking of losses and gains, we plan for the morrow, we even carry our business cares to bed with us, and toss and worry over them when we ought to be restoring our racked bodies and brains with sleep. We burn up our energies with these excitements, and either die early or drop into a lean and mean old age at a time of life which they call a man's prime in Europe. When an acre of ground has produced long and well, we let it lie fallow and rest for a season; we take no man clear across the continent in the same coach he started in--the coach is stabled somewhere on the plains and its heated machinery allowed to cool for a few days; when a razor has seen long service and refuses to hold an edge, the barber lays it away for a few weeks, and the edge comes back of its own accord. We bestow thoughtful care upon inanimate objects, but none upon ourselves. What a robust people, what a nation of thinkers we might be, if we would only lay ourselves on the shelf occasionally and renew our edges!" - The Innocents Abroad

title: The Power of NO!
text: During my years as a working person I had one boss (a lovely and caring individual) who coined this statement with her employees."The answer is yes. Â Now what is the question?"At the time (12 years ago) I thought it was a catchy statement. Â It seemed so positive, so open, so engaging. Â And it was something I always remembered it. Â I thought it was something to immolate in my own life. Â It matched my perception of who I was ... a perky, happy, open and accommodating person.Over the years since that job, I learned that the answer "yes" to every question was not necessarily helpful, or truthful or healthy. Â I began to wonder if she learned that statement in a management course or book on how to manage teams. Â I became more skeptical and resistant to stock statements and catch phrases. Â I learned through some difficult life experiences that "yes" is not always the best answer.And now as a grouchy older woman I find "no" to be the best answer in many situations. Â My path from a "yes" person to a "no" person is not so dismal as you might think.Here are the situations where "no" really is the best answer.No, I don't want my home to be filled with too much stuff. Â I don't want to struggle finding things that I know I have but can't find. Â I don't want to buy a 6th hammer because I can't find the other 5. (sadly not an exageration)No, I don't want to end my life in a wheel chair or bed bound. Â I don't want my family to struggle with managing my end of life dibilitation. Â I don't want to linger in a marathon of stuggle and pain. Â No, I don't want my personal time filled with activities and obligations that I don't enjoy or value. Â I don't want to say "yes" to requests because it is more socially acceptable to do so. Â I don't want my personal time (that is slowly ticking away) filled with others expectations.But really, as the quirkiness of language can sometime show, the "no" statements can be restructured into "yes" statements.Yes, I do want to get rid of that 6 bags of stuff I decluttered. Â I do want to minimize my belongings so that I can find and use them. Â I do want to value the things I love without having them buried in stuff I don't.Yes, I do want to keep active, flexible and engaged in life - so I do want to exercise and stretch because I want to keep control of my own life and not abandon that responsibility to my children.Â Yes, I do want fill my hours with fun, thoughtfulness and happiness, and my perception of what that is exactly is my decision to make - not someone else's.For me "no" is a more empowering word. Â I learned the value of "no" in saying "yes" to caregiving. Strange as it seems, I said "yes" to a huge responsibility, but "no" was where I learned how to stand up for myself and for my mom. Â "No" to doctors, nurses, social workers, other family members, and religious professionals when I didn't accept their point of view ... "no" to administrative types and billing folks .... even "no" to my mom when her deteriorating brain failed to serve her well. Â It was in those last years I learned that "no" was more powerful than "yes." Â In fact, I was told several times near the end of mom's life, "You never gave up on your mother." Â  True. Â It was an observation made because I said "no" far more than I said "yes." Â I really wish I had been wise enough to 12 years ago to challenged that little management "yes" statement ... maybe with some carefully worded questions that wouldn't get me fired like ...Can I have a 25% increase in pay?Can I have a corner office?Can I have a 3 hour work day without a cut in pay?I bet I could have massaged a "no" from my boss's lips.So - are you more of a "yes" person or a "no" person? Â And don't let my post sway you from your opinion. Â The world is filled with "yes" people. Â And with enough challenge in life they just might graduate to "no" people. Â Really, all the interesting people in life are "no" people.:-)

title: Not Torture!
text: GREAT NEWS!Yesterday's walk outside was not torture. Yes, I know, I guess I have sunk pretty low when reaching the threshold of "not torture" is great news. So here is why I have achieved the "not torture" status!I can now walk and breathe at the same time without panting and drawing attention to my plight.I can walk up a slope without slowing my speed to much - faster than a turtle I bet.Â I can now pass a bench without seriously considering a sit down to black out for a bit.I can now enter the house without immediately seeking the couch.I can now complete a walk without hip pain.I can now enjoy about 90% of the walk without wishing for death!Let's hear a rousing cheer!!(Louder, please.)I also returned to Yoga at the Senior Center in February. Â That was a humbling experience! Â No, "humbling" is the wrong word. Â It was embarrassing. Â My strength, flexibility and balance are pathetic!! Â No, "pathetic" is the wrong word. Â It was ... hmm ... can't use those words here. Â So lets leave it at pathetic ... pathetically embarrassing. Â Thank God I can be at the back of the room.Â I leave those classes thinking, "You are only a few years away from becoming a totally inflexible pretzel." Â But my personality is such that I won't accept that fate. Â Almost every evening I do stretches from some DVDs I have. Â This slow progress has also reached the level of "not torture." Â So improvements all around! Â I am psyched!!! Â Onward to the next status - Improved and Uninjured!

title: Fresh Air
text: I try to not get too excited. Â Not too much anticipation. Â No expectations, for sure. Â But ...It is the beginning of MarchÂ and the sun is outÂ and it is WARM! Â Ok, not entirely warm. Â Mostly in the high 40s and low 50s, but really folks, for us that temperature is now blessedly warm. Â I see people out in shorts and sweaters and I think ... spring has got to be here soon!It has been a difficult winter for me. Â I feel like I have been in hibernation through most of it. Â Maybe it was a normal reaction ... a time to just be and to heal and to assess. Â Maybe it was a kind of grieving time for what I lost. Â The loss is larger than just the death of my mother, but that is a topic for another time. Â But I can't help wondering ... would I have hibernated like this if her death happened in summer? Â Was her death the straw that finally broke the camel's back - so to speak? Â Was my reaction timed more to the seasons than by life events? Â Questions that I have pondered in my quiet times. Â Answers that don't really need to be discovered.I have always loved winter, but this winter has been so very cold and dark and snowy. Â There is a ton of salt all over our environment to combat the ice - glad for the chemical melting, I guess, but the salt that is left behind clouds everything with a gray with film. Yes, this winter was one to forget.Official spring is just weeks away. Â And I for one cannot wait. Â Our whole world needs a good bath of spring rain to wash away winter. Â We need the warmth to wake up the plants and melt away the snow FINALLY. Â I greatly desire to pack away my shovels and boots. Â I need to be able to step outside and take deep breaths of fresh air without risking frozen lungs. Yes, I am ready ready ready for spring.This spring holds many promises of fun things. Â Two cousins weekends are planned: one in Pennsylvania soon and one at my house in May for The Maryland Sheep and Wool Festival - "high holy days" for us fiber obsessed folks. Â Time with cousins always pumps up my joy of living. My house is undergoing a reorganization and decluttering - a sure sign that I am waking out of slumber. Â After 2 days of house focused activity, I feel lighter already!! I can't wait to finally open the windows and fill my lighter space with fresh air. This spring I celebrate 68 years on this earth. Â Each birthday is a gratitude-inducing event now-a-days. Â Many people don't make it this far in life. Â I have seen the road ahead of me through my mother's own aging. It was an up close and personal journey. Â Today, however, I am healthy and blessed in so many ways. Â My birthdays always remind me of that fact. My new motto is to keep focused on today and let tomorrow take care of itself. Â A time to rejoice for sure.AND I can finally get outside and walk and walk and walk. Â My FitBit friends ... look out. Â I am going to pass you in the Leaderboard! Â No need to fear icy patches, snow filled sidewalks and frost bitten noses. Â Time to get these nearly 68 year old bones moving - time to stretch out these muscles and make the focus about me! (Me in the lead on the FitBit Leaderboard, of course.) Â :-)Yes, this spring holds many wonderful promises. So everyone, now it is time for a deep breath of fresh air!!So what are your spring plans like?PS - if you are a FitBit user and want to be Friends at the online website ... just send me an email. Â I would love to keep everyone moving along with me.

title: Slaying dragons
text: I know I took another blog break. Â Shorter this time. Â Not planned. Â Not intended. Â But still a quiet time in my blogging life.But a small evolution seems to be happening. Â Not yet sure yet where it is heading. Â But interesting to watch all the same.I have always been driven by structure and goals and lists and to-dos. Â Always ... my whole life. Â I don't remember anything different. Â Now all that seems so unimportant.I spend a lot of time thinking. Â I may start out reading or playing a video game or knitting or weaving, but I find myself unexpectedly looking out the window ... thinking. Â I look down to what is in my hands and see that I did one row of knitting 30 minutes ago and then stopped. Â The day comes to an end and nothing observable has been accomplished. Â The to-do list has the same items on it as it did 3 days ago. Â Wow, that is so not me!Oh, meals get made and doctor appointments are attended and time with friends happens ... and there are days of continuous activity where house cleaning and decluttering gets done - like today. Â But mostly ... if my butt hits the couch, major parts of my day seem to drift out of focus with little to show for it ... except for thinking.It is like I sit in someone else's body - and the "real me" is off slaying dragons somewhere.I can't help but wonder if the real me is changing. The real me, who kept putting one foot in front of the other while juggling several balls in the air and swinging a figurative sword at anyone who got in her way ... and chewing gum at the same time ... for 8 years of caregiving, that "real me" feels like a stranger. I am beginning to think that slaying dragons is for other folks now.I think ...... I think I like the new me.

title: Structure - Who Knew!
text: I knew structure was important to me. Â After all, I am the queen of list making, I like things orderly, I hate being late to ANYTHING and I live by my calendar as if it was a bible. Â (And as I write those words I am not sure I want to be a person like that, but it is what I am.)awesome-confusing-future-life-quote-Favim.com-335590.jpgBut the end of this month I got broadsided by the realization that the major constructs of my life - the big "gorillas" that were layered over and created major structure in my life Â ... are gone.You know what I mean - things like The Big Three: a job, raising a family, being a caregiver. The big things in life that sometimes define you ...Â gone,Â GONE,Â GONEfrom my life!YIKES!Oh, I didn't really notice any difference at the beginning of January. Â After all, I had a funeral to manage, and some estate duties, and then we had several social engagements that I had responsibility for, and I finally put my own health front and center and saw a few doctors. Â I cleaned up after Christmas, and set up my weaving station and my lego station (more on that later.) Â You know, it has been a busy, busy, busy month!!BUT ... it is grinding to a halt. Â My "to do" lists have shrunk.NOW WHAT!Ok, I am a goal oriented individual. Â So I have a few ideas bouncing around in my mind. Â But those ideas were always there, and I always managed to squeeze them in-between The Big Three!! BUTThe Big Three are GONE!Are those few ideas worth taking center stage in my life now??So what few ideas am I talking about ...MovementTo begin with I need to move more. Â OH . MY . GOD! Â I sooooo need to move more. Â I am not talking about exercise (exercise would be good too, but how about just keeping my butt off the couch where, by the way, I am sitting right now! *sigh* )I did start tracking of my movement with my FitBit. Â Again, I am not talking about exercise. I just wanted to know what my "normal" was without focusing on walking. Â I discovered that I averaged 6,500 a day in January. Â That is my baseline now. Â New Goal - Do more than 6,500 average a day during the month of February. Â And some day I just might see 10,000 steps again!!In truth, I am pretty far away from my movement goals! Â Sadly and embarrassingly so. Â For example, I went for a walk today and mostly what I wanted to do during that 30 minutes of walking was find a bench and sit down! Â Pathetic ... I was brutal with my self talk. "Keep those 67 year old feet moving forward you lazy thing, or you will find yourself sitting in your mother's wheel chair ... which by the way is now available." Â Stuff like that!I did sign up for a Yoga class. Â I need to stop walking like an old lady and getting more flexible will help.My HobbiesI have a long love affair with yarn based hobbies. Â I have enough yarn in my yarn room (yes, I have a yarn room - doesn't everyone??) enough yarn to knit like a banshie every day until I am 98 years old andÂ never runÂ Â outÂ of yarn - even if I stopped buying yarn this very minute for the rest of my life. Â (Which, by the way, won't happen ... the not buying yarn part.) Â Another embarrassment. Â Now I find have the time, the tools and the desire to knit and weave and maybe even spin ... but I also have a little voice in my head that says things like, "Don't you have something better to do with your time." Â And then I think hard and I answer myself, "No, apparently not."ReadingI am reading more and I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE my Kindle. Â I love zombi books, and end of the world books and stories of destruction (hmmm .... is that healthy?) but can I build a life around reading?And .... ok, pretty much the list stops there.So dear readers, only 3 lonely ideas are bouncing around in my brain (avoidance of wheel chairs, yarn hoarding while listening to the voices in my head, and tales of destruction.)Maybe Psych should be my next doctor visit!!Until next time ...Retired Knitter.

title: Sleeping with a bar of soap!
text: Not just any soap!Â No, I have standards.Â Â I am sleeping with a bar of "Irish Spring."Photo CreditAnd now for the remarkable part of that idea (as if sleeping with a bar of soap isn't odd remarkable enough) ...I am sleeping with a bar of soap on Doctor's Orders!"Put it between the sheet and the mattress down near your feet."Bet you weren't expecting that!! Â Even the brand name was recommended.I guess I could just end this blog post here ... just to see if anyone is really reading my posts!But I am not that kind of girl. Â :-) I will explain, and who knows, maybe you too may start sleeping with a bar of soap.***Recently in my quest to get caught up on my own health issues, I visited a Podiatrist. Â I have a chronic issues over 15 years with my feet. Â Mostly I have Plantar Faciitis which probably plagues most of the modern world today. About 7 years ago I stated using prescription orthotics and the foot pain mostly went away.But new pain started recently (like for 2 years or so ... I know, I know ... no lectures please. Â I was busy with someone else's body during that time and tabled a lot of the "me" stuff) ... Â recently with pretty bad leg cramps and terrible terrible foot cramps (the foot cramps were the worst - those suckers would hang around for 30 minutes or so.) Â I have had to pull off the side of the road while driving due to foot cramps that threatened to cause a car accident!!So I self-medicated because that was what I had energy for ...bumped up my water - 32 to 64 oz of water a day - bumped up from almost no water at all.increased my potassium - bananas, coconut water, vitamin water, etc.took an over-the-counter product called "Leg Cramp PM" - the title says it all, don't you think? It was suggested by a pharmacist. Â (I would recommend this product.)These interventions worked some - but the foot cramps were still an issue.And my feet were also starting to get generally sore.So off to the podiatrist!After an examination and a review of what I have already done (including seeing my general doctor for blood work - normal!), she admitted that these kinds of issues were hard to diagnosis. Â She recommended creating new prescription orthotics and bumping up my water intake. Â Agreed. And that is when the interview sort of went off the rails!She asked me if I had ever slept with a bar of soap. Â I considered putting my socks and shoes on and walking out. Â Clearly this woman was having a break with reality! Â But in that moment Â I decided that this line of questioning would be good fodder for a blog post! Â (Yes, guys, I am always thinking of you.)I think my reaction was pretty normal ... eyes unblinking, jaw slightly open, quiet, assessing how far I was from the exam room door ... Â and she had the good grace to laugh sort of self-deprecatingly, and then she plowed on with her story.She read an article on this phenomenon of sleeping with a bar of soap and quickly dismissed it (so thankfully she is not a quack.) Â But then she started having patients report spontaneously to her success with cramping using the bar of soap method. Â And not just a few patients either, but a substantial number. Â So now she suggests it - even though it is still an "old wives" tale in her mind. Â She says sometimes it is discovered that old wives tales have a thread of truth. So last night I slept with a bar of soap! Â Irish Spring as prescribed. Â Not a great success for me. Â If I do start getting success, you can be sure that I will buy a case load of Irish Spring and start taping them to my legs, the peddles of my car, the side of my couch and maybe grind up a soap powder to put in my shoes. Â But no success thus far, so I am saved at present from having my own "break with reality." Â :-)Tonight I will try 2 bars of soap. Â Maybe ...This morning I googled this topic to see what the "experts" have to say, and I found this link. Â Interesting reading.So my question to you is this ...Do you have leg and foot cramps?Â Â What do you do to prevent it?Â Â Have you slept with a bar of soap?(Enquiring minds want to know!!)

title: "Someday" and brain shifts  ...
text: Photo CreditI am going through a fairly intense period of "brain shifts."Here are a few of the biggies ...#1"Never enough time" to "extra time."Â Â I finally feel retired 7 years after my actual retirement date. Â That is a major "wow" moment for me.#2Mind filing!Â Â Ideas pop into my head ...Â things I would like to do, to read, to see, to experience, to play with, on and on and on ...Â and it all gets automatically filed by my brain in the "Someday File."Â Â Is it possible that "someday" has finally arrived?#3Whole days at home!Â Â Many whole days in a row!!! Â That little reality is a sweet pleasure.Â #4Fast food begone!Â  I used to pick up one meal a day on the road. Â Wow, my health might actually improve if I eat only food from my house.Â (ok, I had one little tasty, sugar covered, jelly filled donut today, but just one.)#5Ugh on ringing phones!Â Â I still cringe a bit when it rings, but I have learned to back away from the "panic-cliff" of bad news before I get across the room to answer it.Â Â No bad news. Â Just pain-in-the-neck junk callers!#6Joy at true friends!Â Â I am honored that I was given the space I needed the last year without losing friends,especially since I dropped out of so many friendships without warning.Still shifting ... but not falling over.

title: The Caregiver takes off her mantle ...
text: Not much time has passed since my mom passing. Â Looking over that short period I find that I am a little surprised.I miss her, but I am not mourning her! Â And I feel there is a big difference between those two words.Maybe I should explain.I heard all the well meaning sympathies - all offered by people who care for me and shared their best advice from their own experiences and expectations.Take your time with recovering ...Only time will help this process ...Don't try to do too much ...I am worried for you because she was so much a part of your life ...Those daily little reminders of her life will be difficult to get passed ...And these statements are all generally true, but how can I explain not mourning my mother now.Today on my walk I realized that my mourning began long before she died.Thinking back I mourned her in a million small ways over the last 10 years. Â The first tug on my heart happened when I realized she was really no longer completely viable living independently. Â Moving her into my home 8 years ago made me happier - she was safer - but I remember sadness too knowing she needed this kind of help. Â In 2011 her frequent hospitalizations and in-house rehabs created another jarring realization. Yes, her mind was failing, but her body was too. Â In December 2011 Â I remember standing by my kitchen sink crying like she had already died - she was leaving my home and being admitted into Assisted Living. Â Watching her leave me mentally and physically this last year was a terribly mournful time for me. Â  Â I mourned at each and every decline for too many years.So I am not in a state of mourning today. Â It sounds almost sacrilegious to say that. Â But for me, my time at my mom's side was like one long goodbye. Â And as I lost pieces of her through the years, I mourned and made my peace with those losses every step of the way.I miss her. Â I am not mourning her. Â I think she would be happier about that. I think each individual goes through the process of losing a loved one differently. Â I had years and years of little goodbyes and periods of sadness and mourning. Â There is nothing left now to mourn.***I have two last memories to share - and then I am moving on in a different direction for the blog.About 4 days before mom died, she had a few wakeful periods. Â She was not eating or drinking much. Â She was not speaking. Â I knew she was dying. Â I think she knew too. Â That morning when I came into her room I bent down to say good morning and kiss her face - something I did every time I visited. Â This time, however, she slowly lifted her arm and put it around my head as I kissed her. Â Her message was simple - I am saying goodbye. Â I will remember that embrace for the rest of my life. Â That same day my sister arrived and mom did exactly the same thing again. Â A simple action and yet so meaningful.My last memory caught me by surprise. Â I expected her actual death to be hard. Â I was prepared. Â I was not prepared for the last moments at her grave site. Â The priest had performed the last blessing and had left. Â It was a cold and rainy day - too dismal to linger. Â The small gathering was breaking up. Â At that moment, I couldn't seem to leave. Â I finally walked to the end of her casket and placed my hand on it trying hard to understand this emotion. Â I think the realization that I was finally no longer needed even for the shell of her body had finally hit me. Â I turned quickly and left.I left my caregiver mantle at her grave site. Â I didn't need it any more.***Next time I post ... and there will be a next time ... I will focus on what the "new" me is doing! Â Hopefully you will stick around for that.

title: Through My Caregiver Eyes:  And thus we part
text: This is the last entry in a continuing series calledÂ Through My Caregiver Eyes. Â The full story of 8 years as my mother's caregiverÂ can be found under the label "Through My Caregiver Eyes."Â (Label Section to the right of my blog posts.) Â My mom was 88 years old at her death.The rocky path from independence to living with me, then assisted livingand finally nursing home careÂ is documented in this series. Â While our journey together is peppered with joy-filled moments,Â it tells of many losses for her and sadness for me.Â For anyone who is a first line caregiver of a loved one,Â you may see yourself in my story.A last letter to my mom.Dear Mom,How I miss your sweet smile.Every day I think about you and wonder how you are doing. Â Every day I think it is time for a visit with you and then remind myself, you are no longer on this earth. My time at your side began 8 years ago when you moved into my home. Â Neither of us fully understood how difficult this last journey would be. Â Thankfully we didn't dwell on what could happen. Â Life is a process and we just kept moving forward through it.You were there during my growing years when living in a dysfunctional family was very hard - and I was there during your declining years when increasing age took so much away from your joy of living. Â There is no one I have shared more of life's struggles with than you. Â Through it all you showed how to keep moving forward through the hard stuff while still enjoying the simple pleasures. Â I feel so much in your debt.I am changed by this whole experience. Â How remarkable is it that my personal plans and desires could be so dramatically altered by taking this journey with you. Â Nothing I could have imagined for myself would have equaled the the importance of what I learned at your side. Â  The real diamonds of life are time with family and giving of yourself when it would be easier to walk away. Â I wasn't born knowing that stuff - learned it from caring for you. Â  Oh, the last 8 years were not without our personal disagreements. Â Those bumps in the road were rocky at times. Â But it never derailed you and me. Â I lived the last 8 years knowing this day would come when you would be gone. Â I worried that I would look back and wonder ... could I have done more or something different. Â My motto became - Have no regrets! Â I have looked back. Â There was nothing left undone or unsaid between us. Â I loved you, mom, without reservation or conditions. Â I accepted your strengths and weaknesses and learned from them. Â I met every challenge and pushed every boundary on your behalf. Â No regrets. Â I am now at peace.I know you would be happy to know I am fine today. Â Sometimes missing you suddenly catches me unawares and the tears begin to fall, but that is normal. Â You have moved on and so must I. Thus we part company in this life. You are loved, mom. Â You still hold a place in my heart that no one will ever dislodge. Â You were there when I took my first breath at birth and I was there for your last breath in death. I hope when I take my last breath, you will be there with that sweet smile to help me find my way.Love you always,ElaineRetired Knitter

title: Hello again!
text: It is probably safe to assume that I am talking to myself in this post especially after such a long absence from blogging. Â That is ok. Â That is how this blog started out. Â Just me and my keyboard.The last six months have been hard. Â Maybe I didn't blog because my focus was aimed at just putting one foot in front of the other ... day after day. Â Or maybe I lost my blog mojo. Â Just don't know.Here is a snap shot view of how I spent my "blogging break" - similar to the school child's assignment of "What I did last summer" only less enjoyable.In July Meathead, my dear dear grand dog died, without warning. Â He was a very old bull dog and we knew his days were numbered, but it was a shock. Â I still feel that loss deeply.In August Grimace, my other dear grand dog, developed a series of seizures that took some time to get under control. Â Probably not epilepsy. Â Probably a mass or lesion. Â He is doing fine for now. Â I treasure my time with him.In September Milo, yet another dear grand dog, developed spinal issues causing weakness in his rear legs. Â Left uncorrected, he would become paralyzed. Â He was scheduled for two surgeries - one in November for air way obstructions, typical of pushed-in-face breeds, and one in December for his spine. He is doing well.And then the most intensive loss of all began to develop. Â In November my mother began to fail ... sleeping all the time with loss of appetite and weight loss. Â She died in December, just after Christmas. Â That loss is beyond measure.So it goes without saying that I am pretty much physically and emotionally spent.Â I will do one last Through My Caregiver Eyes post at some point later this month to honor my mother and to close out that long series of posts. Â Beyond that it is too soon to know if or when I will be back to blogging. Â I need to figure out how to live in my own life and not inside my mom's life.If you are reading this post, I thank you for visiting.

title: Through My Caregiver Eyes: Peace
text: My mother passed away this evening.My sister and I were with her when she died.She is finally at peace.

title: Through My Care Giver Eyes - Waiting
text: Waiting. Â Thinking. Â Remembering. Â Sleepless. Â Sad. Â Numb. Â Waiting.Waiting while my mom takes that last step in life, by herself, without my help, to let go of life.I wait so that I can take a last step as a caregiver ... and finally let go of this woman I call my mother who I have cared for and loved with all my heart.I am not ready to let go ...... but she is.Waiting.

title: Prep work begins - the kitchen.
text: I have to get better at doing before and after pictures. Â There are no before pictures in this posting. Â Sorry.In preparation for new floors and painting this month, I began a thorough clean out of all areas. Â Decluttering of stuff has been a happy, positive activity for me. Â I always feel lighter and more content when I am reducing the "stuff-layer" of my life. Â Clear open spaces are less stressful. A related goal is to free up floor space by moving a few pieces of furniture out. Â We have too many road blocks for a person with visual limitations.With home improvement contractors arriving in 2 weeks, Â the time is right to declutter.I started with a small problem area of my kitchen.Imagine a 3 foot high by 5 foot long shallow 3 shelf book case along this wall. Â It was filled with cookbooks and animal foods. Â The top held baskets of clutter-catchers. Â Try to imagine why someone who does not enjoy cooking would have 5 1/2 feet of cookbooks.So I emptied the shelves of everything putting it on the table and dragged the bookcase to the basement. Â It will go to a new home or the dump - which ever comes first. Â Now I have this lovely clear floor space. Â And when the walls are painted, who knows what will hang on the walls. Â Maybe nothing.Of course, now I had a table full of stuff. Â Hmm.... I gave half of the cookbooks to Good Will.I then turned to the pantry. Â A "pantry purge" was in order. Â It is a small space, but once I cleared out the expired items, the duplicates and the stuff that I never use, 2 spaces were clear: Â the top shelf and the floor. The top shelf now holds my essential cookbooks. (Still considering if they are all really "essential." Â I think not!) Â I hate the stacking of books on top of books. Â But the remaining books will need a more careful review before I get rid of any of them. The floor holds the animal foods (dog food and bird seed.) Some canned and boxed foods are housed in our basement. Â I don't understand why 2 retired people like us need that many food items. Â But that is another problem for another time - food hoarding! Â I am sure that "hoarding" is not quite the right term, but my habit of buying extra of things that I find on sale is counter productive if the items expire and I throw them away. In theory, I love the idea of a nice large pantry close to the cooking area, but the reality is that I don't preserve home grown foods and I have easy access to a grocery store. Â So the fact I even have a pantry is a luxury. Â When I was growing up, we didn't have a pantry - just found space in the limited cabinets to hold canned and packaged foods. Â I guess the expansion of large pantries and multiple kitchen cabinets is an extension of the growing sizes of houses in the 20th Century - and our habit of acquiring lots and lots of stuff.I am very pleased with this one kitchen solution right now. Â My eat-in kitchen is fairly small and adding a bookcase years ago was a bad idea. Â It just ate up floor space and encouraged stuff gathering.Of course the next step is to box all this up and move it to the basement - because the whole area will be painted - but that is 3 weeks off so I have time.

title: So it begins ... the carpet requiem
text: After almost 30 years we are finally replacing the carpeting in the main part of our townhouse. Â The contract is signed and within the month, we will see this carpet ripped out and carried out the door.Yes, this carpeting is 29 years old in July of this year. Â It is the original carpeting that the builder put in and it was the best thing we chose when we selected options for our new town home those many years ago.Many vendors who have passed down this hallway (carpet installers and professional carpet steam cleaners) have told us this is excellent carpeting ... Â that you can't buy this quality carpet today no matter how expensive you go because carpet manufacturers don't want you to have carpet that lasts 30+ years!! Â Planned obsolesces, they call it.It is silly, but I get attached to "things" - things that have served me well and that I have owned and used for a long time. Â And this stupid carpet is one of those "things." Â I didn't shed any tears when we replaced the xyz things (refrigerator, stove, dishwasher, front door, glass door sliders, storm door, washer/dryer, water heater, roofing, deck, bathroom flooring, toilets, bathroom sinks, furniture ... it is an extensive list ), but for some crazy reason, pulling the carpet out makes me a little sad.But everything wears out and this carpet is ready to go to "carpet heaven." Â After all, it has been walked on, run on, spilled on, peed on, vomited on - you name it ... it has happened. Â Even red wine. Â It all came out - there is not one visable stain or wear path, but I can't get it really clean any more ... down below the rug surface into the pad where it really counts, and on humid days ... well, you get the idea.The replacement?? ... No more rug for us. Â Hard wood floors! Â And it will be a dirty, noisy, intrusive Â job for about 2 days. Â Upstairs hall way, two and half flights of stairs and the first floor area - all hard wood. Â No more hidden areas I can't clean.And when they complete the flooring job, we are contracting to paint about 60% of the interior of the townhouse. Â So the *#@%$ "fun" will just continue. Â But it has been almost 20 years since we painted and that is also long over due too. Â May as well get all the pain out of the way at one time!I feel pressured to move forward with these jobs ... they are well passed due by many years and I now have this window of time without a mom-related emergency. Â Really, for the last 7 or 8 years I stalled at doing anything ... couldn't handle "just one more thing, don't want to disturb mom, too tied up with her assisted living care, need to focus on nursing home transition, etc. etc. etc."But now the environment of my house is causing me stress and it is a problem I can do something about. All I need to do is write the check! Oh, yes, the check! Â There is another stressor! Â These folks don't work for free. Â But no matter. Â It has to be done. We are doing it this summer!And I will be joyful at the end! Â :-)

title: Recovery
text: So here I am again, almost one month later. Breaking a blog-silence.After the recent "mom-illness-hospitalization-rehab-nursing home" episode, I have come to realize a few things about myself. #1 - I don't know myself as well as I think I do.Â The rest of my story just falls like an avalanche out of #1!I am not as resilient as I think I am or as I used to be. Â Each set back in mom's situation is a set back for me personally and each of my set backs take longer to dig out of. Â Sounds like a mom-related behavior! Â Seniors taking care of seniors. Exhausting.I still can "dive into" a mom-related crisis with the energy and the focus of someone half my age, but the personal price that is paid after the crisis gets longer and longer to recover from. Â I can't seem to "dive out" with the same energy and focus and take back my own priorities without a long hard fight with myself.Here I am 3 months later finally getting re-connected with my own needs ... but it seems like such an effort!But I am trying ... really, really trying! Â Two weeks ago I prepared a blog post and pictures, but never posted it! Â Does that still count?I gained an all-time-high of body mass ... yes, too much weight! Â I am back to watching my food intake and have thankfully settled back to my previous "all time high of body mass." Â *sigh* Does that count?I started walking and exercising but have missed the last week and a half. Â Does the start of walking count?I have started calling home improvement vendors to replace carpeting and flooring (long, long, dreadfully long overdue.) Â But I dread the total upheaval that this kind of improvement will cause in my personal space. Â No contracts signed yet, but will the effort of talking to someone about making improvements actually count?I am knitting on a shawl for myself that I really don't care for - I bought the kits over 10 years ago. Â Too bad I didn't make the shawl then when I loved the colors. No matter. Â It came from deep stash and I thought I would come around when I got into it. Â I didn't! I am almost finished so I can use it this fall in the house. Â Certainly that finish object should count?My other crafting lives are in another temporary limbo - that always seems to happen when I am in recovery. Â Nothing there will count. (But ... I love walking into my yarn room and admiring my newly Â assembled loom and stand with the newly started weaving project on it. Â That counts for something.)I returned to knitting group three weeks ago and enjoyed every moment, but felt like I was stealing time from other more worthy endeavors - like sitting on the couch and doing nothing! Â Ok, now we all can agree that knitting group does count!!!On the surface of my life everything looks under control. Â But under the surface ... I am still struggling. Â And I dread the thought that any gains I make will go up in smoke when mom takes her next downward step in living.This "Recovery" stuff is hard hard work!
