title: Nothing to blog about ...
text: ... she says after another brief blogging absence. Could it be that my life is just that boring? Â Probably.Oh wait, there was the stunning multi-car accident that I happened upon while I was going out to pick up Chinese food! Â Just 1/4 mile from my house.Yes, that SUV is on top of and crushing another car!The car with the missing front end was the third one in this accident.There were 2 fire engines, 3 ambulances, 4 police cars, and 2 large tow trucks all gathered in a very small intersection. Â Looks like someone was traveling just too fast in a effort to make the light and two other cars were in the right place at the wrong time. Â Amazing ... and never seen on this quiet little intersection. No way to know about injuries, but I am just hoping no one was killed.Not boring I guess.I did, however, visit a new Community Center just 10 minutes from my house. Â Just 10 minutes away, only 2 years old, and I had absolutely no idea the building was even there. Â (Do I live in a paper bag or what!) Â They have a great indoor walking track and in this muggy hot weather, an indoor air conditioned track sounds just fine. Â I prefer being outside but when conditions are so terrible that I can't take a deep breath - indoors I go! Â They also have a state-of-the-art gym with great looking equipment. Â Seniors (which I am), can use the gym for $25 a year! Â How's that for a deal? Â Use of the walking track is free! Â Can't beat the price.My walking has taken quite a hit this summer. Â  Â Walking and breathing at the same time is kind of important! Â But I am still loving my FibBit Flex. Â That is why I am eager to find a viable option for walking indoors on these terrible days.At my dad's grave site.Several weeks ago I had a chance to visit my Dad's grave. Â My sister and I were doing some planning on mom's behalf and it took us to his grave site. Â He died in 1970. Â Even after all these years, and after all the bad memories of my upbringing, it gave my heart a tug to see his name on the tomb stone. Rest in peace, dear dad. Â Sorry I don't visit more often. Â I know you were ill with alcoholism and when you lived there wasn't much help for that. Â At least I have a few good memories and mementoes of your life. Â I wish you had lived long enough to meet your grandchildren. Â You would be proud of them.Finally, here is a picture I have been holding on to a bit.Easter at Brooke GroveI love this picture of mom with one of the activity coordinators dressed as an Easter bunny. Â They really try to make the holidays grand for the residents. Â Easter was a good day for mom. Â Lately she has had days when she mostly sleeps. Â Then other days she seems more alert. Â She has Congestive Heart Failure and these up and down periods are fairly normal. Â We just take each day as it comes. She has started to ask me again when she is "going home." Â It breaks my heart when she says that as I want to think she is content where she is. Â Coming back home now is next to impossible. Â She can't climb even one step and I have tons of them. Â And her care has reached a level beyond my abilities. Â So technically she is "home." Â During our last Family Meeting, the staff reported that mom seems "content." Â Maybe she is content Â at times, but there must be a small part of her that is not content. Â It continues to pain me.Guess there were a few topics to blog about after all! Â :-)Hope you all are doing well this hot summer. Â Be back again soon.

title: FitBit Flex
text: I have a new pedometer as of the middle of June. Â My daughter gifted me a FitBit Flex for Mother's Day. FitBit FlexPhoto Credit:Â http://www.fastcodesign.comLong time readers know that I have struggled with maintaining a walking program. Â Walking is my preferred form of exercise. Â There is nothing like slipping out the door for a quick (or long) walk with my iPod playing my current audio book or just enjoying a beautiful morning when the weather is inviting. Â It beats gathering my stuff for a trip to a gym, getting in the car and driving, parking, waiting for time on equipment, etc. etc. etc. Â But my success at keeping to a walking program has been spotty.So walking it is.It is helpful for me to have a quantitative measure of how active I am. Â It keeps me honest. Â It pushes me to do better. Â My tool for doing that has always been a pedometer. Â And I have had a bunch of them.My new favorite pedometer is the Fit Bit Flex - for a lot of reasons.The model is worn on the wrist. It only comes off to be charged.It tracks just about everything, but steps are my interest. Â There is, however, Â no face with numbers - just a small line of 5 lights. Â I don't miss seeing the numbers at all. Â If I am curious, I just open my phone, hit the App Icon, the device syncs automatically - and there is my total. Â In fact, I think I prefer not having those numbers staring at me on the device. Â It takes the pressure off for achieving a certain number ... but keeps me moving all the same.When I reach my goal - for me it is 10,000 steps - the lights flash and the band vibrates. Â Pretty cool, as well.The device is meant to sync to your computer or Smart Phone. Â This can happen automatically when within a certain range of your computer or phone, or you can manually sync when you log on to your phone or computer. Â This feature is pretty awesome.Step totals do not roll of memory after 7 days like many pedometers. Â The totals are out there when you want to see them.The battery must be recharged every 6 to 7 days.The device is water proof - apparently you can even shower with it.It can also be set to track the quality of your sleep - a very cool feature.Because it syncs to a free website, you can have "friends" and can easily see how they are doing. Â You can even send messages back and forth.And it appears to be very accurate.There are many features I haven't even touched on - more features I use - but I will say this is the best pedometer that I have ever used. Â It's a winner.Â So, if any of you great folks are already FitBit users and are looking for a new "friend" to help inspire you to walk, please let me know.

title: One last yarn-y stash post: a question!
text: Picture credit: www.galenfrysinger.comNo, this is not my yarn stash! Â But this is what my yarn stash feels like and resembles on occasion. Â And this is what I spent time trying to fixing this week.My current organizational system is not even as systematic as this picture, but I do try to get it all to fit in one full size closet. Â When new yarn comes into the house, it gets stacked on a card table until it can be logged in Ravelry and I have time to problem solve where it will go. The card table is just a temporary option. Â You see I share that room with my husband who visits daily to work on his computer. Â When he enters the room everything usually looks, well ... normal. Â The yarn stash is mostly not visible. Â He knows better than to open the closet (he did that only once and quickly slammed it closed before he lost control of the contents and needed to send out an SOS!) Â As long as my hobby stays safely contained in a confined space that is seldom viewed, he can claim plausible deniability. Â His wife is still normal and may need to (on occasion) buy more yarn. Â :-)Really ... he is mentally just fine, but "out-of-sight, out-of-mind" plays big in our house.It is a method that works for us!But back to the storage issues: Â I did manage to get all my cotton yarn together (gosh I have a lot of cotton yarn,) all my weaving yarn together (ditto on the weaving yarn), and all my wool fiber together. Â Oh, that's right. Â I haven't talked about my wool fiber stash! Once I am spinning will be Â ... wait for it ... yarn! (See why I didn't talk about it?)All the other skeins are stored wherever there is a space in the closet plastic drawers or in plastic bags squeezed in spaces between the drawers. Â I try to make sure I use bags that you can see through - so I don't have to dig too far to find stuff. Plastic may save me from the horrors of a stray moth setting up housekeeping in my collection. (Dread beyond measure!)But as a "Collector" of yarn, this storage system seems chaotic and disrespectful to my stash.I would love to hear how you manage your storage of anything - we all store stuff, we all have our methods, even if you aren't a yarn hoarder collector like me. Â How do you do it? Â What are the challenges you have and what have you done to overcome it?

title: Knitting and a Confession
text: I am a knitter! Â I dabble in a number of other fiber related crafts - but if I could choose exactly one activity to be stranded with me on an isolated tropical island ... it would be knitting. Â I wouldn't be able to wear any of my creations because tropical islands are hot and knitting produces warm garments but no matter!That is not my confession.This year I have several project goals - all of them are pretty big.I finished my mom's shawl. The story of why this shawl was pushed to the top of my project list can be found at this post. Â It just needs a few ends woven in and blocking. Â I wish this was a shawl that I could leave with mom all the time - but Assisted Living laundry is unforgiving. Â Everything gets cleaned using much heat and agitation - which is 'death' to wool. Â So the shawl will make periodic visits only. Â I am still thinking about buying some beautiful acrylic for a shawl that she can keep with her - but extending my project list is a low priority ... and buying more yarn is not ... *sigh* ... well, more about that later.This is also not my confession.My daughter's lace shawl (with fingering weight yarn and #1 needles - (yes, #1 needles - who the heck makes a shawl out of toothpicks - and before you say - use bigger needles - the pattern suggested #0 needles - insane I say!!!) .... anyway, I get distracted. Â My daughter's lace shawl was about 8 inches in depth when I decided that: Â 1) Â I couldn't live with the small errors I had made, Â  2) that I would always see those irregularities and be bothered by them, Â  3) Â that I would forever cringe when Kris would proudly tell people that her mother made the shawl, Â 4) that is OK to be anal and want perfection. Â So I ripped it all out and started again. Â Here is my second try.And just for the record: Â I am an Aries. Â That means I am stubborn, bull headed, persistent and ornery. Â I have no intention of letting this thread-like yarn and tiny tiny needles best me!I have also started a Faery Ring jacket for my cousin, Leslie. Â It is in the beginning stages but the process has begun. All together now ... no, this is not her confession.There are two other projects - my own sweater and a pair of socks - that are on the needles, but are not picture worthy yet. Â There are a few other projects on my list, but they are not even close to getting cast on the needles.Now for the confession.My yarn stash! Â For my non-knitting readers: a yarn stash is a bunch yarns (or fibers, or cloth ...) that is owned by you but not presently being used. Â It might have projects assigned to them, or it might be yarn that you just had to own because you physically could not walk away from it. Â Most knitters have a stash of yarn. Â Most knitters have enough years left in their lives to use up their stash of yarn.Then there is me!About 2 years ago I did an inventory. Â I listed the yarn by maker, weight, and color - I also noted how many yards I had of each entry.Two years ago that yardage number was 143,000 yards - (pause for gasps). Â For non-knitters that is about 79 miles of yarn (the gasps grow in volume). Â And based on using about 5,000 yards of yarn a year (equal to about 2 sweaters and several smaller projects), I would have enough yarn to last me 28 years even if I never bought another skein of yarn (pause for a belly laugh - mine, of course.) Â I was however, appalled at the quantity of yarn I had amassed. Â It was a bit embarrassing. Â The total would slowed my acquisition of yarn! Â I was glad I did the inventory.One year ago I updated my inventory - deleting yarns I had used and adding new ones. Â Remarkably my yardage total was now 156,000+ yards or 88 miles of yarn. Â That is an increase of 13,000 yards. Â 13,000 YARDS more yarn!! Â GASP! Â Just not possible! Â Now I could live another 31 years without running out of yarn - (time for math: Â I was 65 then so I wouldn't run out until I was 96 years old.) Â I did some soul searching. Â If that yarn was not developing gonads (I haven't entirely ruled that out yet) and increasing yarn babies on its own - then I had bought all those 13,000 yards. So I did the only reasonable thing I could think of. Â I decided that I was no longer a stasher of yarn - I was a "collector" of yarn. Â That sounded so much better. Â Yes, a Collector - with a capital C! Â I would still be cautious in my purchases, but as a serious "Collector", I was "normal" (an important word) - adding only unique selections to my "collection."Normal! (Is anyone else "buying" my assessment of this yarn stashing problem?)This week I updated my inventory again. Â (I really need to stop doing that!) Let see hands of how many think the inventory has gone down (great wasteland of silence!) You are right, it went up.Let see hands of how many think the inventory increased less than before (great wasteland of silence!!)You are right, it went up alot! Â (and I hate that you knew this!)Drum roll please.My current inventory of yarns is 188,475 yards, 107 miles of yarn ... I could live to be 104 years old before I run out of yarn. Â HOLY COW! Â I increased my yarn from last year by 34,475 yards! Â (and secretly I think I missed a few yards in this count - but whose counting, right?)I am now past "soul searching." Â That was a worthless endeavor. I am now in survival mode. Â I am still just a Collector (yes, I am), but if I reach 200,000 yards by this time next year - I will need to change my title from Yarn Collector to Yarn Store Owner or Hoarder! I vote for Yarn Store Owner - a unique yarn store where I don't sell any of my inventory. Â Yes, that is it! Â A unique store owner that does not sell stuff!! Unique is still normal, right?*sigh*Well, that is all for now. Â Need to get knitting.Also need to shop for some nice acrylic yarn for my mom's shawl!(Oh my, did I say that out loud?)Don't you hate it ... when you discover a vendor you patronize ... a vendor with a charming name for their business ... a name that triggers memories of an idyllic setting ... a name that in your mind's eye you want to visit to just get away ... don't you hate it when you find out that this vendor is not anything like the name they have picked???Well ...that is most definitely not the case with Kiparoo Farm.Â Kiparoo Farm is even better than my mind's eye imagined. Â My sister and I made the trip to visit Kiparoo Farm this past weekend. Â This is an actual working farm where sheep graze and cows are milked. Â And it is only about one hour from my house.Kiparoo FarmAnnie Kelley3511 Bussard RoadMiddletown, MD 21769301-371-7454kiparoofarmstudio.usI have been a yearly visitor to their fair stand at The Maryland Sheep and Wool Festival. Â I own a lovely selection of their yarns.This wonderful farm is located in rural Maryland.Â The farm house serves as the home and studio for Annie Kelley who is the owner of the Kiparoo Farm yarn brand. Â The yarn is from her sheep. Â She freely talks about her life as a farmer - and as a milker of cows. Â And her enthusiasm for her life and craft is infectious!This farm dates back to the 1700s and she says there is actually one very dilapidated building on the grounds from that time. Â The farm house was built in the 1800s.Â She is surrounded by beautiful rolling farm country.The first floor of the house has 3 rooms that serve as her studio. Â But through all the windows, glimpses of the farm can be seen. Â Of course, for knitters like my sister and I, the yarn is the star of the show. Â One of my favorites is her Silk Road - 50% Marino Wool, 50% Silk.Â Â There is little that compares to the feel of this yarn.The colors of this yarn were so much better in person!Darn camera!It goes without saying that I bought some yummy yarn.Â Â A wonderful cotton called Celtic Cotton now has a new home with me.Â Â The moment I saw it I knew that some of this great stuff was going to be mine.This cotton is machine wash and dry. Â It is spun around a central core that prevents the cotton from sagging - something that cotton is prone to Â do.All of her yarns have pattern support - and samples of the patterns are on display in the studio.The basic patterns are well written and attractively presented.Â The farm even has a mission statement ...Amazingly, I did not get any pictures of the sheep or the cows! Â Go figure! Â But I know I will be making this trip again and will correct that omission. Â It would be a wonderful day trip when my cousins come to visit.Thank you Annie Kelley for your gracious assistance - spending much precious time away from your farm duties with my sister and I. Â Our visit was memorable.

title: A Yearly Bath
text: Trust no one!Really!Trust no one!So here I am, the Meathead, the main dog, the man ...at my Papa's camp grounds. Â Soaking in the beautiful sun. Â Life is good! Â I am with all my peoples.Â Â No problems on my radar!Suddenly the sun is blocked - by too many bodies!Hmmm... too much attention focused on me!Hey, Meathead, Milo here. Â This doesn't look good. Â Not good.Not good at all!What!!! Â Water on my back?I think I remember this happening before.This is not a good development!Crap! Â Soap! Â This is not going to throw me!Â Â Proceed with dignity!Sigh! Â Water again! Â OK, guys. Â You knew this was coming.Â The Shake!Ah, better.This is unacceptable. Â I am not happy.I will not forget! Â I am never going to forget this, Grandma. Â You could have rescued me instead of taking pictures.My eyes are closed. My expectations are totally dashed! Â Finally. Â A towel! Â I repeat! Â Trust no one.

title: The Toilet Tale!
text: I have 4 of these in my house. Â Yes, 4 toilets. Â Three full baths and one half bath. Â I believe I have an embarrassing abundance of toilets.Â In my next abode, one toilet, one bathroom will be enough - well ... let me amend that statement. Â After living for 3 days with just one toilet, one full bathroom and a powder room will be enough. Â But I digress!This little toilet above is sitting in my eat-in kitchen. Â Didn't you always want an eat-in, poop-in kitchen??This little toilet should be in my half bathroom on the first floor - but because we are replacing the bathroom floor, the toilet had to be removed from the plumbing and put somewhere else while the work was being done. Â It now sits where all my guests can see it! This second little toilet is sitting in my bathroom tub. Â I guess that is an improvement over the kitchen because I could always do my business on it and at least it wouldn't leak out onto the floor! The third little toilet in the second full bathroom looks just like this one. Â I won't bore you with that picture.So for anyone who is counting, we have exactly one functioning toilet and it is located in the basement (my third full bathroom is there.) I guess this is an improvement over going outside to an outhouse to do the deed, but our bedroom is located on the top floor and our one functioning toilet is located 2 floors down. Â  My husband and I are both 66 and cannot be too far from the bathroom for those random visits in the middle of the night. Â You old fogies out there get my drift, I am sure. So my dear husband and I are sleeping on our pull out couch that is only one floor removed from the one functioning toilet! Â Our bladders are happier about this, but our backs are less than thrilled.All of this inconvenience is because my 28 year old tile floor was broken and ugly and it needed to go!!! Â So without thinking about the ramifications of doing 3 bathrooms all at once, we scheduled the work. Â The picture above shows the tile - minus the grout. Â Tomorrow, they say they will finish the job.I can't even just close the bathroom doors and pretend everything is normal ... because the bathroom doors have been removed and are propped up in my dust filled third floor. Â (Did I tell you just how dusty ceramic tile instillation can be? I don't think my allergies will let me sleep up there until I do a complete cleaning.) Â My back may be happier in my own bed, but my sinuses will create a major conflict of enormous proportions if I try to sleep upstairs right now.My bladder, my back, my sinuses ... all so that I can have new bathroom floors.I suffer so!:-)

title: Write 30 Interesting Facts About Yourself
text: I made another visit to Paula's Place and she is in Day 6 of a blog fest - each day she covers a different topic and each one is entirely different. Â Today's assignment was to write 30 interesting facts about yourself. I am game! Â Here goes ...When I was younger I wanted to be an actress. Â I had the female lead in my high school play.I didn't know what I wanted to do after college - so I chose teaching.Â I was a fair teacher of children by my standards. Great teachers are not made from people who wanted to be actresses.If I had the chance in another life to choose a profession, I would teach college level students or be an actress (or a Cow Boy or an Indian Chief.)I always wanted to be a mother. Â Thank God I got to do that.I have a talent for leadership - I always wound up being in charge.I hate being in charge.I have an undeveloped talent for Art - I hope God isn't too unhappy that I ignored that gift.My favorite TV show is Dancing With the Stars.I like a clean and orderly house.I hate to clean.I never had the chance to live on my own. Left my parents' house to get married.I have no tolerance for ditherers. Â Make a decision, move forward. Â If it is wrong, Â make another decision. Â It is not rocket-science!I am bad at forgiveness and I never forget. Â Some hurts cut too deep.Crap, this is becoming less fun and more like work!! Â Just like most everything I have done in my life!I am an evening snacker. Â I sleep better with a small snack right before bed.I have a weakness for animals, children and the elderly.Â I have been married once. Â Once will be enough.I love being alone. I don't get to do that very often.I love the beach.I love the mountains.I love hiking - don't get to do that any more - as my hiking buddy (husband) can't see very well.I love a great big thundery, windy, rain storm.I am wild about snow storms - 2 feet or more is heaven.Â My favorite season is winter.I had cataracts in both eyes repaired in my early 50s - early onset cataracts inherited from my father. Â To this day I still marvel at the clarity of my repaired vision. Â I remember how poor it was before. Â I truly appreciate the gift of sight.I hate my neck and chin area. Â If I was ever inclined to have something fixed, that would be it.There is nothing I hate more than throwing up! Oh, I abhor snakes. Â I guess snakes are worse than throwing up.I love silence!Done! Â Don't know how many of these were "interesting" but at least I got to 30 (I had doubts!).

title: In 10 years ...
text: I recently discovered a blog called Paula's Place. Â I enjoy following her posts as her current life Â somewhat mirrors some of my past and current experiences. Â She is a caregiver for her husband who is now in hospice. Â I encourage you to visit Paula's blog and say Retire Knitter sent you!! :-) She offers readers a chance to share thoughts about how you see yourself 10 years into the future. Â Other participants can be found at the above blog link.Myself ... in 10 yearsGosh! Â At first I didn't want to do this. I thought,"Ten years in the future?? Â I don't know if that is a good idea.Â Â Ten years into the past I would never have imagined I was doing what I am today.Â Â My life looks nothing like I planned. Â The future is so uncertain.Â Â Why set myself up for disappointment, wishing for things to beÂ how your rose-colored glasses imagine when life has other plans for you?"Then my old "goal-centered-self" shook a finger at my "curmudgeon-self" and thought,"You silly person, sure life is uncertain,Â but you set up this blog thinking about how you wanted to live the next 20 years of your life.Â Maybe you should re-focus, maybe you should look at those goals again,Â maybe, just maybe,Â you can pick goals that you are certain you can attain - that are in your control."So here I go ...10 years from now ....Stuff I have some control over.I will be 76! *gulp* (But on the bright side - I plan to be alive!)I will look in the mirror and see only the marks on my face of a wonderful life. Â (If I can't do that, I won't look in the mirror.)I will be happy. (No one controls this but me.)I will be healthy. (I am the main contributor to this.)I will be active. (I will be active, I will be active, I will be active, I will be active ...)I will be financially independent. (Fingers crossed)I will look at my blessings, not my limitations. (hmmm .... tattooed on my forehead.)I will still be knitting, weaving, reading, and enjoying friends and family. (Otherwise I won't be breathing - and I will be at Maryland Sheep and Wool Festival yearly until I am not breathing! Maybe even when I am not breathing I can get someone to take my ashes there!)Â I will be living in a much smaller place with less stuff. Â (Amen!!!)I will live in the moment - not yesterday, not tomorrow, but today!Â (Another tattoo)Stuff I don't have control over.I will celebrate my 54th Wedding Anniversary! Â (I won't be alive by myself!!)My husband will still have enough vision left to enjoy life. Â (Prayers for that please.)I will have my family members close by.I will have healed from losses of loved ones that I know are in my future. (deep breath)And the BIGGEST goal of all will be at 76 to look another 10 years into the future at 86 and and say,Â "Ha! Â Age is just a numberÂ Â and I will celebrate each anniversary of my birthÂ like I did at age 6Â with enthusiasm and zestÂ ... and a big piece of buttery vanilla cakewith a big fat sugary red rose right on top!!!"

title: Through My Caregiver Eyes - the Law of Loss
text: It has been some time since I did a post on my mom under the continuing series ofÂ Through My Caregiver Eyes. Â New readers can find other posts in this series under the Through My Caregiver Eyes labelÂ (Section to the right of my blog posts.) Â The short summary:Â  Concern for my mom started when she was around age 78.Â Â She was independent but red flags began to flicker in my awareness.The path from independence to living in my home, and finally Assisted LivingÂ is documented in this series. Â While our journey through mom's aging is peppered with joy-filled moments,Â it is mostly continuing losses for her and increasing sadness for me.Â For those of you who are caregivers of elderly loved ones,Â you will see yourself in this story.We are all sisters and brothers under the skin.Â There should be a law...I propose that as we age our age-related losses be limited to a fixed number ... let say 5 or 10 ... and no more. Â More losses than that from a life spent building and growing is a cruel and unusual punishment for the aging person and the caregiver.My case in point:The sky is blue, the wind is calm:Forgetting namesThoughts that frequently escape in mid-sentenceOrnery left arthritic knee is more orneryThe horizon gets cloudy:The checkbook won't balanceDecision making becomes a major hurdleLearning how to do new things like email is never achieved.Clouds obscure the sun, the wind is picking up:Social circle shrinks because friends either move away or dieOutside activities become limitedFamily begins to worry about your drivingLiving independently becomes a question in the minds of loved onesYou begin to prune down your belongings for a future move.The prediction is for stormy weather:You move in with family - Â independence is lost forever.You require oversight for paying your bills.You take a fall but no major damage is done.Reaching out to distance friends and family is less frequent.Your car is finally not your car any more - that freedom is lost forever.Health problems cause hospitalizations and rehabilitations - trouble free health is lost forever.You become a familiar face at the local hospital.Emergency Medical Technicians become more frequent guests.You walk with a cane. Â Walking without assistance is lost forever.Thunder and lightening begins to fill the sky:You fall again. Â This time you injure yourself.You move into Assisted Living - seeing family becomes less frequent.Your daughters take over complete control of your medical and financial affairs.Making new friends is harder and harder.Hobbies and past times like TV and reading no longer hold your interest.You walk with a walker. You are labeled a "fall risk."The storm is here and intensity is growing:The recliner now is your best friend - even more than your TV.Sleeping is your main activity - even staying awake for company is very hard.Medical issues become the major focus of your family.Walking even short distances is tough.The wheel chair is the safest way to travel.This much loss should be illegal. Â Last Sunday as mom and I were leaving Mass, she said she wasn't sure she could make it to the car. Â The walk was painfully slow, with many stops to rest. Â I suggested next time we take the wheel chair - she weakly nodded. Â We made it to the car. Â She then told me she didn't think she could go to church on Sunday any more. Â I am not a church-going Christian, but for 15 years I have taken her to church every Sunday because going to Mass was so important to her. Â Her words made me want to cry. Â As I write these words my eyes fill with tears.Another loss.Â Â  Â  Â  Retired KnitterÂ  Â  Â  Daughter and Caregiver

title: Today is special
text: Today is a special day for me. Linda - leftElaine (me) - rightThis is the day that my dear cousin Linda was born.For all you folks out there who have large extended families, who get together regularly at holidays or Â family reunions, who live near to each other and share the fun things of life together, Â ... for all you folks out there ... you need to know that not everyone is a lucky as you.As children Linda and I enjoyed playing together. Â We were friends. Â Our parents were related (our fathers were brothers) and had been close. Â Her father was my God Father. Â Growing up I was several hundred miles away from my cousins. Â Somewhere along the years, family issues separated us. Â We continued to grow and change, but separately. Â As adults, that cousin relationship seemed lost forever.Then one miraculous day, the distance and years seemed to disappear. Â The story and pictures of our reunion thanks to my sister can be found here at this link. Â Joy, love and companionship has grown from that reunion and it still remains a miracle in my mind. Â We lost probably 40 years of sharing in each other lives, but we are once again loving family and friends. Â We are living the life now we were meant to live so many years ago.Â It was meant to be!Â Things that are meant to be cannot be deterred.Happy Birthday, my dear cousin.Â You are much loved!Â May we continue to build many wonderful memories together going forward.

title: Chats on the porch
text: Although you cannot tell from where you are sitting, our chat today is not on the porch but under a big shade tree. Â It is the day after Memorial Day and comfortable - not too hot, not cold. Â The days will only get less comfortable as the heat builds, the humidity drips, the earth dries out, your car gets so hot you get burned getting in, you can't take off enough clothes to cool down, the bugs become annoying, the sun never seems to goes away ... (can you tell I am a "winter" person?) Â LOL Â Oh where is my beautiful winter!No matter. Â It is another day visiting with friends at Everyday Ruralty. Â And there are questions to be answered ...QUESTIONSWhen you were a child, what age did you think was "OLD"?How often do you have dessert?What's your favorite kind of exercise?Do you watch movies on TV, movies from a rental or the library, or movies online?Tell me something you remember about your grand mother's/grand father's house? I'm thinking of something you saw all of the time, like a picture, clock, statue, teapot. or some thing that was always there.1. Â How old was "old" when I was a child? Â I think considered 40 to be old. Â  And if my son happens to be reading this post ... it still is old, my dear boy. Â Oh, and I hope you have a Happy Birthday this September. Â You will be how old? Â Now let me think. Â I was there so I should know. Â Oh, yes, I remember now ... 40!!!:-) Â That felt good.Â Â Glad that was one of the questions!!2. Â How often do I have dessert? Â Every darn chance I can. Â I don't want to get to the end of my life thinking - oh, why did I pass up that Boston Cream Pie for boiled carrots!3. Â What is your favorite kind of exercise? Â Walking. Â I should be doing it more. Â And second to that is knitting. Â My fingers get such a work out.4. Â Do you watch movies on TV, movies from a rental or the library, or movies online? Â We mostly watch movies from a rental. Â No commercials, on when I want it to be on, and no trips out of the house to get them - delivered by the post office. Â Sometimes we watch movies online, but it seems like the ones we want to see are most readily on disk only.5. Â Tell me something about your grandparents' house? Â Gosh, I had to think about that one a bit because I only saw them at their house - maybe once a year. Â I think the thing I most remember (and sometimes dream about) was my grandparents' porch. Â It was a screen in porch - not all that remarkable, but when our family would come to visit (we lived in another state), my dad would sleep out on the porch. Â I think they had a big rocker.Well that is it for this Tuesday chat. Â I don't always participate, because I am trying to become more of a free soul - not tied down to stuff like I always seem to do. Â There are things in my life that tie me down in a big way, so on the little stuff - I like to keep my options open. Â But these questions were fun this time, especially #1!!!

title: I am naive!
text: I just made an unsettling discovery.Last year I joyfully deleted my Facebook account. Â I was frustrated with Facebook but mostly I needed to just get away from a few "time wasters" - Facebook in my life was a time waster.For those who are curious - there are two levels of Facebook separation. Â I can't remember their exact names but here is what I remember from last year:First level: you have put yourself in a "temporary time out." Â You aren't really serious about leaving. Â You want a breather. Â You might want to come back again, just not sure. Â You want to hold onto your account and all the contacts and information ... but you might want to say "Good Riddens" .. just not sure! Â I did that once and came back.Second level: you are permanently deleting this account. Â You are done, done done with Facebook forever. Â Your screen name, friends, pictures ... all the details of your account will be gone . permanently . not to be recalled . not ever not never again. Â  This is a final action that cannot be recalled. Â You cannot change your mind!! Â Be sure you want to do that before you hit the "submit" button. Â I hit that button last year. Â I was done, done, done with Facebook.Facebook lied. Â Apparently FacebookÂ isn't done with me.My account was never gone AND just the past month I started getting Facebook updates from friends in my email. Â I didn't pay much attention at first. Â I saw the word "Facebook" in my in box and I just deleted it. Â I was done done done with Facebook! Â I was deleted . permanently . finally, forever and ever. Â Facebook told me so.Then I discovered that not only is everything still out there, but my account was ACTIVATED and not by me!!Everything is still out there and shows just like it did before. Â Very very odd. Â So I promptly went out and changed my password - 'cause maybe I was hacked! Â BUT there shouldn't have been anything out there to hack! Â My account was deleted . permanently . finally . forever and ever! Done!!Ok,Â it is now terribly evident to everyone reading this postÂ that I am very naiveÂ and nothing on the Internet is ever totally gone.I'll try again later to delete this account. Â Right now I am afraid to go out to my account - because I will get sucked back in to that "black hole" that I call Facebook. Â *sigh*

title: 10 Years - Then and Now
text: Have you ever looked back to the person you were 10 years ago and pondered,"Wow, who the heck was that person?"Â Â I was 56 and didn't like it. Aging was a negative thing.Â My retirement was planned to be travel, crafts, friendships, and fun.I was more interested in pleasing everyone - keeping the peace, putting other's needs first, submerging my opinions and ideas to those offered by others.I was a "yes" person - without regard to the impact it would have on me and the quality of my life. Â I was a working full time professional with respect, higher income and responsibility ... at the cost of my personal time and my family's needs. Â I was not a caregiver. My inner voice believed that mom would age gracefully and remain independent keeping both her mental and physical status in tack.I loved my townhouse even then and didn't desire a bigger and bigger home.My body and mind were sound - I assumed only the best in the future."Today" was only a path to the "future:" Â things to buy, future vacations to take, to-do lists to manage. Â I never seemed to think "in the present!Â 10 years has changed my perspective:66 is pretty darn young! Â I like 66 a whole lot!!! Â It is as young as I am ever going to be. Aging is my reward for not dying!My retirement is filled with friends and some pretty good stuff Â - but travel isn't one of them. Â In fact, even day trips are problematical due to disabilities."Doing more" is highly overrated! Â Less is better. Â I enjoy the present more when less is on my plate.My working life is history. My personal life is my focus. Thankfully not too much damage was done by my obsession with work in the past.With the exception of my mom, I am less interested in pleasing anyone. Â Sounds stunningly selfish, I know, but healthier for me. No one looks out for me, better than me. Â "No" is a good word, if I am over committed, not interest and/or "just don't wanna." Â I am my mom's caregiver. Â Her decline and loss of independence is the hardest thing I have ever watched. Â I still love my townhouse. Â Fewer stairs and less space would be nice, but nothing is perfect.My body? Â In my 60s I got a more realistic view of the nature of the human body - what it can do, how long it is meant to last, and how much work it takes to keep it up. Â  I don't assume it will last forever and I accept the fact it will look different.Today, this minute, is the most important time! It is all I can count on.Â What a difference 10 years can make!Â I don't think any other 10 years in my life have taught me so much.I can hardly wait to see what my perspective is in 10 more years.I am glad the person of 10 years ago is gone.Â Â Whatever was she thinking?Maybe she was thinking this ...

title: Retired Knitter's Corner of the World
text: Boy, when you don't blog daily, stuff backs up. Â Hard to know if any of this stuff is of interest ... but no matter. Â Here is an update from my corner of the world ...The Year of House ImprovementsAfter years of putting off, and putting off, and putting off Â - we have finally decided to do more than just clean the house! Â It started in the spring with trimming the yard and mulching. Â Mulch makes everything look better. Â And then a new front storm door was installed today. Â Coming up we are replacing 3 bathroom floors and some window screens. Â Let's not forget the defective bathroom mirror upstairs that has to go, and the light over the kitchen sink that was cheap and ugly (and new) when we moved in 28 years ago - and has not improved with age. Â Finally the aluminum siding is DIRTY and GREEN (neither color is light gray the siding was born to be) so a pressure wash is in our future. Â Who knows, if I get on a roll this year I might do some of next year's things - interior house painting, 28 year old carpeting that needs to go, kitchen cabinets that have out lived their usefulness. Â We put so much stuff off for so long that we are now facing change after change after change.This year I added some color to my simple uncluttered external environments. Â I have bushes, trees, mulch and some brick. Â That is it! Â Simple, uncluttered, easy to maintain. Â But I love nurseries. Â I love picking out plants, putting them in pots, watering and fertilizing them, pinching off the spent blossoms, talking to them over the morning coffee - I haven't done this for awhile but it lifts my spirits. Â After my frustrating Mother's Day ... I needed a little spirit lifting. Â But I do feel sorry for these small gentle blossoms because they were adopted by the killer of green things ... just saying.The Mother's Day that wasn't ...Mother's Day was an "up and down" event for me. It was Sunday so that meant church with mom, which was an "up" because it is so important to her. Â And lunch with her at Assisted Living was an "up" - the food there is great. Â But her allergies were making her miserable - a "down," and I discovered her allergy meds were discontinued at some point in the worst allergy season in years - a "great big down" for both of us, and her legs seemed to freeze up at times making her very unsteady - another "down" that worried me quite a bit. Â Then there was the sour "icing on the cake" - Â I discovered that a beautiful hand woven wool shawl (shown in the picture) I made for her a few years ago had been accidentally machine washed and dried by the staff. Â It was now a napkin! Â You can't machine wash and machine dry wool. Â Big fat "no no" unless you want a felted napkin. Â Mom loved that shawl when I gave it to her and she enjoyed it mostly during the winter months when she would get cold. Â She doesn't know it is gone. Â Reduced mental functioning has saved her from this disappointment. Â I was, however, upset enough for both of us. By the time I got home my kids were on to other commitments - that was OK - I was focused on getting some of mom's medical issues corrected. Â And I had the company of my kids earlier in the weekend.My daughter ordered me a FitBit Pedometer for Mother's Day which will come in June and I am totally excited about it. Â And my son and daughter-in-law made a lasagna for our Sunday dinner before they left for the evening. Â That was totally yummy and I didn't have to cook. Big thumbs up on that!!I guess the ups and downs finally balanced out this Mother's Day. My Crafing Life ...I treated myself to a new set of Interchangeable knitting needles by Knitter's Pride - LOVE, LOVE, LOVE these needles. Â Go out and buy them. Â Buy them even if you don't knit. Â :-) Â I started a new shawl for mom right away using these needles, and I love the feel of them. Â I am using the same yarn as the woven shawl for mom's new shawl - except I added a strand of purple yarn to boost the color. Â I am pleased with the product so far. But the knitting list has got to stop growing. Â Here is my 2013 list:Mom's shawl - 10% doneMy Autumnal Cardigan: - 40% doneMy daughter Leaf Lace Shawl - 0% done - but working on the guage swatchÂ My cousins' Faery Ring Jacket - 0%My son's Dr. Zoidberg hood and mittens - 0% doneMy Walking World ...Walking is going ok - in a not-so-ok sort of way!! Â :-)Ok ... in that I am not giving up, and I am walking at least a few days a week, and I am getting my step counts up, and I feel better now than that day several weeks ago when I went for the first walk and felt like death! Not-so-ok ... in that I am not yet walking 5 times a week and I don't reach 10,000 steps every single day. Â But I hit 7,000 to 8,000 steps a day most days. Â That is better than the 4,000 to 5,000 I was doing.So this post is the iceberg of my life - the pieces that are showing. Hope your corner of the world is treating you well.

title: Making Room
text: The constant internal theme of my life seems to be "Make Room." Â It has almost become a mantra.Clear those counters.Pick up those items.Give away stuff.Pitch that clutter.Step down from leadership.The last example is the newest in the ever expanding theme. Â When do you feel that your stuff and your life's activitiesÂ comfortably equals the space and the time given to you?Â Over the last few years I have focused on the obvious! Â Make my environment less cluttered. Â As I look around my kitchen I have a long way to go. Â It is hard to wrap my mind around what life would be like right now if I held on to everything I discarded over the last 4 years. Â Flashes of The Hoarders - a TV show about folks who can't let go of anything - pops into my mind. Â The "de-clutter bug" is starting to eat away at me again. Â I can feel another purge coming on soon.Today I am focusing on the less obvious.Time and guilt. Â Today I will be telling my Knitting Group that I am stepping down as their coordinator and handing over that role to another member. Â This group holds a special place in my heart. Â They are fun, interesting, non-judgemental, supportive, creative (big time creative) and welcoming. Â They supported me through my most difficult days in caring for my mom. Â My hope is that today ... after I tell them this news, they will be happy for me. This change will allow me the flexibility to "drop in" as a fellow participant rather than be the linch pin that connects everyone. Â I've missed too many meetings this spring - time continues to be a commodity Â in short supply. Â I need to make room in my life to participate in this wonderful group - without the guilt that comes when I miss meetings.They are wonderful people. Â They will understand!Fingers crossed!

title: Visiting on the Farmhouse Porch
text: Oh . my . God!Â Â Is it Tuesday again?Â Â Wasn't it Tuesday justÂ yesterday?(gets up and checks the paper calendar on the wall)Ok, guess not! Time once again to visit on the farmhouse porch - the porch of Everyday Ruralty.QuestionsWhen it's time to cut the grass (mow the lawn), who does it?Ha!! Â We have no lawn. Â Problem fixed. Â When we moved here we decided to cover the front yard with landscaping and mulch. Â The back yard is a brick patio and mulch. Â No pesky grass. Â I should note, however, that we have a stamp size front and back yard since we live in a townhouse community. :-) Our "fix" wouldn't work for most people. Â We are very happy NOT being large land owners. Â If someone gave you $500 dollars, and you could not spend it on yourself, who would you spend it on?I would spend it on my mom who currently lives in Assisted Living. Â It would pay for only 2 days of care but I can't think of another person who deserves (and needs) my help more in that regard. Â Her life was never flush with assets. Â She saved and led a frugal life, and now we are blowing through that savings with breath taking speed for her Assisted Living. Â It makes me sad. Â She lived with me for 5 years prior to being admitted to Assisted Living. Â You can find our story together on my blog at Through My Caregiver Eyes label. Â My experience was not a traditional "sandwich generation" story ... my kids were grown and on their own, but my life with mom mirrors many of the struggles that others have faced. Â Have you ever taken a blogging break or considered one?Funny you should ask. Â I just came off a considerable blogging break (about 2 months). Â Blogging breaks sort of catch me by surprise. Â I don't know they are coming. Â All of a sudden I notice that it has been a week, then two, and before I know it an official break from blogging has occurred. Â This last break was the longest. Â I couldn't get in gear to write even one word, although ideas would pop up in my head, and I would say to myself ... yes, I should blog about that ... and then I wouldn't. Â I am back now but never say never with regards to blogging breaks.Are you bothered by spring allergies or hay fever? If not spring, any other time of the year?Yes, year round, in door and out door! Â And if I could be more compliant in taking my allergy meds, my life would be more peaceful. Â What's new with you?Nothing. I lead a very busy but boring life. Â Â All I can say at this point is ... tomorrow better not be TUESDAY!!!

title: A book from my nightstand
text: My nightstand isÂ was filled with books I wasn't reading (blogging was not the only thing I wasn't doing.) Â If I wasn't blogging or reading blogs, maybe I should be reading some of my many books! So many books!Â Â Gosh, there must be something in this stackÂ that can capture my attention.What a waste!!I pitched a bunch of them ... titles that were worthy of buying many moons ago seemed boring and irrelevant now.And then I picked outÂ Amish Peace: Simple Wisdom for a Complicated World, by Suzanne Woods Fisher.I can't remember when I got this book ... but it was a theme that caught my attention sometime in the past, and I wanted to sit down and read it right now ... so I did.Amish PeaceÂ is filled with short chapters about the central themes of Amish life. Â Each chapter includes Amish proverbs and facts about the Amish community told through the words of real Plain People. Â Each theme shows how less can result in more ... more peace!Simplicity of life style, respect for time, focus on family and community ... are a few of the themes concisely covered in this small book. Â Although "going Amish" is outside the realm of reality (in fact it is nearly impossible), their wisdom is definite something to be emulated.In my own life, I have used a few tried and true methods to simplify and add more peace to my own life.Back down external commitments to create more down time.De-clutter my environment to make my world seem less "busy" and stressful.But that is just the tip of the iceberg for the Amish culture. Â There is so much more to learn from these people who have managed to successfully live in a way that is simply contrary to "the American way of thinking."As quoted by "Uncle Amos," an Amish man who wrote occasionally for the Small Farmer's Journal:"If you admire our faith, strengthen yours. Â If you admire our sense of commitment, deepen yours. Â If you admire our community spirit, build your own. Â If you admire the simple life, cut back. Â If you admire deep character and enduring values, live them yourself."Well said, Uncle Amos!Blessed are they who have nothing to say, and can't be persuaded to say it.He who has no money is poor; he who has nothing but money is poorer.Use it up, wear it out, make it do or do without.A task takes as long as it takes.Enjoy today. Â It won't come back.

title: Chats on the Farmhouse Porch
text: I enjoy the virtual visit to everydayrurality.com. Â It is like visiting a farm and spending time on the porch with friends. Â Now that I am back to blogging it seemed like a good time to return to the front porch! Â To participate, visit the Every Day Ruralty and follow the instructions. Â It happens every Tuesday, but feel free to come and go as it fits your schedule. Â Answer the questions offered ... and visit others who are sitting on the farm porch with you. Â CheersDo you prefer to drive or be driven?I used to prefer to drive, but now my husband's eyes are so poor that he has given up driving. Â I am the only driver in the family. Â I love being driven now - it seldom happens, but when it does it is pure joy for me.What's your favorite kind of jam, jelly, or preserve?I love blueberry preserves. Â They aren't very common - easier to find strawberry!Do you have any special plans for this spring or summer?I will be attending Maryland Sheep and Wool Festival in May. Â This is a major event for me - sort of like High Holy Days for knitters, weavers, and spinners. Â In June I will visit The Mannings in PA for their annual Spin In (a day long event devoted to spinning wool). Â In August, I plan to attend the annual Knit In at The Mannings (a day long event devoted to knitting). Â See a theme here? Â Lots of folks are becoming aware of issues with food. There are many articles, books, and movies on topics like allergies, GMO, pesticide use, bad or no labeling, over processed foods, foods from other countries that may not have high standards, and many more topics. What concerns you the most? If nothing concerns you, have a cookie and skip to the next question. Â Guess I am pretty trusting about my food and the suppliers. Â I am sure there are issues, but I am 66 and have eaten pretty freely without regard to food safety (other than making sure to avoid spoilage or undercooking), and I haven't had any problems. Â I am trying to eat less processed foods and more fruits and veggies, but that is it.Do you use nailÂ polishÂ often? Finger nails, piggies, or both? Â Never. Â All my nails are a mess. Â I am not fussy in that regard.

title: Lips
text: Seriously.Don't you just wonderÂ what God was thinking when he made lips like these?It has been 5 months since our dear elderly English Bull Dog, Meathead, was so sick,Â and we thought he might not make it. Â And here we are today, with the the best picture ever of any lips on the planet!A reason to rejoice!Happy Monday.

title: I blinked!
text: Wow, that was a long blog break!Â Â About two months.And I had no idea that a break was coming.Â Â No idea!!And if you "blink" ... things change.During the blink (ok, it was a 2-month blink - but who was counting) - I discovered a few things:I missed blogging! (I guess that shouldn't be a shocker, but it was.) Â I missed writing. Â I missed visiting blogs. Â I missed being visited.I missed stuff! Â All kinds of stuff. Â Stuff like: Â Â  Â  Â Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â A good blogger friend was hospitalized! Â Double yikes!! Â  So sorry, HappyOne.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Another blogger friend returned to blogging after a long absence like me. Â Welcome backÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Noofy.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â One blogging friend just picked up everything and moved away. Â Wow,Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Diane, when you make a change you don't mess around.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â My cousin who knits, spins, and weaves ... knits, spins and weaves rings around me!Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Talk about productive, Linda. Â (So I clarifyÂ a bit. Â This isn't new behavior for her.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â She has been doing it for a long time. Â But sitting on your own butt for 2 monthsÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â exacerbates the impact of her creative output. ) Â Hangs head in shame.I panicked a bit when Google Reader announced their departure. Â They were my blog post capture tool. Oh my God!! Â How will I keep up with everyone? Â (... that is after I stop blinking) But now I subscribe to blogs by email - a much more civilized method of keeping up with blog posts. Â So "good riddens" Google Reader - I blinked, you bowed out, and my blog life improved! Â So there, Goggle Reader!Â Going forward I need to be more reasonable about blogging - so I can avoid the "blink" effects.Blog on a semi- regular schedule. Â At least once a week sounds good - thanks for the idea, Noofy.Limit blog subscriptions. Â It is totally unrealistic to have over 500 outstanding blog posts to read. Â And, seriously, that was the number when I was brave enough to peak at Google Reader during the blink.Subscribe to blogs by email - Â I get new posts each day a little at a time. Â Really, folks, that has been refreshing!Woo Hoo!Glad to be back ...Â even if I am talking to myself only after all this timeand all you guys have moved on to otherswho don't have blink issues.:-)

title: You guys will understand!
text: I have a tale of woe. Â I must share because you guys are the only ones who will understand.In November I stopped walking. Â  You know how this goes ...walking every day,feeling good,Â feeling energetic,Â ready to attack life.Normal response for a logical, intelligent, enthusiastic person in this situation ... ?Quit walking, of course. Â OK, not normal or intelligent, but it is what happened.Now, today I took my first walk in 5 months. Â Here is the blow-by-blow of how it went.Stepped out the door in my new expensive walk/run shoes.Â (Yeah!)Plugged in my new audio book to keep me company.Â (Double Yeah!)Weather ideal. Cool, clear, perfect.100 steps out, my left big toe joint began to hurt.Â (Toes in obvious shock!)10 minutes later the toe pain stopped.Â (Toes finally noticed the new expensive new shoes.)Left heel pain starts.Â  (Really?Heel pain in my $150 dollar shoesÂ and my $400 prescription orthotics??Â Seriously???)Pain resolves in about 5 minutes.Â (I should think so!!)Nose starts to run. Â Allergies. Â But I am prepared. I have tissues.Tissues have blood in them. I have a nose bleed. Â (Is this a joke?)Headed back home. Â Walking in the front door, the toe is fine, the heel is fine and my nose bleed dries up.Â (Good, because I was out of tissues.)I can hardly wait for tomorrow!I have lots more body parts that don't want to cooperate. Â PS - Not blogging. Â Just sharing.:-)

title: So ....
text: Hard to know where to start. Â Hard to know what to say.I find myself in an odd position ...I wouldn't call it a "blog fade," but it might be a "blog cliff." Â I sort of feel like I fell off of a cliff back in February when I suddenly stopped blogging.I have spent some time trying to sort out in my mind why I am not blogging. Â I asked myself a bunch of questions.Are you giving up your blog? Â No, I don't think so. Â That doesn't feel right.Are you going to blog in the near future? Â No, I don't think so. Â I am not really inspired to do so.Do you know why you are not blogging? Â Not completely. Â I get ideas for posts, I take pictures ... but it stops there.So here I sit trying to figure out why I am not doing more of this thing ... this thing that I am doing right now.What I do know is that over my life time I have a habit of over committing ... and then dropping out ... and then creeping back into stuff again ... until I over commit again ... then drop out ... and ... and ... and ... Â It is a lot like going in circles. Been there. Â Done that. Â Seem to be doing it again!I kind of feel that I am busy enough right now. Â The priority stuff gets done and the rest seems to have fallen off my radar. Â *sigh*Anyway, I thought I would drop in just to say hi! Â Everything is alright here. Â Life is full and busy. Â I miss being here, I really do, but I can't seem to get my act in gear just yet to write.So ... I am off again. Â Not blogging yet!Take care all. Â I'll check in again when my head is more connected to my neck!! Cheers.

title: Not dead
text: I swear ... I am among the living.Credit: frommycherryheart.blogspot.comÂ Rumors to the contraryÂ are greatly exaggerated!Yes, I have been quiet on the blog. title: The Beach and The Snow
text: Last weekend I was at the beach!I love the beach.I love my cousin.I love snow.It was a win-win weekend for me!My cousin is part owner of a lovely condo right on the beach. Â This was a regularly scheduled craft weekend and it was just perfect.These pictures were taken from the balcony. Â We are close to the ocean.Although I love the beach in any season, my least favorite season for beach visits is the summer. Â See I am a selfish beach bunny. Â I want to look out on the beach and see no one! Â Just the sand, and the water ... that is it. Â And if you go in January, snow is also welcome.The next day the snow was gone and we were left with a beautiful scene.And as the moon began to rise, we tried to get pictures. Â I say "try".Â Â Because as much as I tried, I couldn't get a picture without the rays off the moon.No matter. Â The view was beautiful.Tomorrow ... the results of 2 days of uninterrupted craft time.Pictures of the hand woven scarf for the give away - also included.Be sure to comment on my blog sometime between January 18 and 31Â to be entered into a drawing to win it.Details found here.Today I am visiting on Patrice's farmhouse porch.This is a feature every Tuesday on everydayruralty.com, a new blog I am following.Â Every Tuesday there are a list of questions that each participant answers.These chats are all about getting to know othersÂ and hopefully, they get to know you.So here goes...QuestionsHave you ever been on a boat? (Motor boat, sail boat, cruise ship, ark, or Good Ship Lollipop).Do you need an alarm to wake up in the morning, or do you wake up naturally? If you have an alarm, tell us what type.Have you ever had a yard sale?Do you like kitchen gadgets? What are some of your favorite?Do you read labels at the grocery store?Have you ever been on a boat? Â Lordy, yes. Â Many times but motion sickness is a problem. Â Good boats - cruise ships with stabilizers and medical staff who dispense nausea meds. Â Bad boats: motor boats, sail boats and mid size ships - like the ones that take you out to whale watch! Â I remember one whale watching trip. Â The ride out wasn't so bad. Â The waiting and waiting for a whale to poke his head or tail above the water was painfully difficult. Â Gently swaying, gently drifting, up and down, side to side, with nothing happening ... except I wanted Â to vomit over the side of the boat! Â For some reason on that day the whales weren't cooperating with the tourist ship. Â And the ship was scheduled to stay in place until some whale made a guest appearance. Â I remember praying as I hung over the boat, Dear God: Please .... pleeeaase, send whales! Â Send someone is a whale costume. Â Oh heck, please send a rogue wave that forces us back to shore. Â The trip back to shore was terrible too - they were serving greasy burgers on this tourist boat, AND PEOPLE WERE ACTUALLY EATING THEM!! Â Do you need an alarm to walk up in the morning? Â Apparently not. Â I must have some internal clock that pops my eyes open around the time I need to get up - no matter what time that is. Â It is a spooky talent, I can tell you.Have you ever had a yard sale? Â Yes when I was much younger. Â When I worked out the hours I devoted to the preparation, the sale, and the clean up ... against what I earned in sales, I made about .87 cents an hour. Â No more yard sales for me.Do you like kitchen gadgets? Â Well I don't like to cook, but I do have 2 favorite kitchen gadgets. Â My coffee maker. Â Makes it possible for me to form complete sentences about 30 minutes later. Â And my microwave. Â Makes it possible for me to heat up food made by others!Do you read labels at the grocery store? Â You betcha! Â But the best foods of all are the ones that don't have labels: fruit, veggies, etc. Â Well, that sure was fun. Â Now off to check out some of the other blogs in the porch chat!

title: Dear Mother Nature
text: Dear Mom Nature,We have talked before ... you and I. Last year we had a serious talk in March about your winter performance. title: Grandma is so ...
text: ... Grand!!She adores us! Â So a little introduction.From left to right,Â I am Meathead, the English BullDog. Â I am the senior member of this family even though Grimace is a year older than me. Â You see I was here first as a puppy. Â Grimace was rescued at the age of 3 - so I have seniority. Â I am 10 years old. Â I am magnificent!Next in the center is Milo, the French Bull Dog. Â He belongs to my Aunt Kris and he is 2 - a young, energetic, egotistic, Â pushy, overly alert, and exceedingly cute dog. Â The last quality saves his butt more times than you could imagine. Â We remind him frequently when he is being a "yo-yo brain" (something that happens frequently), that his mom was shopping for a blond female French Bull Dog when she got him! Â Blond! Â Female! How she got side tracked by a brown male (even if he has melty bedroom eyes), we will never know!Lastly on the right is Grimace, the Pug, who is my adopted brother and a pretty good friend to everyone. Â He is 11 years old. Â But he loves Grandma with an intensity that would be considered stalking in the human world! Â  Anyway, Â here are The liver cookies our Grandmother bakes for us every Christmas. Â They are cut in the shapes of hearts and bones. And she doubles the quantity of liver listed in the recipe. Â She knows her boys!!Shapes are very important.Â Likevery,Â very important!Making these cookies in simple circles is a bad idea. Â When Grandma made these last year they were in circles. Â They were cooling on the kitchen counter ... she was busy in the living room. Â Then Grandpa came into the living room chewing and chewing away, asking ... "These aren't chocolate chip cookies, are they!":-)Since we don't like sharing our liver cookies, (and Grandpa doesn't like liver), the shapes save our treats for us.New followers ... Welcome to Grandma's blog. An introduction to Grandma can be found here. Â Information on Grandma's first Give-Away (it isn't liver cookies), can be found here.Sincerely,Meathead

title: Give Away Creation Begins
text: This posting is part of the Grow Your Blog Event.Â Â Introduction to this event and to me can be found here.As part of the Grow Your Blog Event, I am holding a give away. Â The details of how to participate can be found here, but in truth, it is simple.Leave a comment on any of my posts from January 18 up to mid-night on January 31 - and you are automatically entered. Â No anonymous comments accepted.Â Â Leave your blog or email address in the comment.Names will be put into a basket and one person will be selected to win this hand woven scarf.Â And now to give you the first update on the prize I am creating.The fun part of weaving comes after a lot of preparatory steps. Â Here is a quick pictorial tour of how it is done.The yarn is prepped by making them into yarn balls.The warping yarn is threaded into the rigid heddle reed slots.As a novice weaver, I keep reference material handy to be sure I have the steps correct.Keep threading the yarn through the slots until the width you want is reached.The warp yarn is Â barber pole style.Once all the slots are filled, the holes are threaded as well.Then the majority of the yarn is wound on to the back beamand the front ends are tied to the front beam.The weft or weaving yarn is wound onto a shuttle.The yarn in the holes and in the slots is separated by moving the reed up and downÂ creating a shed or space to pass the shuttle through.The white yarn will be removed and discarded when the weaving is complete.It serves to even out the warp threads so they are more parallel.And then after a bit magic happens! :-)Ok, that was impossibly brief! Â Bunches of steps were left out. Â To technical to show it all. Â Most of the readers would have clicked off the page is I showed everything. Â But it does give you the flavor of the process and a peek at how the weaving material will look when completed.I like the way the colors are turning out.We will do another update in a week.

title: Hello!
text: I think I see a new face or two coming for a visit to my blog.My name is Elaine, and in some circles I am called Retired Knitter.I am participating in a Grow Your Blog event, sponsored by Vicki at 2 Bags Full. Â This creative fiber artist decided it was time to say "Thank You" to the blogging community for all the support she has received over the years by helping bloggers to grow their readership. I love these events because I love to discover new blogs.Vicki suggested several elements for the event participants to follow.Â Â Start with an introduction ...Who the heck are you!Â So here goes:I am a blogger.I am a knitter.I am a sometimes crocheter.I am a new-be weaver.I am a wanna-be spinner.I am a walker.I am a grandmother and dog sitter to three magnificent dogs (Meathead, an English Bulldog, Grimace, a Pug, and Milo, a French Bulldog).I am a wife of 43 years, and a mother to 2 grown children and 1 new daughter-in-law.I am a caregiver and daughter to my 86 year old mother.I am retired, and thank God for that because ...I am completely out of time or energy with the above stuff for anything like a real job.Before I begin the next segment (Why I blog), I plan to bore you for just a few minutes with pictures of my "grandchildren." Â I am a typical grandmother, after all. Â So please stick around. Just pretend I have taken out my wallet, and I am sharing some family pictures with you. Â And you, being a good blogging friend, can't back out gracefully ... Â you smile, Â show enthusiasm, and remark on how cute they are.Left is Grimace. Â Yes, his tongue is sticking out. Â It is one of his charming features.Right is Milo. Â Yes, his ears are sticking up. Â He is doing his "deer imitation."This is Meathead. This is how he looks most of the time.Meathead is 10 years old and that is very old for an English Bulldog.I caption this picture as "Sleeping dog with heavy lips."There! Â That wasn't so bad. Â I think we are going to get along just great. Â :-) Â Thank you for sticking with me this far. Â Now we can move on to the next part of my participation.Answer the question ...Why do I blog!It started innocently enough.I discovered blogging through my friend, HappyOne, at Life is Good-Smile. I always felt better after visiting her blog. Â The posts weren't exciting or unusual, just a chronicle of her daily walks and the activities that filled her days. Â But reading her blog was like a shortÂ visit to a peaceful island where life was calm and orderly ... when my own life was anything but peaceful. Â That was July 2010.The blogging seed was planted ... maybe I could have a blog too. Â You see in July 2010, I was in my 3rd year as primary caregiver for my elderly mom. Â She lived with me. Â The intensity of her care had not reached a critical point in 2010, but it was growing in challenges and responsibility, and it was constant - 24/7. Â In fact, I retired early from my job to care for her. Â The story of my journey as an elder caregiver can be found on my blog under the labelÂ Through My Caregiver Eyes. I didn't start out wanting to write about my caregiving experiences ... I just wanted a way to express myself about fun stuff, life observations, my goals ... a distraction of sorts. Â Caregiving was rapidly shrinking my world as I became more and more house bound with mom. Â I wanted this blog to be about the life I wanted and to focus on stuff important to me. Â I did not want to write about caregiving. It was important but private.A year of blogging passed!On August 15, 2011, I changed my mind and decided to write about my life with mom. Â That year was terribly difficult. Â Like the valve on a pressure cooker, I needed to let some of the steam out. Â So I posted my first caregiving post on August 15th - and closed it to comments - private. Â Just a place to sort out my conflicting emotions - because they were spilling out of the cracks in my life anyway. But bloggers are persistent people. I got a few private emails ... readers wanting to share their own experiences with me and to express a camaraderie. Â It was surprisingly comforting.Then I received an email from Doris, a Nursing Home Social Worker, who blogs at Hold My Hand. Â She wanted me to Guest Post on her blog - sharing two of my recent caregiving posts. Â I remember the overwhelming emotions of that moment like it was yesterday. Â One morning ... sitting at my kitchen table in my pajamas, facing my computer with a cup of coffee, struggling to read Doris' email through my tears. Someone saw and understood. Â No judgement, no criticism. Â And this nursing home professional thought I could do something good for someone else by sharing my story. Â (The link to the Hold My Hand blog above, takes you to that post on my mom.) I agreed to the guest posting.And I put the comments back on my caregiver series of posts.Mom has now moved to Assisted Living. I am still her caregiver, but my primary role is now "daughter" ... as it should be. Â I have taken back most of my life. And the experience of caregiving has changed me forever.My blog has evolved as well. Â I share all sorts of things ... my entries are eclectic. Â I have written about vacuum cleaners and tree bark, family life and all my dearly loved crafts, my grand dogs and my cats, my walking and my couch sitting (I won't lie, the walking habit is a struggle.) Â I write about everything. And I still write about Mom on occasion. Â But my life is now more balanced, more normal (well, except for writing about vacuum cleaners and tree bark - how normal is that?)Â :-)This blog was there for me when I really needed it ... as well as my blog friends ... during the most difficult months of my life. Â It was a life line. Â And unconsciously, I think I knew that at the time.Why do I blog?I now think you know!Hope you come back to visit again soon. Â And I will be searching out your blogs, because the real joy of this kind of event for me is discovering new blogs. Â  FinallyOffer a contest!!Be sure to leave a comment - maybe introduce yourself if you are new here. Â All commentors will be eligible for a prize if they include an email address - my first contest ever - more on that next time!Be sure to come back on Monday, January 21st to find out more.Like seriously!I can see it in your face.You know you want to come back!!!Cheers!ElaineÂ  Â Retired Knitter,Â  Â Caregiver,Â  Â Daughter, andÂ  Â BloggerPS - A final picture of my 3 grand dogs - sleeping! The most blessed of all times!! PPS - Ok, so it is not the final picture. Â No sense in starting off our new relationship with a lie!!

title: Band Wagon Thinking
text: If you read blogs, you can't miss the January theme of the month - simplify, de-clutter, organize!!Image: Â julielomoe.wordpress.comÂ What is it about the simple month of January that brings out this clean-up, clean-out feeling in folks? Â Why does everyone jump right on this band wagon very single January?Is it a reaction to the rampant consumerism of November and December?Is it that the pathway from your front door to your refrigerator has gotten too narrow to negotiate?Is it that you bought yet another hammer, because you can't find the 5 others you own?Is it that you are trapped in your house for the first really cold month of the winter, and you are forced to face down all your crap?Â Â "Holy Crap!!Â Â Where did all this crap come from?Â Â Is the crap multiplying on its own?Â Â Have 5 other families moved their crap in when I wasn't looking?Â Crap, crap, crap!!Â Â Guess my new favorite word!Â Â :-)No, I am not going to bore you with my January Simplicity Post du gour. Â I have already done that 16 times over the life of this blog. Â It is not a new topic for me. Â In fact, to be successful at de-crapping cluttering, it shouldn't be a new topic, or a January topic, or a seasonal project. Â It needs to be a life style!So, how is that for NOT blogging about de-cluttering!!

title: Achy breaky knuckles
text: For the last few weeks I have noticed a definite change in my hands. Â Specifically my knuckles!They are sometimes achy.Like today. Â Outside it was cold and wet and my knuckles were very achy. Â Enough that I needed to pop a few Advil!!So what the heck is that all about. I am 65 and those knuckles have served me well for many years without complaint. Â They aren't particularly beautiful, and they aren't knobby or wrinkly or bumpy or crackly. Â They are just knuckles.They have done their job for many years without calling attention to themselves.And now they are becoming attention-getters! Â Crap!Could this be the early signs arthritis? Â No. Â My mom and sister are plagued with this condition, but I have always felt blessed to have missed that bullet. Double Crap!Now I am not feeling so blessed. Triple Crap!

title: Settled Down
text: After the celebration of the holidays and the flurry of activity when my son and daughter-in-law moved in ... and after the Christmas take-down of all the decorations ... things have finally settled down in our household.The new normal has evolved in my life ... it kind of looks like this ...Early to bed, early to rise - now I have working folks in my house, and they are up early and out the door. Â So I am up early to be with my grand dogs. Â No more staying up till 11:00 pm or midnight - not if I want to find my way to the coffee pot and happy dog faces at 6:00 am.Dog walks, dog walks, dog walks. Â All the time. Â Meaty so loves his pee breaks. Â No more waiting for 8 to 10 hours for is papa to come home for a pee break. Â Now he has "pee breaks on demand." Â Life is good.Grimace is my new companion for visits to Assisted Living. Meaty prefers laying on the couch.The kitchen table is busy almost every night - not just on the weekends.Company while I blog and canine editorial suggestions are the norm - Grimace has very definite ideas.It has been a very busy period, but the routine is now settling down. Â And I am loving it.

title: Grow Your Blog
text: Or better yet ... discover new blogs!I follow a pretty phenomenal fiber artist blogger ... Vickie at 2 Bags Full. Â If you aren't familiar with her blog, check outÂ this link. Â Visitors who stop and comment will be eligible to win a prize. Â There is no requirement that a visitor be a follower of my blog or have their own blog. Â The winner will be announced on my blog on February 1, 2013.So if you are tootling around the internet on January 19th and you find me talking about myself - just out of the blue - for no apparent reason other than I like to read about myself ... :-) ... you will know what I am really doing.
