title: The New Year Looks Different
text: Day 2 of 2013! Already the New Year looks very different.Over the holiday period my son and daughter-in-law moved temporarily into our home. Â 2013 is the year that they prepare their townhouse for sale, sell it, buy a new place closer to work and move again. But for the near future, my home has once again expanded to shelter family. Â And this time the Â "family" included my two grand dogs. In fact, as I sit here on my couch at 6:30 am typing away, my two dear boys are sacked out on either side of me snoring away. Â That is their usual schedule on a work day: get up, walk with Papa, get fed by MoMo, and go back to sleep. Â The only difference for them is that now they have a grandma nearby every single day to give them lovies and walks. Oh the difficult life they lead!! Â :-)Of course, it helps that the dogs are here and won't be underfoot while their former home is spruced up for sale and shown.So the New Year is different with many changes expected in the future.I welcome it all. Â I am enjoying every moment of it as I sit here on Day 2 of 2013. PS - I love having family under my roof. Â I love the feeling of a filled house. Â I know this situation is temporary. Â All the family move-ins over the last 10 years have been temporary - as they should be. Â But I have loved them all. Â One day it will be our turn, and my husband and I will move into less space. Â We won't have the luxury of opening our doors this way ... but for now, it is grand!

title: On the other side of my mountain.
text: We are on the other side of the holiday season - and I welcome it each year!Yes, that is me! Â Struggling to the top,Â each and every year.I try to simplify so that this desire to "get passed" the season is reduced. Â  But still my mountain looks a lot like this:Create a "to do" list right after Thanksgiving. Â (My reduced list this year had about 25 holiday items on it.)Decorate the tree. Â Christmas shop.Â (This time online shopping saved a bunch of time.)Wrap presents.Make Christmas cookies.Plan Christmas Eve menu.Plan Christmas Day menu.Plan Holiday Gamer Party menu.Food shop.Food preparationÂ (About 50% food prep done by the grocery store.)Clean.Christmas EveChristmas DayHoliday PartyClean up.Take down and pack away holiday decorations.Update the new 2013 calendar.Sit back and recover.This is my simplified list, my simplified holiday. Â I know it looks a lot like your list, your mountain. Â But I desire a simpler holiday. Â On this first day of 2013, I am in a celebratory mood. Â I have reached the other side of this mountain. Â My to-do list each day has gloriously shrunk. Â IÂ celebrated with a walk, my first walk in many weeks. Â It was short - only 30 minutes. It is a start (I am a big starter.) Â  And my stretching routine - well, I need to start over on that. Â My husband and I went out to eat at a restaurant this New Year's Day ... where someone else cooked, delivered the food to the table, and cleaned up.But best of all, I am past the mountain. Â Now I can enjoy my truly favorite season of the year - Winter.Happy New Year!

title: Pondering the Holiday
text: If you are here and I am here, then it is safe to say that at least the two of us survived "the end of the world."My tree is decorated, the gifts are purchased, wrapped and under the tree, some of my Christmas cookies are made - at least the cookie dough is prepared, and the holiday cooking is in full swing!This holiday has been a very carefully staged event. Â Nothing too big, just the basics. Â Time spent with family enjoying the season, gazing at my very lovely Christmas tree, rubbing the ears of my dear, dear grand dogs and crocheting. Yes, time spend on crafts that give me a peaceful feeling. Â (Knitting would give me more peace, but the project under the deadlines is crochet.)And here is the biggest Christmas gift of all ...Â an English Bull Dog, named Meathead,who is healthy, happy, ornery, stubborn, and loving. Â How dear that gift is. Â In the beginning of November we feared that this dear soul our family has come to love with an intensity that is fearsome ... this dear dog might not make it to Christmas. Â He is well and appears to be going strong! The best gifts don't come wrapped in holiday paper and ribbons!Merry Christmas to all!***Posting will resume after Christmas.

title: Prepare - the end is near
text: ... or so they say.Who says?The Mayans, of course.When?Why, today! Â Sometime today!!Oh wait!Â Â You don't believe in the prediction of the end of the world today?My husband and I went with friends to a museum in Philadelphia last month to see the Mayan exhibit and find the answers to the question of ...Â Will the world end today?Here is what we discovered.The parking lot next to the museum had a speed limit of 7 1/2 miles per hour. Â Not 8. Â Not 6. 7 1/2 miles per hour, people! Â Be sure you take note. Â I bet it is radar enforced!!We discovered that the city of Philadelphia has a sense of humor!The Mayans were serious about their wall art. Â Magnificent.We discovered that the Mayans were very symbolic in their art and writings. Â The museum provided private listening devices to hear shortexplanations of the various exhibits.We discovered that their written language was picture writing - some of which can be seen on the statute on the left.A good question.We discovered that scholars have been studying the picture writing for a long time and believe they have translated the meaning of their writings.Interesting! Â And true.We discovered that the idea of the end of the world did not begin or end with the Mayan culture."The Maya did not predict the end of the world in 2012 - we did."We discovered that a lot of what we know rests heavily on our interpretation of the symbols. Â We also discovered that this interpretation may not be a prediction. Â Is it possible that we have just misunderstood what the Mayans were staying? Here is a cartoon with another interpretation of the symbols. Â I vote for this interpretation!Anyway, we had a great time.See you guys tomorrow!! Â :-)

title: Christmas at Brooke Grove
text: Christmas as Brooke Grove is always a festive affair.The hallways are graced with the red of the season.The table decorations are colorful and sparkly.The shared living areas are warm and inviting.Visitors make the festivities more enjoyable.My two nieces, mom and me.Smiling faces are food for the soul.MomÂ Resident pets are the icing on the cake.The big holiday is fast approaching. Â Remember to take time and enjoy the moments of the season!

title: A Prayer and a Shawl
text: Cancer is a reality that drops brave men to their knees.This holiday an extended member of our family is struggling with cancer. Â And with that comes the chemo that is all too familiar to those who have dealt with this disease before. Â It is the kind of fight that each cancer victim must make alone ... but not without the support and prayers of others.This month I was moved to make a Prayer Shawl for this person. Â There is little I can do to make the fight back to health easier, but I could knit a shawl to wrap around shoulders when tired or chilled. Â A visible reminder that there are those who care.It was my first prayer shawl - and, actually, it was my first shawl ever. I enjoyed the process, the knitting and the thoughts of giving it as a gift. Â The action of knitting it helped slow down time and remind me that this is what is important, this is how I can help, this is how I can put a smile on her face.And I didn't want to box it up. Â I shopped for a basket that complimented the colors of the shawl. Â And it was no easy task to find such a basket during the season when everything, and I mean everything is red or green. Â :-)A gift from the heart ... during a time when we sometimes forget that gifts should come from the heart!

title: Illusive Time and Sorrow
text: Time has a way of passing quietly and quickly. Â I know I have the same amount of time each day that I always have, but the end result during this season is always the same ... not enough time, too much to do, no time to focus on what is important..My walks have been short and infrequent ... a fact that was frustrating me. Â One walk this month the fog of the afternoon was heavy. But the beauty of the fog provided a gentle and peaceful atmosphere. Â A lovely personal space in a busy day.My thoughts focused on slowing of life, enjoying the moment, simplifying the frantic noise of too much in too little time. Â My pace was more of a stroll. Â I visited the water's edge frequently to listen to the silence. Somehow the time spent thinking seemed more important than how many steps I was taking or how quickly I made it around the lake.Life goes on.Then the inconceivable happened. Â The violent slaughter of innocent children. Â Newtown, Connecticut sounds like a quaint New England town where only good things happen. Â A town that is a peaceful as the lake pictured above ... and yet this month, it was a horror - worse than any hurricane or earthquake. My thoughts were in a turmoil once again ... sorrow for the families and this town, and sorry for us as a society. Â Somehow these children who lived hundreds of miles away from my town ... these children felt like our children, my children. Â Words were useless. Â Actions ineffective. Â Disillusion that anything could change this now or in the future.And then I heard on TV that Newtown has been flooded with requests for a town address. Â Citizens around the country were seeking a way to send personal messages to the members of this town, our town, to let them know of the sorrow that we all share with them. I am not sending Christmas cards this year, but I will be sending a note to this town, our town, so that they know - "You are not alone. Â We are in deep sorrow with you. Â We are all citizens of Newtown this day."If you care to send condolences to our neighbors in Newtown, follow the link below to get more information. Â The address is listed below.Peace my dear blog friends. Â Slow down your time by not rushing the days.Don't fret about what doesn't get done.Love your family and your friends.Take time to enjoy the moments of your life.You never knowÂ how many moments you have left.Â LinkCondolences to Newtown ConnecticutPO Box 3700,Newtown, Connecticut 06470.

title: The Monster in my Hand
text: You are not going to believe this!This little monster,Â small enough to fit in my hand,Â this time sucking creature that is now firmly rooted to my hip,Â this thing called an iPhone... is now my best friend!The obvious feature is the phone. Â I am happy to have reliable equipment without worrying about taking a deep breath and slipping out of cell phone range - dropping the call. Â Yes, even the phone function has grown on me. Â I have assigned ring sounds to various people. Â My kids rings are "barking dogs."I still enjoy the audiobooks and pod casts, just like on my iPod Touch. But then there are the other new things that I have grown to LOVE! Â Like ...The Reminder List app - I use it like a To-Do list for each day. Â This little app works similar to a calendar. Â I stack up my activities, I mark them off, they get moved to a completed list, undone stuff gets automatically moved to the next day. Â No more writing down everything on a piece of paper and then misplacing the paper. (I can't tell you how often I did that.)Now I have GPS - I know. Â I am probably the last person on the planet to get GPS, but now it is my new toy. Â I have my son's address on this screen. Â I know where he lives, but I play, I play. Â Someday I might go somewhere where this would be handy.Let's not forget the apps. Â My favorite app right now is PT Timer - it allows me to set the time sequence on my stretching exercises so that I don't have to count to the 60 second hold with each exercise. Â It times me and tells me when to stop. Â Love it. Â I can watch TV or listen to a book while doing my stretches. What is nice is that this "monster" is the only piece of equipment I need to carry. Â  Before I had 3 things: iPod, cell phone, camera. Â Now it is all in one. I can take pictures (great pictures), check email and surf the web without needing to be in a hotspot. I can see your expression! Â "Well, of course you can do these things. Â Everyone can do these things. Â Why aren't you keeping up?" Â *sigh* Â I guess I am a slow adopter to technology. Why do I call this phone a monster? It is a monster because I started out not wanting it, but somewhere along the way I "drank the cool aid" and now I love it. Â Not sure how that happened. I did make one final last stand: Â No texting! You have to take a stand somewhere!! Â :-)PS - Steve Jobs - you will be missed.

title: I do not share.
text: Oh yes,Tis the seasonThe time has come.Prepare for a taste sensation.Do not get between me and this winter treat.It is here for a limited time only.Peppermint Ice Cream! Â It is in my bowl.I do not share.My husband doesn't even know it is in the house.All for me!

title: Beach Trip
text: I know I am behind in reporting on this fun trip ... but better late than never.In November I made time for a weekend trip to Ocean City, Maryland with family and friends. This is one of many trips to the edge of the North American continent (the beach by any other name) - thankfully I live only about 3 hours from the ocean.Camera shutter in the way! Â This visit was interesting because several weeks prior, Hurricane Sandy had made a visit to Ocean City. Â The area really had missed a major bullet because when you hear about the New Jersey shore communities, you know that beach erosion was a minor issue.And yet, it was a remarkable visit.Here is a picture of my sister and I standing in front of a beach dune that was worn away by hurricane ocean waves. Â Pretty impressive, but at least the dunes did what they were suppose to do ... protect the properties behind them.Our visit was great fun ... weaving, knitting, crocheting, pajamas (which we pretty much lived in), wine, crab cakes, walks along the shore, walks along Ocean Highway ... really, it was all perfect!

title: Queen of the Return
text: I am sincerely the Queen of the Return. Â Return to walking that is.I know I am in a minority on this ... but I love winter. Â I love winter walking specifically. Â I love the long shadows of winter, and the chunky coats and the scarves and the gloves ... I love it all.But most of all, I do love walking. Â I remember my love affair with walking every single time I return from an absence!Really ... even if you have started and stopped a walking program, you can start again, and again, and again.After all, who is keeping track!And the body remembers ... so it bounces back pretty quick. This is good time to take up walking. Â Crisp chilly weather is perfect for walking.Get out and do it ... the body remembers.

title: The measurement monkey
text: My life seems to always have been about measuring.Measuring my progress against professional goals,Â Â measuring my weight, my activity, my expectations, my project progress ... you name it, I have measured it. Â And although I have seen positive elements to measuring stuff, I have also wondered if the act of measuring has negatives as well.I follow a blog called ZenHabits. Â Zen ... sounds like something that evolved out of 1960s thinking. Â But it is a site that sometimes posts pieces that ring a bell with me. Â That happened recently. Â The blog post is called "Untrack: Letting Go of the Stress of Measuring." The link is here.As I read this piece I could see myself in many places. Â Somehow it always seemed important to document, to see improvement, to measure. Â After reading this blog post, I decided to simplify and to limit this measuring monkey I have allowed to ride on my back for years.After careful thinking I have decided to limit my measuring habit to two areas:To see accountability in my walking life, measuring my progress in Walker Tracker makes sense. Â It helps me see how active I am and it help me continue to be active. Â Activity is vitally important to my health.Keeping track of my yarn stash is also productive. Â It help limit my spending in that area.But all measuring methods that I have layered all over my life in other ways just have to go. Â It eats up too much time, adds stress that isn't necessary, and does not add any real value.Hope you have a chance to read the ZenHabit blog post.We are in the last hours of the Thanksgiving weekend ... which began on Thursday and ends shortly at 11:59 pm.Our Thanksgiving was special. Â Friends now have joined our family festivities, for the second year. My main goal this year was to simplify. Â I eliminated one big chunk of time by purchasing a pre-cooked Butterball turkey. Â The instructions said to put the bird in the oven at 325 degrees for about 2 hours to heat. Â The house filled with the wonderful aroma of turkey, there was no basting or constant temp checking for doneness. Â And remarkably, it turned out PERFECT!! Â Everyone one said it was one of the tastiest and juiciest we have had in years. Even my husband who doesn't typically enjoyed turkey, loved this one. Â He even ate turkey as leftovers the second night. Â (That was a first, I assure you!)I was shocked, of course, because for years our turkeys were always special purchases with special preparations. Â Since I was taking this short cut, I really didn't hold out much hope that this turkey would measure up. Â But I am a believer now. Â And after all, shouldn't Butterball know how to cook a turkey perfectly!??!And it looked pretty darn good as well. Beautifully browned. Â It weighed only 12 pounds but that size turned out perfect for us as well.Every last bit of that bird is now gone - either eaten in the last few days or frozen in many containers as turkey soup in my freezer.*****Â The only down side of all my holidays now is that mom cannot be with us. Â Still ... those 20 steps that lead to my house are beyond her abilities. Â So my son and I went and shared lunch with her on Thanksgiving at Assisted Living. The main meal served at noon was, of course, a turkey dinner. :-) I wish I could be casual about this whole thing and make excuses why she wouldn't enjoy the business of the holiday at my house ... but I can't. Â Holidays for us traditionally are family times. Â She is my dearest of family members, and she is not with us on these days. Â  Christmas will be another hard holiday for me that I just need to get passed because there is a sadness that I won't have her with us. Â Oh yes, we will take her out to lunch on Christmas Eve and I will take her to Christmas Mass on Christmas Day. Â But it is not the same. It is just not the same.

title: My New White iPhone
text: So, the "big girl" phone arrived.I am now the owner of an iPhone. Â I have always been excited about my new Apple "toys."Â products. Â Always.I remember vividly when I got my iTouch, and my iPad, and my Apple computer. Â I dearly enjoyed each acquisition and the new functionality it gave me.Â For some reason my new iPhone doesn't do that for me.Â I have had it for almost 2 weeks. Â It works like a charm. I can now sit on my couch (in my living room in my house ... I mean really inside my house ... with the door closed even ... ) and make a phone call - no easy trick with my old cell phone which treated my house as a "dead zone." And it is nice to be able to check my email anywhere, anytime - not just in a hot spot.However, I still am not a "cell phone junkie." Â I could easily return to "the land of no cell phones." Â (Joyfully return) Â And the increased flexibility of access to the internet and email - well ... it just isn't all that important to me.But I am ready for the next big storm that takes down the power ... which means ... we should have a mild winter! You all can thank me later!:-)

title: Meathead
text: He is improving.It is slow, but he is pulling back from "the brink" we so terribly feared just 2 weeks ago.This past Friday I took him back to the Emergency Vet for a repeat chest xray. Â My son met me there. Â The xray showed improvement - the shadow over one lobe of his lung was receding. Â The vet could see more heart and lung than before. Â She could see more inflation of the lung. Â That finding along with his general increased energy means that the antibiotics are making a difference. Â They are leaning away from lung torsion as a diagnosis (exceedingly good news) and towards a deep seeded pneumonia. Â His symptoms for pneumonia are considered atypical - so the vet cannot be definitive on her diagnosis.No matter, he looks and feels better. Â He will continue on his antibiotics for another 2 weeks and another xray will be done.He is an old bully. Â Age range for English Bull Dogs is 8 to 10 years. Â He is 10. Â And he is no stranger to many near-death experiences. Â My daughter and I still vividly remember the time he chocked on food, stopped breathing, lips and tongue turned blue, and he collapsed. Â She and I had minutes to turn the situation around. Â The Heimlick Maneuver is very hard to perform on a stocky bull dog. Â But adrenaline is a mighty "drug" and sticking my hand clear down his throat didn't hurt either. Â He survived.I suspect he will be on antibiotics for a long time.It is a reminder that nothing lasts forever. Â I will take every beautiful moment I have with this deeply loved bully and treasure it because "the brink" isn't gone forever either.

title: Spontaneous Slumping
text: SoooReturning from a slump.I now call this period Spontaneous Slumping.I considered calling this Slouch Slumping.And then there was Lump Slumping.A near runner up was Grump Slumping.But Spontaneous Slumping won out, 'cause that is how it happens.For me Spontaneous Slumping looks like this:One day I am "great guns" doing everything, the next day I am not - sort of like catching a virus!One day leads to another of doing nothing ... and another and another ... and then 3 weeks of absolutely nothing have accumulated.My life starts "tripping," and bad things start happening to people I care about and I find myself thinking - "Gosh, was this slump a psychic warning of bad things?"I decide that I am over thinking this. Â  Thinking this was psychic anything means I have hit the bottom of my slump.Finally I don't like who I am in a slump - so I start kicking myself in the butt.So now that I am past the butt kicking stage, I am back to:walkingtracking my step counts and milagestretchingbloggingmaking my "to do" listsdoing the stuff on my "to do" lists Â :-)planningThe bad things have settled down again. Â We are all coping. Â And at least the "badies" seemed to have stopped dumping down on everyone's head at the same time. Working on a few posts to share some of the good things that happened while I was slumping!

title: What Matters
text: Life has a way of stopping you dead in your tracks, pealing away the extraneous in an instant and focusing you on what really matters in life.I will be gone from my blog until next week to focus on what really matters.We had a serious scare with my dear dog, Meathead. Â He is an older English Bulldog. Â Thursday night my son called and said he needed help getting Meaty to the emergency vet. Â Meaty was having trouble breathing. Within minutes I was out the door. Â (My husband later said I didn't even hang up the phone.) Tests were inconclusive, but the x-ray showed something near his lung. Â The vet recommended the specialists at another ER vet clinic 40 minutes away. Â Meaty spent the night at the second ER. Â After more tests and exams Â - the firm diagnosis was still missing. Â Pneumonia, tumor, lung torsion ... maybe, maybe ... Â It came down to treating for Pneumonia. Â If not Pneumonia, the only choice left was euthanasia. Â Surgery in such an old bully is not a humane option. Â Antibiotics were started. Â My son, his wife and their dogs spent a long weekend at Grandma's while we waited to see if Meaty's breathing improved. Â We showered Meaty with love, with treats, help up stairs, and our undivided attention. Â If this was his last weekend at Grandma's, we had to make the most of it. Â The outcome was this ...A guy and his dog. Â Buds!More weekends at Grandma's are in the future.Struggling with the right choices for Meaty was difficult, especially when you aren't sure what the diagnosis is. Â We are apparently treating a deep seeded pneumonia. Â His breathing has improved greatly - almost totally normal. Antibiotics will be part of his regimen for at least 2 weeks, but maybe longer. Â A repeat chest x-ray will be done in 2 weeks. Â We are hoping for good news. Â My son and his wife deserve the "Dog Owners of the Year Award." Â Such heart wrenching choices they struggled with this weekend. Â Thankfully they made all the right ones.If that black cloud wasn't enough, my daughter-in-law's mother was hospitalized and is seriously ill. Â She was in the ER with her mother while my son was in the Vet ER with his dog. Â Now hours are spent at the hospital at her mother's side ... wading through all the issues and decisions that go with being a first line care giver. Â My heart goes out to her as I have a sense of what she is dealing with. Â We are all worried for the family.Just those two issues should have been enough bad karma for this couple. Â But one of their friends was in an auto accident and very seriously injured. Â He spent the week in Shock Trauma with a life changing injury. Â He has a long road ahead to recovery. Â This was shocking news for all of us.It was good to have everyone under the same roof to help juggle the many competing issues that kept falling on their heads. Â Some of the bad has started to resolve, some of the bad has yet to begin the mending process. Â Some things can't be fixed by simple antibiotics.But this week my focus will be family - what really matters. I'll post again sometime next week.PS - If you pray, please spare a few prayers for my son and daughter-in-law ... and for her family.

title: Epic Fail
text: So all my frantic ice making preparations for Hurricane Sandy were an epic fail for keeping the power on along the east coast. Â You thought I was joking about that, but usually when I prepare for something, it doesn't happen. Â To everyone in the path of Sandy ... sorry. Â I did my best.We lost power for about 24 hours. That wasn't the only epic fail we experienced. Â We lost our land line phone service. But, hey, I have a cell phone, right? Â hmmm ... well sort of.I have this simple cell phone. Â It cost $20 for the unit. Â The service was the cheapest I could find - $20 every 3 months through Virgin Mobile. Â  Early days with this plan (2009) I used it so little I had accumulated about $90 is unused minutes. Â I was and continue to be - a low user of cell phones.But ..Mom got sick a few times prior to 2011, and then she was sick pretty much all of 2011! Â I used that $90 quick.Now why would I tell you this story?Well here is the real epic fail of my phone service.My house is a dead zone for my cell phone. Â Ha! Â No problem, since I have a land line in the house.The power goes out. No lights.My land lines go dead. Â No phone. Â No problem. Â I can use my cell phone to report the outages.Oh, that is right. Â I need to stand outside to make a call.Lest we forget there is a mega hurricane on the eastern seaboard. Â No matter. Â I stand on the side walk and make the call. (Thinking Rambo thoughts - Sandy doesn't scare me!)My land line phone company, AT&T, wants to do some "problem solving maneuvers" while I am on the line before they schedule a technician to visit the property. Maybe this can be fixed quickly. (Bets anyone if this will be quick or not?)Remember - if I go into the house with my cell phone to make "the maneuvers," my call will be dropped! Â Can't do that.Oh wait. Â I am not alone! My husband can do the maneuvers, so I yell the phone company instructions to him from the sidewalk (where I am standing in the rain.)ahh ... it is very dark in the house. Â  We have 5 telephones on 3 floors. Â He must stumble his way around the house using a flash light and his poor eye sight to do my bidding. Â Wet. I am very wet.Oh, and before you say my husband should use the cell phone and I should disconnect the land line phones - you need to know he doesn't use cell phones. Â It is a thing with him. Â I must admit at that point standing in the rain, I thought he might be on to something!! :-)So the "maneuvers" didn't work. Â We are still without land line service. Â But we still have our trusty $20 cell phone - which is soon to be history.I think I will maneuver this little Virgin Mobile phone with its stinko network into the trash and get myself a "big girl" phone ... Â I think an iPhone is looking pretty sweet right now!Two epic fails in 24 hours is quite enough for me.

title: Rhinebeck
text: Today makes me want to sit by a window and just watch the rain pour out of the sky. Â Thankfully the rain is still only pouring straight down ... not side ways with great winds like expected this afternoon and evening. Â It is funny how weather can make you feel energized or sedentary. Â It is a sedentary day for me right now.But 8 days ago, the weather was perfect and I was walking around the NY fair grounds at Rhinebeck. Â The Sheep and Wool festival was in full swing.It began with a bus ride.And not just any bus ride, but one where almost everyone was doing this ... so nice to be surrounded by my "peoples."Of course, you know me now pretty well. Â I had to do something a little different.Yes, that is me in the bus bathroom. Â I did legitimately need to use it,Â but I also legitimately needed to take a picture.:-)Thank God that small area had hand rails all around!I think the bus driver must get his kicks by increasing thechallenge level of using the pot successfully.The fair grounds were spectacular. Â No inadequate words from me are needed.And then, of course, the best of the best - a picture of me with my cousin.The bus trip was arranged by my cousin's yarn shop - Gosh Yarn It. Â Cute and catchy title for a yarn shop I think. Â They also have these very cute bags that I have been coveting for some time. Â (I know coveting is a sin, but it isn't like I am coveting something sinful, like some one's husband. Â Mine is a small covet.) Â Here is a close of up the bag.The day ended with a return trip over the Hudson River. Â Beautiful place to have your gy-normous summer mansion if that is your style.But here we are now 8 days later with this ...Actually rain is just fine with me. Â I love rainy days (even Sandy-Rainy-Windy days) as much as I love sunny ones. Did I buy anything at the fair? Â Gosh, yes. Â Need you ask? Â No yarn, though. Â Hard to believe right? Â Do you need a reminder picture of my yarn closet?Pictures on that to follow at some point.On a severely rainy, windy and generally stormy day like today (yet beautiful in its ferocity - Thank You Hurricane Sandy), it is pleasant to remember another beautiful and the fun filled weekend in Pennsylvania and New York - just 10 days previously.It all began with a wonderful drive up through Pennsylvania. Â It took hours and hours, mostly because I made a few stops before my destination. Â But I find that I enjoy driving long trips by myself. Â It wasn't always the case. Â But over time and with a few trips under my belt, I have discovered the joys of day traveling by car as a solo traveler. Â Sort of like a private adventure - time for thought, time for audio books, less stress when I get lost - which I did a few times - it is all good.Maryland has hills. Â Pennsylvania has mountains. Mountains that make your ears pop.Pennsylvania was also a few weeks ahead of us in the leaf colors.My cousins live on a large area of land on top of a mountain in Northern PA. Â Their "driveway" is about 1/2 mile through the woods and up a rugged hill. Â All wheel drive is pretty much a requirement. My cousins' drive way - looks beautiful and is beautiful. Â It is also "Mr. Toad's Wild Ride."I couldn't seem to capture a picture that would show the "wild,"Â just the "beautiful."Looking down the hill beyond their entrance to "Mr. Toad's Hill" is the beautiful view . Â  The hill continues further down another 1/2 mile or so from this point.But the real challenge is looking up ... and up ... and up.And if you look closely, you can see one of the houses just between the trees.As you are nearing the house the road is bordered by a rock wall.A charming feature I have seen in other areas like Gettysburg.The hill is kind of a "major event" for me. Â I decided on my first day to walk the one mile trip to the bottom. Â Some areas were so steep that you had to be very careful with your footing. Â Falling on the uneven rock bed was not on my agenda for the day.And as I was descending the very steep parts near the bottom, I gently reminded myself that I had 2 ways back up the hill. Â I could walk back up, or I could call my cousin to drive down and pick me up. Yeah! Â Right! Â I wasn't calling my cousin! Â No way. Â I am an active healthy person and I can do this. And I would do it if I had to crawl on my hands and knees.And so I began the trip up with a positive attitude. After about 100 feet of walking (do not laugh), I stopped. Â I checked my phone Â (you know, to make sure it was working,) took a picture of the surrounding trees, breathed deeply, checked my pulse rate, retied my shoe laces, checked my pulse again, deep breaths - and decided I could continue.The road flattened for about 20 feet and then got remarkably steep again.Focus, focus, focus.You can do this! Â Just keep breathing.Got to the next flat part and decided to recheck my shoes again! Â :-) Â Yep, shoes were still on my feet! Â Breath, breath. Â Yep, phone battery still charged. Â Breath. Pulse pounding strongly in my ears so that is a good sign (right?). Â A heart attack on this hill was not on my agenda for that day either.And so it went. Â By the time I got half way up the hill, I got my sea legs for this little jaunt and was able to make it the rest of the way up without stopping. Â I did, however, began to peal off clothing before I made it to the house. Â I was still decent when I walked into my cousin's house, but the thought did occur to me that under pants and a bra were really all that was needed in 50 degree weather. Â More clothing is just ostentatious.I spared my cousin that experience. Â I love her and want to be invited back again.Later that day I learned there was a story to those steep and flat parts of the road. Â Apparently my cousin's grandfather built that road a long time ago. Â He build the flat parts so that he had a place to "rest the horses." The man was a genius ... just say'en!Tomorrow .... (if I have electric - remember Sandy is being a witch outside) ... if I have power I will share my time at Rhinebeck. Â Great fun.

title: Sandy who ??
text: Yeap! Â My house is right in the path of this storm.I have been working on my post from last weekend's trip to Rhinebeck and the thought occurred to me. Â EVERYONE, and I mean just EVERYONE is stoked about Sandy. Maybe I should write something about that.Wouldn't it be a total hoot if Sandy did the "female thing" and changed her mind about where to set down on land? Â Wouldn't everyone get a chuckle if she turned a hard right and headed right back to the African coast?Ok, so that probably won't happen. Â But I have taken steps to ensure that electrical power stays on during the storm.Been making ice since Wednesday for the ice chest and for any empty spaces in my two freezers. Â I ain't loosen any frozen food this time. Â No sir!Been making various foods that can be eaten at room temperature. Â We will not go hungry. In fact, we will probably gain weight. :-(Will make coffee in advance 'cause I am not facing even one frick'en morning without caffeine for some broad named Sandy.Filled the car with gas - cause if I WANT to take a leisurely drive around town to see all the beauty of fall - I damn well will do it - cause I will have gas! (Traffic should be down, too.)Pulled in the lawn chair and the bird feeder - cause I am not going to spend money on new ones because of Sandy blowing into town.I am prepped. Â We will not loose power now because of all my preparations. Â You can thank me after it is over.In fact, I have made (and bought) so much ice, I would guess that the entire eastern seaboard is safe now from power outages. Â The big story on the news in a few days will be how the lights stayed on. Â They will wonder why. Â But I will smugly point to my freezers that are filled to the brim with ice! Â I will know. Â Oh ... and I have red wine. Â Best at room temperature, you know.Cheers everyone.Stay dry.

title: New Duds!
text: Hi all. Milo here!Gosh, it has been a long time since I made a guest appearance on my Grandma's blog. Â Time to correct that error in judgement on her part! title: The Virtual Appalachian Trail Hike - Becoming Odyssa
text: I have just finished reading a wonderful book by Jennifer Pharr Davis - Becoming Odyssa: Adventures on the Appalachian Trail. Â There was nothing virtual about this story.It all starts with a simple premise. Â When Jennifer graduated from college she didn't know what she wanted to do with her life. Â She decided to hike the Appalachian Trail by herself and take time to think about her future. Â This is the story of her solo hike on the AT and I found it fascinating. Â And believe me when I say ... Â her journey wasn't simple.I have read a few books about the experiences of those who hiked the trail - Becoming Odyssa is one of my favorites.I found a YouTube video where Jennifer talks about her experiences on the trail that first trip (she has since walked the trail again and set the fastest time for a woman thru hiker on the AT). Â You can find that link here.Â  It runs about 30 minutes, but you don't need to watch all 30 minutes to get a flavor of who she is and what her book Becoming Odyssa is about.Even if you aren't into hiking or walking, I know you will enjoy this book.

title: Clutter vs Organization
text: For anyone who knows me or who has followed this blog ... you know I am a big believer in researching stuff: books, blogs, websites, talking with others with similar experiences ... you name it!My "fall focus" is reducing clutter. Â There are alot of current reasons why I am so focused now, but there is a long history of "pitching" stuff to make more space and less stress in my life.Reducing clutter seems to go hand-in-hand with simplifying life in the materials I have seen. Â While I didn't start this clutter reduction process to simplify my life, it seems to have that natural outcome.In my research I made this discovery ...While reading another blog I found the first issue of a free online magazine called Simplify Magazine. The focus of this magazine on simplifying your life generally. They had a great article called You Can't Organize Clutter. Â I have read a lot on the clutter subject, but there were some new ideas for me ... like:You canâ€™t organize clutter.Â It just doesnâ€™t work.Â I donâ€™t care how many plastic bins, crates, or boxes you haveÂ neatly stacked in your basement.When you try to organize your clutter,Â you are actually just hiding it.Pretty simple stuff, right? Â But for some reason the idea that you can't organize clutter never occurred to me. And I totally agree with this statement.In my professional life I was a big believer in organization. Â I thought there was no substitute for a well ordered professional life, organization made things easier in the end, and I was recognized time and time again for that quality. I am not so rigid in my personal life, but I do think that it helps things run more smoothly. Â But the simple idea that organization isn't the answer to a clutter problem was a new thought for me.If you are interested in simplicity, or downsizing, or decluttering, or just trying to get control of your environment ... check out this free monthly online magazine.

title: Walk the Talk - Steps Update
text: Time to take accounting of what I did and didn't do in my walking program.Â The history looks like this ...May Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  11,133 Average Steps (Partial Month - no real goals)June Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 10,306 Average Steps (Goal 10,000)July Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  9,849 Average Steps (Goal 10,500) - failed to reach goalAugust Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 10,782 Average Steps (Goal 10,500)September looks like this ...September Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 11,212 Average Steps (Goal 10,750)But it wasn't as pretty as it looks here. Â Several days I fell below 5,000 steps. Â Of course, other days I was thousands of steps above my goal average. Â This is why I like to look at averages over a month's time. Â I made my step goal average for September. Â Time to bump the goal up to 11,000 steps average per day for October. title: Deep declutter
text: I just spent hours quickly looking through a life time of greeting cardsÂ that goes back about 50 years.Â Â I feel drained.Sorting and discarding is part of my deep de-clutter process for this fall. Â  We have the greeting card collection my mother-in-law left behind (she died in 1997), and I have avoided taking action on this for a long time.She was a person of very moderate means. Â Her apartment was her castle - it resembled a gift shop more than a home, but everything was perfectly arranged, orderly, clean, and loved. Â And she loved greeting cards - she saved every one given to her. Â Because they meant so much to her I was unwilling to discard them after she died. Â But the downsizing process can be brutal - we haven't even gotten down to shedding the stuff we care about yet ... Â much less holding on to the things that she cared about. Today I tackled that large box of cards.It has made me sad in unexpected ways.Discarding the box without opening it would have been the easier path. Â I didn't do that. Â I examined every card. Â It was fun to see the progression of my husband's signature (and my childrens' signatures) as they matured. Â Most cards did not have dates so there was no way to determine age except through the immaturity of the signature, and the classic look of the cards. I did find some cards that had notes in side - I kept those. Â  Most of her cards were from family. Â There were, however, a few affectionate looking cards signed Steve, and then others signed "J." Â She was divorced from the time my husband was 7 or 8. There was nothing beyond the signature from Steve or "J" (and that was how it was signed - with quotes), but they are part of a life long gone and the details were known only to her.And so I kept a few with personal notes that reflected some history. Â The others are gone. Â Kind of sad. But I content myself with the thought that most of those cards were her memories - not ours. Â I have kept a small sampling of her cards with respect for the history represented in some of them.Interestingly, I followed in her path as a newly wed in keeping greeting cards. Â So, yes, I have a large number as well. Â  The review is ahead of me. Â I'll will keep enough to remember, but most will be discarded as well. Â Maybe 30 years from now my own children will be looking and deciding what to do with mom's greeting cards.My advice? Â Chuck the cards - keep the photo albums! Â (*sigh* another big project ahead - a good snowy day activity.)Do you save greeting cards?

title: Sleep
text: OK,so which one of you is it!Â Seriously,There will be no negative consequences to owning up.I just need to know who is doing this.Getting a full night's sleep is getting harder and harder. Â Maybe one night in seven is normal. Â Sometimes I can't settle down for sleep, sometimes I get to sleep and then wake for about 2 hours in the middle of the night, and sometimes (my all time "favorite" ... not ...) I wake at 4:00 for the rest of the darn day. Â And if I am really "lucky" I can have a mix of these situations.And, of course, I am tired in the middle of the day as a result ... and, no, I am not a napper. Â I have tried. Â My eyes are closed, my body is relaxed, but I am not sleeping. I am trying to determine the cause. I like the idea above,Â because it puts the blame on someone elseÂ (so typical in our society, don't you think?)Â Â Maybe I need more exercise.Nope ... I get plenty now.Â Â Maybe my head is filled with worry. Â Hmmm ... sometimes that is true but not all the time. Â Maybe I need less sleep now 'cause I am older.Â Â They say as we age we need less sleep.Â Â Crap!Â I definitely don't like that reason. I am not that old!Â Â And if you looked at my mom, she sleeps all the time!So, now, which one of you is it? Â And how do I get out of your dreams!!

title: The Holiday Season - looming ahead
text: Warning!Â Â If you are a big fan of the coming holiday season,Â you might want to skip this post.With the beauty of Fall and the magnificence of Winter (I hope ... )Â comes another season that is separate from nature.The Holiday Season.Â (Already??? Didn't I put away those darn Christmas decorations just last week??)If you are anything like me your reaction to the Holiday Season is complex. Â I feel I am facing down Halloween, Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Years all in the space of about 2 months!I know, I know ... it is only September. Â I can hear your thoughts: aren't you rushing things a bit? Well, not really. Â The stores are stocking Halloween paraphernalia now. Â By October 1st Â Thanksgiving and Christmas stuff will be all over the place. Â In fact, they will start putting the Christmas stuff on mark-down by December 1. I have even seen a few references in blogs that I read about preparing for the holiday season."Bah!Â Humbug!"Â Â For the last 2 holiday seasons (2010 and 2011) ... what I really wanted to do was skip the whole thing. Â But is that even possible living on planet earth! Isn't that sad?How did this happen to me? Â I do enjoy the company of friends and family who are in a celebratory mood,Â but there is so much I feel I could skip.I don't think the "Bah Humbug" mood happened over night. Â I think it has been growing steadily over the years.Thinking back to when my kids were young, I decorated for most holidays - Easter, Halloween, Thanksgiving, and Christmas/New Years. Â Christmas decorating was the BIGGY! Â All my regular stuff got packed away to be replaced with green and red, and gold and silver STUFF!! Â (There's that word again.)For about 10 years I have been backing down all the decorating. Â I turned a real corner Christmas 2010. Â That year mom was sick from Thanksgiving until Christmas. Â There were no decorations, cards, wrapped gifts, parties, cookie baking ... nothing, until the day I brought her home - December 23rd! Â The whole month of December I wanted to stop the clock so I could catch up. Â But Christmas still came or the spirit of Christmas arrived on the day mom came home.Even Christmas 2011 was different. Â Mom was newly placed in Assisted Living that December - I still felt time-constrained to do the traditional holiday prep. Â New holiday traditions were forced to evolve. Â And the spirit of the season still arrived - just looking different.I think in the spirit of my new "pitch it, donate it, minimize it" mood, I will prepare and participate in the Holiday Season this way:I will buy a precooked Thanksgiving turkey and limit the side dishes to just a few. (Maybe I will eventually evolve to celebrating with dinner out as some have suggested.)I will buy a Thanksgiving dessert - maybe cheese cake (I feel so bold picking cheese cake over apple pie.)I will drag those 8 boxes of Christmas decorations out and shrink them down to 3 or 4 (there used to be 15 boxes - big boxes - ostentatious! Â To be fair I inherited a bunch of Christmas stuff from my Christmas-loving mother-in-law so that holiday clutter was enormous for a few years.)I'll decorate a tree, put a wreath on the door, Â mount the candle lights in each window, and put a festive something on my kitchen table. Â I will stop there.Â Christmas dinner will be much like Thanksgiving - easy!There will be gifts (I like that part - especially wrapping and giving), but I will skip sending cards (there are a few hours saved!)I will avoid the overly decorated Malls with the invasive holiday music.And I will get mom into the car one evening in December for a ride around to see local Christmas lights - she likes that.hmm ... seems like a lot of bullets!No matter. Â I swear to you this list is WAY DOWN from 10 years ago ... scrooge-like by comparison.Maybe if I stick to only this ... I won't feel like I need to move to another planet this season!

title: Downsizing the onion!
text: I have talked about clutter a number of times. Â It just keeps popping up again and again and again. Â On my blog I have 13 (now 14) postings about de-cluttering. Â It pops up in my mind way more than that. Â  It is like a baby chick picking its way out of a shell - something in me just wants to be something else.So I have been cleaning out again. Â This time the intent not to make more space in my current home, but to live in less home somewhere else. Â We don't use the 2,100 feet of living space we have now. Â We live in about 800 to 1000 feet of it. And what is the rest of the space doing?It is a close, cheap storage unit for stuff that is never used, or touched, or seen, or even remembered!! Â We cool it in the summer and warming it in the winter and collect dust on it through all the seasons (dust that it heated and cooled as well.) I grow very weary of it all!Oh, don't get me wrong. I love my dear town house. Â It is located in a lovely safe neighborhood. Â It has housed growing children, adult children who bounced back briefly, and two mothers who needed help at end of life. Â It has been the home for 7 of our cats over the 25+ years and a regular second home for my 3 grand dogs. Â In the next year it will house my son and his wife for awhile as they spruce up their own town house, sell it and move closer to jobs. Â This home has been a safe haven for more than just my husband and I.I have always said, "Oh, we will be in this house another 10 years probably." Â Now ... maybe a year or two.I will be sad to leave this house as it is filled with many great memories (and a few not so great) ... but I won't be sad to stop:cleaning 4 bedroomscleaning 3.5 bathroomscleaning all the other spacesclimbing steps, steps and more stepsheating and cooling 1000+ feet of living space we don't need filled with things we don't needI want to spend my time differently.Â I have also shifted my focus in other ways. Â Over the last year I have discovered an unintentionalÂ mind shift away from these faulty ideas I nurtured for so many years:more is good (we had 6 functioning TVs - now we have 2 and we seldom watch those)newer is better (used is cheaper - saved $250 dollars on a used loom - "used a few times" kind of used.)expensive must mean quality (we used to have a $100 coffee maker - now we have the $30 one - they break at about the same speed)"want" must be "need" (I used to have a melon baller, had to have a melon baller ... seriously, who really needs a melon baller, I ask you.)Â pricey vacations are the only way to unwind (pricey vacations require pricey salaries with headachy strings attached - fewer headaches mean less need to escape.)Those are small changes in attitude that indicate big changes for me. Â So like pealing away the layers of an onion, I am making changes and sorting through the stuff of a life time - in both my mind and my environment. And this time my de-cluttering is a sign of a root change in me.

title: Sharing the food of the Gods
