title: Hiking with friends and nature
text: The secret to a rich lifeÂ is to have more beginningsÂ than endings.Dave WeinbaumToday was the first hike of knitting friends.Â Â We met for a walk at Middle Patuxent Environmental Area in Howard County, Maryland.Â Â The day was wonderfully cool, with bright sun and deep shaded and tons of greenÂ ... all provided by Mother Nature.Walking in the woods was something my husband and I really enjoyed doing years ago.Â Â We had gotten away from it as his eye sight began to fail.Â Â But I always missed those hiking vacations.Following a path that sometimes was wide,Â and sometimes was narrow ...Â sometimes was steep and sometimes was flat ...Â arriving at a fork in the woodsÂ and trying to decide the best way to go ...Â Being grateful for a path marker that confirms -Â Yes, this is the path we expect you to be on!!Good Job!!And there are always choices when you come to the fork in the woods.Â Â Sometimes those choices are confusing ...Â like that blue arrow that is pointing to the sky! Â Having sharing time with friends who enjoy the same beautiful surroundings,Â who want a little bit of adventure,Â who are curious to also see what is around the next bend ...That is what I did today. Â I will admit my legs from the knees down are a bit tired,Â but my spirit is smiling broadly.Â Â Nature and friends ... an unbeatable combination.This is the first movie I have ever made with my camera, and I didn't even realize I was making it. Â I think I was set to Movie by accident. Â But when I played it back, it was a pretty good sampling of my hiking adventure this morning. Â So I thought I would just post it. Â Here is hoping this works.A regular post with regular pictures will follow.

title: Begone!
text: The declutter bug has taken hold of me again. Â It started with tossing Facebook out my life (which, by the way has been great! Â I highly recommend it.)And then I hired someone to haul away 2 large old TVs, along with an old recliner chair and a short chest of drawers - both of which the cats were using as a scratching posts.And then there is the treadmill in the basement. Â I never walk indoors if I can help it. Â Yes, the treadmill still works, but it is one heavy and large piece of equipment that is taking up floor and, more importantly, life space for me. Â It must go.The books had another "go through" and many of them are going to Charity.This is just the beginning. Â These are just the things that are visually in my way each day. Â Come this fall, I start on the stuff that is tucked away in closets and drawers and rooms that are not used. Â This is the stuff that is not evident because it is hidden, and lingers on year after year after year ...As each thing exits my life, I feel lighter, happier, more focused on the things that really matter. Â Although I see many beautiful images on the blogs I follow - stunning household items that are fun to see - I seem to crave clear surfaces - the look of less. Â I find it more calming.We are in a serious DOWNSIZE mode (again)!

title: What will your story be?
text: If I could have one wish in life, it would be that my mom had aged as well as Rose. Â Below is the story of Rose. Â It is a story that has circulated the web universe thousands of times I am sure. Â I thought it was worth reading again, and sharing with you. Â Even if you have read this before - read it again. I believe we all age in our own way with some help or problems that genetics deals to us at birth. Â Striving to age in your own way and overcoming road blocks is all up to you through your personal choices.Although my own aging goals look different from those of Rose, I choose to follow the spirit and the words of wisdom from Rose.Here is Rose's story ... (working on making my story look similar to this).***The first day of school our professor introduced himself and challenged us to get to know someone we didn't already know. I stood up to look around when a gentle hand touched my shoulder.I turned around to find a wrinkled, little old lady beaming up at me with a smile that lit up her entire being..She said, 'Hi handsome. My name is Rose. I'm eighty-seven years old. Can I give you a hug?'I laughed and enthusiastically responded, 'Of course you may!' and she gave me a giant squeeze..'Why are you in college at such a young, innocent age?' I asked.She jokingly replied, 'I'm here to meet a rich husband, get married, and have a couple of kids...''No seriously,' I asked. I was curious what may have motivated her to be taking on this challenge at her age.'I always dreamed of having a college education and now I'm getting one!' she told me.After class we walked to the student union building and shared a chocolate milkshake.We became instant friends. Every day for the next three months we would leave class together and talk nonstop. I was always mesmerized listening to this 'time machine' as she shared her wisdom and experience with me..Over the course of the year, Rose became a campus icon and she easily made friends wherever she went. She loved to dress up and she reveled in the attention bestowed upon her from the other students. She was living it up.At the end of the semester we invited Rose to speak at our football banquet. I'll never forget what she taught us. She was introduced and stepped up to the podium.. As she began to deliver her prepared speech, she dropped her three by five cards on the floor.Â Â Frustrated and a little embarrassed she leaned into the microphone and simply said, 'I'm sorry I'm so jittery. I gave up beer for Lent and this whiskey is killing me! I'll never get my speech back in order so let me just tell you what I know.'As we laughed she cleared her throat and began,Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 'We do not stop playing because we are old;Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â we grow old because we stop playing.There are only four secrets to stayingÂ young, being happy, and achieving success.Â You have to laughÂ and find humor every day.Â You've got to have a dream.Â When you lose your dreams,Â you die.We have so many people walking around who are deadÂ and don't even know it!There is a huge difference betweenÂ growing older and growing up.If you are nineteen years old and lie in bed for one full yearÂ and don't do one productive thing,Â you will turn twenty years old.Â If I am eighty-seven years old and stay in bed for a year and never do anything I will turn eighty-eight.Anybody can grow older.Â That doesn't take any talent or ability.Â The idea is to grow up by always finding opportunity in change.Â Have no regrets.The elderly usually don't have regrets for what we did,Â but rather for things we did not do.Â The only people who fear death are those with regrets..'She concluded her speech by courageously singing 'The Rose.'She challenged each of us to study the lyrics and live them out in our daily lives. At the year's end Rose finished the college degree she had begun all those months ago.One week after graduation Rose died peacefully in her sleep.Over two thousand college students attended her funeral in tribute to the wonderful woman who taught by example that it's never too late to be all you can possibly be.***Excuse me now, while I go out for my walk!Cheers

title: Cheated!
text: The weather for walking has been just perfect. Â By the time I get out the door in the morning it is in the 50's. Gosh, I can live with that!After the hot summer we have had, it feels like we will have an early Fall. Â Truthfully, Â I am a "winter baby." Â I love the fall, and the spring, but the winter is my season. Â So an early fall and a traditional winter suites me just fine.(stepping up on her soap box:The truth is that we were CHEATED last year.Â Â Cheated, I tell you!!!Â Cheated, CHEATED, CHEATED!!Â Â There was NO winter - just extended Fall.Â Â Ba Humbug, I am ready for the real thing.Â Â Do you hear that, Mother Nature?Â stepping back down again and putting her soap box away)On my way into church with mom last Sunday, many commented on the wonderfully cool weather. Â One familiar face (who also brings a senior citizen with her) said Fall was her favorite season. Â Fall is a favorite of many. Â I shared my favorite season is Winter and she did a double take when I mentioned that. You know, like I had 3 heads or something."Guess I met the one person who loves winter," was her comment. Â Well, I am sure I am in the minority, but I am betting there is more than one of me.But even if there isn't another one of me,who cares,I love winter!!!!I think I will go sit on the couch and take a few deep breathes!

title: September 11th - Jumpers
text: Never forget!Remember the pain!I thought long and hard (at most 5 minutes) about what I would say on this day. Would I include a picture that was draped in patriotic fluff (like the one of the Statue of Liberty shedding a tear while the towers burned behind her) or a horrific picture (of the poor souls who jumped to their deaths)? Â Would I state my true feelings? Would these thoughts and images be too much for folks with a more forgiving heart than mine? Â Would this be considered morbid or in bad taste?I chose horrific because the event was exactly that. Â Anyone who witnessed that day cannot help but be changed by it. Â My true feelings are filled with anger and rage at this terrible event even after so much time. Â It serves no one to make this terrible day a memorialized memory. Â  I did not know anyone who was in those towers, but they were fellow citizens who were brutally murdered while going about their normal day.In searching for a photo I settled on a "jumper" picture. Â How terrible it must have been to choose to jump rather than stay tethered to the building.And then I read an article that said these folks (at least 200 of them) didn't choose to jump. Â The link to the full article can be found here. Â But if you were upset by my one picture in this post, be aware that there are many more pictures of jumpers. The article did address my concern about if this discussion of jumpers was morbid or in bad taste. Â Here is that section:***These are photos with a question that makes a lot of people angry. Reactions to it in the comments section are mixed; some feel that it is needed to "never forget", and to galvanize our resolve in the WOT. Others feel it's morbid and in bad taste.I think it all these things. Murdering people in terrorist acts is morbid and in the worst possible bad taste. I'd much rather think about other things. But ignoring and not dealing with things is precisely what led up to 9-11. If we can't even look at what's happened, how are we going to stop it from happening again? If we continue living in a 9-10 world, where we just refuse to look at or deal with some things, what will come next? If we can't look at the ugly truth, the whole of it, how are we going to respond to it effectively?***

title: The Virtual Appalachian Trail Hike - Disappearing Trails?
text: I am making good progress in virtually walking the Appalachian Trail. Â Since August 1 I have reached 200.7 miles which brings me to Mt. Collins, TN. Many of the pictures of the trails are beautiful - like this one, but I couldn't help be wonder - isn't there a chance that nature can reclaim the trail making it easy to lose one's way? Â Doesn't this trail look like nature is trying to reclaim it. Â There are white blazes on trees, but they aren't on every tree ... what if the trail "disappears."Thoughts to ponder.I am reading the book Walking Home: A Woman's Pilgrimage on the Appalachian Trail by Kelly Winters. Â It is very good, but almost all the trail books I have read about the Appalachian Trail have been really interesting. Â I am beginning to think that it is the trial's story that is interesting rather than the individual experience.Ms. Winters makes a number of interesting observations during the book. Â Here is one that never occurred to me."All of us know everyone who's hiking within 100 miles of us--even if we've never met--either through reading their entries in the shelter logs or from gossip passed on by word of mouth from others who have been seen or heard of them. Â We have a community, a culture, and a fellowship that grows stronger as we all walk farther and endure more. Â It's a long, thin community, spread out over 2,000 miles, but like Gypsies, we keep track of our tribe."It is this theme that permeates her story.

title: Zebra Butt
text: So last weekend my daughter and I visited my son at his campground in Southern Maryland. Â It is a two hour drive through very nice rural areas of Maryland. Â  On our way down we passed the most interesting farm called Flat Iron Farm. Â Interesting because they have the most unusual array of animals in their fields. Â Like the Clydesdale horse above. Â Isn't he magnificent.And there were two zebras. Â Zebras in Maryland, USA. Not an everyday sight. Â This one wasn't interested in visitors. The grass was more appealing.BUT this one, Â he was very interested in company. Â Try to imagine (what really happened) ... Â my daughter yelling at me as I leaned over the fence to get the picture to "pull back, pull back" Â and "MOM, PULL BACK." Â (She is so protective of me.) Â :-) Â I pulled back.Gosh, if she hadn't been there I might have made friends with this beautiful creature.When I pulled back I got this great picture of his butt. Â  He lost interest in us really fast. Â Oh well, how often to do you get see this such a great picture of a zebra's butt.And in the same enclosure with the two incredible zebras and the magnificent Clydesdale was this Lama - at least I think that is what he is. Â He also was into showing off his butt. Â He had no interest in us. Â I think he knew I was a knitter and I am only interested in his fur.Anyway, it was a fun trip down, a fun time spent with family, and a fun trip on the return. Who would have thought we would see such diverse creatures all in one location.Monogamy and crochet - an unlikely pairing.Right now I am a monogamous crocheter. Â Not because I love crocheting, or because I am super good at it. Â I am monogamous to this technique so I finish a promised Lacy Cardi Wrap for my daughter. Â Monogamy is the only way that will happen, I fear.I will say that this darn project tests my needlework resolve. Â If you don't count the 4 times I ripped out my work and started over, and the 3 times I set it aside so I could complete knitting a sweater, and the 5 wash clothes I just HAD to make because my wash cloth stack was a little low, and the learning to weave (6 scarves, 2 table runners, and joining a weaving club) ... if you don't count all those things .... I am making great progress in crochet!!An early false start.I am, however, getting more skilled. Â I don't need to use those jumbo eye glass magnifiers any more to see my work or aim an intense light on the stitches so I can see what the heck I am doing. Nope, when I crochet I can honestly say I look competent, comfortable, skilled, confident. Â I can actually carry on a conversation while I crochet (talking mostly to myself, swearing, making faces, questioning my sanity, but heck, it is still a conversation!) Â Just 6 weeks ago I could hardly breath and crochet at the same time. Â Progress.Of course, there are a few sniggly little details I haven't shared.I still can't read that stupid crochet pattern worth a darn. Â I have been told it is written poorly, so that is my story now. Not my fault.Â And I only know how to make 3 stitches because the body of the piece is just a repeat over and over again of 3 stitches. Â There are some lacy parts coming up, but I'll panic when I get there.Â And counting all the way up to 5 seems to be a unexpected problem. The repeated stitch that forms the body of the project requires 5 stitch repeats. Just 5. Â But sometimes I have 6. Â Sometimes I have 4. *sigh*. I wonder if they will take back my college degree if I can't count to 5 consistently!!But ... on the up side ...I think I have gotten past the "totally ignorant beyond measure" stage as a new crocheter, and I am rapidly approaching "absolute swearing-fool beginner" stage! Â Yeah!I am not giving up my knitting needles any time soon, my spinning wheel is really annoyed to be idle, Â my empty loom keeps calling my name, and I am purchasing a larger loom in October because I am totally hooked on weaving, but this crochet thing just may be a possibility in the future - after I finish this first project.Like maybe this project for me!! Â I aught to be able to count to 5 by then.My next crochet pattern?Current status on the wrap for my daughter.I think this crochet thing is growing on me.Maybe monogamy counts for something!

title: Facebook is gone
text: ... for me.I joined Facebook in 2008 - I didn't join to "reach out" to friends and family. I wanted to see my kids pictures. Â That was where they shared all their photos. Â In 2010, I "dropped out" of Facebook for a time. Â But I came back again. Â I don't remember why.Now I am leaving Facebook for good. Â Many reasons ...it eats up too much time - with no real satisfaction for meso much is just trivia about totally nothingwhat isn't trivia is lots of political posturing, religious expressions, and uncharitable opinions all of which I find irritatingcomments are sometimes rude or embarrassing (even when they aren't meant to beSometimes sharing on social media like Facebook is counter productive.So I am leaving Facebook behind for good. Â This won't make a difference to anyone, so I won't be missed.And my kids pictures ... they send me an email attachment of anything they want me to see.Woke up today just plain tired - and for a change I slept really good. Â What gives??I increased my walking in September. Â Maybe I just need to take a rest day today. Â Sometimes I wake up tired and then get a second wind. Â Maybe when I get that second wind, I need to just use it for something else and let my body rest today.Looking back I can see I am making progress.May Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  11,133 Average Steps (Partial Month - no real goals)June Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  10,306 Average Steps (Goal 10,000)July Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 9,849 Average Steps (Goal 10,500)August Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  10,782 Average Steps (Goal 10,500)September (to date) Â 13,000+ Average Steps (Goal 10,750)White blazes on the Appalachian TrailSome of this progress is due to the mind games I like to use to keep me motivated. Â Mind games are a useful tool in the walker's arsenal - especially when you are starting a walking program. Â In August I started virtually walking the Appalachian TrailÂ (walking north) on my blog. Â And in September I started on the Appalachian Trail on Walker TrackerÂ (walking south). Â The Walker Tracker event is not a race, but I like to note my position with other participants. Â I am in 4th out of 14 (as of this morning). Â Some have not logged their steps for yesterday yet, so I am probably somewhere in the middle of the pack - which is my usual position in these events. Â I like holding down the middle!!At this point I should meet myself on the trailÂ coming from the southÂ and coming from the northÂ maybe in January 2013.Â Â :-)Anyway the double incentives of walking the trail in both directions have caught up with me today and I think I will lay low. Â If I were really on the Appalachian Trail, this would be a rest day spent in one of those 3-sided shelters. Â I imagine it would be a rainy day spent waiting for the skies to clear sharing walking stories with other hikers who are also waiting out the weather. Â A rest day.Walking the dogs this afternoon and evening will do for me. Â I will share my "walking stories" with them.So how are you doing on the trail?

title: Steps Update
text: They looked like this ...And then this happened .....And now they look like Â ....Cement! Damn.The Start.Â Typical Shelters.(Continuing series of my virtual trail hike. Â Other posts found under the label The Virtual Appalachian Trail Hike)Total August milage: 149.5Springer Mountain, GA0 MilesSo here starts my journey. Â The walking steps/miles in August have been applied to the Appalachian Trail.Sweet Water Gap, Mile 149.5Trail and CampsiteI think I did pretty good.I virtually reached Sweet Water Gap, North Caroline after my first 31 days of walking on this trail.I passed the Georgia-North Carolina border. Â Nice they have a marker on the trail for that.North Caroline - Georgia Border, Mile 76.4The Appalachian Trail is approximately 2160 miles long. Â Sometimes it is reported as 2150 miles and sometimes 2175 miles. Â The distance changes because the trail is always under reconstruction somewhere and minor changes to the route are made. Â The trail is cared for primarily by loving volunteers. A labor of love for sure.Usually hikers start in Springer Mountain, Ga, in the spring and travel north to Maine to finish in the fall. Â Traveling from south to North gives you the best weather at both ends of the trail while walking but there are thruhikers who start in the north (during the chilly spring) and go South (to the hot summer and fall). Â Regardless of the direction traveled, hikers can experience all weather types from extreme heat with humidity and freezing temps with sleet and snow.One of the biggest challenges from my perspective is where to sleep. Â I am not big on sleeping in a tent. I have always said that "camping out" for me was staying a Days Inn, a simple and inexpensive hotel option found in most typical US states.Mile 2I would say these accommodations are a step down from Days Inn and a step up from pitching a tent.I am not into bugs or rodents, and you can find these creatures as regular residents in these structures. Â Other casual "residents/visitors" could include snakes, skunks and bears. Â Yes, bears. Â Days Inn doesn't have those!Most of the shelters have only 3 sides. Â Most have water somewhere near by. Â "Bathrooms" can be found behind the nearest tree. Â Sleeping in one of these is a shared experience - sleeping bags side by side like sardines in a can if the hikers are abundant. Â  Â You really get quite a sampling of humanity at these shelters and for some this might be a big negative. Â You know, some of humanity isn't so great! Â I guess this beats sleeping in a tent on the cold ground. And you have very little to pack up in the morning before moving on.***I have decided to track my progress against a mileage chart found at SummitPost.org. Â If you are tracking your steps/miles and "walking" with me, you can find your own location against this chart and let me know how far along the trail you are. For those who are walkers using a pedometer, you might enjoy tracking your own progress on an actual map of the Appalachian Trail. Â Walker Tracker is a free on line site that provides a place to log your steps each day. Â There are many other features that make this a wonderful incentivizing tool, but the most appealing feature are the "competitions" that can be joined by just clicking the "join" button. Â Then each day as you log your steps, the steps are applied to any competitions you have joined. Â A "little" icon (that represents you) shows up on map with all the others in the competition and marks where each person is on the trail. Â Very cool!I have started a competition called The Appalachian Trail on Walker Tracker. Â It isn't really a competition - mostly an opportunity to track your progress on a trail map and see if you can finish the trail by May 1, 2013. Â At Walker Tracker my name is "esknitter". Â If you decide to participate there, look me up and "friend" me - friends are called "comrades" on Walker Tracker. Â Be sure to tell me you are coming from my blog.I will post Appalachian Trail blog entries at a minimum of once a month - but I suspect I will drop in to report my progress a lot more frequently than that.Hope to see you on the trail! Â But if not at Walker Tracker, at least here on my blog.Happy Trail Walking!

title: Who are you ... really!
text: So who are you .... really!I mean really,Â underneath,inside,where no one sees but you!The real you!It is the kind of question that some people find difficult. Â They spend their lives being someone else because -they don't like who they really are,or they were formed by parents to be one way and find breaking those habits too hard,or they don't know who they are because they are so busy just "fitting in."One blogger I follow, Chatty Crone, addressed that question in a recent posting called Â Thursday Thoughts. Â As I read her post I thought - wow, I could have written some of this! Â I wonder how many people can relate to that feeling after reading her words ... or after reading my words.So I decided to answer that question about myself - because I am not the same person I used to be just a short time ago. Â Please check out Chatty Crone's posting to see if it rings any bells for you.My first 60 years can be summed up in one word: conform. Â Raised in the 50's (a conforming period) and the 60's (a non conforming period), it was a confusing and changing time. Â But by the 60s, I strove to fit in and to not challenge. Some of it was in deference to my mom and the dysfunctional family we lived in. Â I wasn't into causing her any more headaches. Â Some of it was because I am (was?) an easy going person. Â I was also raised within a religious tradition that was big into conforming. Â If you didn't conform, if you questioned, there was guilt.Self esteem, independent thinking, trusting your instincts, questioning, self direction ... were not ideas that held any meaning for me growing up. Â I grew into adult hood, selected my professional path from the narrow range available to women at the time (secretarial, nursing or teaching) and married the weekend after my college graduation. Â I followed the path that was expected of me.It wasn't all bad. Â Luckily my selection of a husband was good. Â We are in our 43rd year of marriage and we have 2 wonderful kids. Â I wouldn't change any of that. Â But so many other decisions over the years were tempered and limited by my learned response to conform. When I look back on that point in my life, I despair at my lack of vision and independence.When I was 60 the transition began. Â Mom moved into my home when I was 59. Â The years between 60 and 64 were increasingly difficult years: Â growing care giving responsibilities, constantly increasing demands, changing roles, and, at times, unsupportive and challenging attitudes from unexpected places.Those years changed me. Â It was like a baptism by fire. I learned to speak my mind, to question authority, to take definitive action, and most importantly, listen to my gut rather than the opposing chatter around me! Â I learned to set aside previously important relationships. Â I learned to put myself first, finally. Â I learned to question even the most basic truths of my religious upbringing without guilt. Â  I am not saying any of this is easy. Â Sixty years of habits are hard to overcome. Â But the change is now solidly established within me. Â There is a different me!For my mom, I still do the same things she has always expected. Â For her and her alone, I can set this "new me" aside as it would only cause her stress ... old age is hard enough without expecting her to adjust to a "different" daughter.And so Chatty Crone opened a flood of realization. Â I wonder if my care giving years had never happened, would I still be cruising through my life living the expectations of others and seeking to conform. Just like the zebra in the picture above, I look the same on the outside, but on the inside - I am facing in a very different direction. Note: Â I think my butt is smaller than the zebra's. Â At least I hope so. Â :-) (Gosh, is that a cultural conformity that I need to shed? Â Most certainly!)

title: Better today ...
text: ... becauseMy husband only had a medicine reaction causing his blood pressure to drop which is easily corrected by adjusting meds. He is not dying from any dreadful disease - which, OF COURSE, I immediately assumed and which raised MY blood pressure and pulse rate off the charts. (Excuse me while I go take my own blood pressure pill.)Both cats are now on meds for their coccidia infection. Â And Wally's butt has been shaved with excellent results. Â We can now see his little butt, but more importantly, we can see no poop or poopy mats in his hair. Â Yeah for vet groomers. Â  AND we discovered Pill Pockets, a tasty cat treat that totally disguises to offending pill hidden within. Â They both swallow those Pill Pockets down their gullets without a wrestling match. Â (All those Internet jokes about what happens when you give try to give a cat a pill are TOTALLY AND UNDENIABLY TRUE - and we have 2 cats to pill each day for 14 days, so "All Hail to Pill Pockets"!!)The retail store was adequately stocked with Bissell rug cleaning solution so I can get my carpets back to their normal dirty state without cat poop smears.Mom is now adequately stocked with all those un-named items she needs everyday. She was also happy with the surprise visit on a non-visit day. Â She enjoyed all the stories of my last 24 hours. Â Glad someone enjoyed them.I will be getting my dear Meathead and Grimace today so I can see for myself how they are doing (which reportedly is just fine), but you know how grandmothers are. Â They need to see for themselves.AND, I got my hair cut today. Â I consider my hair cut my "face lift" day!!See, Wednesday is better.PS - I am sure this was way more information than you wanted to know. Â But I feel better getting it out of my head and into my blog!! Â Hope your day is as good as mine.

title: You know you are having a bad day when ...
text: .... whenYour husband almost passes out, gets gray and clammy, and falls into his chair so he doesn't fall down. Â And you take his blood pressure and it is low, low, low. Â And he is on blood pressure meds for high blood pressure. Not today! Â So off to the doctor we go.Your cats are diagnosed with Coccidia and you wake up in the morning to stool smears all over your floors and rugs because one of them had diarrhea. Â And he is a long haired cat so it is alllllll over his beautiful long hair as well, and you can't get it clean without being bitten. Â And you take him to the vet so they can shave his beautiful hair off his butt because it is the only way the poopy lumps are coming off. (Trust me, he tried all night long!)And you are almost out of steam cleaning fluid for your rug cleaner. Timing is everything.And your mother, who was running out of a vital item (don't make me name it here) on Sunday is still running out today, because you forgot to bring her more on Monday. Â So a trip back out to Assisted living must be made this afternoon.And you discover your grand dogs, Meaty and Grimmy, had a troubled night. Â Meaty also had loose stools and Grimmy dug away at his ear till it bled. Â Their papa is taking care of them today, but still it upsets me.Tomorrow will be better.

title: Not an Empty Nest - the way it is supposed to be.
text: Sometimes I feel like I have nothing to say.Then I read a post on another blog and I find I am commenting with more than just a few words.That is what happened this morning.One of the blogs I follow is called A Simple Happy Life. Â She posted about being a new empty nesterÂ  and the emotions of that state in life. Â It sparked a realization in me.I was an Empty Nester a while back with all the emotions of that state. Â I don't think I am now.That was a new idea for me.Both my kids moved home separate times after moving out the first time. Â It seems to be the way of it in this economy. Â But now they both have property that they live in and one is married. Â I doubt either will move back home again.I remember when they both moved back home and I was joyful. Â But I also remember after a few months feeling like this was not how they should be living their lives. Â And I began to want independence for them again, while still enjoying their company at home. Â When they moved out I was happy for them. Â The house was quiet again and I was sad, but this was how if is supposed to be I thought.Now they are in their 30's. Â Although they both have their "adult wings", they would still always be welcome if needed. Â They will always have the option of a roof over their heads in my home as long as I live, but I enjoy my own separate life now, and I am slowing down so live-in family under my roof would be a stretch for me. Â I know that they are supposed to be on their own, and this is the way it is supposed to be. Now as I approach my older years I take care of myself - and must focus doing a good job of that because I don't want them to have any responsibility for me ... I have lived through that with my mom. Â It is a very hard path to travel and I don't want that for them. Â It is not the way it is supposed to be!! My nest is empty only if I expect one of them to move back home. Â I don't. Â My nest is perfect the way it is. Â So it is not empty.Life is a cycle - so it is said.Funny, I don't think we truly know that in our hearts until we live through it.Guess I still have something to say.

title: Another one of those dog days
text: It is now 6:45 am and I am checking my email and blogs.Need to get my walk in before beginning my day.Today will look a lot like this:Leave to go pick up Milo about 9:00 am. No, the last time I left at that time it was too late. Â That darn DC traffic! Â Must leave earlier, maybe around 8:30 am.Get to Milo's around 9:30 am.Pack that dear little boy into my car and head out to see mom - probably around 9:45 am - if I am lucky.Drive north through city traffic to Sandy Spring, MD where mom now lives - get there around 10:45. Â Last time I did this I pulled into mom's around 11:15. Â No joke. DC traffic sucks.Visit with mom for an hour - leave around 12:30.Get home around 1:00 pm. Â Walk that cutie, Milo. Eat lunch. Sit on the couch with the boy for 30 minutes or so. Â Try not to fall asleep.Leave the house around 3:00 to pick up Meathead and Grimace. Â Get there around 3:30.Walk those cuties at their house. Â Load them into my car and get home around 4:00 pm.Quickly run in the house to retrieve Milo and walk all 3 dogs - who all resist walking together in a single direction. Â grrrIt is now 4:30 pm. Â Dinner time for the mutts. Stand guard over Meathead who is the slowest eater of the 3 and make sure no one else eats his food. Â Meaty always needs to walk right after eating. Â At 4:45 pm it is harness time for the 3 again, and do the walk-poop-pee thing.Â It is now 5:15 pm. Time to start our dinner. Â Cook, eat, clean up.Meaty is at my front door again at 6:30, because the end of my dinner marks his 3rd walk of the day. Â Yep, we all harness up again. Â Out the door.Around 7:00 pm we return. Â Time to sit on the couch and snuggle.What the heck happened to my day?Enough blogging. Â Need to get moving. Â Dogs await!

title: The Beautiful Orange Mushrooms
text: Sometimes the colors of nature are so brilliant, so striking ... that you just have to stop your car by the side of the road, get out, walk across with your camera in hand, and take a picture of it (even if people are slowing down to stare at you.)That was the case today. Â I was on my way to see mom, and along the retirement village drive I spotted this absolutely striking patch of orange color. Â It was just radiant in a sea of green.I couldn't believe my eyes. Â Remarkable. Â And, of course, I looked them up on the internet.There were a number of different kinds orange colored mushrooms (who knew...), but the Jack-O'-Lantern Mushrooms seemed to be the closest in description. *****Jack-O'-LanternÂ (Omphalotus olearius)This bright-orange mushroom is well named. Not only is it pumpkin-colored and found in the fall, butÂ it also glows in the dark. Fresh specimens sometimes give off a faint greenish glow at night or in a darkened room.These common mushrooms have caused many poisonings because they look, smell and even taste good. They cause mild to severe stomach upset but are not life-threatening to healthy adults.Jack-o'-lanterns have a pleasant, fruity fragrance. They are sometimes mistaken for the edible chanterelle, which is the same color and also hasÂ aÂ pleasant smell. Chanterelles, however, have flat-edged, interconnecting ridges or wrinkles instead of knife-like gills and grow on the ground. Size: 3 to 10 inchesÂ tall, cap 3 to 8 inchesÂ diameter.These mushrooms are found in summer and fall, in large clusters at the base of trees, on stumps or on buried wood.*****The only difference is that these were not growing at a base of a tree - they did appear to be just growing on the ground. Â Maybe there was some buried wood I didn't see. I think they are just beautiful.So, does anyone know what these are?

title: Talk the Walk - Virtual Appalachian Trail Hike
text: Some people have a "bucket list" ... stuff they want to see or do before they die. Â I don't have that kind of list.But over the last 10 years or so, I have had a small voice inside me that whispers a nagging message."Too bad you never hiked the Appalachian Trail." Â Yeah ... I know ... that sounds like sort of a mid-life crisis reaction ... something you do because you fear advancing age and you gotta squeeze in just one more thing ... hoping to slow down the march of time. Â Some people buy a red sports car, some have an extra marital affairs, some take up running, some live in house boat and sail off to see the world.Me? ... I would have loved to walk the Appalachian Trail. Â Well, I am past my mid-life now at 65. Â But the AT hike idea did pop into my head around 50. Â And although my husband and I discovered light hiking late in life (our 50's), our later years have been filled with family responsibilities for me and increasing visual impairment for him. Â So even light hiking now is out unless you considered the walk from the kitchen to the living room a "light hike". Â We weren't campers, or hikers, or outdoors enthusiasts earlier in life. Â The preparation for so strenuous an adventure wasn't there.Â But it doesn't stop me from reading about people who have taken long hikes. Â Currently I am reading Walking Home, A Woman's Pilgrimage on the Appalachian Trail by Kelly Winters (publication 2001).Does she look 65 years old to you?hmmMaybe in my next life.It is one of many books I have read about people who have thru-hiked this 2160 mile trail on the eastern coast of the US. Â I recommend it if you enjoy arm chair travel books that share an adventure you probably would never take. Â I think it is out of print, but my library had it.Â Then I got to thinking. Â I can't actually walk the AT trail, but wouldn't it be fun to virtually walk it. Â This trail has a long shared documented history with many pictures. Â Wouldn't it be fun to periodically apply my milage to the Appalachian Trail (AT) map and see where I wind up each time. Â What are the sights I passed and the typical challenges of that trail, what can I expect going forward, and how long would it take for me to virtually walk the entire distance? Â Yes, I am not making sterling progress on my current 1,000 miles a year goal - although I am picking up steam (and distance - with more on that later). Â But, heck, it is a virtual walk and I am actually walking the steps anyway so why not see how they play out on the AT map.This new posting series will be called The Virtual Appalachian Trail Hike. Â And I will do my first post at the beginning of September. Â It will give me time to get organized. Â I will apply my total August mileage to the AT and report on what I passed with pictures. Â (I will try to avoid waxing on about my virtual blisters!) I am also looking for an online map of the AT that will allow me to post a little marker on it - sort of a visual that shows where I virtually am. Â I haven't found anything yet.I would welcome company - either with comments on my "adventures" or with reports on your own progress should you care to join me in this walk. Â Hey, come on! Â 2160 miles sounds like a big number, but ... really ... it is just a walk in the woods!Oh, you should also check out A Walk in the Woods by Bill Bryson! (My review here.) It is my favorite book of all time! Â It is the story of the author walking the trail. Â He is so unprepared at first that he makes me look like an AT veteran! Â Great fun.Cheers!

title: Talk the Walk - The Big Picture: Age Well
text: Keeping the "big picture" in mind is very important to me. It is easy to get distracted by breaks in exercise, times when the pattern of activity gets interrupted by life in general. Â It is then when the temptation to take the easy road (the couch) is the strongest.For me - I have really only one goal - my big picture: Â age well, age comfortably, age with enough energy and flexibility to do what I want for a long time.Aging well - guess that means different things to different people. Â So often in our culture aging well means: keeping up with the younger generation, wearing a size 4 or 6 pair a jeans, using the advances in medicine to "correct" the signs of a aging, applying more make up to look younger. Â Sometimes those things just point out your increased age - not how "young" you are.I wish our culture wasn't so shallow in their judgements of its older citizens.Well, I can't change that. Â But I can march to my own drum. All the really "young at heart" people I know are active. Â They are moving. Â And they are interesting people who have active minds and bodies. Â They are interested in living, thinking, creating. I believe aging gracefully includes respect for the limitations of the aging body (that isn't supposed to live forever), and making the most of what body and mind are left to you at any given time of life. Â It is accepting the limitations that nature has hard wired into you at birth while using the rest as best you can.For me - walking is the key to the "big picture."

title: So far so good
text: The Vomiting Queen seems to have missed this little bug that showed its ugly head in my house Monday night - at least so far. Â One night I felt queasy, but it is hard to know if I was fighting off a virus or just talking myself into being sick. I hate that kind of GI upset - it makes you just want to lay down and die. Â So hopefully I haven't jinxed myself by talking about it. Â If I get through tonight (72 hours), I will consider that I missed that bullet.I did, however, make some really interesting discoveries since Monday night.Because no one wants to be sick or around someone who is sick ... or might be sick soon, I cancelled my life - trying to stay away from people and waiting out the incubation period. Â And big chunks of my days opened up. Â  Wow, it felt odd. Â I kept thinking - is this what if feels like to be only responsible for me? Â  I discovered I had time for things like walking, picking up my house, cleaning, weaving, reading. Â I struggle getting that stuff into my day at times.Next week I will joyfully return to my regular schedule (hope my dear grand dogs don't forget who grandma is.)Old picture of the boys - Milo on the left is at least as big as Grimace on the right.

title: Waiting my turn.
text: So we are sick!Well, at least my husband is. Â I am waiting my turn. You know the drill! Â One person starts vomiting and everyone else thinks it is such a fun idea that they start doing it too! Â (Not!)Anyway, as soon as he got sick I could see the writing on the wall. Â At some point I would be next, laying in bed wishing for death. Â So I ran out to the store while I still could, got stuff needed to weather this bug, and then came home and made chicken soup. Â I paid mom's bills that had been waiting. Â I picked up around the house. I cloroxed all the surfaces he touched. Â I washed my hands dozens of Â times.I am ready!I am sticking pretty close to home right now. Â Maybe I can get caught up on my blogging and my reading. Just hoping I didn't bring this bug out to mom on Monday when I took her to a dentist appointment. Â The last time this bug hit our family she wound up in the hospital on IV fluids and stayed 4 days. Â It was the beginning of a very bad year health wise for her.Fingers crossed.

title: Love it, hate it, love it
text: You know, every aspect of weaving for me is such a mystery. Â First you pick the yarns. Â I love the lime green Tofootsie yarn. Â It is such a cheerful color - bright and sunny. Â And love the purple and green yarn that is wrapped on the shuttle.Â Â The colors compliment each other so well. Â So I knew these beautiful colors would look great in a scarf togetherÂ and beautifully match my winter coat.Love it!So I warped up the loom and started weaving!Hmmm. Â In my mind's eye I saw this coming out differently.I think I imagined there would be more purple showing.I think I envisioned something else - something I liked more. Â Butonce the warping is done and the weaving begins, it is alittle late to say "ugh".Better to keep on weaving. Â Better to see the finished project off the loom.Hate it! (sadly)Scarf is done! title: Hard day for step count
text: 12,925 steps for today!It was a tough day to achieve a big number!Â I got a phone call at 2:30 am this morning. Â And, as is typical, I didn't get back to sleep until 4:30 am. Â I think my age is catching up with me. Â Sleep interrupted is sleep lost! Â When I was younger I could go back to sleep with no problem. Â Not now.So when I got up this morning, I skipped my Tuesday Morning Knitting Group. Â I decided to spend my last precious energy of the day in a morning walk. Â It was productive. Â I felt pretty good while walking.But later ... when not walking ... slump, slump, slump!! Â I tried to nap! Â Never happens. Â I am just not a napper! I did spend some time just laying on the couch!So the fact I made over 12,000 steps today is a miracle!Tonight? Â A "benedryl and Advil cocktail" to ensure good sleep. Â Tomorrow? Â A morning walk! Yeah!!!I am so close to finished on the sweater - it is almost hard to believe.Â Â I started the project in October 2011 and want it done for that winter.Â Â Silly me.Â Â Here is hoping it is done for this winter.Â All the actual knitting is done.Â Â I have to sew on these pretty buttons - a perfect match for the color of the sweater.I have to tie in all the loose ends.But the button holes are not satisfactory. Â I always make terrible button holes. Â I actually got out my books to look for new options in creating these holes. Â I'll try to put an edge on the holes to neaten them up some. Â If that doesn't look good, I will sew up holes and put loops on the band opposite the buttons. Â That worked well on another sweater.The real question is ... how long will it take for me to do that! Â These are not the fun steps that are left!The fun steps were making these beautiful cables.One note: the color looks orange. Â It is not. It is red. Â I couldn't find lighting that would show the colors correctly.I am also making some dish cloths. Â I love knitted dish cloths.Â They do a fabulous job as cleaner-uppers in the kitchen and they are mindless, fun and quick to make. Â Instant gratification. Â Well, instant as in a day or two as opposed to 11 months for a sweater!!I will also get back very soon to a crochet wrap I started for my daughter. Â Another project that I want done for this winter!!

title: The Juicer
text: I am a big believer in the idea:"If you can buy something as good or better than you can make,Â buy it. Â Save your precious life moments for something that can't be bought." Â Since my favorite room in the house is NOT the kitchen, I amend that statement to describe food:Â "If you can buy something nearly as good as you can make,Â buy it."Now ... meet the Juicer!This piece of equipment doesn't make something that is nearly as good or better than good. Â It makes something that is so much superior to what you can buy, that the name "juice" shouldn't be used to describe it.Just like the "juice" from grapes is called "wine," this produce fluid should have its own name.During a recent visit my cousin brought along her Juicer. Â This piece of equipment is part of her new focus to eat better and to feel better. Â Every morning she produces this wonderful fluid for her breakfast (I won't call it juice because that label is just so misleading.) It takes some time to prep the vegs and fruits, but once that step is done, it is quick work to produce the most yummy beverage that is amazingly filling and tastefully satisfying ... and healthy as well.***Oh, and colorful! Â Something that colorful has to be good!

title: Sizing Down
text: Yesterday I stabbed the Evil Clutter Fairy to death. Â I have done this many times in the past. Â I guess fairies are immortal. Â The Clutter Fairy most certainly is.I get the feeling to reduce my stuff probably once a year. Â The "stuff" around me becomes too much. Â It seems to close in and make my living space smaller and smaller. Â And then the "need" hits and I start the down sizing cycle again. Sometimes my efforts center on one room - like the kitchen. Â Not this day. My one extravagance in life is my yarn and fiber crafts. Â Tools, yarn, fiber, equipment, patterns, books ... Â it has taken over one whole room so you know it is serious. Â I like this room to look organized. Â I live with the impression (not the reality) that I can find what I need in that room because I just reorganized it this spring. The room is small, only 8'x10', so if I need something, it most certainly can be found.Yesterday that impression was tested. Â I tried to find a knitting pattern. Â One pattern. Â It was probably 5 sheets of paper clipped together. Â No luck. Â Ridiculous! Â I was just using it. Â It is right in this one little space - a small book case - in this small room. Â No luck.This book case has about 40 books and five binders - filled with patterns I have clipped over the years - all categorized for ease of use. Â But still. No pattern. On top of this book case was a stack about 18 inches high of patterns I had yet to file away. Â Eighteen inches is a lot of patterns. Â I looked through the stack. Â No pattern. Then the thought hit. Â Even if I lived another 25 years, I wouldn't knit all the patterns in that stack or in the binders. Â Time to thin this space out.I went through every single pattern. Â My God! Â What ever was I thinking. Â Some of those patterns were butt ugly. Â Some patterns would look good if I was a size 2. (Not!) Â Really ... that pattern has no shape. Â Holy Moly! Â I would go crazy with boredom knitting that pattern! Â  And so it went.Four hours and a huge bag of paper recycling later, the patterns were thinned out and all were filed. Â And the one pattern that I wanted still wasn't found. I guess it truly wasn't there. You know, I feel so much better.But I can feel the Evil Clutter Fairy rising from the dead again! Looking around! Â Yep, time to clean out another spot!

title: Two walk day - 17,000 steps
text: July was a pretty tough month for walking steps. Â It was hot!! And early in the month I was on an unofficial vacation from life - no blogging, no walking. Â I still tracked my steps, but I made no effort to bump up my totals. Â As a result I didn't reach my July goal of 10,500 daily steps average for the month. Â My 30 day average was approximately 9,900 steps - ok, just not at goal.So the August goal is a repeat - 10,500 daily steps average.But today, the last day of July, I wanted to go out with a "bang." Â With my 30 minutes of stretching (conversion steps) and my 2 long walks today, I reached 17,000 steps! Â That is a record for me since Â May. Â (My all time record was 31,000+ steps in one day back in 2009.)Anyway, I am pleased that I ended the month well.Finally, I am looking forward to Fall and Winter (my favorite season). Â If I can keep focused, keep increasing my step totals, keep increasing my physical endurance now ... the fall should be great. Less heat, better endurance!!

title: Weaving
text: I own a rigid heddle loom - aÂ Kromski Harp - 16" wide. Â And the more that I use it, the more I want to use it.But it has been a slow road to climb and I am a novice. Â I bought my loom in May 2011 (yes, over a year ago), in a desperate attempt to keep connected to all things yarn (knitting had sadly slipped off my radar in 2011.) Â It was that kind of year.My dear cousin assembled the loom that May 2011 and helped me get it warped up. Â I finished that first project in January 2012 when I saw her again (May to January - a casual weaver could complete 10 scarves in that time.) Â Hem stitch on edgeObviously desperate attempts are exactly that. Â Desperate. Â But in 2012 the complexities of my life began to clear, and I took up the loom once again. Â I am joyfully hooked to weaving. I love my loom. Â I am eager to weave and to warp up new projects. Â I am still a rookie, but I know this hobby has now put its stamp on me! Â I am many scarves into this craft. Â I am now working on a table runner (pictured here). Â It is turning out problematically but I am learning from it.I am haunting web sites looking for another Harp - this time 32" wide - so that I can make a broader range of projects. Â I will get the stand that hold the loom because 32" wide is to big a loom to brace against a table.Â And I joined a weaving club. Â Spunky Eclectic Weaving Club. Â A club project is sent to you every other month. Â Each time the project and the skills used are different. Â It will is a good way to expand my skill level with this new craft.Like a bug bite that needs to be scratched ... I am now weaving.Someday - maybe this year - I will get out that beautiful spinning wheel that I named Agatha back in 2010 - a Kromski Sonata - and take care of that spinning itch that has not left my radar.

title: Talk the Walk - Mind Games
text: Other than a good pair of walking shoes, you don't need much to walk.That is why I like it.I step out my door and I am walking.So why are mind games important. Â After a time the mind gets bored (mine does) and starts working against you, trying to engage you in other things so that it is happier. Â The mind has good intentions but it doesn't benefit your body.The most obvious method that works for most people is reading about walking. Â I won't suggest reading materials here but they abound. Â Just do an Amazon or Library search on the words "walking exercise" and you'll have your pick!One of my favorite games is my pedometer. Â Currently I am using the Striiv Pedometer, and I have blogged about it here. Â But generally any step counter will work if you are new to the idea of "counting your steps."It is simple. Â The more steps you take, the more you have moved. Â Yes, getting your heart rate up for a specific period of time increases the health benefits, but it all starts with moving. Â You can't lie about how much you have moved if your step count for the day is around 2,000 steps instead of 10,000 steps (the recommended number of steps needed each day for good health.) Â And if you think 10,000 steps a day is enormous, look to the Amish. Â Pedometer studies have shown that the Amish take an average of 18,000 a day. Â An average!!For me: I am trying to do 10,500 steps in July. Â I won't make it. Â I had too many days below 10,000 earlier in the month, but August is another month and I will make it then. Â And then I will move the bar - September might be 10,750 steps. Â The goal is to keep moving and keep increasing. Â The pedometer keeps me honest. Â And my brain likes to beat my last step number.Another brain game I particularly like is Walker Tracker - a free online site where you can log your steps each day. Â Walker Tracker is almost like a Facebook for walkers. Â You can do the minimum which is log your steps each day - and see trends and stats from that simple action alone. Â You can also bump up your participation by blogging some on the site, or making friends called "comrades" (I am esknitter there), you can get information about walking in the discussion groups, you can see ratings for pedometers, you can join like-minded groups on that site (Walking Women of 60, Audiobook Listeners, Weight Loss, Walking Knitters, etc. all with the option of sharing information). Â But the reason I am on this site is for the "competitions." Â The map below shows a graphic representation of a competition - walking the Oregon Trail. Â If you join the competition, your little avatar shows up on a map letting you know where you are in the walk and how far to the finish, what your rank is, etc. Â Great fun. Â There are no prizes for winning, just the satisfaction of participating. Â Check out Walker Tracker if it sounds like something you would enjoy. Â Look up esknitter - and make me your comrade!Writing about walking on my blog (yes, doing what I am doing right now), helps me. Â I love taking pictures on my walk. The paths I take are pretty much the same each day, but the pictures I capture are the snapshot in time of something I saw. Â I enjoy reading blogs that do this as well - like Life is Good-Smile, my dear blogging friend Happy One, who walks 6 + miles each day in all kinds of weather. Â Happy One has been doing this for over 25 years. Â She has risen to a new level - she walk for the joy of walking - I hope to be there someday. Volks Marching has recently caught my attention. I don't know enough about it to say much now, but I will share what I find out at some point. Â It is a new mind game for me. Â And finding new minds games is as important as participating in old ones. Â Remember, the mind gets bored!Audio books are a regular part of my life - especially while walking. Â I couldn't read as many books as I can listen to. Â There are so many great reads out there and they are often enhanced by a talented reader. So those are my current mind games - and I am always looking for more. Â Share what works for you.

title: Morning Light
text: You might wonder how I would know anything about morning light. My normal day begins around 7:00 am with a stumble to the bathroom, and a stagger to the coffee pot, and a slump over the lap top while I sit at my kitchen table ... all in an effort to get my brain Â coordinated with my body before I must interact with other beings I share the earth with ... like around 9:00 am.Yes, until recently that was the sad state of my early morning.But intense heat this summer has changed all that. Now if I walk it is in the morning right after coffee.And so, I know about morning light. Â It was a wonderful discovery. Â The walk starts slowly because the caffeine has not yet reached my extremities as I step out the door. Â But within 10 minutes my focus has shifted from my back, my knees, my elbow, my knuckle ... to my stride and my surroundings, and the morning lightÂ ... like this.Â You miss a lot if you wait to long too step out the door.Â Best of Luck to all the Olympians of the 2012 Summer Olympics.I think of you during my morning walk.

title: Through my Caregiver Eyes - A visit
text: Most weeks include 3 or 4 visits to see mom. Â In December of 2011, I was forced to place my mom in Assisted Living. Â (The story of our journey over the terrible times from November 2010 to December of 2012 are found under the heading - Through My Caregiver Eyes on this blog.) Â That move was a hard and tearful decision for me, but she no longer had the strength to climb the 20 steps into my house.Â We were lucky enough to get her into Brooke Grove Assisted Living - the same organization that had provided her rehab on several occasions.And so my regular visits to Brooke Grove continue.And many days my dear grand-dog, Milo, comes with me. Â Look at that face. Â Look at that bone. Â He is such a welcome little soul during my visits with mom. Â In fact, when I show up without Milo, staff asks how Milo is doing!!And he is an "attention sponge." Â If you have a free hand for scratching, he is there!Mom's adjustment for the most part has been wonderful. Â She no longer peppers me with questions about when she is going home. Â She thinks of Brooke Grove as "home." Â And I am grateful. Of course, a little part of me is sad that she cannot be home with me. Â Sad that she cannot pick up the threads of the life she had before all the loss. Â That same little part worries that she doesn't ask any more about going home because she has given up. Â And it is just part of a long list of things I have sadly watched her give up over the last 5 years. I know that she doesn't feel this sadness. Â It is my sadness at experiencing all her loss. Â Now her life settles around a very few things. Â Visits from her family and weekly Mass on Sunday. Â I can do that for you mom.You don't need to give up those things as well.

title: God as a Neighbor
text: My daughter moved into her first condo - first purchase of property. The end of June I spent the weekend with her - cleaning, unpacking, getting settled.And, of course, I was checking out my daughter's neighborhood ...the place were she will live and walk her dog. Â The place where I want her to be safe.I am happy to report, she picked very well.My daughter now lives in the best neighborhood.Her neighbor is God.The National CathedralSeriously, I am not kidding.This is the view out her living room and bedroom windows.See - right between Milo's ears?Even at night, the view is beautiful.And the rest of the neighborhood is just as great!Yes, there is an apartment development with my name on it!!Apartments with style abound.The neighborhoods behind her building are residential and beautiful.After years of moving all over the area,Â I think my daughter (and Milo) have finally settled in a great place.A beautiful area.

title: The Anniversary That Was ...
text: Dear Blog,Retired Knitter here!On July 20th I missed your 2 year Blog Anniversary. Â  Â I feel bad about that - like I had missed one of my children's birthdays or something! What kind of a blog owner am I if I could miss that kind of event?After all the help you have given me over these past years, I am shamed faced that I didn't discover my error a few days earlier.You were born when when my thoughts and emotions threatened to explode if they didn't go somewhere. Â You were there when it was just you and me and no one else. Â You were there when blog friends started to show up to share my life, to lift my spirits, to make me smile, and to surprise me with their sharing. Â You were there (sitting patiently) while I zoned out and didn't write for weeks.Now 514 postings and 127 followers later, you are still there. Â And thankfully so are many of those blog friends.So Happy Anniversary my dear blog (a few days late.) title: A Pause - brought to you by Mother Nature
text: Ok, that storm a week ago was note worthy.Photo from WikipediaCalled a Derecho, this weather front is what brought our region to its knees more effectively than any hurricane. Â As of this writing, there are still people across our area without power. Â Thankfully, our power returned earlier in the week. Â But storm recovery isn't all about the return of power. Â Some unlucky folks had severe house damage, large downed trees and smashed cars.We were lucky. Â We only needed to clean up the refrigerator and the freezers. Â But this event did give pause to think:I was raised without air conditioning. Â Apparently I can't live without it now. Â Crazy!I had way too much food in the house for 2 people. Â What gives with that? Â I am totally disgusted with human nature. Â It was reported by the news that although most people welcomed the electric crews into their neighborhoods, some crews had fireworks thrown at them while they tried to make repairs. Â We need to weed out these defective humans now before they reproduce and create others of their kind. Â These defectives need to be isolated on an island in the equator with no electric!! Â Or better yet, tie those thoughtless individuals up on the top of a power line in 100+ degree heat for 12 hours ... and see how it feels to do that kind of work.I love big weather events. Â A Derecho isn't one of them.Next time: local pictures

title: Storm aftermath
text: Our area was hit by mega storms on Friday night. Â My electric power is out! Â Besides the fact we have no juice to power our computer (you can't imagine the withdrawal symptoms), we have no air conditioning!! Â It is amazing to me that I grew up without air conditioning. Â With temperatures reaching 100 to 103 ... we have been struggling. But we are fine, our home is fine, our family is fine, all our pets are fine ... we are blessed! I am briefly using my son's home for a web connection (and his wonderful air conditioning)!It will be several days before we have electric - probably next weekend if the news reports are to be believed. Â It was a regional event and more than a million folks were affected. Â  Once we are powered up, we will be cleaning out our fridge and freezer - and shopping for replacement stuff. Â So postings will be spotty for awhile.Cheers!!

title: My Soul Mate
text: When you love a dog, like I love this one,seeing him in pain puts pain in your own heart.Grimace had a fatty tumor removed from his chest last Friday. Â So grandma when into "nurse" mode Friday, Saturday and Sunday. He did fine! But his grandma saw every change in his face, every painful move of his body, every change in his normally sunny personality, and smothered that dear pooch with love and affection all weekend. Â That included sleeping on the floor with him for 2 nights, carrying him up and down my front steps so he could pee, feeding him by hand when he couldn't reach the bowl, and putting ice compresses on is "boo-boo." Â And he responded by sticking by my side - following me to whatever room I was in the whole darn weekend. Â He couldn't be talked out of that!!My God, I love that dog and he loves me.In fact, he loves me like no other being on the face of this earth.I should be as wonderful as he thinks I am!

title: Talk the Walk - My History
text: I thought this picture was representative of what I am trying to do.Bring back some of the person that I was before.Connect the dots with walking.When starting any new endeavor, talking it out can be helpful ... even if you are just talking to yourself. Â So in this semi-regular blog post, I am going to pretend I am talking to myself - about me and walking. Â I am happy to share this "talking to myself" with you.Walking for me has been an on-again, off-again habit. Â I started running back in my 30's. Â I was younger and all my body parts cooperated without complaint (looking back I am amazed how little I appreciated that then.) Â I was a hobby runner. Â I ran about 2 miles several times a week.On those runs I discovered a few things about me and exercise.I feel better within a week. Â It happens just that fast.I improve in time and speed quickly.I sleep better.I am happier.I love the natural rhythm of running.Also in my 30's I discovered that:Regardless of all the positives exercise gave me, I always stopped. Â Always.In my 30s, however, the benefits weren't so in-your-face important. Â After all, I was 33, 35, 37 ... and I didn't need to do anything to feel better or look better or be normal. Â I wasn't disintegrating before my very eyes. Â I was going to live forever - every 30 year old knows that!! Â So why work up a sweat if the person I see in the mirror is just fine!! (The logic of 30 year olds!)So I stopped.In my 40s, the person in the mirror was less sure about living forever. Â I tried running again. Mistake! Â My knees popped, my lower back spasmed,Â and my plantar faciitus (foot/heel pain) began ... all were a constant reminder that pounding the cement was probably not a good idea for me. Â But still I tried, because I was never very good at listening to my body. After a few falls and injuries that benched me, Â I stopped running, but tried walking.I know, I know. Â There are ways of working into a running routine safely, but that didn't happen. (The logic of 40 year olds is ... I am still 30. I don't need to do anything special. Â I am still "young.")So walking it was, and walking gave me all the same positive benefits.Â But still, I stopped. Â In my 50s the reality of the physical decline was hard to ignore. And now I knew I wasn't going to live forever. Â But I still had another 100 good years ahead of me. Â I also saw more of my future watching my mom struggle with the aging process that was complicated by her inactivity. Â So I "fixed" my feet with prescriptionÂ orthopedics, bought expensive walking shoes, Â and put time aside to walk regularly.And guess what happened ... (all together now), "She stopped."Now I am in my 60's. Â The road ahead doesn't look any rosier that it did 10 years ago. Regardless, I tried to keep walking, but it was an off-again, on-again kind of thing! Â All the benefits I know by heart, all the consequences of non-movement clearly understood ... all the excuses have been used up.So I am walking the roads again.Next time: Â Talk the Walk - Mind Games

title: Paying for Piscasa Memory
text: How much do you know aboutÂ Piscasa Web AlbumÂ - the storage used by Blogger to house your blog pictures?I know very little ... and I kind of liked it that way ...Â until recently!In the last week or so another blogger commented that she could not find her percentage of Piscasa storage used by going through the new editor interface on Blogger. Â She could only find the percentage by using the old editor (which is going away soon.)hmm...It got me thinking about how much Piscasa storage I had used up. Â Better check now while I still have access to the old editor.As you can see below, I have used up 78% of my free Piscasa storage in about 2 years. Â Yikes!!!Your current plan:Free5 GB of Drive (0% used)10 GB of Gmail (1% used)1 GB of Picasa (78% used)Upgrade:25 GB$2.49 / Month+25 GB for Drive and PicasaBonus: Your Gmail storage will be upgraded toÂ 25 GB.Choose this plan100 GB$4.99 / Month+100 GB for Drive and PicasaBonus: Your Gmail storage will be upgraded toÂ 25 GB.Choose this planNow I am not totally oblivious to the limits of "free." Another blogging friend, Happy One at the Life is Good Blog, ran out of memory recently. Â I remember that she was offered a plan that cost $5.00 for a year.I looked for that plan, and I found it - listed as the "old" pricing. Â  The "new" pricing is as shown.If my math is correct, the charge for more memory has gone from $5 a year to $30 a year. That is a pretty large jump in cost.So ...I guess this memory storage thingy on Blogger is the only game in town. Â I guess when your storage runs out you have no choice but to buy more or you can stop posting pictures. :-(At first I was upset, but after I thought it out, I decided that $30 a year wouldn't break me, and it is a small price to pay for the enjoyment I get out blogging.But a number of questions come to mind. Â I would really like to hear from you.Do you know how much free space you have on Piscasa?How can you find the percentage of expendedÂ Piscasa storage using the new editor - which will soon be the only editor?Are you already paying for memory space? Â Are you paying the new rate or were you lucky enough to get the cheaper one?When you ran out of free Piscasa how did you know?Â Is there a "work around" to using Piscasa and avoiding this whole thing?Â What happens if in 3 years you decide not to pay ... do your currently stored pictures disappear from your blog?Â Is there another Piscasa option that provides less memory? Â It took me 2 years to use up 1 GB. Â The new plan provides 25 GB. Â I don't need that much memory.Questions, questions, questions ....
